DOC.HEAD: Einstein's `Blunder' May Have Actually Been Correct, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: Albert Einstein called it the biggest blunder of his life, but scientists said today that an idea he presented in 1917 about the universe may have been right after all. Einstein came up with the ``cosmological constant'' to fix a problem: His general relativity theory clashed with his belief that the size of the universe was unchanging. The constant was a mathematical term that implied that the universe contains a repulsive force that acts against gravity. When Einstein added it to an equation describing his relativity theory, the equation predicted a constant-size universe. But scientists later showed that the universe was actually expanding. The cosmological constant fell out of favor. The late physicist George Gamow, in his autobiography ``My World Line,'' wrote that Einstein told him that introducing the cosmological constant was ``the biggest blunder he ever made in his life.'' But there might be something to it after all, British scientists suggest in today's issue of the British journal Nature. George Efstathiou, William Sutherland and Steve Maddox of the physics department at the University of Oxford argue that the existence of the force represented by the cosmological constant would solve several problems with a standard theory about the universe. It ``should be taken seriously,'' they say. The standard theory includes the Big Bang that gave birth to the universe, and says that by far most of the mass in existence now is unobserved stuff called ``cold dark matter'' that would have a gravitational effect on the rest of the universe. Recent observations show more clustering of galaxies on very large scales than basic versions of the standard theory predict, the new report says. But the clustering could be accounted for by incorporating the force described by the cosmological constant into the standard theory, the scientists propose. Their hypothesis suggests that the expansion of the universe was dominated by cold dark matter through perhaps the first one-third to one-half of the history of the universe, but that the cosmological constant force governs it now, Sutherland said in a telephone interview. The hypothesis also accounts for the uniform intensity of the energy left over from the Big Bang, and a number of distant galaxies that are difficult to fit into the volume of space allotted them by the standard theory, Sutherland said. ``It's still very speculative,'' Sutherland said. ``I certainly would not like to claim that the cosmological constant is definitely there. It's a longshot. But it's a possiblity that we have to take seriously.'' In a Nature editorial, theoretical astrophysicist Edmund Bertschinger of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said the new report ``may be the strongest case to date for a non-zero cosmological constant.'' Still, he said in an interview, the new evidence ``would not convince a jury, I think, beyond a reasonable doubt.'' There are other possible explanations for the clustering of galaxies, he said. But the new work will promote debate, and scientists will ``start to consider more seriously the consequences of having a cosmological constant,'' he said. For Einstein, of course, it comes too late. ``He missed a golden opportunity,'' Bertschinger said. ``He could have predicted on the basis of his theory that the universe must be either expanding or contracting. But he didn't trust the theory enough to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: For Israel's Doves, Hopes For Peace Confronted By Reality of Fear
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Nehama Ben-Eliahu is one of the few Israelis still willing to brave the hawkish trend in public opinion and turn out for street protests against military rule in the occupied territories. But she also is lending her son money to buy a gun, so that he feels safe from Palestinians who could threaten his isolated farm near the West Bank. Her situation illustrates the new dilemma of the doves in Israel: how to reconcile their calls for peace with the Arabs with new fears of random attacks against Jews. The dilemma has been heightened by a recent rash of Palestinian stabbing attacks on Israelis, and also by Iraqi threats to attack the Jewish state. The result is that Israel's peace movement, usually active in times of stress, has grown unusually quiet. ``There is a lot of confusion and worry. We have tried to build bridges, and now a volcano has come,'' said Aryeh Eliav, a leading activist in the left-of-center Labor Party. Meetings between Israeli and Palestinian activists, once common and public, are now held either behind closed doors or not at all. Only 1,000 activists attended a candlelight peace vigil staged outside Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's residence for the recent third-year anniversary of the Palestinian uprising. At the outset of the revolt, such Israeli peace protests routinely drew crowds exceeding 10,000. But that was when consciences were guilty over soldiers shooting at youthful, stone-throwing demonstrators. Now that the Arabs are attacking Israeli civilians, sentiments are different. Earlier calls for Jewish-Arab coexistence have been replaced by a new battle cry of ``separation'' - recreating the old Green Line dividing Israel from the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Persian Gulf crisis also has undermined the peace movement. Leftists can no longer argue that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is at the heart of Middle East instability, and the Palestinian question - for the time being - has been removed from the top of the United States' agenda. ``Nobody wants to be active because they don't see where it will get them,'' said Nahum Barnea, a political analyst and left-leaning columnist for the Yediot Ahronoth daily. Public opinion surveys show Israelis taking a hawkish turn, pollster Hanoch Smith said. ``A harsher attitude is permeating the entire society...The impact of the events is a tougher line,'' he said in an interview. At the same time, however, the growing violence is challenging right-wing beliefs that Israel can annex the territories captured in the 1967 Middle East war, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. The effect, in many cases, has been an unexpected meeting of the minds between right and left on the need to separate the Palestinian and Jewish populations. ``Nowadays almost everyone, left and right, wants separation,'' Barnea said. ``The Jew has never so feared the lone Arab working in his neighborhood.'' The shared mood has legislators Michael Eitan of the right-wing Likud bloc and Gad Yaacobi of left-leaning Labor cooperating to draw up a plan for gradually separating the economies of the West Bank and Gaza Strip from Israel. But Yosef Lapid, a right-winger, noted in the daily Maariv that a more common reaction to the violence is an all-pervasive gloom. ``Despair has invaded Israeli society, it eats away at us,'' he wrote. Hawks consider it pointless to press their arguments and the doves believe that ``whether consciously or not, there is no chance for dialogue with the Palestinians,'' Lapid added. Through the uncertainty, the ``Women in Black,'' a grassroots organization born with the uprising, remains the most visible vestige of the peace movement in Israel. Mrs. Ben-Eliahu is a member. She and several hundred women line up in downtown Jerusalem and a dozen other towns every Friday, wearing black dresses and holding placards that read: ``End the occupation.'' The key to their survival, says organizer Anat Hoffman, is that they appeal to the majority of Israelis who are sick of the occupation. ``We aren't standing up for the Palestinians. We say the occupation is bad because of what it does to us. It costs us ($2 million) a day and is morally disastrous,'' Mrs. Hoffman said. Mrs. Ben-Eliahu, 55, who was born in New York City and is a zoologist at Jerusalem's Hebrew University, started demonstrating for peace after her 19-year-old son lost a leg in the 1973 Middle East War. The Palestinian uprising only reinforces her feelings, she says. ``There is no question that unless we reach a political solution, there will be an escalation in violence.'' But being a pacifist isn't so simple these days, she adds, noting the money she is loaning another son for a pistol. ``You see, these are our needs today. It shouldn't be this way ... We would all just have a better chance if there were peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Husbands Raise Kids, Run Household While Wife Goes to War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Robert Buffham had to send his children to live with friends. Felix Dean had to learn mothering skills. Other men lament that they can't even go to neighbors for consoling. They are the spouses of soldiers, and their wives have been sent to the Persian Gulf for Operation Desert Shield. In a reversal of roles from the nation's previous military deployments, many a man has been left behind to raise the children, run the household and deal with the possibility that his wife could be killed in war. ``Their greatest fear has been that Mommy won't come home, that Mommy's already dead,'' said Robert Buffham, husband of Spec. Lona Buffham of the 3rd Armored Cavalry at Fort Bliss. Buffham, 38, was left to care for children ages 5, 2{, 1{ and a 7-week-old newborn. ``She had her maternity leave, (but) two days after her maternity leave, they said: `Hey, let's go. Time to pack up and leave,''' Buffham said Monday. Although Buffham, a Vietnam veteran, was accustomed to caring for the children and home while his wife pursued her Army career, this latest seperation has been difficult, especially for his oldest son. ``When all this happened all the kids - Aaron mostly - started asking, `Where's Momma?' And (Aaron) knew that Momma went away. I said, `Momma's going to Saudi Arabia. ``Then he said: `I know what's going on there. Mommy won't come back alive.''' On the advice of a doctor, Buffham sent his children to live with friends who had raised seven children. ``He (Aaron) needed to be with someone with mothering skills. I did not have that much mothering skills,'' Buffham said. Buffham attends support group meetings on post to discuss problems and exchange suggestions with other male spouses. Fort Bliss' Army Community Services started the group in September to cater to male dependents. ``No matter what happens she knows I'm there. My wife knows my kids are well taken care of, because she knows that's No. 1 in my household,'' said Felix Dean, 33, whose wife, Spec. Beverly Dean is with the 11th Air Defense Artillery. Dean's poor vision and other disabilities forced him out of the Army, so for years he has been staying at home with his five daughters. ``My friends ask me, `Did your Dad go to Saudi Arabia?''' said Felicia, 8. ``And I say, `My Dad didn't go, my Mom did.''' Mrs. Dean's deployment helped Dean heal a strained relationship with his oldest daughter who now lives in Georgia. ``She called me and talked to me and she talked to me about boys ... Since my wife's been gone, we have grown a bond. We can talk and laugh. I'm there for her because her mom isn't,'' Dean said. The men say many of the adjustments they are making are not very different from the adjustments wives of soldiers must make, such as living on less income. But there are some distinct differences. ``The wives can always go next door and knock on their neighbors' door and have coffee with them and talk,'' said Scott Chamberlain, 32, at home with five small children. The former Marine's wife, Spec. Brenda Chamberlain, is a cook with the 11th Air Defense Artillery. ``I go next door and it's, `What do you want?''' Don Dittsworth, who stays home with Candy, 2, said he avoids visiting female neighbors so he won't be accused of ``hitting up on them.'' His wife, Spec. Cristal Dittsworth, drives an 80-ton tractor trailer and is a member of the 233rd Transportation Co.

DOC.HEAD: If U Cn Rd Ths, U Owe Me $125
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: At Success magazine, an editor's mistakes are costly: $25 for a mispelling (er, misspelling). Another $25 for poorly-placed hyphens. A whopping $500 for getting somebody's name wrong. For the past two months, sloppy copy has meant surrendering cold cash at Success. Gleefully plundering inattentive editors is Editor in Chief Scott DeGarmo, who says he grew tired of making the same complaints to the same people about the same errors. ``When my people see a typo anyplace, I want them to step on it like a roach,'' DeGarmo said Wednesday. But taking money for mistakes? Isn't that a little extreme? ``No! If you asked the average guy on the street, he would say of course an editor should know how to spell,'' DeGarmo said. ``If a bricklayer made a crooked wall, or an accountant couldn't add, people would be angry. But editors think it's nothing to not know how to spell.'' The wallet-lightening approach to achieving good grammar began Nov. 5 at the monthly magazine, when DeGarmo fired off a memo to his six senior editors. Errors would no longer be tolerated; fines would be levied. DeGarmo, in the course of his job, would check all copy handed in by his senior editors. If he caught any grammatical or typographical errors, the person responsible would pay: $25 for spelling mistakes, the same for hyphens after words ending in -ly (highly-sought, for example). The fines would come from the money budgeted for their raises. ``The editors? They were appalled and astounded,'' DeGarmo recalled. ``But all the so-called positive reinforcement hadn't worked.'' How serious was DeGarmo? Ask senior editor Michael Maren, who had a $600 lesson in how to spell epitaph, guerrilla and prestigious, among other words. After watching DeGarmo take a big bite of his money, Maren was apologetic. ``We probably didn't check things as carefully as we should have,'' he told The Wall Street Journal. DeGarmo's approach has paid off in more than one way. In addition to collecting $625, he has not seen a glitch in copy since Nov. 29. ``It's not enough to ask people to do their best,'' DeGarmo said. ``You've got to tell them what you want; in my case, it was perfection.''

DOC.HEAD: Boycott Strikes At Heart Of Miami Area's Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Black anger erupted into violence four times in the last decade, but now black lawyers are leading a ``quiet riot'' - an economic boycott that is costing millions of tourist dollars. The activists were aggrieved by local government's handling of anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela's visit in June. Instead of enthusiastic welcomes and ceremonies Mandela received elsewhere on his U.S. visit, he got an official snub and criticism for refusal to repudiate staunch supporters Fidel Castro, Yasser Arafat and Moammar Ghadhafi. ``They have personal feelings, but that has nothing to do with their official duties,'' boycott organizer H.T. Smith said of Miami-area officials. Under the name Boycott Miami: Coalition for Progress, organizers asked groups with national conventions set for the area to go somewhere else. The boycott was announced July 17. As of Tuesday, the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau reported eleven groups had canceled their gatherings - some as far in the future as 1993 - costing nearly $5.5 million. Other estimates have ranged as high as $12 million. Organizers want four things: an apology from area mayors for the Mandela snub; greater business and employment opportunities for black citizens; a review of federal immigration policy regarding Haitians, who routinely are detained and deported while Hispanics are admitted to this country; and a federal investigation of the Miami police's violent breakup of a July protest by Haitians. Boycott organizers prepared a video comparing Miami to Selma, Ala., notorious symbol of discrimination and police violence. Now they have their sights set on the National Football League, in hopes of chasing off the 1993 Super Bowl. At first, local officials seemed to ignore the boycott. But as the conventions continued to leave - and non-black groups, such as the National Organization for Women and the American Civil Liberties Union, joined in - worried community leaders began to speak up and say they were sorry for the way Mandela had been treated. Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez, who had joined four other Cuban-American area mayors in signing a letter critical of Mandela, issued a statement Dec. 12 expressing regret for pain felt by members of the black community. But Suarez did not apologize in a statement also watched carefully by his city's dominant Cuban-American constituency. The tourism industry feels helpless, said conventions bureau spokesman Mayco Villafana. ``We feel we have been held as victims since some of the demands are political in nature,'' Villafana said. ``Only the entire community working can solve them or resolve this.'' Black support of the effort has not been monolithic. The National Urban League, whose Miami president opposes the boycott, went ahead with its three-day gathering. Pickets greeted them at their hotel Dec. 12. Critics said coerced apologies would be meaningless, but Smith disagreed. As an example, he spoke of the unwilling apologies children give under orders from their parents. ``The object is not their sincerity, but to have them subjugate their ego and recognize the personhood of whomever they've disrespected,'' Smith said. And organizers also discounted claims that the boycott was costing the jobs of minimum-wage black laborers. ``You don't hear black folks saying `Oh woe is me' because they're not the ones losing the money,'' said Rev. Victor Curry. Maria Devalle, spokeswoman for the Hotel-Motel-Restaurant and High Rise Employees local 355 of the AFL-CIO, said she had not heard of any jobs threatened or lost. ``We would love to get the business back, that's for sure,'' said Jeff Abbaticchio, spokesman for Doral Resorts in Florida, which owns an oceanfront hotel in Miami Beach and a resort on the outskirts of Miami. He said the hotels were trying to make up the lost business by courting European and Japanese travelers as well as ordinary non-convention tourists. ``The bad publicity, I think that's what hurts us most,'' Abbaticchio said.

DOC.HEAD: Fined Nearly $3,800 For Failed Barrel Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollar figures U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A daredevil whose attempt to shoot Niagara Falls in a barrel hit a snag at the last moment has been fined nearly $3,800. David Munday's 790-pound steel-and-foam-rubber barrel became stuck at the brink of the falls, which straddle the U.S.-Canadian border, on July 15. He was fished out of the swirling waters by rescue workers manning a crane. Munday, 53, was attempting to become the first person to twice shoot the falls in a barrel, having successfully made the plunge in 1985. Defense lawyer Donald Loney said Munday - also an experienced skydiver and helicopter pilot - had planned to put no one but himself in danger. ``He was sober and at all times co-operated with police,'' Loney argued. ``Aside from this fixation with Niagara Falls, he has no criminal record.'' Prosecutors on Tuesday asked the presiding judge, Morley Kitchen, to fine Munday, a diesel mechanic, 10,000 Canadian dollars ($8,633) - the maximum penalty for performing an illegal stunt on Niagara Falls property. Munday had been fined 1,500 Canadian dollars ($1,295) for his first plunge. Sgt. Fred Hollidge of the Niagara Parks Police said July's rescue operation put his officers in danger and tied up emergency personnel for more than two hours. ``We don't need these people to show the beauty of the falls,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Resistance Center Uncovered at Alpine Resort
DOC.TEXT: The Swiss Alps are riddled with underground military bases, but apparently none like the top secret installation on the edge of this plush resort. Deep inside Mt. Horneggli, men and women were trained to become the nucleus of a Swiss resistance force to fight foreign occupiers. The facility was ordered shut down after its existence was revealed last month, but the political furor continues. A camouflaged gate opened into a 100-yard-long tunnel lined with 13 rooms where the would-be guerrillas - nicknamed the ``Swiss Rambos'' - lived, learned and practiced combat shooting in classes of 20 each. At least one member was a high-ranking Defense Ministry official, and others served in the Swiss militia army. Swiss officials have denied the commandos had any links with ``Gladio,'' the recently uncovered paramilitary network in NATO countries set up to fight a potential Soviet invasion. Switzerland is neutral. Word of the 400-member unit, codenamed P-26, and a parallel and equally secret intelligence unit, P-27, came to light in a parliamentary inquiry last month. The parliamentary commission concluded that P-26 and P-27 were financed through the Swiss army but operated without any supervision from civilian authorities. The government branded both units ``vestiges of the Cold War'' and ordered them disbanded. The disclosures brought unwanted attention to the Swiss militia army a year after a national referendum showed considerable public sentiment - one of every three voters - for abolishing it. Ursula Mauch, a Social Democratic member of parliament, said the inquiry revealed ``only the tip of the iceberg.'' ``These Rambos, Swiss-style, were to defend a democracy which they didn't think much of,'' she said in a parliamentary debate on P-26 last week. ``It's like ordering a wild dog to guard a sausage.'' Defense Minister Kaspar Villiger rejected as absurd allegations that P-26 could have been used in a military coup, but he admitted he had little information on the unit. The parliamentary inquiry discovered that Villiger's chief spokesman, Hans-Rudolf Strasser, held a key post in P-26. Strasser was then suspended from this job for failing to inform his superior of his double life. The parliamentary committee found that Ferdinand Jakob Knecht, a construction engineer, headed P-27, and Bernhard Wehrli, the president of the Swiss Association for Environmental Protection, served as an aide. Public attention focused on Efrem Cattelan, 59, a lawyer and reserve colonel who quit his job as insurance executive in 1979 to head P-26 at an annual salary of $160,000. Cattelan directed training at the Gstaad underground center, only a few minutes' walk from Elizabeth Taylor's luxurious chalet. The resort homes of other celebrities, like violinist Yehudi Menuhin and actor Roger Moore are also close by. Cattelan said he was never one for spy thrillers. ``I once tried to read a John Le Carre novel but then put it aside after about 40 pages, never touching it again. I felt it was too complicated.'' Cattelan said P-26 cooperated with unidentified British contacts but he denied it had any links to Gladio units in NATO countries. ``The British have great experience, dating from colonialist times,'' he explained to an interviewer. ``Just think of Lawrence of Arabia.'' Most of the P-26 members, including about 20 women, were in their 40s or even older, according to Cattelan. ``These were people who were ready to be tortured or killed and to risk reprisals against their family,'' said Lt. Gen. Heinz Haesler, the army's chief of staff, defending P-26 against the widespread criticism. The unit was supposed to expand into a network of independently operating sabotage and resistance groups in case of an invasion. Members knew each other only by code names. The independent Bern newspaper Der Bund suggested that life at the unit was rather mundane. ``There was no uprising being plotted, there were no agents a la James Bond at work and there were no silent killings.'' ``P-26 was comprised mainly persons of advanced age who had to sign a contract, were insured against accidents and received official per diems,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant in Detroit Scam Trial Allegedly Tried to Involve Mayor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Kenneth Weiner said he liked working in the shadows as the Detroit Police Department's resident security expert, a self-styled cloak-and-dagger man. But when it came to his other job as a commodities investor, Weiner was more out in the open and liked to drop names - especially that of Mayor Coleman A. Young, according to the government and dozens of Weiner's ex-clients. During the past two months, Young's name has been invoked in the federal courtroom where prosecutors are trying to prove that Weiner and two co-defendants skimmed millions of dollars invested with them from 1983-86. The mayor of the nation's ninth-largest city has never been indicted or charged with a crime. But Young has cited the Fifth Amendment against self-incrimination in refusing to testify in the tax and fraud trial of Weiner, his one-time business partner and son of his former stockbroker. Weiner, steel broker Alvin Gendelman and radiologist Steven Lewin are being tried on 36 counts of wire and tax fraud. The trial is expected to continue into next year. Before Weiner began testifying Dec. 6, nearly 60 investors told the court they lost money in what the government claims was an illicit pyramid scheme. Some have testified that Weiner's Comsec Corp., founded in 1980 and dissolved by the state in 1985 for failing to file annual reports, lured their money in part because Weiner played up his connections with Young and Police Chief William Hart. Weiner, Gendelman and Lewin returned more than $13 million to investors during 1983-86 but pocketed $4 million on which they paid no taxes, an Internal Revenue Service investigator testified in late November. Prosecutors say Weiner sought to save himself by turning on Young - offering to secretly record conversations with the mayor for the FBI. Thirty-nine such tapes were made from February to May 1987 at the mayor's residence, but they produced only speculative evidence against Young. Several months later, Weiner struck a deal with the IRS, recording 40 conversations with Young. Those tapes, like those made for the FBI, apparently failed to incriminate the mayor. As the police department's civilian deputy chief and security specialist from 1979 to 1986, Weiner met with anti-terrorism experts and added high-tech security systems to the city's water system and mayor's residence. While Weiner is on trial a federal grand jury has been investigating allegations of Police Department corruption. No one has been indicted in that investigation, focusing on the alleged theft of more than $1 million from an undercover police fund. Weiner has been publicly accused by the police chief of looting the fund. Weiner told investigators that Young and Hart helped him take the money from the fund, according to an FBI memo obtained by The Detroit News. Young and Hart have denied any wrongdoing. They refused to comment about the memo, the newspaper reported Tuesday. Under questioning by U.S. Attorney Sheldon Light, Weiner brusquely denied earlier statements he gave the FBI indicating the money went to allegedly fake corporations he set up with Young's blessing. ``Weiner stated that all the money from the secret service fund which went to ... companies established by him was for his sole use and not for any type of contract work for any type of security project,'' according to a transcript of a May 1990 interview by the FBI. Weiner told Light his security and consulting firms received money from the fund for ``any and all expenses, all travel, time, equipment ... for any project assigned me by the mayor, anywhere I had to go.'' He also denied telling the FBI that in 1986, Young suggested propping up the failing Comsec by having Weiner ``become a Detroit Police Department consultant, and any money Weiner needed he could get from the Detroit Police Department.'' Pressed to explain those and other discrepancies in his testimony and his earlier statements to investigators, the tone of Weiner's testimony turned in a week's time from self-assured to plaintive. ``I've done my best to tell the truth,'' he told Richard Lustig, Lewin's attorney. ``I learned how to lie when I went to work for the government.''

DOC.HEAD: Santa Suds: More Brewers Toasting Season With Special Beers
DOC.TEXT: At the New England Brewing Co. in Connecticut, the holiday spirit flows this season in flavors of cinnamon, nutmeg, cardamom and vanilla. This is the stuff of winter, of eggnog, fruitcake and cider. But this is beer. New England's 1990 Holiday Ale is one of an increasing number of special seasonal beers that are being cooked up at small breweries around the country. Scholars of suds can raise toasts this season with mugs of Hoppy Holidaze, Kris Kringle, Our Special Ale, Celebration Ale, Wassail, Christmas Ale, Winterfest, Winter Welcome, Winter's Tale - just a few of the names given by brewers to their holiday offerings. ``A lot of the small breweries, a lot of the microbreweries, are doing what brewers in Europe have been doing for centuries, and that is brewing different beers for the different seasons, and the most special season is the winter,'' said Tom McCormick, a specialty beer distributor in Rocklin, Calif. McCormick is carrying nine holiday brews this year and said his volume in winter beers has roughly doubled each year for the past several years. ``There's really been an increase in awareness of microbreweries and specialty beers in general, so it's all part of that,'' he said. The holiday beers are usually stronger and fuller-bodied than brewers' usual offerings; they typically are a deep reddish-amber and are relatively high in alcohol content. And increasingly they are brewed with spices, including cinnamon, orange peel, ginger, nutmeg and cloves. The tradition, beer-o-philes say, goes back centuries. The main flavoring ingredient in most beer now is hops, a bitter vine, but brewers once used whatever spice they had on hand. Philip Markowski, the brewer at New England Brewing in Norwalk, Conn., traces the tradition to America's colonial days. David Edgar, news editor of the New Brewer magazine in Denver, said it goes back much further, ``to pagan festivals at which they would brew a ritual ale.'' ``So basically,'' Edgar said, ``the tradition of a special winter festival beer has existed since before Christ - since before there was a Christmas.'' In the United States, the modern tradition can be dated more accurately. It goes back 16 years, to the first holiday ale produced by the Anchor Brewing Co. of San Francisco. Anchor's first offerings were strong, hoppy ales, perfect for sipping in front of a fire on a cold winter's night. Later, the brewery began adding spices that gave the beers a delicately fruity smell and taste. Other early entrants on the holiday beer scene included the Sierra Nevada Brewing Co. of Chico, Calif., which produces a bold, unspiced Celebration Ale, and the Yakima Brewing Co. of Yakima, Wash., which makes Grant's Spiced Ale. Once distributed only locally or regionally, these beers are now in gourmet liquor shops and bars across the nation. They have company in some imported holiday beers, including Aass Winter Lager from Norway, Young's Winter Ale from England and Samichlaus from Switzerland, which claims to be the strongest lager in the world. The giants of the beer industry have mostly ignored the holiday beer trend. The small brewers say it's simply too difficult for the major brewers to interrupt their production lines to make seasonal batches of beer. One exception is the Adolph Coors Co., which has been marketing Coors Winterfest, a full-bodied lager, since 1986. The company won't release sales or production figures, but spokesman Todd Appleman said the market for Winterfest has been growing annually. ``I think each year you're going to see it become a little more national, a little more high-profile,'' Appleman said. You'll hear no such claim from Grant Johnston, the brewer for the tiny Marin Brewing Co. in Larkspur, Calif. His Hoppy Holidaze winter beer won a gold medal at this year's Great American Beer Festival in Colorado. But fans of Hoppy Holidaze are lucky to find it on the other side of San Francisco Bay, much less across the country. This year's entire production was 28 barrels, each containing 31 gallons of pale, spicy beer. Still, Johnston isn't complaining. He's only worried about selling out. ``We try to have it on hand through Christmas and New Year's,'' he said, ``but I doubt we'll last that long.'' After that, it's just like baseball. There's always next year.

DOC.HEAD: Official at Center of Scholarship Storm No Stranger to Risks
With PM-Minority Scholarships Bjt
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The man who ignted a firestorm over minority scholarships is used to living dangerously. He spent years prosecuting Ku Klux Klansmen and other perpetrators of violent racial hate crimes. But this time the peril was political, and Assistant Education Secretary Michael L. Williams acknowledged Tuesday that he was not prepared for it. The 37-year-old lawyer said last week that universities receiving federal money could not legally reserve scholarships for minorities - and promptly created turmoil in the White House, the civil rights community and the ranks of higher education. ``Politically naive,'' Williams called himself, although he had served in 1988 as a domestic policy adviser to the Bush campaign before his appointment to head the Education Department's civil rights office. Others had less charitable descriptions. ``An outrage,'' said Ralph Neas, executive director of the 200-member Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. ``We don't find this helpful at all,'' said David Merkowitz, spokesman for the American Council on Education, an umbrella group of colleges and universities. At the center of the storm is a black Texan with a blue-ribbon resume, solid conservative credentials and an equally solid record of fighting racial injustices. Williams is a Midland, Texas, native and childhood friend of President Bush's son George. His parents and his wife, a pilot and mechanical engineer, all attended historically black colleges. He received three degrees from the University of California - a B.A., a master's in public administration and a law degree. And while he was there he challenged the school to admit more blacks by weighing socio-economic factors as well as test scores. Williams' resume also lists community involvement: he was a Big Brother in Midland, and now he tutors elementary schoolchildren in reading. Then there is his career at the Justice Department, where he served from 1984 to 1988 as a senior trial attorney in the civil rights division headed by William Bradford Reynolds. He tried and won cases against North Carolina Klansmen who conspired to obtain stolen military weapons; an Idaho white supremacist who tried to drive black and interracial families from their homes; a Kentucky Klansman who fire-bombed the home of a black family; and law enforcement officers in Alabama, Arizona, North Carolina and Oklahoma who assaulted private citizens. ``He went after them with a vengeance and was very successful,'' said Reynolds. ``He was a very savvy lawyer, a thoughtful, level-headed kind of guy who learned very quickly and did exceptionally well.'' Not on his resume, but mentioned often by friends and associates, is Williams' sense of humor - reportedly as acute as Eddie Murphy's. Another trademark is an ever-present pair of lizard cowboy boots. He also collects plates - one from every state in which he's tried a case. Awash in ambivalence last week over Williams' blanket ruling, Bush nevertheless defended the official as ``extraordinarily sensitive, very intelligent.'' Even his political opponents are charitable. ``I will not question Mr. Williams' integrity or his credentials,'' said Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., who summoned Williams to a hearing of his House Education and Labor Committee to explore the scholarship issue. Hawkins, echoing the views of many, said he believes Williams ``just merely issued an opinion which is based on what he perceived to be the administration's position.'' That turned out not to be the case, at least at the highest levels of the administration, and Williams announced Tuesday that colleges could keep offering minority-only scholarships if they used private money earmarked solely for that purpose. A senior White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Williams was not ordered to change his mind. ``We had a conversation in which we were exploring what could and couldn't be done under the regulations. And Michael was very cooperative, very interested in finding what his full flexibilities were,'' the official said. ``I think he deserves credit for being able to come up with a solution.'' Williams himself rejected any suggestion that he had been manipulated by the administration, either in his initial ruling or in softening it. ``I haven't been a lackey for anyone,'' he declaed. ``The position I took was a position I took because I thought it was right.'' Whether the current brouhaha will lead to stardom or oblivion is anyone's guess. ``In this town,'' said Reynolds, ``I would not dare predict.''

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Warns Severe Military Cuts Could Lead to Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs on veto announcement, statements by president, gives president's new figures for proposed army spending in 1990 and 1991, CORRECTS that veto had not yet occurred. Picks up 5th pvs, `The 1990 ...'
DOC.TEXT: Seeking to avert unrest by members of the Sandinista-controlled army, President Violeta Chamorro said Tuesday that she was vetoing military cuts approved by lawmakers of her governing coalition. Mrs. Chamorro said cuts beyond those already negotiated with the leftist military leaders could ``raise political-military tensions which could have unforseeable results.'' She earlier warned that the cuts approved last week by the 92-member National Assembly could push the country into ``chaos and a bloodbath.'' The military has already accepted a drastic cutback. In a videotaped statement broadcast late Tuesday, Mrs. Chamorro said she was sending the veto to the legislature. It was not clear whether it arrived before lawmakers adjourned for the night. The president said she was using a line-item veto against the National Assembly's $19.6 million cut in the military budget. She offered a compromise $8.5 million reduction in her original proposal of $78.6 million. Either figure would be far below the $177 million budget she said the army had in 1990 or the $131 million that she said military leaders had proposed for the coming year. She kept overall spending to roughly the legislature's total of $495.8 million by cutting money from the contingency fund and the finance ministry. The 1990 military budget was the last passed by the Sandinista government, which waged a 10-year battle against U.S.-supported Contra rebels. Mrs. Chamorro defeated the Sandinistas in elections earlier this year and took office in April. Deputies debated the budget package late Tuesday as government leaders lobbied lawmakers to change their vote and army leaders to accept some cuts as a compromise. Earlier Tuesday, about 150 recently retired military officers held a march in front of the assembly building to protest the budget cuts, claiming up to 10,000 officers would be fired if the assembly overrides Mrs. Chamorro's veto. The demonstrators were among 5,000 who retired under a generous program that has reduced the size of the armed forces from about 100,000 when Mrs. Chamorro was inaugurated April 25 to less than 29,000. But the retirement program would not cover officers fired because of budget cuts, Sandinista lawmakers say. The 51 members of Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition and one independent legislator voted in favor of the larger military cuts last week. If they stick together, they would override Mrs. Chamorro's veto. The 39 Sandinista deputies don't have the majority needed to counter the pro-government bloc. A budget needs 47 votes to pass. Under the plan opposed by Mrs. Chamorro, the $19 million taken from the military would be spread around to benefit 15 other ministries and government departments. Mrs. Chamorro has said that while she favors further reducing the armed forces, ``we can't do it overnight.'' ``I think this (veto) will serve so that the gentlemen deputies reconsider this matter in its true dimension, and decide whether or not they will support Mrs. Chamorro,'' said Minister of the Presidency Antonio Lacayo. Lacayo last week also warned that drastic cuts in the armed forces budget would endanger the nation's stability. A final budget for 1991 must be approved by midnight Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: HA! The Comedy Channels Merge In 50-50 Joint Venture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes name to HA! to make consistent throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Cable television's two comedy channels are ending the battle of the belly laugh, merging into a single cable channel next year, the companies said Tuesday. HBO's The Comedy Channel and MTV's HA! will become Comedy TV. ``Over time, the network will develop its own identity,'' said Frank J. Biondi, president and chief executive of Viacom International Inc., which owns HA! and the MTV Networks. Biondi spoke at a news conference with Michael J. Fuchs, chairman and CEO of Home Box Office, the world's largest pay TV service. Comedy TV will begin early next year, Biondi and Fuchs said, with HA! and The Comedy Channel continuing their separate operations in the interim. No money changed hands in the deal. The assets of each comedy channel will be transferred on Jan. 1 to the joint venture, based in New York City and staffed by employees from both HA! and The Comedy Channel. A president for the new channel will be chosen from outside Viacom and Time-Warner, which owns HBO. It has been tough sledding for both channels. HBO's channel was launched in November 1989 and MTV's HA! on April 1 this year. Both made original shows, but relied on reruns of off-network comedies to fill their 24-hour schedules. The two channels reached a total of 15 million households, with HBO's channel in 8.5 million homes and MTV's in 6.5 million, but each rolled up big losses - as high as $20 million a year. They also had trouble getting channel space on already packed cable systems. The CEOs said the merger made economic sense. ``The bottom is that it would have been very expensive for us to push on,'' Biondi said. ``Common sense just prevailed. We were doing a very good job of standing each other up.'' Rumors of the merger had been circulating for months. The deal was struck less than than a month after two proposed rival cable services devoted to law - ``In Court'' and ``American Courtroom Network'' - said they would merge. About 12 new cable services plan start-ups in coming months, according to one estimate by Erica Gruen, a cable analyst at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. The hopefuls range from a 24-hour talk show channel to the Cowboy Channel. All-sports ESPN serves the most cable homes, 55.9 million, followed by Turner's Cable News Network, which serves 54.4 million.

DOC.HEAD: Reservists May See Desert Shield Tours Extended by Six Months
DOC.TEXT: Some of the 125,000 reservists called to active duty for the Persian Gulf crisis may be away from their homes and jobs longer than they had imagined. The Defense Department said Tuesday it may ask Congress for authority to keep non-combat reservists on active duty for a full year. The current limit is six months. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has made no final decision but probably would seek the extra authority after Congress returns in late January. Non-combat reservists provide support such as medical care, intelligence analysis, aircraft maintenance, truck driving, water purification and legal assistance. They account for about 110,000 of the reservists called up from all four services. ``We would like to have from the Congress the authority to extend both combat and non-combat reservists to the full 180 (days), plus another 180,'' Williams told reporters. ``We don't need to have that authority in our hand right now because we just haven't come to that time yet, but I think as a general proposition ... it would be nice to have as much flexibility as we can in terms of dealing with the reserves,'' he said. Congress already has authorized Cheney to keep combat reservists on active duty for 360 days, although the only such units activated so far - three National Guard combat brigades - were called up for 180-day tours. Cheney probably will extend their tours by another 180 days if they are deployed to the gulf. Williams said no decision has been made on whether to send the National Guard combat brigades to Saudi Arabia or keep them in the United States as backups. The first non-combat reserve units were called up in late August, so some reservists have been scheduled to return to their civilian jobs and their homes in February. Williams said some Reserve or National Guard units may be needed for longer periods. ``It may well be that there are units with unique capabilities, one-of-a-kind capabilities ... and when we hit the six-month period ... we need to decide whether we want to come back and ask Congress to extend that,'' he said. In other developments related to troop deployments in Operation Desert Shield: -The Pentagon said 10,000 U.S. troops have arrived in the gulf area this week, bringing to more than 270,000 the number of American soldiers, airmen, sailors and Marines in the region. -Williams said Iraq has added 10,000 troops to its force in and around occupied Kuwait, bringing the total to 510,000. The Iraqis have about 4,000 tanks, 2,500 armored personnel carriers and infantry fighting vehicles and 2,700 artillery pieces, the spokesman said. -The Army said elements of the 7th Corps Artillery, based at Augsburg, Germany, have begun deploying to the gulf in support of Desert Shield. It also said elements of the 11th Combat Aviation Brigade began deploying from Illesheim, Germany. -The Army ordered to active duty 636 Army Reserve members from Alabama, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, for aviation and intelligence support.

DOC.HEAD: No-Layoff Clause Keeps Cash-Strapped City from Cutting Work Force
DOC.TEXT: Two years ago, 16,000 city workers traded pay raises and increases in benefits for a no-layoff clause. Now, with the city facing collapse, what looked like a so-so deal to employees seems pretty good. As New York and other cities in the Northeast consider municipal layoffs by the thousands, most non-uniformed workers in Philadelphia know they won't be out in the cold. They just don't know if there will be paychecks. The cash-strapped city says it will go broke next week, raising the possibility that paychecks for Philadelphia's 30,000 employees could be held up. In 1988, Mayor W. Wilson Goode and non-uniformed workers represented by two unions reached a four-year agreement that capped health and welfare benefits, delayed wage increases and offered early retirement to avoid 1,400 layoffs. In return, Goode agreed to no layoffs during the last two years, starting this year. James Rawls, a heavy-equipment operator for the city Water Department and president of Local 394 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said Tuesday he originally opposed the contract. ``To me, a four-year contract is too long,'' he said. ``But after we passed it and the city got into this financial condition, then we realized that it was a better deal.'' The clause ensured labor peace for Goode's second term but has cost him maneuverability during the financial crisis, said Dianne E. Reed, local director of the Pennsylvania Economy League, a government research group. ``I would say it was a big concession on the part of the city,'' she said. Before agreeing to the no-layoff deal, Goode had won a bitter 20-day garbage strike in 1986 by threatening to fire the trash haulers. They later ended the strike without any significant contract gains. Former City Controller Joseph Vignola said the no-layoff clause surrendered too much, especially after Goode's tough stance in the trash strike. ``Taking a strike of that length, I think the city could have come away much stronger in its labor-management negotiations,'' he said. The cash crisis - blamed on sluggish tax revenues and rising labor costs - threatens the city with a projected $229.5 million budget shortfall for the current fiscal year and $278 million for the next. The city is trying to sell $200 million in short-term notes to banks and two pension funds. That amount could help prevent paydays without paychecks, but isn't likely to cover bills that have languished for months. Meanwhile, there has been no talk of trying to break or circumvent the no-layoff provision. ``A deal's a deal,'' said Larry Lyde, a heavy-equipment operator for the Water Department. Police and firefighters have no similar provisions in their contracts but are likely to be safe from layoffs because their services are considered essential. Despite looming paycheck fears, Lyde said he just tries to keep his mind on his work, such as clearing out clogged drains after Tuesday's morning rain. ``It's unfortunate what's happening with the money,'' he said. ``But the job still has to be done and the public still expects the job to be done well.'' City officials have said if they can't meet an entire payroll, they may issue partial payments in hopes of keeping people on the job. Managers have urged workers to keep working if their biweekly paychecks stop, Rawls said. ``That's fine if you miss one pay,'' he said. ``After one pay, a lot of people are going to have to start looking elsewhere'' for jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Limited Western Help Has Not Much Improved A Hard Life
DOC.TEXT: When Romanians overthrew the Communist dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu a year ago, they expected help from abroad to quickly improve their low standard of living. But Western aid, scaled back in recent months because of political repression in Romania and harder times hitting the donor countries, has had little effect on the widespread miseries of everyday life. ``The aid was like a drop in the huge ocean of our needs,'' said Emanel Cosmovici, head of a Bucharest-based international humanitarian aid organization. Officials hope Romania's solid support for the West in the Persian Gulf crisis and government economic reform begun in November with the approval of the International Monetary Fund will restore the country to the West's good graces. The hopes for a new ``Marshall plan'' for Eastern Europe were initially fed by the flood of food, medicine and energy aid that immediately followed the revolution. A variety of Western organizations - such as World Vision International, Project Concern International, Caritas, Orphanages Trust, the French Medecins du Monde and Medecins Sans Frontieres and the International Red Cross - have set up programs throughout Romania. Some governments also have helped. Germany donated $33 million worth of energy last year and is expected to do so again. The United States has been the leading aid donor, according to diplomatic sources. U.S. aid in 1990 included 500,000 tons of feed grain, 7,500 tons of butter and more than $4 million in medical aid. The European Community is providing some heating and electricity in the dozens of orphanages nationwide that house an army of 100,000 orphaned and abandoned children, the legacy of Ceausescu's policy to increase the population. But conditions at most orphanages are still very poor, and the infant mortality rate in Romanian hospitals is still among the highest in Europe, at 30 per 1,000. Half the deaths occur because of complications related to malnutrition, said Nicolae Dirina, head of Bucharest's Budimex children's hospital, which received aid from Caritas. ``Aid did not improve our situation,'' he stressed. ``The problems are nearly the same.'' And the economic misery grows. Prices have doubled or tripled, stores are empty, industrial production is down 20 percent and the average monthly paycheck is worth only $20 on the black market. Under market reforms, money-losing state enterprises face bankruptcy and the government has said it will stop providing industry with cut-rate energy. By and large, private homes are dark and cold. The flow of aid slowed down halfway through 1990 because of fears of recession in the West and doubts over the new Romanian leadership's sincerity about democracy and economic reform. The United States froze non-humanitarian aid to Romania in mid-June in response to the National Salvation Front government's methods in breaking up a 53-day anti-government sit-in. Six people died in the crackdown and the National Front was widely condemned for calling miners in from the provinces who beat opposition activists and journalists. Romanian officials hope their economic reform as well as support of the United States and its allies in opposing the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will pay off. Premier Petre Roman welcomed this month's European Community decision to grant Romania and neighboring Bulgaria medical, food and energy aid worth $343 million. Some aid officials believe the best solution to Romania's ills is in retraining Romanians. Dr. Barbara Bascom, manager of World Vision's Romanian Orphans' Social and Education Support Project, said economic problems are matched by ``the disaster with Romanian professionals who had been deprived of any information from outside the country.'' Bascom's group has launched a $10 million project aimed partially at retraining nurses and doctors in relating to their patients. She said the program would improve the lives of at least 7,500 Romanian orphans. At one Bucharest orphanage, 11-year-old Robert Dragomir, who was paralyzed from the waist down in a car accident, was less ambitious. He asked Western reporters to bring him aid consisting simply of ``oranges and a television. ``I have been here for six years and never got out to see anything,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Music Director Designate Masur Conducts Philharmonic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Mendelssohn wrote to his brother in 1846 that never had a debut of one of his compositions gone so well as ``Elijah,'' his dramatic oratorio for orchestra, soloists and chorus. It went exceptionally well again Tuesday night. Kurt Masur conducted ``Elijah'' with the New York Philharmonic, taking over the first of four performances that had been scheduled for the late Leonard Bernstein. This was the first time Masur has conducted the Philharmonic since being named its music director. He will follow Zubin Mehta who resigned, effective at the end of the present season. The Philharmonic, which took part in selecting Masur, played for him with sweep and alertness. The back of the Avery Fisher Hall stage was filled with the majestic strains of the huge Westminster Symphonic Choir. Texts are from the Bible, telling of the Hebrew prophet Elijah pitting God against Baal, who is called by his priests. When God sends fire, after Baal didn't, Elijah has Baal's priests killed. Jezebel wants Elijah killed and he flees to the wilderness but returns, with God's protection. Finally, he is taken to heaven in a fiery chariot. Baritone Kevin McMillan sang Elijah. He was the least loud of the four soloists but one could hear a fine voice, a focused tone and his words very well. The other three were good, soprano Edith Wiens, mezzo Marietta Simpson and tenor Richard Leech. There were five other singers with small solo parts. Masur looks at home on the New York Philharmonic podium, nis body often swaying, his left arm jutting out and back like a boxer. He didn't use a baton. The music and its performance were solid, rising to heights of emotion at times. At the end of the first half of the concert, there was foot stamping along with applause, to emphasize the audience's welcome to Masur. When Masur left the stage, he waved to the orchestra, his welcome to them.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Conservatives Unhappy With Bush, Sununu
DOC.TEXT: ``We're going into a Christmas mode here,'' President Bush declared joyfully. But conservatives are finding little to cheer about as the president prepares to head to Camp David for the holidays. Bush is making right-wingers increasingly unhappy. Even their longtime envoy to the White House - chief of staff John Sununu - is turning out to be no Santa Claus. With Bush absorbed in the Persian Gulf crisis, Sununu has been tending the store more and more, and with a firm hand. Sununu has been involved in a series of decisions that have not exactly thrilled the Republican Party's right wing - including fillig two Cabinet vacancies with moderate Republicans and an ungainly about-face on the Education Department ruling on minority scholarships. ``Sununu is setting up the office to let be Bush be Bush. He's not trying to move his own agenda forward. He's not advancing the conservative agenda,'' said conservative activist Richard Viguerie. About the only Christmas present Bush could give conservatives that would prompt widespread cheer - naming Jack Kemp as the new Republican Party chairman - did not seem to be in the cards. Bush leaves the White House on Friday and will stay at the presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland until New Year's Day. The president, clearly winding down for the holidays, told reporters Tuesday: ``No more questions. No, no, no. I've been too accessible here. We're going into a Christmas mode here where I won't be doing as much of this kind of work.'' But he leaves Washington with many problems unsolved. Topping the agenda is the lack of progress toward a peaceful end to the Persian Gulf crisis. He had planned to spend much of the time, as always, hunting for quail in Beeville, Texas. But because of the gulf crisis he decided to stay closer to the capital. Camp David is just a 25-minute helicopter ride from the South Lawn of the White House. Bush also must confront other problems when he returns. The economy is slumping. International trade talks have broken down. And domestic spending will have to be slashed to the bone to comply with the recent budget agreement, to finance military operations in the gulf and to account for lower revenues from business because of the recession. Bickering among Republicans may seem the least of Bush's immediate worries. But it doesn't make his job any easier. And some of the harshest criticism from conservatives is directed at Sununu. The GOP's right wing had already been annoyed with Sununu for his role in Bush's switch on taxes. Conservatives now are griping about Bush's decision to bypass conservative candidates in picking two moderate Republicans, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee and Rep. Lynn Martin of Illinois, to be the secretaries of education and labor, respectively. Alexander is a longtime friend of Sununu's, and Martin and Sununu worked together in Bush's 1988 campaign. Furthermore, conservatives are grumbling about the administration's effective reversal - also carried out by Sununu - of last week's ruling by the Education Department against minority scholarship programs at publicly funded colleges and universities. Many conservatives supported the ruling, although it created a storm among civil rights groups. And, in what might be the final straw, the administration is even talking about jettisoning a proposal long dear to conservative hearts: a cut in the capital gains tax rate. Bush said Tuesday that while he still strongly supports a lower capital gains rate and thinks it would stimulate the economy, ``rigid caps'' under this fall's budget agreement will make it difficult to include in his new budget. ``I haven't given up my philosophical commitment ... But we're faced with this practical problem,'' he said. Viguerie, who has been openly critical of Bush, said the president ``is not even giving us half a loaf. He's giving us crumbs now.'' If Bush is re-elected in 1992, ``he will never need conservatives again in his life. And then it will be open warfare,'' Viguerie said. A senior administration official, who briefed White House reporters Tuesday under ground rules guaranteeing anonymity, was asked about the administration's latest trouble with conservatives. ``We will continue to stay open to conservatives,'' the official replied. ``I think we're developing an agenda that makes sense for the next couple of years and I think they're very much a part of providing input.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Law Ministers Weigh Move to Outlaw Eastern Communists
DOC.TEXT: Driven from power, accused of corruption, routinely derided by prominent politicians, East Germany's former Communists have found yet another reason to circle the wagons. The top lawmen from the 16 states that comprise the united Germany will decide next month whether to seek to outlaw the party as ``an enemy of the constitution.'' The interior ministers, who run the justice systems in their states, say they want to know whether the party violates laws against extremism that initially were devised to prevent a resurgence of Nazism. They agreed to meet in January and decide whether to begin the legal process that has been used to outlaw extremist groups in the past. The former Communists, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, denounced the move as ``scandalous.'' They said they would in fact use the constitution to prevent such a probe from taking place. ``We'll raise an objection with the Supreme Court,'' said party board member Klaus Steinitz. Purged of many Stalinists, the Party of Democratic Socialism says it espouses essentially what its name says and contends it is willing to work within the constitution. It remains a distant third in popularity among eastern Germans and won enough votes in the Dec. 2 national elections to seat 17 lawmakers when the new united Parliament convenes Thursday in Berlin. The effort among the interior ministers, hatched at a conference in Dresden over the weekend, is the latest move to kick the Communists out of the new society. Since West Germany swallowed East Germany on Oct. 3, authorities have: -Fired all of the top officers from the East German army because they were considered too close to the old regime. -Arrested or tried to arrest top leaders on charges ranging from corruption to manslaughter. Former party chief Erich Honecker is holed up at a Soviet military hospital outside Berlin. -Quickly accepted the resignation of Lothar de Maiziere from the Cabinet of Chancellor Helmut Kohl after it was alleged the former East German prime minister may have worked for the Communist secret police. -Staged a massive police raid on the former Communists' headquarters in a hunt for clues to absconded cash, which was located after a party official allegedly transferred it to the Soviet Union. -Arrested dozens of reputed spies for the former Communist government. Likewise, the new state governments in eastern Germany have vowed to purge their bureaucracies of the old guard. Workers routinely complain that their factories are still run by Communists. In the past week, students have staged several protests against the planned revamping of the socialist school system. Now, the 16 interior ministers who run Germany's law enforcement are entertaining the possibility of having the party banned. At the interior ministers' conference, Dietmar Schlee of Baden-Wuerttemberg state called for a ``quick and united clarification of the question of whether the PDS is an enemy of the constitution.'' Bavarian Interior Minister Edmund Stoiber even said his state, Germany's largest, would initiate its own secret surveillance of the party to dig up evidence unless the issue were decided by the end of January. He said because the party is ``based on orthodox Marxist-Leninist fundamentalism, it should be classified as a constitutional enemy.'' If the state governments ask for a probe, the Supreme Court would have final say on whether the party is a threat to the constitution. Former West Germany, the laws of which now govern the united Germany, has outlawed neo-Nazi groups but let a far-right group and the small West German Communist Party run candidates for office.

DOC.HEAD: Scope of Mortgage Rate Errors Unknown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report; version also in financial report.
DOC.TEXT: Reports of lenders botching mortgage rate calculations sent homeowners scrambling to see if they're being overcharged and left bankers wondering if they're losing millions. The controversy over adjustable rate mortgages, loans with variable interest rates, began when a former federal banking auditor estimated widespread errors in the loan portfolios of failed savings and loans in the Midwest. John Geddes, formerly with the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., estimated up to 35 percent of adjustable-rate mortages nationwide were miscalculated and borrowers were overcharged $8 billion from 1979 to 1989. There haven't been any additional studies to confirm Geddes' statements. Officials were unclear how widespread the miscalculations may be. ``Clearly the portfolio that we were looking at is the smaller savings and loans in the Midwest. But whether the problem is broader than that, I don't know,'' said Steve Seelig, director of the FDIC's division of liquidation. An adjustable-rate mortgage, or ARM, has an interest rate that fluctuates according to a financial index, such as the rise or fall of Treasury bills. Errors may arise when a lender mistakenly uses the wrong index, calculates the index at an improper time, or lacks proper computer software to tabulate the mortgage. Geddes' allegations in August 1989 sent shockwaves through the lending community. At least four class-action lawsuits have been filed in Indiana, alleging savings and loans excessively overcharged borrowers. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, issued a report on the problem in October. Federal auditors now pay special attention to the loans when reviewing the financial records of banks, credit unions and savings and loans, said Mitch Rachlis, senior economist for the GAO. Meanwhile, the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council, an umbrella group of federal financial services regulators, is coordinating an examination of banks, savings and loans, and credit unions which have adjustable-rate mortgages in their portfolios. The move by the council shows the federal government is taking the problem very seriously, said Fritz Elmendorf, spokesman for the Consumer Bankers Association in Arlington, Va. So, apparently, are homeowners. HSH Associates, a New Jersey mortgage information service, is marketing kits for borrowers to double check their mortgage calculations. Paul Havemann, HSH vice president, said last week his office had gotten about 400 telephone calls in a couple of days, ``and that would be a conservative guess.'' Attorney George Plews of Indianapolis said he's working with attorneys in 15 other states whose clients have problems with adjustable-rate mortgages. Plews, who filed the four class-action lawsuits in Indiana, said a typical loss ranges from $200 to $1,400 over the term of the loan. ``Our information is that this is not a new problem in the industry,'' said Plews. ``The inaccuracies in the portfolio was relative common knowledge in the late 1980s'' among bank regulators. Plews said his review shows the problem afflicts banks as well as savings and loans. ``It's almost an accident the lawsuits right now are against the S&Ls,'' he said. The American Bankers Association disagreed, saying the problem now appears to be confined to just savings and loans. Spokeswoman Tara Little said some lenders have reviewed their portfolios and found ``almost no errors.'' Industry officials said they were unaware of any consumers avoiding ARMs in light of the recent publicity. Some analysts say the bulk of the errors may even be in consumers' favor. Others say the damage is evenly split. ``The adjustable-rate mortgage problem is more a problem of complexity as opposed to a problem of greed,'' Seelig said.

DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Minority Scholarships, Bjt ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: ``We don't find this helpful at all. There is just further confusion and no clarification. What's next? Gender? Religion?'' - David Merkowitz, spokesman for the American Council on Education, on the Bush administration's new policy on race-exclusive scholarships. --- ``The confusion is considerable. It's only made worse by this clarification.'' - Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, which represents about 1,800 public and private colleges and universities. --- ``This is a major shift in policy and it was developed in a vacuum. It needs close examination and full debate.'' - Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Warns Against Tinkering With New Farm Law
DOC.TEXT: Start tinkering with the 1990 farm law and farmers might wind up with a further cut in federal payments, not more money, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter warns. Last week in Denver, the board of directors of the National Farmers Union called on Congress ``to reopen and rewrite parts'' of the five-year law passed this year. The NFU directors said the 1990 law will devastate family farmers and rural areas unless changes are made. Yeutter told broadcasters Tuesday in a telephone news conference that ``opening the farm bill would be a big mistake for everyone, including the folks from the Farmers Union.'' In the view of some critics, a problem with the 1990 legislation is that it was subject to federal budget-cutting restraints. This pared $13.5 billion from commodity program operations over five years. One result was to reduce the amount of acreage eligible for direct subsidies, or ``deficiency payments,'' under annual crop programs. Critics say this will cut into farm income. ``In my judgment, U.S. agriculture came out very well in the budget exercise, when one considers the circumstances under which that bill was legislated,'' Yeutter said. But he added, ``There are still some folks in American agriculture who believe that the $26 billion in federal subsidies that was provided in 1986 ought to be the norm and that if they just make a strong enough appeal in Washington, that would still be possible.'' That was a reference to the record $25.8 billion paid to farmers in fiscal 1986 under Agriculture Department commodity programs. Those payments since have declined to a fraction of that annual rate. Yeutter said he sees ``no chance whatsoever'' that Congress would return to the agricultural spending levels of the past. Rather, he predicted that if lawmakers reopen the farm bill debate the chances would be 50-50 that spending would be cut, not raised. Bob Denman, a National Farmers Union spokesman in Washington, said no one had suggested that commodity spending be boosted to $26 billion a year over the five years of the law. But the NFU does believe some parts of the law can be strengthened and adjusted to help protect family farmers more than the 1990 act does. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Unless world trade talks get back on track, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter thinks the European Community may suffer major political and economic damage for its refusal to compromise. And if it comes to an agricultural trade war with the EC, said Yeutter, the United States is prepared to fight. Negotiations among 107 nations in the so-called Uruguay Round of trade talks collapsed Dec. 7 in Brussels after the EC refused to bend on U.S. proposals on major farm trade issues, including cutbacks in internal price supports and export subsidies. The United States, backed by Australia, Brazil and other major exporters, sought sharp reductions in subsidies, while the 12-nation EC, Japan and South Korea were against the plan. Efforts are being made to reconvene the talks in mid-January, but Yeutter said further negotiations would have little chance unless the EC is prepared to change its hard-line stance. But Yeutter told reporters Tuesday he thinks some internal pressures are developing in favor of a reassessment of the EC position. He said he was Europe last week in the aftermath of the Dec. 7 breakdown and found the community to be ``very embarrassed by what happened in Brussels.'' The community ``will probably not concede that publicly, but the fact is they suffered a major geopolitical defeat in Brussels, with essentially all of the world leaving with dissatisfaction and disappointment in the EC position,'' Yeutter said. ``A lot of folks in Western Europe are chagrined by the present status of the Uruguay Round and are concerned that the (EC) may bear the lion's share of the blame for failure, should it occur,'' he said. Consequently, he said, a number of ``working level'' people in the EC are trying to reassess the bloc's position in hopes the stalled talks can be rejuvenated. But Yeutter said he didn't know at this point whether this can translate into changes at the EC's leadership level. ``I'm pessimistic about the potential outcome (of the talks) so long as the community maintains its present intransigent stance,'' he said. Earlier, in a telephone news conference with broadcasters, Yeutter he was not ready to tip off the EC what the United States might do if the Uruguay Round of talks fail completely. ``I want them to be uncertain about what our response would be - and a bit frightened by the potential,'' he said. ``So, I'm not going to discuss publicly what the United States might do.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - After a two-month layoff, the Soviet Union has bought a substantial quantity of U.S. corn, according to the Agriculture Department. Officials said Tuesday that private exporting companies sold 266,500 metric tons to the Soviets under terms of the current long-term supply agreement between the two countries. No prices or other details were disclosed. The pact, including a three-month extension, expires Dec. 31. A new five-year agreement will begin at that time. A metric ton of 2,205 pounds is equivalent to 39.4 bushels of corn. Thus, the 266,500 tons would be about 10.5 million bushels. Corn prices have been averaging about $2.19 per bushel at the farm level, according to USDA's five-day average. Thus, the latest sale could have a farm value of about $23 million.

DOC.HEAD: BBC Considers Banning Big Ben's Bong From Christmas Airwaves
DOC.TEXT: Big Ben's chimes, which traditionally announce the queen's Christmas Day message and ring in the New Year, might not make it onto BBC airwaves this time around. Seems the main bell has lost its distinctive bong. A decision has yet to be made, and some British Broadcasting Corp. officials think it would be a big mistake depart from tradition by banning the bong this holiday season. Big Ben's bells have traditionally been used on BBC airwaves as a lead-in to news bulletins, but disappeared temporarily in March after cracks were found in the hammer arm of the 132-year-old main bell that sounds the hours. The original Victorian hammer was removed and replaced with a new $15,000 steel hammer. But ever since the 13-ton bell went back into service in August, BBC executives have been unenthusiastic, so much so that they have begun phasing the chimes out of regular broadcasts. ``It just sounds wrong,'' said Simon Schute, the BBC's general manager of operations and engineering, responsible for setting up microphones in the Big Ben belfry, 334 steps above the street. ``I'm no expert on bells, but this one has a sort of curious start and finishes sounding sort of small and clattery. It certainly doesn't sound rich and important anymore,'' Schute said. Britain's Independent Television News has solved the problem by continuing to use a 1967 recording of Big Ben. But BBC executives won't hear of it. ``We shall either use the real thing or nothing at all,'' said John Breach, presentation organizer of Radio 4, the BBC's flagship domestic channel. ``These are the chimes of Big Ben. To play a recording would not be the same. It's not part of our tradition.'' BBC Radio 4 replaced the bong with pips, the electronic signal of Greenwich Mean Time, to introduce its daily news at 6 p.m. and midnight and the weekend morning news. ``We don't mix pips and bongs,'' said Breach. ``Listeners have missed Big Ben, but the decision was made at a more senior level than myself that the sound quality wasn't as good as it used to be and the switch to pips was permanent.'' Breach said listeners understood the reason for the change, but BBC executives fear the public may not be so patient with a change in a holiday tradition that dates back to midnight, Dec. 31, 1923. Every year since then, the live sounds from Big Ben have rung in the New Year and introduced the monarch's speech on Christmas Day. ``We're still trying to decide what to do. I believe we will decide to use the bell. After all, what is more important, tradition or a faulty bong?'' said Breach. BBC engineers have experimented with moving the microphones which transmit the live bong. They tried placing directional microphones on a nearby building in Parliament Square. Nothing worked. David Heathcoat-Amory, the former junior environment minister, told Parliament in October that the new bearings were to blame and they would just take time to settle in.
