DOC.HEAD: Women Call for More Information, Safety Testing on Silicone Breast Implants
DOC.TEXT: Women who have had silicone breast implants seem to agree on one thing - that people considering this procedure need more information and the implants themselves need better safety testing. A panel of women told of their experiences with implants before a House subcommittee Tuesday, urging action that ranged from a moratorium on the sale of implants to an appeal to keep options open for women who want their breasts reconstructed after cancer surgery. Sybil Niden Goldrich of Beverly Hills, Calif., said the two sets of implants she had have left her with a ``silicone sword of Damocles hanging over my head. ``I've gone seven years without a recurrence of (breast) cancer, but what will happen from the silicone?'' she said at the House Government Operations human resources subcommittee hearing. ``I shudder when I think about it.'' The first implants left her with a body rash, pain, fever, ``rock-hard'' breasts and gynecological problems. They were replaced with another set, but the problems continued. These implants were removed also, and she had her breasts reconstructed in a different procedure using her own body tissue. Her gynecological problems continued and she had a hysterectomy two years ago. A biopsy of her liver at the time identified silicone, she said. ``I encourage you to demand a moratorium on the sale of these products until we are absolutely certain that the safety of these implants can be proven beyond reasonable doubt,'' she said. Silicone breast implants have been used since the early 1960s. They have been placed in about 2 million American women and are implanted at the rate of about 130,000 a year. When 1976 amendments to the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act required regulation of medical devices, breast implants were ``grandfathered'' into the market. This meant they did not have to meet the specifications required of new products. The Food and Drug Administration has classified silicone implants as high risk, but it has not yet finalized a regulation that would require manufacturers to submit safety data or remove their products from the market. FDA officials testified the rule would be made final in March. Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., chairman of the subcommittee, said he was concerned about the ``inordinate delay'' and ``seven years of the agency dragging its feet,'' especially in light of the unanswered questions about silicone implants. Another implant recipient, Rosemary Locke, director of a women's breast cancer support program in the Washington D.C. area, gave the panel a different perspective. Locke, who had a double mastectomy and reconstruction, said she had some complications after surgery but explained that ``having my body restored eased away much of the trauma of breast cancer.'' ``I have never regretted my decision, even though I now know more about silicone implants than when I made my decision,'' she said. She urged the subcommittee and the FDA, as they consider breast implants, ``please keep in mind the women who have lost breasts to cancer. Silicone implants may be their only option for surgically restoring their body.'' Dow Corning Corp., one of the largest makers of silicone breast implants, distributed a survey by the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons that found 92 percent of women with breast augmentation or reconstruction said they were satisfied with their implant surgery. About 25 percent of silicone breast implants are for breast reconstruction after breast cancer surgery. The rest are for breast enlargement. The FDA has received 2,017 reports of adverse reactions from silicone implants, said Walter Gundaker, acting director of the FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health. About 3,000 other such reports are from saline-filled breast implants, which are less common than silicone ones. However, the saline implants also contain silicone. Witnesses at the hearing said these numbers were conservative because many physicians and surgeons do not report the problems.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Recommends Restrictions Against Neil Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil was guilty of conflict of interest but should be allowed to accept a future position with a savings institution under certain restrictions, an administrative law judge says. The Office of Thrift Supervision charged Neil Bush in January with conflict of interest in his role as a director of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson, who found that Bush exposed Silverado to ``abnormal risk,'' could have recommended that he be barred permanently from the banking and savings industries. Instead, Davidson proposed to OTS Director Timothy Ryan that Bush be required to meet certain conditions if he again becomes a director or officer of a savings and loan or bank. For example, Davidson said, Bush should be required to get advice from a lawyer on potential conflicts of interest if he takes such a position. His recommendations, made Monday, were announced late Tuesday by OTS. Davidson's proposals followed closely the recommendations of OTS lawyers in the case against Bush, 35, an oil and gas developer. Davidson agreed with the OTS attorneys that Bush's failure to fully disclose his business ties ``involved a significant conflict of interest constituting an inherently unsafe or unsound practice.'' Silverado's collapse in December 1988 is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion. In his recommendation, Davidson said Bush's conduct was ``contrary to generally accepted standards of prudent operations and exposed Silverado to abnormal risk.'' Ryan will review Davidson's recommendation and is expected to make a final decision this spring, agency officials said. Ryan could adopt the recommendation, reject it or revise it, OTS spokesman Tom Mason said. Bush's attorney, James Nesland, said his client would appeal Ryan's decision if it embraced Davidson's proposal. Under administrative law, Bush would have the right to appeal the director's decision to a federal court. President Bush had no comment on the judge's recommendation, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Davidson held a public administrative hearing in late September in Denver, at which Neil Bush and government witnesses testified. The regulators accused Bush of failing to adequately inform fellow Silverado directors of his business ties with developers Kenneth Good and Bill Walters, who invested in Bush's oil company. Good and Walters eventually defaulted on more than $132 million in loans from Silverado. Bush has insisted that he committed no wrongdoing in voting as a director to approve loans to Good and Walters. In addition, Bush told Davidson in a legal brief submitted last month, ``there is no likelihood that the alleged unsafe or unsound practices will continue.'' If he again becomes an S&L or bank director, Davidson said, Bush should be required to abstain from voting on any proposals involving people or companies in which he has an interest. Bush also should make a full disclosure at least once a year of his business relationships with customers or potential customers of the S&L or bank, Davidson proposed. He said the information should be updated each time there is a relevant change in Bush's financial situation. In addition to the government's conflict of interest case, Bush also faces a $200 million negligence lawsuit filed against him and other former Silverado directors by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Der Spiegel Reporter Suspected of Spying for East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The prestigious newsmagazine Der Spiegel's cover story has a common theme these days in Germany but an unaccustomed main actor: one of Spiegel's own reporters is suspected of spying for Communist East Germany. This week's Spiegel, published Monday, spent 13 pages examining the allegations against Diethelm Schroeder that surfaced last week in a television expose. The Hamburg-based news weekly left Schroeder's name on the roster of its Berlin bureau, but noted he was ``on leave.'' Spiegel showed the drubbing it took from other German publications: a headline in the mass-circulation daily Bild asked if Schroeder was ``a traitor.'' A cartoon republished from the Rheinische Post showed a Spiegel sleuth following a spy's tracks - in a circle that became Spiegel's own trail. ``I have to live with this story,'' Schroeder said in a telephone interview, denying he had worked for the East German secret service or done anybody any harm. Spiegel called the denial a ``half-confession.'' The 60-year-old native of eastern Germany, a military specialist who worked in The Associated Press' German-language service for five years in the Sixties, said his Spiegel colleagues had explained that they had done major stories on other spy allegations ``and now we have to write a story about you.'' ``I think it's correct,'' Schroeder said, adding with a laugh, ``I would have had more fun if it was another story, I think.'' Last week, ARD television named Schroeder as having worked from 1964 to 1987 for the Stasi, as the now-defunct East Germany's Ministry for State Security is called. Prosecutors confirmed that Schroeder was under investigation, though there was no word on how serious a case he might face. Conviction for passing state secrets can bring life in prison, while a lesser charge of passing information to a foreign espionage agency carries a maximum 10-year prison term. As Germany works to clear up the decades of cross-border spying, prosecutors have already issued 61 arrest warrants this year. Spiegel, which grew up with postwar West Germany, has been hitting the espionage issue hard along with other issues facing newly united Germany. Only a week earlier, Spiegel had a scoop revealing evidence that East Germany's first and only non-Communist prime minister, Lothar de Maiziere, had a Stasi past. De Maiziere denies cooperating with secret police but quit as deputy head of the governing Christian Democratic Union while prosecutors look into the evidence. Schroeder, who remains free, denies any wrongdoing, telling Spiegel he had had taken no money, sent no written reports and hurt no one. Spiegel's article wondered whether his denial might have been a ``half-confession,'' and asked, ``Through which activities was no one hurt?'' Doing the cover story was difficult, said Wolfram Bickerich, a senior editor in Hamburg who had been friends with Schroeder through working together 16 years. ``But it was the only decision we could make, because we said if we have such a case in our own house, we are obliged to do this,'' Bickerich said in a telephone interview. The cover story quoted Schroeder as saying the allegations were a ``conspiracy against me or probably even against Der Spiegel.'' It said three former Stasi officials had revealed details about Schroeder's purported services for East German intelligence. But the magazine cast doubt on the claim in the television program that Schroeder had given the East Germans valuable material on West German and NATO defense planning and equipment. The affable reporter was on close terms with the current NATO secretary-general, Manfred Woerner, a former German defense minister. Schroeder was the first reporter to fly in a Tornado fighter-bomber. He knew about scandals in West German officialdom. Schroeder came from the Baltic coastal region that fell under Soviet occupation and became East Germany after World War II. He was trained as a journalist under the Communist system but moved to West Germany in 1956. His own story is that the Soviet suppression of revolt in Hungary caused him to abandon the East. The allegation is that he was slipped into the West as a budding spy. In his late 20s he worked for West German newspapers, and then for AP's German news service in Frankfurt and Bonn from 1960 to 1965. He was questioned in 1964 on suspicion of espionage against American forces. Schroeder read out a memo issued then to subscribers of AP's German-language service saying a reporter had been questioned, his home and desk had been searched, and he had been set free because the interrogation yielded no reason for his arrest. The memo did not name the suspected reporter, partly because he had relatives living under Soviet occupation. Asked in the telephone interview if he had worked for the Stasi, Schroeder said, ``No, the answer is no.'' The questions directed to him, he added, were ``from former times, not from the last 20 years.'' In 1965, Schroeder went to work for the Bild newspaper in Bonn, and moved to Spiegel's Bonn bureau in 1974. Spiegel quoted the chief federal prosecutor, Alexander von Stahl, as saying proceedings also were under way against two western German journalists other than Schroeder.

DOC.HEAD: Country of Emigrants Confronts Illegal Immigration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For five centuries, Spaniards emigrated to the four corners of the globe in search of new worlds, gold or just a better life for their families. Today, an economically solid, democratic Spain has become a magnet for new generations of immigrants fleeing poverty and dead-end lives in countries from Morocco to the Philippines. Although the steady flow of immigrants over the past decade has not yet become overwhelming, Spanish officials are concerned about how the country will cope with the newcomers, most of them illegal. European Economic Community officials worry that Spain's loose border controls will encourage illegal aliens and help them pass into other Western European countries. They are part of Europe's greatest refugee migration since World War II. It became a tide sweeping from east to west after the Communist regimes of the Soviet bloc collapsed a year ago. This week, the government circulated copies of a report on immigration to opposition leaders prior to coming parliamentary debate. The report proposes an annual quota on immigration, tighter border controls and heavy fines for those employing illegal immigrants. According to Fernando Puig de la Bellacasa, head of the Interior Ministry's domestic policy department, immigration is a new phenomenon for Spain. ``We were an exporter of emigrants, now we're a country receiving immigrants,'' he said. ``We're not used to it. We're not set up for it.'' A year ago, Mulie Jarju worked in a plaster factory as an illegal alien from West Africa whose requests for work and residence permits were repeatedly denied by authorities. Today, the 33-year-old native of Gambia is the star of a new Spanish film about the lives of illegal African aliens and their encounters with racism and exploitation. ``Letters from Alou'' won the top prize at the San Sebastian Film Festival and Jarju received the best actor award, but he still can't get a residence and work permit. The government of Socialist Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez passed an Alien Residence Act in July 1985. It took effect the following May and gave all illegal residents 10 months to apply for legal residence and work permits. Only 38,000 applied. The number of aliens living legally in Spain has jumped over the past decade from 181,000 to 400,000, according to Interior Ministry figures. More than half are from other Western European countries. Government estimates put the number of illegal aliens in Spain, a nation of 40 million, at between 70,000 and 140,000. More than half are believed to be Moroccan. Non-governmental agencies dealing with immigrants and refugees say the total number is closer to half a million. Spain's lightly monitored frontiers, its physical proximity to North Africa and its cultural ties with Latin America have become issues in the 12-nation EC. In March, Spain will require visas for nationals of Morocco, Tunisia and Algeria; Denmark will then be the only EC member that does not require visas for North African nationals. But EC countries north of Spain still fear Madrid will not be able to keep illegal immigrants from flooding into the rest of the Community. In a recent interview in the French daily Le Monde, Gonzalez said border controls were not sufficient to stem the tide of illegal immigration. He also expressed particular sympathy for North Africans. ``If I were between 18 and 25 and lived on the other side of the Mediterranean today with an income 10 times lower than the European minimum wage, there would be no frontiers. I would get by them all.'' Interior Minister Jose Luis Corcuera has expressed concern about signs of growing racism and xenophobia in Spain, a country with a historically tiny non-European population. Other government officials are expressing concern privately over rapidly increasing immigration from Eastern Europe. ``More than 1,000 Poles a week are arriving,'' one said. ``We're extremely worried about the dimension this could take.'' As a signatory of the 1951 Geneva Convention on Refugees, Spain is obliged to receive foreigners who seek refuge for political reasons and see they are paid a stipend until their cases have been decided. Both government authorities and private relief agencies agree that most asylum seekers show up in Spain for economic, not political reasons. But the snail-paced bureaucratic process of reviewing individual requests for asylum allows many immigrants to slip through the cracks and into the underground economy where they find jobs in construction, garment sweatshops and in fields and orchards picking fruit and vegetables. Since the summer about 150 Africans awaiting decisions on their asylum petitions have been sleeping in a Madrid park or in abandoned buildings because no one will rent them rooms. Since coming to Spain six years ago, Jarju has picked fruit, carted junk, sold trinkets and sewed shirts in an illegal sweatshop. His experiences served as a basis for the film.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Faces Probe, Search for New Chairman
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Monday correct in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A financially troubled presidential commission planning the 500th anniversary celebration of Columbus' 1492 voyage to America faces a congressional investigation and a search for a new chairman. John Goudie of Miami resigned Monday as head of the Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Jubilee Commission out of what his deputy said was a sense of frustration. Goudie was a fund-raiser for the unsuccessful re-election effort of Florida Gov. Bob Martinez, who is President Bush's nominee as director of national drug control policy. He was appointed to the commission by former President Reagan. The commission is $600,000 in arrears on an agreement to pay Spain for replicas of Columbus' three ships. The ships are to tour American ports for the celebration. Texaco Inc., which has pledged $5 million, stopped its donations in September because of ``some technical matters and overall management of the program,'' Texaco spokesman K. Peter Maneri said Tuesday. He said the company hopes the problems, which he refused to detail, can be worked out and financial support resumed. Another potential sponsor, Chrysler Corp., says it wants to clear up unspecified contractual questions before making a donation of more than $1 million. A House Post Office and Civil Service subcommittee, meanwhile, is delving into Goudie's longtime friendship with Manuel Gonzalez, a Miami businessmen who has been involved in plans for the celebration. A businessman, Peter Dunev of Miami, paid $50,000 for the right to place the 500th anniversary logo on T-shirts. Gonzalez came by Dunev's office last summer to pick up the checks for the $50,000, Dunev said in an interview. The checks were made out to Christopher Columbus Licensing Group Inc. of Miami and New York. The commission has awarded the licensing group a contract enabling it to keep 85 percent of commission-related sales on T-shirts and souvenirs. Bill Rolen, a Knoxville, Tenn., businessman who had made a proposal for the celebration, said Goudie introduced him to Gonzalez as a friend who might be able to provide Rolen with financing Rolen said the two didn't do business because Gonzalez wanted part ownership in Rolen's proposed venture. It was to have been a renovation of a former world's fair exposition hall in Knoxville for the Columbus celebration. Gonzalez did not return telephone calls to his home and office in Miami. Goudie also couldn't be reached. However, the commission's deputy director, Jana Joustra, said Goudie's resignation from the non-salaried, part-time post was ``completely voluntary.'' She said Goudie ``got fed up'' with the problems, the lack of financial support and the criticism he faced after spending a great deal of his own time on the project. ``Nobody appreciated it,'' she said. Congress appropriates $212,000 a year for the commission to pay part of the salaries and rent for the six-member staff. The congressional subcommittee's investigation of the commission will continue, said the panel's chairman, Rep. Thomas Sawyer, D-Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Crime Trend: Killing for Coats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to DELETE extraneous `and.'
DOC.TEXT: Anthony Palmer and Marvin Scott were the lucky ones, survivors of the city's latest crime wave: killing for coats. At least five young people have been killed in the past four weeks in the New York City area by thieves who wanted their trendy coats. Palmer, 22, was grazed by a bullet Sunday after he refused to hand over his jacket to four men as he left a party. The men fled without the jacket. Twenty-year-old Scott was shot in the leg at 3 a.m. Sunday trying to run away from a gunman who demanded his goosedown jacket. He limped to a hospital. Police say two coats have become popular targets for thieves: A jacket that has a billiard ball in multicolored leather patches and a white sheepskin collar, and coats made of shearling leather, preferably three-quarters length. ``It's become the in thing,'' said Lt. James Malvey. ``Years ago it was bomber jackets. Now it's leather jackets. Nothing's changed but the fashion.'' About 20 people have survived such attacks, police said. At least five others died. Malvey said Edward Dobbinson, 19, was charged with murder in the shooting death of an unidentified youth over an 8-Ball brand jacket on Dec. 10. Rashid Smith, 17, wore his 8-Ball jacket to a party Dec. 7. His coatless body was later found by partygoers. No arrests have been made. On nearby Long Island, Michael Wise, 22, of Hempstead, died Dec. 7, a day after he was shot in the back when he refused to give up his $350 leather coat. The gunmen fled without his coat. Nicholas Best, 16, was fatally shot Dec. 3 when he ran to help a friend against two muggers demanding his Chicago Bulls leather and suede jacket. Bernard Richardson was shot Nov. 26 while walking to a store with two friends who wore expensive shearling coats. When they refused to give up the coats, the robber opened fire, killing Richardson.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Breeders Plan to Challenge Ban on Pet Breeding
DOC.TEXT: The nation's first ban on pet breeding has become law, and owners of show animals promise a dogfight to overturn it. San Mateo County's breeding ban, which requires that most pets be spayed or neutered, received final approval Tuesday. Opponents campaigned for a last-minute reversal before the Board of Supervisors voted 3-1 in favor of the law designed to reduce the number of strays put to death in the county just south of San Francisco. Under the law, breeders who obtain permits would be able to continue furthering bloodlines, but that's not enough for some show dog owners. ``The whole thing is going to end up an enormous legal battle,'' said Susan Clough of Redwood City, a show dog owner picketing with her dog Loree. ``The intent was never to go after any group of people but to rectify an untenable situation in which we kill 10,000 pets a year,'' said Supervisor Tom Nolan, author of the measure. The ordinance bans breeding by private dog and cat owners for six months starting in July. By 1992, only dogs and cats owned by professional and hobby breeders holding permits will be allowed to reproduce. All other cats and dogs will have to be spayed or neutered. Violators face a $500 fine. The cost of the permit and other details have not been worked out. The ordinance affects only unincorporated areas amounting to about 10 percent of the county's population of 628,000. It would not affect such cities as South San Francisco, Redwood City, San Mateo and Menlo Park.

DOC.HEAD: Church a Haven for The Poor, A Power Base For Aristide
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The apparent choice of a leftist priest as Haiti's first democratically elected president may be a historical phenomenon, but is not a complete surprise. The poor multitudes that voted for the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide on Sunday have traditionally found haven - and inspiration - in churches. In the 37-year-old Aristide, believers saw a prophet who could end the political murders, torture and corruption perpetrated by a series of repressive dictatorships. Even people who lack electricity managed to have a battery-run radio to tune in to his sermons broadcast on Catholic radio throughout this mountainous Caribbean nation of 5 million. Roman Catholicism, voodoo and Protestant missionaries have played key roles throughout the turbulent 186-year history of Haiti, the world's first black republic. But in recent history, politically oriented leftist offshoots of Catholicism had perhaps the greatest popular influence. Such sects blossomed during the late 1970s, when Haiti was ruled by the Duvalier family. At the time, hundreds of young priests, nuns and layworkers moved away from the traditional church, forming grassroots organizations in slums and among the peasantry. Opposition parties were banned and Haiti's bishops either praised the dictatorship or were silent. ``The people were beginning to see their bishops as authority figures and beginning in some cases to associate that authority with the authority of the hated regime'' wrote Amy Wilentz in her book, ``The Rainy Season''. The new religious movement was called the Parish of the Poor - or Little Church - and stemmed from Liberation Theology, which advocates that the church become politically active to improve the lot of the poor. Liberation Theology was rapidly spreading in Latin America and its adherents in Haiti were speaking out against the violence and overwhelming poverty the nation's people were enduring under the Duvaliers. In 1983, Pope John Paul II visited Haiti and admonished the nation's rulers, boosting the efforts of the Little Church. The Duvalierist regime, enforced by a private militia of thugs called the Tonton Macoutes, began in 1957 with the rise to power of the late ``Papa Doc'' Francois Duvalier. It ended after mass protests forced his son, Jean-Claude Duvalier, into exile in France in 1986. ``The opposition to Duvalier was expressed in these churches,'' said Jean-Claude Bajeaux, a widely respected human rights activist. ``It was a place where fears and anger toward the Macoutes could be expressed.'' It was largely inside the yellow St. Jean-Bosco church, located on the edge of a slum, that the young, fiery and charismatic Aristide berated the regime in Biblical terms. ``Aristide was a priest who used the poetic words of the Bible to speak out against Duvalier,'' said Laennec Hurbon, a Caribbean religion expert and author. ``He was a Moses whose mission was to save these people from the devils - the devils being the Macoutes,'' said Bajeaux. Ordained a Salesian priest in 1982, Aristide was given at the beginning the go-ahead by the conservative order to battle against Duvalier. But as his congregation grew larger, the Salesians backed off their support. ``In their view, he was leaning too much to the left,'' said Hurbon. In 1988 he was expelled from the order for preaching ``class struggle.'' ``The crime of which I stand accused of is the crime of preaching food for all people,'' Aristide wrote in his book ``In the Parish of the Poor.'' ``That is what the Salesians and the Haitian bishops and the Vatican call politics,'' he wrote. Many conservatives interpret liberation theologians' efforts to organize the poor as Marxism, and U.S. officials have privately expressed fears that Aristide could try to turn Haiti into another Cuba. For their part, holdovers of the Duvalier regime have vowed to prevent ``an ultra-communist'' from taking power. ``Liberation theology has been misunderstood. It is just reading Exodus,'' which tells the story of the emancipaton of Jews, said George Price, prime minister of Belize and one of some 800 observers for Sunday's elections. Former President Jimmy Carter, a born-again Christian, agreed. Carter, who also monitored the elections, said he respects their ``the social commitment.'' Aristide remains a priest but is barred from saying Mass in public. He has said he will renounce the priesthood if the Vatican, which has a policy against priests holding public office, asks him to. ``The title of priest is just a title. Jesus was not a priest,'' he said last week. ``I continue to preach the same truth without Mass.'' International and U.S. observers predict he will win with more than 60 percent of the vote. The vote count is expected to be complete by week's end. ``Aristide's popularity is not so much because he is a priest. He had that something, because there were other priests doing the same things. But they didn't have his popularity,'' said Laennec. ``He stood for change.'' The Roman Catholic-run Radio Soleil, where many of Aristide's sermons were broadcast, was also his pulpit, reaching thousands in the countryside who had no electricity or running water but owned battery-run radios. The radio was often shot at and forced off the air, but along with Radio Haiti-Inter, Radio Soleil was the only source of news that reported human rights violations and corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Inflatable Sunglasses Wrapped Around Opera House
DOC.TEXT: The Opera House sported a huge pair of sunglasses for about an hour today, put there clandestinely by the environmental group Greenpeace to demonstrate concern about ozone depletion. The inflatable sunglasses - 70 feet wide by 20 feet high - were placed across the largest of the building's seven sail-like roof peaks. An acompanying banner read: ``Ozone Depletion: stop it or we'll go blind.'' A portable generator inflated the glasses at about 6:30 a.m. and they stayed in place for about an hour until police pulled the plug. That made them visible to many of the commuters coming across the harbor in ferries. Greenpeace spokeswoman Karla Bell said the stunt was designed carefully to prevent any damage to the Opera House. The activists all were experienced climbers, including two who have reached the top of Mt. Everest. All seven were arrested after rappelling down the Opera House, but were later released without charge. Scientists say they have found evidence of a hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica that appears each year. Ozone filters out cancer-causing ultraviolet radiation from the sun. Greenpeace is calling for a speedy phase out of chlorofluorocarbons, man-made gases believed to cause the ozone layer's depletion. Chloroflourocarbons are principally used in refrigeration and air-conditioning, and Ms. Bell said there has not been enough movement to switch to safer alternatives. ``Australia is at the forefront of continuing ozone depletion, which threatens our health and way of life,'' Ms. Ball said. She contended that, ``for every 1 percent of ozone depletion, 100,000 people worldwide will lose their sight. ``Australia has the highest rate of skin cancer anywhere in the world; continued ozone depletion will be responsible for a significant increase in these cancers.''

DOC.HEAD: 23 States Sue Over Marketing of Schizophrenia Drug
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-three states have sued the only U.S. manufacturer of a schizophrenia drug, accusing the company of violating antitrust law in requiring patients to pay for expensive monitoring for side effects. The lawsuits were filed in federal court here Tuesday against Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp. of East Hanover, N.J., and Caremark Inc. of Lincolnshire, Ill., which has an exclusive contract with Sandoz to do the monitoring. According to the lawsuits, Sandoz charges $172 a week, or $8,944 a year, for the drug Clozaril and the blood monitoring. In Germany, where the drug is not tied to other services, patients pay $1,666 each year, the lawsuits said. ``Removing this unlawful, anti-competitive tie between the sale of Clozaril and the monitoring package can improve the lives of thousands of people suffering from schizophrenia,'' said Minnesota Attorney General Hubert Humphrey III. Sandoz has said the monitoring is needed to check for a potentially fatal side effect, agranulocytosis, that reduces the level of infection-fighting white blood cells. Caremark vice president Jim Mieszala said the monitoring is fairly priced. New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams said the safety claims were merely ``camouflage'' for anti-competitive practices. ``The issue in this case is simply whether Sandoz or the patients' own doctors should choose how to monitor their patients' use of Clozaril,'' he said. Sandoz spokeswoman Maria Sweeney said the company is trying to reduce the drug's price. The drug was approved by the Food and Drug Administration last year and Sandoz began marketing it in the United States in February. The lawsuits seek a court order requiring Sandoz to sell Clozaril and its generic equivalent, clozapine, without the blood monitoring services; end Sandoz's exclusive marketing rights, and award damages to the states. In addition to Minnesota and New York, attorneys general from the following states also sued: California, Colorado, Connecticut, Florida, Iowa, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Carolina, Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia and Wisconsin. Schizophrenia is a disorder often characterized by a distorted sense of reality, delusions, hallucinations, personality fragmentation and bizarre behavior.

DOC.HEAD: Business Coalition to Fight Tougher Standards
DOC.TEXT:
A 53-member business coalition is trying to energize Americans to oppose toughened federal automobile fuel economy standards on grounds they would inhibit lifestyles. ``It will limit what consumers can buy,'' said Greg Dana, vice president of the Association of International Automobile Manufacturers. The domestic and foreign auto industries organized the Coalition for Vehicle Choice to demonstrate that the battle over fuel economy is not simply a fight between automakers and environmentalists, said Jeffrey B. Conley, the coalition's executive director. Among the coalition's members are groups representing farmers, iron and steel manufacturers, electrical contractors, police chiefs and cattlemen. All recognize that a proposal to require new-car fleets to average 40 miles per gallon by the year 2001 could cost jobs and money, Conley said. Dan Becker, spokesman for the Sierra Club, dismissed the coalition as a ploy to mask Detroit's predominant role in opposition to the tougher standards. ``They're wrong if they think a phony coalition is going to help them win,'' Becker said Tuesday. ``People recognize that fuel efficiency is the key to curbing global warming and freeing us from having to send troops to the Middle East to fight for our energy security.'' The issue will be debated next year in Congress.
---
DOC.HEAD: AT&T Rate Cut Coming
DOC.TEXT:
AT&T Corp. plans to reduce weekday long-distance rates starting Jan. 1. The reduction, about $33 million in annual revenue to the company, reflects lower fees that will be paid to local telephone companies for access to customers' telephone lines, AT&T said Tuesday. Basic customer-dialed long-distance calls by individuals and small businesses will be reduced 1.1 percent between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. Monday through Friday, AT&T said. Some other reductions: -Some calls to Mexico and calls from Hawaii to 17 countries or geographic areas will be cheaper. -Calls to the former East Germany will be reduced to the same price as calls to the former West Germany. -Some lower prices under the Reach Out World international calling plan. AT&T handles about 70 percent of the nation's long-distance calls.
---
DOC.HEAD: Not Many Drug Users In Aviation, FAA Says
DOC.TEXT: Fewer than one-half percent of more than 120,000 recent drug tests in the aviation industry showed the presence of drugs, says the Federal Aviation Administration. The tests were conducted among commercial aviation employees ranging from pilots to airport security screening personnel as well as people applying for such safety or security sensitive jobs, the FAA said. An analysis of the 120,642 tests showed drugs in 561, just 0.47 percent of the total, the FAA said Tuesday. Of the 561, 345 were in pre-employment tests, and those people were not hired for sensitive jobs. Employees who tested positive were removed from sensitive positions, the agency said. John Mazor, spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association, said the analysis bore out ``what we have been saying all along, that they were not going to find any significant amount of drug abuse by airline pilots.'' ``We would hope that the government and industry would refocus their efforts away from heavy-handed methods,'' Mazor said. Some 538,000 aviation industry employees are subject to drug testing - before employment, at random or periodically on the job, after accidents and whenever there is reasonable cause to suspect drug abuse. Included are pilots, mechanics, flight attendants, airport security screening personnel and aircraft dispatchers. A breakdown of the test results that showed drug use among both applicants and employees revealed 18 pilots or other flight crew members, 116 flight attendants, 300 maintenance personnel, 48 aircraft dispatchers, 41 security personnel, five flight instructors, and four private air traffic control personnel. Twenty-nine persons were not identified by job function. Of the positive tests, 346 were attributed to marijuana use, 196 to cocaine, 13 to opiates, one to the use of PCP, and 15 to amphetamine use. Those numbers add to more than 561 because of multiple drug use by some people tested.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Cartel Leader Surrenders To Authorities, Could Be First Of Hundreds
DOC.TEXT: In what could be the first step toward a mass surrender of hundreds of drug traffickers, a cocaine baron wanted in the United States on drug and murder charges has turned himself in under a leniency plan. The program is aimed at ending a war between the government and the traffickers that has left hundreds of people dead. Fabio Ochoa Vasquez, 33, the youngest of three brothers who help run the Medellin cocaine cartel, surrendered Tuesday to a court official in a church south of Medellin, Colombia's second largest city, officials said. He was the first cartel leader to accept a government offer of no extradition and reduced prison sentences to drug traffickers who surrender. U.S. officials, in their request for Ochoa's extradition, say he once managed the cartel's cocaine distribution network in Miami. They say Ochoa is also accused of having ordered the 1986 murder of Barry Seal, an informant for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. Ochoa's surrender came just one day after the government offered new enticements to drug barons who turn themselves in. ``I hope this contributes in the best way to peace and understanding in Colombia,'' Ochoa said, referring to his surrender in a statement released by his family. A prison official said Ochoa was in good health and was being held in a jail in the Medellin suburb of Itaqui. Ochoa is taking advantage of two government decrees, one issued on Monday, that prohibit extraditions and offer lenient judicial treatment to surrendering traffickers. In late November, the cartel said that between 200 and 300 drug traffickers were willing to surrender in return for legal guarantees. In its decree Monday, the government granted the cartel's demands for human rights safeguards and the preparation of heavily guarded jails. Jaime Cordoba, the attorney general's human rights coordinator, said human rights delegates were being appointed to oversee Ochoa's surrender. President Cesar Gaviria, who took office in August, told reporters he was pleased with the results of the decrees he issued in a bid to secure the surrender of leading traffickers. ``The government is very satisfied that (its decrees) are having all the effects they should have in Colombian life,'' Gaviria said, speaking over the Caracol radio network. In the past month, four mid-level traffickers have accepted Gaviria's offer and turned themselves in. The decrees have exposed the president to intense criticism from foreign diplomats, the press and local politicians who say the government is going soft in the drug war. But the government insists its policies will lead cocaine traffickers to serve time in Colombia instead of relying on U.S. courts to prosecute Colombian drug criminals. In the past, drug barons have threatened, bribed or killed Colombian judges and prison authorities to obtain their freedom. ``We are sure that all (of the traffickers) will find it much easier to surrender than to continue a sterile fight that produces only pain and death,'' Justice Minister Jaime Giraldo told reporters Tuesday evening. The Medellin gang has been blamed for killing around 550 Colombians since the government and traffickers declared war on each other in August 1989, when a prominent presidential candidate was assassinated. It was not clear if Ochoa's brothers, Jorge Luis and Juan David, were also planning to turn themselves in. The cartel's top leader, Pablo Escobar, also remains at large. Fabio Ochoa's statement indicated that other drug kingpins may demand further guarantees before surrendering. He said the recent decrees ``were a long way from satisfying the dreams and expectations raised by the government.''

DOC.HEAD: Christie's Auction House To Cut 146 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Christie's International, the auctioneers, says it plans to cut about a tenth of its work force following a 50 percent drop in its autumn season sales. Christie's announced Tuesday that it would lay off 146 employees worldwide, from clerks to art experts, over the next few weeks. Its total work force currently totals about 1,450. The company said in a news release that it also would freeze its senior staff's salaries as part of the cost-cutting program. Christie's sales sank to $645 million in the months of August to December from $1.3 billion in the same period a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Friend of Jailed Activist Ends China Trip, Thwarted by Bureaucracy
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese student trying to ensure justice for a jailed pro-democracy activist left today for the United States, ending a frustrating trip with no new information about his friend's case. Ge Xun, 31, came to China after hearing reports that Wang Juntao would stand trial soon for his involvement in last year's pro-democracy movement. Ge said he wanted to attend court proceedings to make sure Wang was treated fairly. But he was stonewalled by Chinese officials, and decided to cut short his trip after 10 days because of pressure from family members concerned about his safety. ``I am not so satisfied with the trip. Probably I could do a little more by continuing here,'' he said. ``But I will follow the developments from the United States and write letters to Chinese authorities to let them know people care about Wang Juntao.'' Chinese sources say Wang and a colleague, Chen Ziming, have been charged with sedition, a crime that could bring the death penalty. Wang was the editor of a now-banned economic studies weekly and Chen was the publisher. They have been accused of manipulating students who led protests last year urging democratic reforms. The Chinese army violently suppressed the pro-democracy movement in June 1989, killing hundreds of people. Thousands were arrested in a nationwide crackdown on dissent that followed. Ge said he was sent from office to office and followed by undercover security agents when he tried to get information about Wang. ``Finally, I was told the case is still under investigation,'' he said. At the Beijing Public Security Bureau, officials quizzed Ge about his background. ``They wanted to know why my friend is more important to me than my family,'' Ge said. ``I told them my family is important to me, but at least they are free.'' Ge said he asked public security officials if Wang is still alive. ``They got very upset about this,'' he said. ``They said his family members know about him and that it is not necessary to explain this to me.'' Trials in China are closed except to a few invited people who often do not include family or friends. There is a presumption that the defendant would not have been arrested unless guilty. Defense lawyers usually confine their arguments to pleas for leniency based on the defendant's lack of a criminal record or a ``good attitude.'' Sentences may be reduced if the defendant admits guilt. Ge, who is working on a doctorate in physics at Texas A&M University, said he and Wang became close friends after they met in 1982 while working at the Institute of Atomic Energy. Ge has been in the United States since 1986 and has not seen Wang for five years. He said he has not decided if he will come to China again to continue seeking justice for Wang. ``I'm going to watch the reports. I just want to make sure everything is fair,'' he said. Ge said he considered trying to discuss Wang's case with Richard Schifter, U.S. assistant secretary of state for human rights. Schifter, who met with Chinese officials today and Tuesday,k was expected to seek lenient treatment for people jailed following last year's pro-democracy movement. ``I think maybe his trip is too sensitive and I don't want to complicate things,'' Ge said.

Joanne Woodward and Robert De Niro were named best actress and best actor of the year by the New York Film Critics. De Niro was honored for his role as a patient who comes out of a trance in ``Awakenings'' and for his portrayal of a mobster in ``GoodFellas.'' Woodward plays Mrs. Bridge opposite husband Paul Newman in ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge.'' ``GoodFellas,'' about a hood who turns on his former Mafia pals, was named best movie by the group of 28 film critics working for New York-based publications. Martin Scorsese was named best director for ``GoodFellas.'' Ruth Prawer Jhabvala won for best screenplay for ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' the story of an affluent couple in the Midwest. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - ``The Tonight Show'' is heading east from beautiful downtown Burbank to the Big Apple for New Year's Eve, with comedian Jay Leno ringing in 1991 from Times Square. The live, one-time-only broadcast marks the show's first return to New York since it moved to California in 1972. The program will feature Leno as guest host, newswoman Jane Pauley, blues guitarist B.B. King and country star Dwight Yoakum. NBC said more 3,000 viewers have requested tickets for the hour-long special, which will count down the dropping of an ornamental big apple in Times Square. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Quarterback Joe Montana, who has led the San Francisco 49ers to four Super Bowl victories, was named the Sports Illustrated Sportsman of the Year for 1990. The 34-year-old Montana on Tuesday became the first National Football League player to be the sole recipient of the award, given to the athlete who symbolizes in character and performance the ideals for sportsmanship. Montana was honored because he has ``defined his sport in his era,'' said John Papanek, managing editor of the magazine. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Sean Connery says his new post-Cold War thriller, ``The Russia House,'' offers a picture of the Soviet Union rarely seen in the movies. The espionage tale based on the John Le Carre best seller dispenses with Bond-style superspy action and spins the tale of a boozy English publisher caught in a web of international intrigue. The 60-year-old actor said he hopes the film encourages younger people to learn more about the Soviet Union. ``My assistant has a 20-year-old daughter who really knows nothing about the Cold War and such. After she saw the film, she was absolutely taken with Russia. The response by most Americans who've seen the film is that they have never seen Russia presented like that,'' he said. The film was shot in the Soviet Union, with cooperation from the government. Le Carre's novel preceded the easing of the Cold War.

DOC.HEAD: ALL Nippon Airways to Buy 25 Boeing 777s and 10 Airbuses
DOC.TEXT: All Nippon Airways, Japan's second biggest airline, said today that it will order 25 Boeing-777 airliners from the United States and 10 European Airbus A-340s, a total package worth $5.6 billion. An ANA official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said contracts will be signed early next year with Boeing Co. for 15 firm orders and 10 options for delivery between 1995 and 2000. He said the planes, with 411 seats each, will be used on domestic routes. The official said ANA also will sign contracts early next year with Airbus consortium for five firm orders and five options for delivery between 1996 and 2000. The A-340 planes, with 236 seats, will be used on international routes, he said. The official said both types of plane will cost about $150 million each, and replacement engines and other related equipment could bring the value of the total package to some $5.6 billion. ANA now has a fleet of 105 aircraft, including 44 Boeing 767s, 14 Boeing 737s, 17 Boeing 747-SRs, five Boeing 747-LRs, two Boeing 747-400s, 11 Lockheed TriStars and 12 Japanese YS-11s.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo, Dollar Higher
DOC.TEXT: Tokyo share prices rose sharply today in heavy trading after a key interest rate was cut in the United States, while the dollar edged up against the Japanese yen. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 452.76 points, or 1.85 percent, closing at 24,876.78 points. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 336.11 points. Trading volume on the first section was estimated at 620 million shares, up from Tuesday's 382 million. Share prices rose in response to the U.S. Federal Reserve Board's decision Tuesday to lower its discount rate - the rate it charges for loans to banks - from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, traders said. The market had anticipated the change, but rising prices of interest rate-sensitive stocks buoyed the market anyway, traders said. ``There's a slightly stronger perception that market rates are headed down,'' said Brad Bauer, an equities sales broker for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities (Japan). The heavy volume was a good indication of investor conviction, he said. Some traders thought the market might be starting its traditional year-end rally. ``I think this year-end rally could carry us considerably higher if the yen strengthens against the dollar,'' said John Baldwin, a strategist at Jardine Fleming Securities. In currency trading, the dollar closed at 133.27 yen, up 0.24 yen from Tuesday's close of 133.03 yen. It opened at 132.70 yen and ranged between 132.63 yen and 133.43 yen. Spot trading amounted to $7.23 billion, up from Tuesday's $3.6 billion. The negative impact of the U.S. discount rate cut was countered by year-end dollar purchases, including those by hundreds of thousands of Japanese planning to travel overseas during the holidays, dealers said. ``No one wants to take a huge position before going away for Christmas,'' said a dealer at the Bank of Tokyo, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Dealers said uncertainty in the Middle East also was encouraging dollar-buying. Many investors seek the dollar as a safe haven in times of international turmoil. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 88.23 points from Tuesday's 88.18-point close. Their yield stood at 7.020 percent, down from 7.030 percent on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Prostitutes Coming Back to Mustang Ranch
DOC.TEXT: The former owner of Nevada's most notorious legal bordello says the red light is back on at the Mustang Ranch, but county commissioners aren't so sure. The Storey County Commission had planned Tuesday to debate whether to let prostitution continue at the 104-room brothel under new ownership when former owner Joe Conforte announced his permit for operating the place is still valid. ``We reopened this morning,'' Conforte told the three-member panel. ``I'm not here to ask for a license. I'm here as a common courtesy to this board to tell you how it is.'' The commission took no immediate action, deciding to seek an opinion from the state attorney general's office on Conforte's status. Sheriff Bob Del Carlo said prostitutes were moving back into the brothel on Tuesday but could not begin work again until they had been tested for sexually transmitted disease and issued health cards by his office. The Internal Revenue Service had seized the ranch from Conforte and sold it in November to recoup some $13 million in taxes owed by him and his wife. Under the new owner - Conforte's lawyer, Peter Perry - Conforte became general manager. Commission Chairman Larry Prater said he felt Conforte had lost his permit because of the sale. But Conforte said he paid the county $15,000 for a quarterly license fee two weeks ago plus a $1,500 late charge. When the IRS sold the 400-acre ranch the county lost revenues from its $60,000 annual license fee and a 2 percent tax on its rooms. Two commissioners indicated earlier this month that the county was having second thoughts about losing the money. Conforte on Tuesday offered to increase the quarterly fee to $35,000 and provide a school bus to the county. He angrily denied his offers were meant to win a favorable decision. ``It was strictly a benevolence, because I have a big heart,'' he said. Perry said because of building code deficiencies, operations would resume only at the Triangle River Ranch, a smaller building at the Mustang Ranch compound. The larger Mustang Bridge Ranch will remain closed. Perry is listed with the state as the sole officer of the ranch's new owner, Mustang Properties Inc. After padlocking the brothel, the IRS sold the Mustang Ranch's contents at auction in November.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Wins Network Race, `Cheers' the No. 1 Show
With PM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: NBC had seven of the top 10 shows in the latest ratings, with ``Cheers'' grabbing more viewers than any other TV program last week. A bag full of holiday specials failed to make the top 20, according to figures released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. Even NBC's ``Bob Hope's Christmas Special'' from Bermuda was left out in the cold. It ranked 22nd. A repeat, colorized version of CBS' ``I Love Lucy Christmas'' tied for 30th with the movie ``The Witches of Eastwick'' on ABC. NBC's Tuesday night lineup helped the network to first place with a 12.4 average rating for the week, followed by ABC with an 11.6 and CBS with 11.4. Each ratings point represents 931,000 television homes. ``In The Heat of The Night,'' ``Matlock'' and ``Law & Order'' each won their Tuesday time periods and landed in the top 20 for the first time in the 13-week-old season. CBS' ``60 Minutes'' was the No. 2 show, followed by a tie for third place between NBC's ``A Different World'' and ABC's NFL ``Monday Night Football'' match-up between the Los Angeles Raiders and the Detroit Lions. The network news victory went once again to ABC and Peter Jennings with an 11.6. CBS and Dan Rather had a 10 and NBC and Tom Brokaw a 9.9. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 22.6; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 20.6; ``A Different World,'' NBC and ``Monday Night Football,'' ABC (tie) 18.2; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 18.1; ``The Cosby Show,'' and ``In The Heat of The Night,'' NBC (tie) 17.7; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 17.5; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 17.2; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 16.9.

DOC.HEAD: 7 Killed, 44 Injured as Bus and Truck Collide in Snowstorm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to UPDATE with condition of injured truck driver; RESTORES overline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SK1
DOC.TEXT: Survivors of a crash between a bus and a tractor-trailer that killed seven people in a howling snowstorm lifted each other from the wreckage and broke open luggage for blankets and clothing to use as bandages. Forty-four people were injured in Tuesday morning's crash on an isolated, snowy stretch of Interstate 80 near the Wyoming line. Passengers said the Greyhound bus driver had only enough time to warn, ``You better hold on, folks,'' as the truck carrying frozen hams slid across the divided highway and plowed into the bus and another big rig loaded with sand. Seven of the 43 passengers on the Salt Lake City-to-Chicago bus were killed, said Highway Patrol Sgt. Gary Whitney. Passengers Stuart Palmer, 38, of Buffalo, N.Y., said riders sat helplessly as the truck knocked the bus about 35 feet down an embankment and onto its side. He said he kicked out part of the windshield and began helping those who could walk up the embankment until his own broken ankle gave out. Palmer said it was 30 to 45 minutes before emergency vehicles arrived amid icy winds and snow. He gave his coat to a badly injured passenger. ``We were breaking bags open to get out blankets and make makeshift bandages,'' he said. A witness, Blaine Whimpe of Morgan, said he saw people ``up on top of the bus pulling people out. Everybody that came out of the bus that I had seen was hurt, broken arms, legs.'' Forty-one people, some injured in chain-reaction accidents after the initial crash, were taken to Evanston Regional Hospital in Wyoming. Fourteen were admitted, most with broken bones, and one was listed in critical condition today. Three people with head injuries were flown to hospitals in Salt Lake City and were listed in critical condition. Authorities searched passengers' luggage to identify the victims. The National Transportation Safety Board and National Highway Safety Board said they would investigate the cause of the crash. The temperature at the time was 22 degrees. The National Weather Service said the wind was gusting to 29 mph at Evanston, Wyo., about 10 miles away. The truck carrying the hams was owned by Wanship Enterprises of Salt Lake City. Wanship's owner, Mike Peery, said the driver, Robert Williams, 46, of Salt Lake, said he wasn't sure how the accident occurred. But he said Williams might have been trying to avoid another vehicle when he lost control of his truck. Williams was reported in fair condition at Evanston Regional Hospital today. The driver of the other truck and the bus, who were not identified, were not seriously hurt.

DOC.HEAD: Two Studies Look at Cholesterol in Women, Children
DOC.TEXT: Children with dangerously high cholesterol won't necessarily have the problem later in life, scientists reported today in a study they said casts doubt on the need for cholesterol screening of all youngsters. The authors of the study in the Journal of the American Medical Association said univeral cholesterol screening for children would be expensive and would fail to pinpoint which adults will continue to show high cholesterol levels. In another study in today's journal, researchers said that cholesterol-reducing drugs that help unclog men's coronary arteries and reduce their risk of heart attack do the same for women as well. Previous studies excluded women because men run a far higher risk of coronary problems at earlier ages. Cholesterol kills by clogging the blood vessels with lesions, a combination of fatty deposits and scar tissue. ``There are lots of other risk factors besides cholesterol. But one of the most important risk factors is high cholesterol, and reversal of atherosclerosis can reduce the chances of a heart attack,'' Dr. Mary Malloy, co-author of the study, said in a telephone interview Tuesday. The study loked at 41 women and 31 men with atherosclerosis over several years. Subjects took bile acid-binding resin and niacin daily, which along with dietary changes reduced their cholesterol levels an average of 38.1 percent. After 26 months, coronary artery lesions shrank more than 2 percent among 22 women enrolled in the treatment. The 19 other women, whose cholesterol levels were reduced an average of 10.6 percent through diet changes and less-intensive drug treatments, showed an average increase of slightly more than 1 percent in coronary artery lesions. The treatment's effect on men in the study showed the same trends, but did not result in a statistically significant difference among men, the study concluded. Dr. David Blankenhorn of the University of Southern California, who was not involved in the study, said doctors are less likely to prescribe cholesterol-reducing medicines for women because the evidence on their effectiveness wasn't in. In the other study, the cholesterol levels of 2,367 children between the ages of 8 and 18 in Muscatine, Iowa, were examined, and their cholesterol levels were again measured between the ages of 20 and 30. Seventy-five percent of the females and 56 percent of the males with high cholesterol as children were under the levels described as dangerous by the National Cholesterol Education Program when tested as adults, the study found. ``Childhood cholesterol levels are a poor predictor of high cholesterol levels in young adulthood and will be an even poorer predictor of coronary heart disease later in life,'' said the study's authors, William R. Clarke and Dr. Ronald Lauer of the University of Iowa.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Reporter Says There's No Conflict in Joining McDonald's Board
DOC.TEXT: A columnist and TV commentator who reports on financial news says there is no ethical conflict between her work and her appointment to the McDonald's Corp. board of directors. ``This won't be a problem,'' said Terry Savage, who writes a weekly financial news column for the Chicago Sun-Times and Dallas Times Herald and who appears regularly on Chicago station WBBM, which is owned by CBS. Savage, 46, the first woman named to the company's board in 20 years, will receive $24,000 a year from McDonald's plus $2,000 for each board meeting attended. Officials at the newspapers and TV station said Savage promised to stay away from any issues that could be construed as conflicting with her role on the McDonald's board. ``We will make sure she does not write about the food industry, and McDonald's in particular,'' said Times Herald Business Editor Jim Frisinger. But George Harmon, who teaches business writing at Northwestern University's graduate school of journalism, said it would be hard to avoid the apperance of a conflict because McDonald's influences so much of the business world. He said Savage could be restricted from reporting on the beef, potato and recycling industries and even the stock market because McDonald's is among the 30 companies whose performances are reflected in the Dow Jones industrials average. ``If somebody wanted to restrict Terry from reporting on McDonald's and be very strict about that, it would restrain her considerably,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Court Punishes 79 Soldiers for Coup Participation
DOC.TEXT: A military court today convicted and sentenced 79 soldiers to prison terms ranging up to 32 years for their participation in a 1987 attempt to overthrow President Corazon Aquino. Twenty others - 11 officers and nine enlisted men - were acquitted of mutiny and murder charges in a court hearing that began Tuesday afternoon and lasted until 4 a.m. today and ended a three-year trial. Of the officers charged, Army Capt. Redempto Taisa, formerly of the 62nd Army Infantry Battalion in central Luzon, and eight enlisted personnel received the stiffest penalties. They were sentenced to 12 years for mutiny and 20 years for murder and attempted murder for reinforcing rebel troops that attacked the presidential palace on Aug. 28, 1987. Thirty-one other officers and six enlisted personnel were sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment at hard labor. Thirty-three enlisted personnel received 20-year sentences. The maximum sentence for each charge was 20 years. There is no death penalty in the Philippines. Col. Ananiano Disierto, the military's chief prosecutor, said 81 witnesses and hundreds of photographs and other exhibits were presented against the accused during the trial. Wives and children of the accused soldiers burst into tears as the sentences were read by Brig. Gen. Raul Imperial, head of the seven-man general court martial. Some of those convicted wept while those who were cleared of charges clapped and shook hands with each other. They later offered Christian songs and prayers. ``I have prepared my mind to expect for the worst - even the death sentence if that's the worst penalty that would be given to me,'' said Lt. Col. Jose Reynaldo Ochosa, 41, before the sentence was read. Ochosa said he joined renegade soldiers not to topple Mrs. Aquino's government but to show his protest against how she was mismanaging the government. The rebellion, the fifth armed attempt to oust Mrs. Aquino, left at least 53 people dead and about 300 others wounded, including Mrs. Aquino's only son, Benigno III. Mrs. Aquino has survived two other coup attempts since.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT silver closing on Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against major foreign currencies today in calm, early European trading. Gold prices were also lower. Dealers said trading was settling down from Tuesday's tumble after the U.S. Federal Reserve announced a drop in discount rates from 7 percent to 6.5 percent. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.24 yen to a closing 133.27 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 133.95 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: -1.4775 German marks, down from 1.4840 -1.2655 Swiss francs, down from 1.2695 -5.0415 French francs, down from 5.0550 -1.6647 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6735 -1,118.50 Italian lire, down from 1,121.25 -1.1560 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1563 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9345, compared with $1.9350 late Tuesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $376.65 per ounce at midmorning, from $377.50 bid per ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $376.45, down from $377.20 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 16 cents to close at a bid $377.47. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $3.97 a troy ounce unchanged from Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Visit Auto Parts Store to See Image of Virgin Mary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT name to Trevino sted Maldonado.
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 people a day are flocking to the back of an auto parts store, past the spark plugs and fan belts, to see what many believe is an image of the Virgin Mary on the bathroom floor. Each day as the multitudes arrive at Progreso Auto Supply in this tiny Mexican border town, owner Reynaldo Trevino directs them to the spot in the concrete of the shower stall, next to a toilet, where thousands say they have seen the image of the mother of Christ. ``She's so beautiful, so beautiful,'' 14-year-old Bonnie Maldonado said Tuesday as tears streamed down her face. The foot-wide image is in varying shades of gray that Trevino said used to be one shade. He said he first noticed it on Dec. 3. ``I asked her, `Why on the floor? Why the bathroom?''' Trevino said. The 45-year-old Roman Catholic said something within his heart told him to spread the message that the Virgin Mary's presence on the floor symbolized the way many neglect their faith. ``So I started telling every customer who came in,'' he said. ``Before I sold them a part, I took them back.'' Officials at the Roman Catholic Archdiocese in Brownsville have declined to comment on the image. What could be interpreted as facial features are vaguely discernible in the markings. Others have said they see even more, including an earring, flowers and an angel to the side. As word of the site has spread through the Lower Rio Grande Valley, more than 1,000 people a day have flocked to the store. Most come only to see the image, and Trevino said his auto parts business has suffered. But he said he welcomes them all, asking only that they leave no money or other offerings. ``I don't want this to be commercialized or anything,'' he said. He also discourages the taking of photographs. ``I want them to take the image home with them in their hearts,'' he said. Many of those who come to the store kneel to pray. Some make the sign of the cross or touch the image. Ernestina Maldonado, 41, who lives in nearby Weslaco, said seeing the image filled her with pain. ``We are in a very troubled world right now,'' she said. ``Maybe it's a sign for people to think about it and repent because it's getting real ugly in the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Menuhin, Berio To Be Honored for Music Achievements
DOC.TEXT: Violinist Yehudi Menuhin and composer-conductor Luciano Berio were named today as winners of Wolf Prizes in the arts for 1991. The awards, which carry $100,000 grants, are to be presented in May at the Israeli Knesset, or parliament. Prizes also will be awarded for chemistry, medicine, physics, agriculture and mathematics. The selection committee said the musicians were chosen ``for bringing peoples together through their musical achievements.'' Menuhin, 74, who was born in New York City and now lives in London, was a prodigy violinist, making his debut at age 7 in San Francisco. In addition to solo performances around the world, Menuhin has founded his own chamber orchestra, directs the Gstaad Festival in Switzerland, established a school for gifted musicians in Surrey, England, and is president of the Trinity College of Music. The Wolf Foundation selection committee described him as ``one of the greatest violinists of the 20th century'' and said: ``His unforgettable interpretations and humanitarian activities contributed significantly to bringing nations together through musical education, enlightening peoples and elevating cultural levels throughout the world.'' He has been particularly active in promoting musical exchange programs with the Soviet Union and India. Berio, 65, of Siena, Italy, was born to a family of musicians and first studied music with his father and grandfather. He composes, conducts, teaches and lectures. Berio is particularly noted for innovations in electronic music. He founded the Studio di Fonologia Musicale at the Italian Radio in Milan and has been associated with numerous training centers, including Darmstadt in Germany and Juilliard in New York. ``He is one of the greatest composers of our generation whose new ideas, in an age of devaluation of human values, help to unify nations, cultures and generations,'' the selection committee said. The prizes, which are given annually, are named for the late Dr. Ricardo Wolf. Established in 1975, they are intended ``to promote science and art for the benefit of mankind.'' Wolf was a German-born inventor and philanthropist who emigrated to Cuba and later served as its ambassador to Israel. He died in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Hit By Arctic Blast, Southeast Gets Rain Showers
DOC.TEXT: The Northwest endured blizzardlike conditions and bitter cold today, rain fell in the East, and scattered snow flurries dusted the western Great Lakes. Fair skies prevailed over much of the nation's midsection, with some rain forecast for Southern California, the South and the Eastern Seaboard. Daytime highs were expected to range from the 80s in southern Texas to zero and below in North Dakota. A rare heavy snowfall blanketed downtown Seattle, where the elevation is 125 feet. Winds topping 60 mph downed power lines and snow drifts forced the closure of most schools. Snow and icy temperatures also hit Oregon, Utah, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, parts of Nevada and Northern California, and the Dakotas. Wind chill indexes dropped the mercury to about 50 below zero in the Pacific Northwest and to 70 below in the Montana and the northern Plains. Elsewhere Tuesday, mid-December heat set Dec. 18 records in many cities. Bluefield, W.Va., hit 69 degrees, topping a high of 59 set in 1967. Bristol Tenn. reached 73 degrees, beating the old mark of 65 set in 1949. Huntsville, Ala., peaked at 73, beating a 1984 record by two degrees. Roanoke, Va., set a record by a degree with a high of 68, edging a 1984 mark and Wilmington, Del., broke a record from the same year by two degrees with a high of 66. Cape Hatteras, N.C., 72, Jacksonville, Fla., 81, and Philadelphia, 64, all tied old marks. The nation's high Tuesday was 86 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Burmese Dissidents Declare Parallel Government
DOC.TEXT: Burmese dissidents who were elected seven months ago but kept from power by their country's military rulers have announced the formation of a rival government. Headed by Sein Win, the cousin of Burma's detained opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, the group on Tuesday announced an eight-member Cabinet at Manerplaw, headquarters of ethnic Karen insurgents near the Thai border. All eight men won parliamentary seats in the May 27 general election. Ms. Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy won the election by a landslide the government has refused to accept. Western diplomats have said it was unlikely any country would recognize the parallel government. And a powerful member of Burma's military government said in a newspaper interview published Tuesday that forming a rival government ``would be a great mistake.'' Sein Win was named prime minister of the ``National Coalition Government of the Union of Burma.'' He said in a speech that forming the body ``was the only option for us to choose because this military junta has no will and no way to transfer power to the people.'' ``Burma has become a country shrouded by darkness because of all the unlawful arrests, tortures and persecutions and human rights violations,'' a declaration issued by the new government said. Copies were made available in Bangkok today. The declaration said the government stood for the immediate elimination of the military government, the calling of a national convention including members of the Parliament and insurgent groups, and the establishment of a ``genuine democratic government'' to create ``an independent, prosperous and modernized Federal Union of Burma.'' It named eight people to a Cabinet: Sein Win, Peter Lin Pin, Win Ko, Than Kywe, Hla Pe, Thein Oo, Hla Tint and Tun Oo. Sein Win is a member of the National Democracy Party, while Peter Lin Pin was an independent candidate in the election. The others are members of the National League for Democracy. All fled the threat of arrest in Burma after their plans to form a rival government became known. The Democratic Alliance of Burma, an umbrella organization of 21 ethnic and other rebel groups fighting the central government, backed the declaration. The Karen are members of the alliance, which has its headquarters in Manerplaw, located along the frontier with Thailand, 120 miles northeast of Rangoon. The military took power by force in Burma in 1988. Soldiers killed thousands of people who joined in a nationwide movement for democracy that year. The government has since detained most leading members of the opposition. These include Ms. Suu Kyi, who was put under house arrest in July 1989. Amnesty International and other human rights groups have cited numerous reports of torture of dissidents by military agencies.

DOC.HEAD: When Does a Calf Become a Cow at Issue in Meat Fraud Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0499 to fix overline.
DOC.TEXT: When does calf liver become beef liver? That question will be raised in the trial of a meat-processing company and four officials charged with conspiring to mislabel meat, defense lawyer James Martin Davis said. The defense plans to show that even among livestock and meat processing experts there is no agreement as to what a calf is, Davis said Tuesday. ``In federal law and U.S. Department of Agriculture rules and regulations, there is no definition of what is a calf,'' Davis said. A federal grand jury indicted VMI Corp. and four officials Nov. 14 on a charge that they conspired to switch labels on 11.6 million pounds of beef liver to more expensive calf liver. The company's president, board chairman, comptroller and plant manager pleaded innocent Tuesday before U.S. Magistrate Richard Kopf.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Upholds Dead Candidate's Election
DOC.TEXT: The Oklahoma Supreme Court upheld the landslide election of a dead judge against a living candidate, saying the results must be interpreted as a vote against the loser. Incumbent Frank M. Ogden III, who died Aug. 11, won 91 percent of the vote cast Nov. 6 in a race against Josh L. Evans, who had challenged the results. ``It is beyond question that the will of the electorate was to cast votes for Judge Ogden and against candidate Evans,'' the Supreme Court said Tuesday. The result leaves the job open for an appointee of the governor. Evans, 74, ran a campaign for the Oklahoma Panhandle judgeship that described him as an able lawyer and a living person. The court said Evans should have filed his challenge to the dead man's candidacy before the election.

DOC.HEAD: President Denies Racism in U.S. Troop Makeup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for 8th graf pvs, Bush also, to include Bush comments on cutting capital gains tax rate.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: President Bush disputes the notion that ``there's some kind of racism'' involved in the makeup of the U.S. military force in the Persian Gulf. ``I don't think this concept that this is a discriminatory army, or an army that is discriminating and thus sending more blacks to the fate, or minorities, Hispanics or something, is proper,'' Bush told a group of regional reporters Tuesday. He was replying to a question that suggested a disproportionate number of the troops he has sent to the Middle East are from minority or working-class groups. ``This is an all-volunteer army. They're not draft-dodging,'' the president said. The situation was different during the Vietnam war, Bush said. ``The kid that got disproportionately there was the guy that couldn't get the (draft) exemption and came out of kind of the lower rungs of society,'' he said. ``This is different.'' Critics say that although the draft was abolished 17 years ago, the volunteer armed forces are composed disproportionately of minorities and the poor who join because they see the military as a way to get the education and job that they might not otherwise attain. On another matter, Bush said he still would like to see the capital gains tax rate reduced, but indicated he was wary of reopening the tax battle with Democrats in Congress. ``I'm a little worried, I'll be honest with you, having laid this tax question down for a while, to reopen many, many aspects of it,'' he said. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said in an interview he was recommending against trying again for such a tax cut next year because he believes it would result in a fight with Congress that the administration could not win, the New York Times reported today. On the gulf crisis, Bush reiterated his position that if war breaks out, ``it is not going to be another Vietnam.'' ``The agony of Vietnam is still with us. People remember a protracted war.
