They remember a war where individuals were asked to fight with one hand tied behind their back, in essence,'' he said. ``This will not be, in my view, that kind of confrontation.'' Bush said he still wants a peaceful solution but doubts that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein believes the United States and its allies are ready to go to war over Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The public would not support ``a long, drawn-out conflagration. I think support would erode as it did in the Vietnam conflict,'' Bush said. Asked why none of his Cabinet members had children serving in Saudi Arabia, he said, ``I just don't know where their kids are.'' The president called the armed forces ``the finest kids, the best trained, the best motivated, the high achievers, not the low achievers. And so this argument that there's some kind of racism ... in this deployment, I reject it out of - the whole cloth.'' Vice President Dan Quayle, meanwhile, told a Washington foreign policy conference Tuesday it's far from certain that the talks Bush offered to hold with Iraq will occur. Quayle accused Iraq of an ``attempt to manipulate'' the process by insisting on meeting dates the United States opposes. Quayle, who had considered a Christmastime trip to the gulf to visit the troops has decided against it for logistical reasons, among them the uncertainty of the timing of Secretary of State James A. Baker III's proposed visit to Baghdad to meet Saddam. Quayle plans to go later time, an official said. On another matter at his news conference, Bush denied his administration had flip-flopped on scholarships reserved for minorities, but he said such aid ``should be beyond challenge'' if it is privately financed. Still, he predicted a possible court challenge to minority-targeted scholarships, and said he would be open to legislation to ``correct it fairly.'' The policy, announced earlier Tuesday by the Education Department's civil rights chief, bars federal funding of minority-only scholarships, but allows aid from other sources to be earmarked for minorities. It was a partial reversal of a more sweeping ban announced last week that caught top White House officials unaware.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Probe Fraud Allegations in Sale of Ex-Beatle's Birth Certificate
DOC.TEXT: State and local officials confirmed they are investigating whether the $18,000 auction sale of ex-Beatle Paul McCartney's birth certificate was faked to inflate the document's value. Officials of the state Licensing and Regulation Department and the Harris County district attorney's office said Tuesday the allegations made by the auction's promoter, Cheryl Bean, could lead to charges of deceptive business practices. Elvis Schulze, general counsel for the state Licensing and Regulation Department, said his agency investigates every consumer complaint. The birth certificate - the legitimacy of which has not been questioned - was put up for sale last month by Marshall Terrell, who bought it from McCartney's stepmother, Angela Williams, according to a bill of sale provided by Ms. Bean. McCartney was not involved in the sale. Ms. Bean accused Terrell, buyer Brian Taylor, auctioneer Ray Simpson and Phoebe Moody, who took the certificate to Simpson on Terrell's behalf, of faking the sale. ``Now when Marshall and them want to sell it, they can say, `Well, gee, it sold for $18,000 in Houston,' and get a lot more for it later,'' she said. ``And Ray Simpson got free publicity, worldwide publicity, and that's worth a lot of money.'' Simpson said the sale was legitimate. ``I'm not aware of any problem,'' he said. ``The sale went fine. Everything's taken care of. As far as we're concerned, it's a closed deal.'' He declined to say if Taylor had paid for the certificate. Taylor, 26, a student at Virginia Commonwealth University, was asked by reporters after the sale where he got the money for the purchase. He joked that he ``had a paper route as a kid.'' Attempts to reach Ms. Moody, Taylor and Terrell were unsuccessful. Ms. Moody did not return phone calls to her office Tuesday. A student affairs officer at Virginia Commonwealth University said Taylor's phone was disconnected and he had asked that no forwarding information be released. Terrell, who lives in Alexandria, Va., has an unlisted phone number.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Human Rights Envoy Says Chinese Visit Opened New Dialogue
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. human rights envoy said today he appealed to Chinese officials to release political prisoners, and U.S. Embassy officials said China's attitude toward human rights was changing. Richard Schifter, assistant secretary of state for human rights and humanitarian affairs, said the Chinese made no promises but indicated willingness to continue talking about human rights issues. He submitted a list of 150 prisoners' names for future discussion, he said. ``We had worthwhile exchanges,'' Schifter told a news conference. ``There was no ... argument.'' The U.S. Embassy said Schifter's two days of meetings with officials from the courts, police ministry and other departments represented a major advance. China traditionally has insisted that how it treat dissidents is an internal affair. Schifter's visit marked the first time China agreed to discuss human rights issues in such detail with an American official. In addition to political prisoners, topics included China's policy toward religious believers and its policy of discouraging families from having more than one child. ``Attitudinally you've got a sea change,'' said Ambassador James Lilley. ``Whether this ends up in concrete results remains to be seen.'' Schifter said the Chinese told him the cases of students and intellectuals jailed after last year's pro-democracy movement were not ready for trial yet. The relatives of about a dozen such prisoners have received formal arrest notices setting forth charges in recent weeks, but Chinese officials say no trials have started. Schifter said he asked that the U.S. Embassy be notified when the trials start and be allowed to send an observer if proceedings are open. He said the list of 150 prisoners he submitted included people jailed for their roles in the 1989 democracy movement, which was crushed on June 3-4, 1989, when the Chinese army opened fire on protesters in Beijing. ``I made the point that ... I hope after they review the names to engage in case-by-case discussions,'' he said. ``They didn't say no.'' Schifter did not release the list, but said it also included people jailed in past democracy movements, Tibetan independence activists and people jailed for their religious beliefs. He confirmed it included Wei Jingsheng, who is serving a 15-year jail term for advocating a multiparty system during the 1978-79 Democracy Wall movement. Schifter said he made no threats but told the Chinese that the U.S. Congress may revive legislation to deny China preferential trade status if it does not improve its human rights record. ``I cannot predict what they are going to be doing,'' he said. ``We hope for the best.'' He said the U.S. Embassy in Beijing plans follow-up discussions. Kent Wiedemann, director of the State Department's Office of Chinese and Mongolian Affairs, said all the Chinese officials Schifter met ``agreed to continue contact on the issues we raised.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Ministry Urges Iraqis To Store Oil And Petroleum Products
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Oil Ministry today urged Iraqis to stockpile gas and fuel oil during the winter to avoid shortages if war breaks out. The announcement acknowledged oil refineries would be prime targets of air attacks if a U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf goes to war with Baghdad. The U.N. Security Council has authorized the use of military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait if it does not withdraw voluntarily by Jan. 15. The announcement, published by the government's Al-Jumhuriya daily newspaper, said the ministry will provide fuel oil, kerosene, cooking gas, gasoline and diesel so that purchases can be made. ``We hope that all citizens will buy their needs so they may overcome any shortages that might result from an aggression on our oil installations,'' it said. After Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the U.N. Security Council imposed a trade embago that halted Iraq's oil exports. Since then, Iraq has shut down an estimated 75 percent of its oil fields, and production has plummeted from 3.1 million barrels of oil a day to 400,000. Current production is solely for domestic needs. In October, Oil Minister Issam al-Chalabi announced gasoline rationing, citing the refining problems. But the ruling Revolutionary Command Council headed by President Saddam Hussein i Lanka is controlled partially by the Tigers and government forces. Today's attack came a day after a land mine planted by the guerrillas exploded under an army jeep and killed Brig. Lakshmana Wijeratne, the commander of security forces in the eastern Trincomalee district. Wijeratne, 46, a police superintendent and six soldiers were killed in the blast near Panmedawachchiya village in Trincomalee district, 150 miles northeast of Colombo. Wijeratne was the most senior military officer killed so far by the Tamil Tigers in their 7{-year-old secessionist movement. A colonel was killed in 1985, also in a mine blast. More than 14,000 people have been killed since separatists among Tamils started the campaign in 1983, claiming the ethnic minority Tamils were discriminated in jobs and education by the Sinhalese. Tamils form 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Sinhalese, who account for 75 percent, dominate the government and the military.

DOC.HEAD: Trials of Anti-Government Protesters Reportedly Begin
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 200 people accused of rioting in Albania as the nation's pro-democracy movement came to life last week have been placed on trial for vandalism and other charges, a report said today. The anti-government riots occurred in four Albanian cities, prompting both the hard-line Communist government and a newly formed pro-democracy political party to call for an end to the unrest. The Yugoslav news agency Tanjug, citing Albanian radio reports late Tuesday, said 62 people were being tried in the coastal city of Durres, 55 in Elbasan, and 60 in Shkodra. The agency was monitored in Vienna. Thousands of angry protesters burned and ransacked stores and other buildings in Shkodra, Durres, nearby Kavaje and the central city of Elbasan on Thursday and Friday. They demanded political change following last year's revolutions that toppled one-party Communist governments across eastern Europe. Those changes left Albania isolated as the last hard-line Communist holdout on the continent. Tanjug said the defendants were accused of ``acts against property, lives and health, improper conduct, attacks on the organs of (Communist) authority, illegal rallying'' and other offenses. ``Radio Tirana said that the accused admit responsibility, repent, and claim that they should have acted through dialogue, as defined by Albanian law,'' the dispatch said. ``Radio Tirana claims that lawyers and defendants are present at the trials and that the defendants are guaranteed the right of appeal.'' The Tanjug report gave no other details. Albania decreed independent political organizations legal following the riots, and Gramoz Pashko, a leader of the new Democratic Party of Albania, the nation's first non-Communist Party, said Tuesday his group applied for registration. Outlining the decree on political parties today, the state ATA news agency said it ``recognizes the right of the citizens to form political and social organizations,'' subject to approval by the Justice Ministry. The decree approved by the Presidium of the People's Assembly, or parliament, prohibits parties with ``fascist, racist, warmongering, anti-national character or that instigate national hatred,'' said ATA, monitored in Vienna. A political program issued by Pashko's party declared that the party's goal was creation of a democratic and pluralistic society with a market economy instead of central planning, according to the HINA news agency of the Yugoslavian republic of Croatia, reporting from Tirana.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Agrees To Stop Selling `Steve The Tramp' Dolls
DOC.TEXT: Bowing to pressure from advocates for the homeless, the Walt Disney Co. has decided to stop selling an toy figure of a tramp. The Rev. Christopher Rose, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, inspired the protests early this month when he cited ``Steve the Tramp'' as one of the most offensive toys of the 1990 Chrstmas season. ``I'm glad somebody there got a conscience,'' Rose said Tuesday when he learned of Disney's action. ``But I feel it is a hollow victory because it is only a week before Christmas.'' The 5-inch-high plastic figure is one of a series of 14 ``coppers and gangsters'' based on the movie ``Dick Tracy,'' which was produced by Disney-owned Touchstone Pictures. The tramp is described on the package as ``hardened and bitter after a life on the mean streets ... a lout who would just as soon take your life as your wallet ... (and) will use and abuse any young, helpless prey he comes across.'' ``We feel that the action figure, when viewed outside the fantasy world of `Dick Tracy,' is being misunderstood,'' said a statement released by the Walt Disney Co. in Burbank, Calif., Monday evening. Joining in the statement were Playmates Toys Inc. of La Mirada, Calif., which is licensed by Disney to manufacture and market the toy, and the National Coalition for the Homeless, based in New York City. ``Playmates has decided to discontinue production and distribution of the doll. Disney has removed the figure from shelves at its chain of retail stores and theme parks,'' the statement said. However, Disney spokesman Chuck Champlin acknowledged Tuesday that it was too late to recall the toy from other retailers a week before Christmas. Some chains discontinued sale of the tramp doll after advocates for the homeless protested and picketed stores. Rose brought the figure to the attention of advocates for the homeless in his annual ``Warped Toys for Christmas'' display at his church Dec. 2. A nationwide chain of 1,200 stores, Kay Bee Toy and Hobby, pulled the figure from its shelves Dec. 7 after activists picketed its stores in the Stamford Town Center. Marvin Minkler, an organizer of the Stamford protest, said Playmates Toys has donated more than 800 toys to his organization, Gateway Communities Homeless Outreach, to give to poor children. A Disney representative also promised to meet with Gateway in January to see how they might collaborate on a program to help homeless people, Minkler said. ``As you see, in the end we agree the product is indefensible,'' said Champlin, who two weeks ago released a statement defending sale of the figure. Michael Stoops, assistant director of the National Coalition for the Homeless, said: ``We appreciate the responsiveness of both the Walt Disney Co. and Playmates Toys in withdrawing the Steve the Tramp doll from store shelves and ending production and distribution.'' Rose said his Steve the Tramp figure is joining other offensive toys, which he has been collecting for four years, in a church storeroom. Someday, Rose said, he hopes to open a museum of tasteless toys ``as a sad commentary on late 20th-century culture.''

DOC.HEAD: Presley Guitar And Hendrix Lyrics Sold At Auction
DOC.TEXT: The Rock 'n' Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland purchased a handwritten copy of the rock anthem ``Purple Haze'' by Jimi Hendrix for $17,600 at an auction, Sotheby's said. The sale of entertainment and rock 'n' roll memorabilia brought $176,000 for a collection of handwritten lyrics, essays, song notes and personal belongings of Hendrix, and $24,000 for Elvis Presley's acoustic guitar. Only four out of the 60 Hendrix lots failed to sell at the Sotheby auction on Monday. The collection was consigned by an anonymous collector, said Laura Stewart, a Sotheby's spokeswoman. The 1966 draft in black ball-point pen on yellow-lined notepaper is the earliest known to exist of ``Purple Haze,'' which appeared on Hendrix's debut album ``Are You Experienced'' in 1967. The lyrics were valued at $8,000 to $12,000. An anonymous buyer placed the winning bid for the Presley guitar. The acoustic guitar finished in black from the 1970s was sold by an anonymous consignor, Stewart said. The total for Monday's sale was $293,269, according to the auction house.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Will Visit Troops in Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds last 4 grafs background.
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will visit the U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia Dec. 29 to Jan. 2, and meet with King Fahd, he said today. Quayle will pay visits to all four branches of the U.S. military sent by President Bush to withstand Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's military machine, said Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith. He said the purpose of the trip would be to consult with the Saudis and build the morale of U.S. troops, who received a Thanksgiving visit from President Bush. Quayle met this morning with Prince Bandar, the Saudi ambassador, to discuss details of his trip. ``I'm looking forward to it,'' Quayle said during a photo session. Bandar, answering a reporter's question, said his country would find unacceptable any solution to the crisis that allows Iraq to keep any island off Kuwait, which some have suggested as a possible way to end the occupation. Quayle had considered a Christmas visit to the gulf, but that was nixed for logistical reasons, aides said. Quayle will be back home well before the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for Iraq to pull its occupying troops out of Kuwait. Bandar said the king is looking forward to meeting Quayle and thanking him for the U.S. military support.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Marcos Open to Negotiations on Other Marcos Hidden Wealth
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos has indicated she wants an out-of-court settlement to lawsuits seeking the return of billions of dollars in allegedly embezzled government funds, an official said today. The government claims Mrs. Marcos, her late husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos, and their associates stole up to $10 billion until a popular revolt toppled his 20-year rule in 1986. David Castro, chairman of the Presidential Commission on Good Government, said Mrs. Marcos told him she wanted to settle the suits out of court, despite a breakdown last week in talks to settle a suit filed against her in Los Angeles. Castro said he met with Mrs. Marcos in Los Angeles on Dec. 11 and told her the government was aware of Marcos-held assets in at least 10 countries that were not included in the suits already filed against her in the Philippines and the United States. Castro said he mentioned one Swiss bank account the government believes belonged to Marcos that ``could be the biggest thing that we could get our hands on.'' He refused to give details of the account. He said Mrs. Marcos claimed not to know about the account, and he said he had reason to believe her. He did not elaborate. Castro said the meeting ended ``on a very good note'' and Mrs. Marcos gave him her private telephone number. The meeting was held one day after a court hearing on a motion to dismiss civil suits against Mrs. Marcos in Los Angeles. President Corazon Aquino's government filed the suits claiming $50 million in Marcos properties and $5 billion in damages. On Monday, the government said it was breaking off talks on an out-of-court settlement of the California lawsuit against Mrs. Marcos because of bad faith on her part. Castro said that under a tentative settlement, the government would have received 60 percent of the assets held by Marcos trustees in five Hong Kong banks. Castro said that if the government recovered at least $200 million from the banks, it would drop the California suits. But he said the negotiations halted after Mrs. Marcos' lawyers insisted on seeking the dismissal of the California cases, claiming they had reached an agreement with the government to drop them. Castro said the move was ``a dirty trick.'' The court has not ruled on the dismissal motion.

DOC.HEAD: Drug-Sniffing Dog Attacks Fifth-Grader
DOC.TEXT: A dog trained to help police find drugs attacked a fifth-grade girl during a demonstration in her classroom, and the youngster required nearly 50 stitches. The Labrador retriever, named Bruiser, was taken to school Tuesday as part of the Police Department's Drug Awareness Resistance Education program, said Joan Vice, a teacher at Hattie C. Warner Elementary School. The dog's trainer hid a packet of simulated marijuana, used to train dogs, while 20 children were sitting on the classroom floor, Vice said. Bruiser found the packet and the trainer threw it so Bruiser could play with it to reinforce his behavior, Vice said. ``At this point he had taken the dog off the leash,'' she said. ``So the dog ran toward the front of the room where the children were and nudged and messed around with the packet. And then for no reason, absolutely no provocation, turned on this child.'' Ten-year-old Geri Cobb was taken to Humana Hospital-Lexington. She received 35 stitches for severe bites to the back of her head and 14 stitches to her right hand and arm and was released. There was no comment from Bruiser's trainer, policeman Dallas Murphy; he has an unlisted telephone number and was off duty until later today, a dispatcher said. Bruiser has successfully aided police in drug searches for six months, said Maj. Robert Sallee, assistant chief of operations. The dog ``showed no signs of being aggressive before,'' Sallee said. ``It's strictly a drug-search dog, passively trained.'' Sallee said the dog has had rabies shots and other recommended vaccinations and has been examined by a veterinarian. The dog is being kept in a kennel under quarantine during the investigation, Sallee said. Richard Williams, the school's principal, said school officials would review their policy allowing demonstrations involving animals. ``We're going to discuss and see if there is any way that we can prevent any of this kind of thing from occurring again, of course,'' Williams said. ``If they can't control their dogs they don't need to have them in the classroom,'' said Geri's mother, Donna Cobb.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Reveals Potential $1 Billion Deficit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Philadelphia-o Layoffs, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania's state government is facing a potential deficit approaching $1 billion that could lead to the layoff of state workers and cuts in welfare and other programs, officials said. State Budget Secretary Michael Hershock said Tuesday ``every indication'' showed the state's economy had stopped growing and was expected to be in a recession through March. The disclosure of the looming $959 million deficit marked the first time the administration has acknowledged the magnitude of the state's financial problems. Only last month Gov. Robert P. Casey's campaign commercials described the state as ``the rising new star of America'' where the economy was flourishing. Hershock said the state would take a wide array of cost-cutting steps aimed at balancing the budget by June 30, the end of the fiscal year. He said it was too soon to say if a tax increase would be needed. Taxes ``will be the last resort,'' Hershock said, echoing previous statements by Casey. Pennsylvania is not the only state facing a budget deficit because of the rising cost of services, falling tax revenues and slowing consumer spending. At least 30 states face deficits, ranging from $42 million in Tennessee to $1 billion in New York, according to recent studies by the National Association of State Budget Officers and The Boston Globe. Hershock said the state was caught in a bind between a weakening national economy and an increase in the need for welfare programs. Earlier this month, the Public Welfare Department disclosed it was facing a $440 million cash shortfall. Last week, Casey directed state departments to slash maintenance and other operating expenses by 6 percent and ordered continued controls on hiring and purchases. Hershock said a series of task forces would look at additional ways to trim spending and raise revenue, such as selling surplus land and increasing state fees. The state will also consider curtailing some programs that are optional under federal rules, Hershock said. Among them are dental, podiatric and drug-and-alcohol abuse programs for welfare recipients. Layoffs for state workers are also being reviewed.

DOC.HEAD: Group Claims Responsibility for Attack on Greek EC Offices
DOC.TEXT: The November 17 terrorist group today claimed responsibility for a weekend missile attack that gutted the offices of the European Community in Athens and wounded two people. In a statement published by the newspaper Eleftherotypia, the group said it launched two anti-tank missiles at the offices Sunday to protest Community loan guidelines. It also said it would attack Saudi Arabian interests if ARAMCO went through with a reported offer to buy a 50 percent stake in Greece's two state-controlled refineries. The EC has told Greece's New Democracy government it must take tougher measures to reduce a 1991 budget deficit of $13.8 billion in order to receive a $2.78 billion loan. The government has taken a series of austerity measures, but has been criticized for failing to adequately reduce spending. ``The EC directorate is today forcing harsh terms and a policy of tough austerity on the people through their New Democracy slaves,'' November 17 said in the statement, which the newspaper said it found in a garbage can after an anonymous phone call. November 17 is opposed to Greece's membership in the EC and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and to the U.S. military presence in Greece. The attack came one day before Parliament approved a new anti-terrorist law and began debate on the 1991 budget. The new law, which will go into effect in about two weeks, will give police wider powers to investigate suspects and will bar media from publicizing terrorist statements. ``This (new) law was approved...on the orders of the EC,'' the group said. Described by the State Department as one of the most lethal terror groups in Europe, November 17 has killed 14 people since 1975 without any of its members being arrested. Three of its victims were U.S. officials serving in Greece. Police officials said security forces are on high alert, as Sunday marks the 15th anniversary of the group's first assassination, the killing of CIA station chief Richard Welch.

DOC.HEAD: Float Plane Pilot Finishes Historic Round-the-World Flight
DOC.TEXT: It took him more than six months to do what he'd planned would take eight weeks, but a seaplane pilot circled the globe landing only on water. Pilot Tom Casey overcame bureaucratic delays, surgery in Saudi Arabia and a crash landing in Alaska during his record-setting trip. ``Sorry I'm late, but I'm here,'' Casey told the crowd of admirers that gathered to watch him land Tuesday on Lake Washington. Casey claimed the title of first person to fly around the globe landing only on water, when his single-engine Cessna 206 equipped with pontoons dropped out of a cloudy, sleet-filled sky onto the lake where he had started his trip six months earlier. Casey, 53, said he persevered because of a desire to finish what he'd started, and ``basically, having to get the airplane back home. There was no other way to get it back.'' He took off and landed more than 75 times on oceans, lakes and rivers in 20 countries during the trip. The flight around the world in a seaplane must be recognized by the Federation Aeronautique Internationale, the official world air record sanctioning body. His backers said they expected it to be certified soon. The original plan was for Casey to fly westward beginning May 20, arriving back in Seattle in time for the Goodwill Games that began in late July. Last spring he arrived in Anchorage intending to fly west to the Soviet Union. But after failing to win timely permission to enter that country he returned to the continental United States, flew to the East Coast and across the North Atlantic, Europe and Asia. In Pakistan and Greece, he encountered delays, and in Saudi Arabia he was hospitalized for nearly a month for back surgery. Casey had said his most difficult bureaucratic snafu, gaining clearance to enter India from Pakistan, took 21 days to resolve. Casey challenged other Americans to go out and test themselves. ``People should go out and try to break records,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mendes' Confessed Killer Says He Would Do It Again
DOC.TEXT: The man convicted of killing Chico Mendes said in a televised interview that his only regret was that he shot the rain forest ecologist and union leader during an ambush. ``That was kind of cowardly,'' Darci Alves Pereira, 23, told the SBT network Tuesday night. ``I would kill Chico Mendes again, but differently ... Now I'd do it face-to-face,'' Pereira said in an interview from prison. Pereira confessed to the shooting during a dramatic four-day trial that ended Saturday in the remote jungle town of Xapuri, where Mendes was shot on Dec. 22, 1988. Pereira's father, rancher Darly Alves da Silva, was convicted of planning the shotgun slaying of Mendes, an internationally known crusader for the preservation of the Amazon forest from destruction by ranchers and loggers. The two were sentenced to 19 years in prison. Pereira also is serving a 12-year prison term for shooting at a meeting of rubber tappers. He is jailed in in Rio Branco, the capital of Acre state, 2,600 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro. Da Silva, who pleaded innocent, again denied any involvement in Mendes' shooting. ``I'm not a killer,'' he told a TV reporter. ``I'm an honest man. I love my neighbor as myself.'' The trial drew worldwide attention to the plight of tappers and native Indians who depend on the rapidly vanishing forest for survival. About one-tenth of the 2 million square mile wilderness has been destroyed, an area the size of Texas. Burning releases methane gas and carbon dioxide and is believed to add to the greenhouse effect that is changing the world's weather.

DOC.HEAD: Arctic Snowstorm Chills, Sends Snow and High Winds Howling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after the 12th, ``It's a difficult ...'' to UPDATE with island residents isolated by storm.
DOC.TEXT: A howling storm dumped up to 14 inches of snow in western Washington, knocking out power to tens of thousands of homes and stranding children overnight in more than three dozen schools. The storm forced the cancellation of classes at most Seattle schools today, and Mayor Norm Rice urged employers to give workers at least the morning off. ``We are anticipating really treacherous conditions, really slick roads, and we want to do anything we can do to help keep people off the roads,'' mayoral spokesman Mark Murray said. Seattle gets lots of rain but little snow and has practically no snow removal equipment. The storm bombarded the Pacific Northwest, northern Rocky Mountain states and the Dakotas with icy temperatures today, and overnight lows dropping well below zero set the stage for daytime highs expected to peak in the 20s. A winter storm warning continued today from southwestern Washington to Portland, Ore. Snowfall ranged from 8 inches downtown to 14 inches in some suburbs Tuesday evening. Winds gusting to 60 mph on Puget Sound bedeviled boat owners. Seattle-Tacoma Airport was closed for nearly two hours for snow removal. There were numerous minor accidents, but no deaths or major injuries were reported. Many roads were closed or impassable because of snow drifts Tuesday. More than 100,000 customers were without power for at least part of the night, said Puget Sound Power & Light Co., the region's largest utility. Other utilities in the area also reported widespread outages. Thirty-seven schools in King County remained open all night to house roughly 2,600 children and faculty who couldn't make it home, county emergency services officials said. In Seattle, children were stranded overnight in more than a dozen schools but had enough heat, food and supervision, said School Superintendent William Kendrick. ``It's a difficult situation. We're doing the best we can with it,'' he said. ``It's the first time in 34 years that I've seen anything like this.'' Residents of Vashon Island, about 30 miles south of Seattle in Puget Sound, remained isolated todaythis morning because ferry service was knocked out. High wind and waves up to 14 feet halted ferry service late Tuesday, and knocked loose the island's pedestrianramp to the ferry, said Washington State Ferries spokeswoman Princess Jackson-Smith. The National Weather Service issued high wind warnings for the western half of the state and a winter storm warning for 3 to 6 inches of snow from the Oregon state line northward remained in effect today. ``Ice, snow, gusty winds and cold temperatures are all coming at the same time,'' meteorologist Hank Treick said. ``The whole blooming state is going to get it.'' Seattle SuperSonics basketball coach K.C. Jones said his usual 30-minute commute to Seattle Center Coliseum took four hours Tuesday night. He missed the first quarter of a game with the Orlando Magic but did better than most ticketholders. Team spokesman Bill Bohlke said of 10,475 tickets sold, only 1,568 were used. Seventy miles north of the city, three people were rescued from a drifting houseboat and three sea-urchin divers were taken from a 28-foot sailboat late Tuesday as winds topping 60 mph hit the San Juan Islands. Four inches of snow had fallen on Salt Lake International Airport in Utah by early today, with more snow expected throughout the day. In the Dakotas, the mercury plummeted as much as 30 degrees in an hour Tuesday, bringing snow and overnight wind-chill readings as low as 70 below zero. Montana had heavy snow and similar sub-zero temperatures. The storm should persist into the weekend, Weather Service spokesman Randy Calaway said in Montana. ``It's like a monster coming in - we don't know exactly what it's going to do,'' Calaway said.

DOC.HEAD: Architects Asking Court to Halt Changes in Memorial Design
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, Instead, they, to UPDATE with suit being filed today.
DOC.TEXT: Four architects are asking a federal court to reject government tampering with their prize-winning design for the $14.9 million Korean War veterans' memorial in the capital. The architects, from Pennsylvania State University, said Tuesday they entered and won a $20,000 design contest last year believing the winning entry would be built on the Mall, across the Reflecting Pool from the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. Instead, they alleged in a suit filed today in U.S. District Court, their design was discarded by the government, a memorial advisory board and an architectural firm. ``From behind closed doors, they surreptitiously developed another design and they have managed to slip before the public, in recent days, their own ideas for the memorial - ideas that glamorize and romanticize the act of war,'' architect Don Leon, one of the plaintiffs, said at a news conference. ``As any Korean War veteran can tell you, that war, no matter how noble its intent, was never glamorous and romantic,'' Leon said. Named as defendants were the Army Corps of Engineers, the American Battle Monuments Commission, the Korean War Veterans Memorial Advisory Board and Cooper-Lecky Architects of Washington. The advisory board was created by Congress to select the site and the design, subject to the commission's approval. Then, Cooper-Lecky was retained by the corps last May to finalize the plan and build the memorial. The suit seeks an order blocking the defendants ``from proceeding with the new, substituted Cooper-Lecky Architects design.'' It also requests more than $250,000 in damages from both the advisory board and Cooper-Lecky. It alleges that Cooper-Lecky failed to consult with the original architects on the changes, as required by contract, and that the advisory board instructed Cooper-Lecky ``on certain design additions and deletions.'' Retired Army Gen. Richard Stilwell, chairman of the advisory board, said the suit ``has absolutely no foundation and, in my humble view, is aimed at frustrating the will of Congress that a national memorial to the veterans of the Korean war be established within the time frame dictated by public law.'' W. Kent Cooper of Cooper-Lecky said Tuesday he had not yet seen the suit, and could not comment. The Penn State design called for ``a dream-like'' collection of 38 soldiers moving, some unevenly, across a remote landscape toward an American flag. The revised design would confront visitors ``with the reality of actual war,'' sculptor Frank Gaylord, who is working with Cooper-Lecky on the project, said last week. Some soldiers ``are responding to unexpected, unfriendly fire,'' he said. The new plan adds a grove of trees called a ``chapel'' and a mural on the history of the war. Stilwell said in October that the original architects ``relinquished all rights to their submission in consideration of substantial prize money.'' He said the new design retains the essential element of the old one - a column of troops advancing toward a flag. Some 5.7 million Americans served in Korea during the 1950-53 conflict; more than 54,000 were killed. The original memorial design was unveiled at a Flag Day ceremony at the White House on June 14, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Cites Widespread Torture, Killings in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Iraq denying claims in report, Soviet reaction. Pickup 6th pvs, `Some international...'
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International issued a report today accusing Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait of torturing and killing hundreds of people, including 300 premature babies who died because incubators were stolen. The Iraqi Embassy in London today said the report by the international human rights group includes ``stories that are absolutely false.'' Amnesty International's first comprehensive description of abuses in occupied Kuwait since the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2 gives few precise figures. But Norma Johnson, the human rights organization's head of communications, said today that ``About 1,000 people have been executed, many hundreds have been tortured and something like 10,000 still remain in detention in Kuwait. ``People going out of their homes to buy food, innocent Kuwaitis, are being picked up by the Iraqi troops, taken back to their homes, and when they are identified by their parents, for example, are simply being shot in front of them,'' she said in a radio interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. President Bush, who has cited Iraqi brutality as a reason for wanting to liberate Kuwait, said Tuesday that the 82-page Amnesty report provides examples of Iraq's ``primeval'' treatment of the vanquished Kuwaitis. In Moscow, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin told a news briefing today: ``It is with anxiety and pain we have learned of the report ... Iraq must leave Kuwait unconditionally.'' The Iraqi Embassy n London said in a statement that the report's allegations were baseless and ``stand in stark contrast to its (Amnesty International's) inaction at a time when hundreds of Iraqi babies are dying owing to acute shortages of baby milk and medicine.'' Iraq contends a U.N. embargo on trade with Iraq has led to a shortage of medicine and baby formula. Some international observers say they fear that reports on Iraqi atrocities might fan the flames of war. The hundreds of deaths that London-based Amnesty and other independent human rights groups are reporting are far less than the thousands alleged by exiled Kuwaiti officials. Amnesty notes in the report that Iraqi authorities have engaged in similar practices against their own people for years. The report cites ``widespread abuses of human rights'' in Kuwait. ``These include the arbitrary arrest and detention without trial of thousands of civilians and (Kuwaiti) military personnel; the widespread torture of such persons in custody; the imposition of the death penalty and the extrajudicial execution of hundreds of unarmed civilians, including children,'' the report says. ``In addition, hundreds of people in Kuwait remain unaccounted for, having effectively `disappeared' in detention, and many of them are feared dead,'' it says. The Iraqis left more than 300 premature babies to die after stealing their incubators from Kuwait City hospitals, the report says. Amnesty says its investigators interviewed several doctors and nurses and that all saw bodies of the babies. One doctor helped bury 72 bodies, it says. Amnesty said its investigators spoke to victims of torture, doctors who treated them, their relatives and witnesses. The report lists 38 methods of torture employed by Iraqi forces, including beatings while the victim was suspended from a rotating ceiling fan; rape of women and young men; stubbing out lighted cigarettes on victims' eyeballs and tethering victims in the burning sun for hours without water. The report said in some cases the arms, legs and ribs of some victims were broken, tongues and ears were cut off and eyes were gouged out. In other cases, victims were castrated, the report said. Amnesty adds, however: ``The Iraqi forces' brutality in Kuwait has shocked many people in the past four months but such abuses have been the norm for people in Iraq for more than a decade.'' A woman at the Iraqi Embassy in London said the ambassador was the only person authorized to comment on the Amnesty report and that he was not available. Bush, in comments Sunday to interviewer David Frost on a PBS-TV program scheduled to be aired Jan. 2, said he read it and ``handed it to Barbara as we left Camp David. And she read about two pages of it and said, `I can't read anymore.''' ``It is primeval,'' he said. The report says some people were slain because they carried Kuwaiti money or refused to pledge allegiance to Saddam. Others were killed for refusing to help Iraqi soldiers steal medical equipment or while trying to flee the country. Some Kuwaiti supporters estimate 7,000 people have been killed by the Iraqis and 25,000 have been arrested. Various human rights groups have given estimates on the number of people killed or arrested in Kuwait, but they say the numbers cannot be verified without direct access to the country.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Plan Envisions Slower Growth in Military Spending
DOC.TEXT: Japan's Cabinet will slow the growth of military spending under a new five-year defense plan, Defense Agency officials said today. Analysts say the new plan, which is to be approved Thursday, follows Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's support of easing military spending in keeping with the collapse of Communism in Europe. Defense Agency officials and senior lawmakers of Kaifu's governing Liberal Democratic Party have opposed a sharp cut, contending the reduction in tensions has not yet extended to the Far East. Analysts say the new plan is only a provisional measure. Critics maintain that it does not go far enough in reducing Japan's defense spending. During the current $138 billion five-year plan, which ends in March, spending increases averaged 5.4 percent a year. The new plan envisions spending of $170.68 billion for 1991-1995, with an average annual increase of less than 3 percent, agency officials said today, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Defense Agency insists it needs at least $175.86 billion to meet 1976 guidelines stating that the Self-Defense Forces, Japan's military, should be capable of repulsing a ``limited, small-scale'' foreign attack. But Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto insists the average annual growth of the defense budget should not exceed 3 percent, an agency official said. Japan also depends on a defense treaty with the United States, which in the past pressed this nation for bigger defense buildups. It now is seeking more Japanese funds to support the 50,000 U.S. troops based in Japan. A policy paper released by the National Security Council on Tuesday said, ``The world situation is heading in desirable directions...and the possibility of a large-scale military conflict is lessening.'' Last week, Kaifu said in Parliament that he planned to restore Japan's self-imposed defense spending ceiling of 1 percent of its gross national product. The 1 percent ceiling, imposed in 1976, was eliminated in 1987 by the administration of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who actively promoted the strengthening and modernization of the Self-Defense Forces. The new plan has generated domestic criticism for not cutting defense spending more. ``The rest of the world, including the United States, is revising its security policies to respond to the new world order,'' said Kazuhisa Ogawa, a political analyst. ``But unfortunately, Japan is still sticking with the conventional stance of only seeing the Soviet Union as a potential enemy and following what the United States wants Japan to do,'' he said

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Prime Minister Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to clarify reference to peace plan. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a veteran of the country's turbulent politics, resigned today to make way for a broad-based reconciliation Cabinet that would boost efforts to end 15 years of civil war. Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, submitted the resignation of his 14-man government to President Elias Hrawi after a four-hour Cabinet meeting, a presidential statement said. Hoss, who turns 61 on Thursday, had formed the government on Nov. 25, 1989. The statement said Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic, asked Hoss to remain in office as a caretaker prime minister pending consultations with members of Parliament to name a successor. ``Hoss' Cabinet has performed some of the most striking achievements since the civil war broke out,'' a commentator on the Molsem-run Voice of the Nation said. ``Conditions now require a new Cabinet with a wider representation to reconcile the nation's major antagonists.'' Hoss, a U.S.-educated former banker, had said that he would not accept a new term. The edia have speculated that his education minister, Omar Karami, also a Sunni, is the front-runner for the post of prime minister. Karami, 55, a lawyer, inherited leadership of the second largest city of Tripoli from his elder brother, the late Prime Minister Rashid Karami. Rashid Karami, the longest serving prime minister since Lebanon gained independence from France in 1943, was killed in a bomb explosion aboard an army helicopter on June 1, 1987. Hoss served as acting prime minister after Karami's assassination until his appointment by Hrawi. That was the fourth time since 1976 that he had served as head of the government. Under Hoss, the Lebanese government crushed an 11-month mutiny by rebel Gen. Michel Aoun on Oct. 13. After that, it moved to enforce an Arab League-brokered peace pact designed to end the Christian-Moslem feud. On Dec. 3, the Lebanese army deployed across the divided capital, Beirut, to reunite the city and end militia control in a first step toward a final settlement of the civil war. The peace plan, which has been endorsed by parliament, is widely regarded as a first step toward eventually ending the sectarian system of government which had been dominated by Maronites. The plan provided for a transitional stage during which the president loses some of his authority in favor of his Moslem premier to ensure a balanced distribution of power between Christians and Moslems. Under an unwritten national agreement that has been in force since independence, a Lebanese president must be a Maronite, the prime minister a Sunni, and the parliament speaker a Shiite Moslem. The new Cabinet is supposed to group key figures from the main rival militia groups and political parties and work toward disbanding the private armies that had slowly eroded government authority since the outbreak of the civil war in April 1975. It also was expected to map out a plan for reconstructing war-ravaged Beirut and shoring up the economy. The civil war has claimed more than 150,000 lives and caused up to $18 billion of destruction, according to the latest United Nations estimates. Under the Arab League peace plan, an international fund would be set up early next year with a minimum of $2 billion for the reconstruction of Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaits Paid Public Relations Firm Nearly $5.7 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Kuwaitis paid a public relations firm nearly $5.7 million in less than three months to promote their country's cause following the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2, Justice Department records show. Citizens for a Free Kuwait, a group that receives money from the Kuwaiti government-in-exile, gave Hill & Knowlton, the New York-based international firm, $5.64 million for a period starting Aug. 20 and ending Nov. 10. The records were filed at the Justice Department as required by the Foreign Agents Registration Act. People representing foreign governments must file the forms every six months. he $5.6 million Hill & Knowlton received from Kuwait was by far the largest amount the company was paid by any foreign entity for the six-month period. The next largest amount was $1.89 million paid by Mazda Motor Corp. of Japan. Hill & Knowlton disbursed $2.7 million of the $5.7 million, including $644,571 on video production and $140,412 on travel. The public relations firm's main aim was to ``provide counsel on a national media program, strategic planning and message development,'' the filing said. Hill & Knowlton coordinated interviews and helped arrange national programs and events including National Free Kuwait Day, National Prayer Day and the visit of various Kuwaitis to the United States. The Kuwaiti government-in-exile, which is based in Taif, Saudi Arabia, has tried to disseminate information about conditions inside Kuwait, including atrocities reportedly committed by Iraqi occupation troops. Frank Mankiewicz, a senior Hill & Knowlton executive, said the Kuwait account was worth a lot of money. ``We think it is a worthy cause,'' he said. But Rep. James A. Hayes, D-La., said he was distressed by the money paid by a foreign entity to a public relations firm. ``It's not the amount of time or work, it's the purpose to which the money is being put to,'' he said. Hayes said it was wrong for a public relations firm to serve as the middle man in a foreign policy debate.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Charges Against Man in Assault of Woman with 46 Personalities
DOC.TEXT: A judge today dismissed charges against a man accused of sexually assaulting a woman with 46 personalities after a prosecutor said a retrial would harm her. Winnebago County District Attorney Joe Paulus said he decided against prosecuting 29-year-old Mark A. Peterson again after doctors for the 27-year-old victim said the ordeal of another trial likely would cause her mental condition to worsen. A jury convicted Peterson Nov. 8 of second-degree sexual assault but the judge threw out the verdict Monday and ordered another trial. The judge decided that Peterson received an unfair trial because his psychiatrist was not allowed to examine the woman, whose name has not been used to protect her identity. ``It is clear that a new trial would not be in the best interests of the victim and in fact may cause her additional harm,'' Paulus wrote in a letter to Winnebago County Circuit Judge Robert Hawley. Hawley signed an order this morning dismissing the charge of second-degree sexual assault against Peterson, said Winnebago County Deputy District Attorney Vince Biskupic. It is a crime in Wisconsin for someone to have sex with a mentally ill person who cannot understand the consequences of their actions. The perpetrator must also know the person is mentally ill. The jury ruled Peterson, a married ex-grocery store bagger, manipulated one of the woman's personalities to have sex with her in the front seat of his car two days after they met. Paulus said the woman was willing to go through another trial. But he told the judge in a letter that he consulted with three medical experts on multiple personality disorder and they advised against another trial. ``One of the primary goals of the prosecution of Mark Peterson was to protect the rights of a mentally ill woman and hold her attacker accountable under the law,'' Paulus said. ``The jury verdict, although now set aside on a legal technicality, sent a strong message to the community that mentally ill individuals in our society must be protected from those who prey upon them.'' Since the case became public, the victim's personalities have grown from 18 to 21 to 46. Police were called to her home after she reported one personality was trying to kill her. She has been under constant psychiatric care and has been hospitalized.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Performers Killed In Truck-Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: Seven members of a Soviet dance company were killed when a truck collided with two buses transporting the troupe in the Soviet Far East border region, Tass reported Wednesday. The performers belonged to the Song and Dance Company of the Pacific Border District, the Tass report said. It said the driver of one of the buses was also killed, and 12 passengers and the truck driver were seriously injured. The collision occured at the 75-mile mark of the Vladivostock-Nakhodka highway, the report said. The cause of the accident was not reported.

DOC.HEAD: Government Warns Slovenia About Secession Referendum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with army joining government in warning Slovenia to cancel the referendum. Pickup 8th, `Prosperous Slovenia...'
DOC.TEXT: The government and the army today said Slovenia will be taking a great risk if voters in Yugoslavia's most prosperous republic choose this weekend to declare independence from the country. The deputy defense minister, Admiral Stene Brovet, told the federal Parliament that the army was ready to ``act in accordance with the Yugoslav Constitution'' and those in Slovenia who ``think differently, are wrong.'' The government on Tuesday rejected the Slovenian referendum and said it would take unspecified steps to preserve the country's unity. There were fears of army intervention, but Slovenian officials said the federal government has assured them that the military would not stop the vote Sunday. The leading Slovenian daily Delo today challenged the federal authorities. ``Do (officials) in Belgrade think they can halt Slovenia's independence, or do they simply want to accelerate our departure from Yugoslavia?'' it asked in a commentary. With Sunday's referendum approaching, ``the old federation is counting its last hours,'' the paper said. The federation of six republics and two provinces has been in existence since 1945. Justice Minister Vlado Kambovski today told Parliament the central government was ``warning state organs of Slovenia about the great responsibility and the risk they are assuming'' if they unilaterally step out of the federation. The government will ``undertake energetic steps to protect reforms and objective, common interests of all peoples and nationalities'' in Yugoslavia, Kambovski said without elaboration. His comments were reported by the state news agency Tanjug. The Parliament ended its session with the demand that Slovenia reconsider holding the referendum ``because of its consequences.'' Prosperous Slovenia, governed by a center-right coalition since spring, wants more independence from central authorities. Slovenia is backed by Croatia, where Communists were also ousted by center-right parties in spring elections. They want Yugoslavia transformed into a loose confederation. Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, where Communists scored a victory in recent elections, wants Yugoslavia to remain a federation with a strong, centralized government. The differences have led to a deepening rift among the republics and strained their relations with the federation, pushing the Balkan nation to the edge of disintegration.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes in Disputed Armenian Enclave
With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf pvs, `Earlier this...' to CORRECT date martial law imposed. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Elsewhere today...'
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded at a Communist Party building in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh area in the southern Caucasus region, Tass said today. No injuries were reported. The official Soviet news agency said the blast on Tuesday did considerable damage to a Communist Party building in Stepanakert, the biggest city in Nagorno-Karabakh, a mainly Armenian enclave inside the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. Authorities also discovered a second, unexploded bomb, the news agency said, without elaborating. In the past two years, more than 200 people have died in ethnic clashes over the control of Nagorno-Karabakh, which Azerbaijan has held since 1923. Tass said six people have been killed in the last week in ethnic clashes in Nagorno-Karabakh and other parts of the Caucasus region, where tension between Armenians and Azerbaijanis runs high. In January, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared a limited form of martial law in Nagorno-Karabakh. The Soviet leader told lawmakers today he will not hesitate to impose emergency rule in any republic where ethnic and political conflicts threaten lives. Elsewhere today, the Latvian parliament denounced three predawn explosions Tuesday in the capital, Riga. No injuries were reported and most of the damage was restricted to broken windows. No suspects or motives were identified. The Latvian Communist Party said some unidentified people were trying to blame it for the explosions. It said it had no role in the blasts.

DOC.HEAD: Toddler Dies After Drinking Father's Methadone
DOC.TEXT: A couple has been charged with negligent homicide after their toddler drank his drug-addicted father's methadone and died, police said Wednesday. The toddler opened the refrigerator in his home Sunday and drank a bottle half filled with a methadone-laced orange drink that his 31-year-old father had gotten from a municipal heroin withdrawal program, said police spokesman Dick Graveland. Graveland said the liquid contained ``several drops of methadone. That's an adult dosage.'' The child's parents did not seek medical help because they thought their son would recover after a night's sleep. The boy was found dead in bed Monday morning, Graveland said. The spokesman did not identify the victim or his family in accordance with Dutch police practice. Most Dutch cities have methadone programs that dispense the synthetic narcotic.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Faces 14 Percent Increase in Crime
DOC.TEXT: Crime in Britain rose by 14 percent between July and September from the previous three-month period, the Home Office said Wednesday. The Home Office, the department responsible for law and order issues, said the largest increase was in burglaries. Violent crime increased by only 2 percent from the same time in 1989, the Home Office said. The metropolitan London police reported an overall crime increase of 9 percent from the second to the third quarters of 1990, the Home Office said. The office's statistics showed that of the 4.3 million offenses reported in a 12-month period ending in September, 4.1 million were against property while 246,000 cases involved violent crimes, including sexual offenses and armed robbery.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. --- Dec. 16 The Sun Herald, Gulfport, Miss., on Congress: Businesses and industries are tightening their belts, cutting back on expansion plans, freezing salaries and payrolls, reducing expenses, and in some cases laying off workers. The people in Congress, in contrast, aren't troubling themselves with such recession-fighting steps. Why should congressmen and women worry? The business of government is booming. Senators, fresh from getting a raise to $98,400 last February, look forward to January when they will get the next pay raise they gave themselves, this one to $101,900. Representatives did themselves even better, jumping their paychecks from $96,600 to $125,100. ... Lest you should think that those increases aren't enough compensation for the wonderful job the Congress is doing, remember that senators will be allowed to keep up to $23,837 in honoraria, the fees for giving speeches, writing articles and similar moonlighting. House members will stop keeping honoraria. One other note about the pay increases. Congressfolk achieved them without accountability. It was done by voice vote. No names recorded, no fingerprints or footprints. No individual accountability, no need to defend a yea vote since the individuals' voices were lost in the chorus. ... Next year, Congress will cost about $2.2 billion. The cost has gone up by almost $2 billion in the last 20 years. The climb upward has been as steadily and as surely as the rise in the national debt. --- Dec. 14 Toledo (Ohio) Blade on limiting Congressional terms: The throw-the-rascals-out brigade received a boost when President Bush added his voice to those calling for term limits for members of Congress. ... Bush is climbing upon a bandwagon that is not yet rolling. Voters in November indicated that they do not yet have a specific idea of how term limits will be achieved or what duration terms should be, although 12 years is most often suggested. Rather there is a distinct hankering for change, for somebody to ``do something'' to improve the way our system of government is, or is not, working. We understand that sentiment, of course. The notion of the citizen/legislator as a public-spirited individual who serves his or her state or district for a limited period and then returns to private life is appealing. It points to politics as a calling, a responsibility to be shouldered, not as a sinecure with a good pension. ... Quality leadership, conscientious lawmakers, representatives expert in their field and diligent in performing their duties would be thrown out arbitrarily with the rascals. ... Even so, term limits reflect the groundswell of obvious public distaste for the game of politics; it should not be ignored. --- Dec. 18 Chicago Tribune on NASA: Even before the shuttle Challenger blew apart shortly after launch in 1986, there were signs that the nation's space program was drifting off course. Critics hoped the Challenger accident would spark thorough self-examination and new direction at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. But recent troubles - flaws in the Hubble Space Telescope, fuel leaks in the aging shuttle fleet and controversy over a planned space station - suggest the program still lacks a sound flight plan. A panel of experts has offered the White House a strong, sensible proposal to get America's space exploration back on the right path. ... In addition to being drafted with singular political sensitivity and shrewdness, the proposals together set clear, logical objectives for a new space era - one defined primarily by federal budget deficits and the end of the Cold War. The first will mean maximizing the available resources to achieve agreed-upon goals; the second should lead to greater international cooperation and a reduced military role in space. The 12-member committee ... called for sweeping overhaul of the space program. Specifically, it proposed that the space shuttle be largely replaced by a new family of powerful, unmanned rockets. It called for a major redesign and simplification of the space station aimed at lowering its $37 billion price tag. And, instead of concentrating on engineering feats and highly visible missions with limited practical value, the panel would make scientific research on the Earth and its environment the top priority. ... This is the correct approach in the post-Cold War, tight-budget era. it can also regenerate interest in space exploration, directing people's imagination and enterprise toward new frontiers and achievements. --- Dec. 12 Daily Times, Primos, Pa., on NASA: The space shuttle's future is up in the air, if we're interpreting signals from the government correctly. The same nation that put a man on the moon is now trying to put the beleagured space shuttle in the garage. A 12-member space panel, which was formed after NASA's embarrassments began piling up, has recommended ... that space shuttle flights be confined only to those that require human involvement. Let's face it, the space shuttle program has had its share of troubles this year. The panel also suggested that NASA go back to the drawing board and redesign its proposed space station and rethink its priorities. One thing for certain is that whatever lies in NASA's future, it can't be much if NASA's space exploration program, in this case, the shuttle, is relegated to just a few flights, all of which would be one giant step backward for mankind. Space travel is and will never be free of risks. We have known and understood that for years. --- Dec. 13 The Waco (Texas) Tribune-Herald on young smokers: The tobacco industry has launched a program to discourage children from taking up cigarette smoking. The industry campaign supports state laws limiting cigarette sales to adults and puts new limitations on billboard advertising near schools. The tobacco industry campaign is, as far as it goes, a worthy effort to prevent American youths from picking up a hazardous habit that can lead to death. ... Congress and state legislatures should not let the tobacco industry campaign sway them from passage of legislation that would further protect the health and lives of millions of Americans hooked on smoking. Smoking is a serious health hazard and governmental bodies have the responsibility to take all reasonable steps to protect citizens from health hazards. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: health hazards.
DOC.TEXT: Dec. 18 Los Angeles Daily News on the education secretary nominee: Lamar Alexander, President Bush's choice to be the new education secretary, is an outspoken education activist who gets results. And that's exactly the kind of person the job requires. As governor of Tennessee from 1978 to 1986, Alexander was a leader - by no means a mere bandwagon-hopper - in the growing educational reform movement. He came up with a package of significant improvements in Tennessee's schools, including statewide merit pay for teachers, before most other elected officials seemed ready even to acknowledge that the nation's schools had severe problems. ... In contrast to Lauro F. Cavazos, who resigned from the position ... , Alexander is a self-starter who probably won't have to wait for cues from the White House to set an agenda for educational reform. Alexander compares favorably to Cavazos in another way as well: The former governor was effective in using his office to take on the teachers unions, fellow Republicans and others who didn't share his commitment to educational reform. ... Alexander will need to use these same political skills if he is to succeed in his new job. The same establishment that fought his reforms in Tennessee will be ready to jump down his throat in Washington at the mere mention of such reform concepts as educational choice and a uniform national test for students. --- Dec. 13 Roswell (N.M.) Daily Record on Germany: A year ago, when the Berlin Wall had just been breached and Germany's future was uncertain, a great deal of concern was expressed around the globe about the prospects of a united, more powerful Germany. The parliamentary elections held recently to choose a new all-German government should allay most of those fears. In the first free balloting throughout Germany since November 1932, the voters reaffirmed the sensible political middle. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union was given a solid mandate to build on the policies that led to swift reunification. Significantly, the voters in the east endorsed Kohl's vision in about the same ratio as the electorate in the west. And Kohl's vision is one of a united Germany firmly moored to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Community. Barely a year after the Berlin Wall was toppled, Germans have voted for a united nation tied economically and militarily to the Western democracies. The once-widespread fears that German unity would wrack the Continent with renewed conflict suddenly seem overblown. --- Dec. 18 Arizona Daily Star, Tucson, Ariz., on the Persian Gulf: Good, red American blood is a renewable resource. Good, rich crude oil is not. Because one represents life and the other represents the fuel that powers what has become the American way of life, you'd think both would be equally precious. They are not. The president who is willing to draw lines in the sand with American blood for the sake of Saudi oil is unwilling to even discuss cutting down on domestic oil consumption. Energy Secretary James Watkins understands that a national energy policy without an energy-conservation component is as useless as a Ford without fuel. That's why Watkins built energy conservation into the proposal he's been working on for 18 months. It's also why the White House dinosaurs (Chief of Staff John Sununu, chief economic adviser Michael J. Boskin and Budget Director Richard Darman) told Watkins to drop conservation proposals from the National Energy Strategy. The White House dinosaurs don't want an energy policy to go anywhere. As minions of oil man George Bush, their goal is to preserve the status quo until every bit of money can be made out of every bit of oil on the face of the earth. And if that takes every drop of good, red American blood, so be it. The laissez faire attitude to energy conservation by the Reagan-Bush administration assured that the United States would remain dependent on oil and heavily dependent on foreign oil. --- Dec. 14 The Bulletin, Bend, Ore., on the Persian Gulf: Former hostages who returned in the past few days from Iraq and Kuwait were almost universal in their praise of the way the Bush administration has handled the Gulf crisis. Bush's quickness to act, his call-up of military strength, his clear warnings to Saddam Hussein and his successful grouping of an overpowering opposition all taken together made Hussein realize he was on shaky ground. Releasing the hostages was his way of meeting at least one of the requirements Bush laid down. Times were not easy for the hostages. Many of them spent four months in hiding. Many survived through the heroism of Kuwaiti friends who hid and fed them. But they might well have been there for years, rather than months, had Bush not acted as strongly and decisively as he did. Almost universally the released hostages appear to realize that. --- Dec. 14 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on the Persian Gulf: Amid the happiness at the freeing of Iraq's hostages, we want to take special note of Nathaniel Howell, the U.S. ambassador to Kuwait, and his embassy staff. During four months of hostile occupation, surrounded and isolated by unpredictable Iraqi troops, Ambassador Howell retained his calm and kept the embassy functioning. With war scares running high, he and his skeleton staff of four other Foreign Service officers managed to make do for most of their enforced isolation on embassy stocks of canned tuna, augmented by water from a swimming pool. By firmly resisting the Iraqi demands that he depart, Ambassador Howell helped to legitimize Kuwait's status as an independent state. He and his staff handled a tough situation with real distinction. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: real distinction.
DOC.TEXT: Dec. 18 Sun-Sentinel, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on sanctions: South Africa and Iraq are as dissimilar as gold and oil, yet the apparent importance of economic sanctions in bringing about substantive change in one country may have timely relevance to the other. Much of the world, but principally the United States and the European Community, imposed a variety of sanctions on South Africa during the 1980s as punishment for that nation's adherence to a system of legal segregation known as apartheid. Now the international community is virtually united in an economic embargo and military blockade intended to compel Iraq to withdraw from occupied Kuwait. While politicians debate the impact of the Iraqi sanctions and ponder the wisdom of going to war to enforce the global will, they could well draw an important lesson from recent developments in South Africa. --- Dec. 16 The Sunday Telegraph, London, on the Persian Gulf: Any visible failure of American nerve in the (Persian) Gulf would mean the end of the present system of world security. What could take its place? Instead of grappling with this urgent question, Europe's leaders prefer to waste their time talking about European political union, which is not only a profoundly divisive aspiration but also one that could not possibly be realized for many years to come. ... For once the United Nations should be the focus of attention. Every ounce of European diplomacy should be concentrated on steeling American resolve to carry out the U.N. mandate in the Gulf. World security, not European union, is the question of the hour. It is sad that there is now no longer a single European statesman with the courage to say so. --- Dec. 17 The Times of India, New Delhi, on the Soviet Union: Though outside reports about the Soviet Union being on the verge of collapse may well be exaggerated, the country and its leader are facing the gravest crisis yet. ... For the first time since (Mikhail) Gorbachev came to power the initiative seems to have shifted to the conservatives. Also for the first time, key representatives of the army and the KGB are making major policy statemenets in public which are virtual warnings that the executive under ... Gorbachev will have to move toward a major crackdown. --- Dec. 17 The Sydney (Australia) Morning Herald on South Africa: Is the African National Congress in danger of losing its grip on the anti-apartheid struggle in South Africa? ... That cleavages within the ANC should be opening up now is not all that surprising. There is a generational gap between the current top leadership and most of its members. There is a jostling for position and power. ... There are inevitable differences of opinion over tactics, over how much trust to place in President de Klerk and over how much should be compromised in the interests of a lasting peace. ... What is surprising is the time it has taken the ANC to begin getting its house in order. The delay has been costly. It has allowed indiscipline to grow in the ranks of the ANC and that in turn to feed the black-on-black violence in Natal province. It has increased the chances of impatience for reform, cutting ANC leaders off from younger, more militant members of the organization. It has played into the hands of whites inside and outside ... de Klerk's government who seek to portray the ANC as incompetent and dangerous for South Africa. It is a luxury of time the ANC can no longer afford. --- Dec. 15 The Daily Press, Ashland, Wis., on tariff talks: Although there are several reasons why the depression of the 1930s happened, it is generally agreed that restrictive tariff wars contributed greatly. Today the United States is participating in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations in Brussels. There has been a call among many politicians for the U.S. to pull out of the negotiations, that we are not receiving the kinds of assurances we need. Granted, the doors are open wider for foreign products entering this country than they are for most. We do pay a price when it comes to marketing our products worldwide. But there are stronger reasons for us to remain a working partner in the tariff and trade agreements. First, levying tariffs on imported products quite simply fuels inflation. Many of the products in question will still be sold here to a willing public. We will simply have to pay more. But most important the U.S. should not be party to a spiraling tariff war that eventually catches up with everybody. Prior to the depression, the trading powers closed their doors to smaller nations thinking that we were immune to recessionary influences. We were wrong. Promoting a world economy not only establishes a system versatile enough to withstand devastating depressions, but also creates economic growth worldwide. Why is that important to us? The world can't buy what we sell unless they have the money first. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Roundup
Applicants For Government Slots Must Fess Up Before Being Hired
DOC.TEXT: Ever had a child out of wedlock, written a letter to a newspaper editor or know someone who will say mean things about you? These are some of the things Gov.-elect John Engler wants to know before he'll make appointments to a high-level post in his administration. The confidential appointments questionnaire obtained by the Detroit Free Press is 24 pages long, and it goes beyond the usual questions about criminal history, drug involvement and health. Some of the more unusual inquiries include: - Do you know any person or group who might take overt or covert steps to attack, even unfairly, your appointment? - Are you a parent of a child or children born out of wedlock? - Have you ever been publicly identified, in person or by organizational membership, with a particularly controversial national or local issue? - Have you ever submitted oral or written views to any governmental authority, whether executive or legislative, or to the news media on any particularly controversial issue other than in an official governmental capacity? William Whitbeck, a lawyer working for the Engler transition team, said the administration wants to know ahead of time what trouble to expect. ``Unfortunately, too often in politics, people get selected and things come out that hadn't been disclosed ... and it's a bad situation for everyone,'' Whitbeck said. The questionnaire comes with an apologetic letter, blaming all the personal intrusion on lawyers, said one applicant, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Whitbeck said the responses will remain confidential and are not subject to disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. Access to them is limited to only a few staffers, he said. Engler, a Republican and state Senate majority leader, beat two-term Democratic Gov. James Blanchard in the Nov. 6 election.

DOC.HEAD: Cold War's End Brings Christmas Liberty to Arctic
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev could be more popular than Santa Claus this Christmas among the troops guarding Norway's arctic frontier with the Soviet Union. The end of the Cold War has made it possible for Norwegian soldiers to go home for the holidays in record numbers, said defense officials. Since the 1950s, half the roughly 10,000 soldiers stationed in this NATO country's frozen north had to stay near their posts during Christmas in case of a Soviet invasion, said Col. Per Boethun of the Norwegian Supreme Defense Command. But only a thousand, or 10 percent, are on duty this year, because of eased east-west tensions, due at least in part to Gorbachev's reforms. ``For the few soldiers left at the base, a visit from Santa is much more likely than an unexpected visit from Gorbachev's Red Army,'' wrote the Verdens Gang newspaper Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Towers of Glass, Pottery, Shells and Wire Becomes National Landmark
DOC.TEXT: Watts Towers, the spiraling amalgam of broken bottles, pottery shard, iron and seashells woven together by chicken wire, is now a national landmark.
