A more appropriate analysis of the research results, Blinkhorn said, suggests that most of the time the tests ``are doing no better than chance.'' But that analysis overlooked successful predictions because it did not look at how particular personality characteristics relate to particular aspects of job performance, said psychologist Leaetta Hough. ``If you analyze what it is you're trying to predict, there are sensible relationships between personality and those performance factors,'' said Hough, who has studied personality tests in employment settings. The predictions are not perfect, but they can indicate such factors as willingness to work hard, striving for outstanding results, dependability and satisfying clients, said Hough, executive vice president of the Personnel Decisions Research Institute in Minneapolis. She and other experts stressed that personality tests should not be used by themselves for personnel decisions, but rather as part of a package of information about a person.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Grandchildren See `Blue Planet'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush took some of his grandchildren and other family members to the Smithsonian Air and Space Museum on Wednesday to watch the panoramic movie ``Blue Planet.'' The president and his flock of five youngsters were applauded as they entered the museum theater and took their seats in an upper row. It was Bush's second trip to the wide-screen theater, one of the museum's top attractions. He took Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir there in early 1989 to see the movie, ``To Fly.'' ``Blue Planet'' features dazzling color footage taken by U.S. astronauts from space through special wide-angle lenses. Accompanying Bush were daughter-in-law Sharon Bush, the wife of Neil Bush, and their three children, Marshall, Pierce and Lauren; the president's sister Nancy Ellis and her grandson, Alexander Ellis. Marshall Bush brought a friend and another Bush daughter-in-law, Margaret Bush, Marvin Bush's wife, also attended.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Officer Says US Won't Be Ready To Fight By UN Deadline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds objections to Waller's comments, inserting 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, In Saudi
DOC.TEXT: American troops will not be ready to attack Iraq until weeks after the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, the deputy commander of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf said Wednesday. Some crucial heavy ground forces likely will not even have arrived in Saudi Arabia by the deadline, and commanders are urging President Bush to delay any offensive action until the deployment is completed, Army Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller said. If Saddam ignores the deadline and Bush wants to order an attack in the days immediately following Jan. 15, ``I'd tell him, `No. I'm not ready to do the job,'' the general said. Waller said he believed Bush was aware of the readiness timetable but said it would be stressed again in three days of meetings that began Wednesday between field commanders and Bush's top two military officials, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Colin Powell. Bush said Monday that U.N. resolutions against Iraq, which include one authorizing force if Iraqi troops aren't out of Kuwait by Jan. 15, should be enforced ``right on schedule.'' At the White House, presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday when asked about Waller's comments, ``What he really said is they might not be as ready as they would like to be ... for all the contingencies.'' ``We are assured they will be ready to do whatever they are called upon to do,'' Fitzwater said. In Saudi Arabia, aides to Powell and to Waller's immediate boss, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, expressed concern that Waller had been too candid in discussing U.S. readiness and deployment in his meeting with reporters just after an initial meeting with Cheney and Powell. Speaking privately, several senior military officials suggested that his comments could undermine diplomatic efforts based on persuading Saddam to take the Jan. 15 deadline seriously. Cheney fired former Air Force chief of staff Gen. Michael Dugan in September after Dugan talked openly of the likelihood of bombing certain Iraqi military and economic targets if hostilities began. Waller was the first senior military officer to say publicly that the American deployment will reach 430,000 troops when completed. But he said several vital components still were missing, including Navy carriers due to leave home port just after Christmas, combat aircraft due to arrive by Jan. 15, and some 117,000 Army armored forces coming from Fort Riley, Kan., and from Germany. Some of the latter group, Waller said, might not arrive until late January. And even if the troops did arrive by the U.N. deadline, he said, ``there's a distinct possibility that every unit will not be fully combat ready until sometime after the first of February.'' Likening himself to a football coach, Waller said: ``I certainly want everything that I can possibly get and have at my side of the field when I get ready to go into the Super Bowl. ... I would say to the president and to the secretary and as well to the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that until our full complement of forces are on the ground that we should not initiate hostile activities.'' Of Bush, Waller said: ``It's my understanding that he's been briefed and received briefings that the forces will not be ready for combat activity until sometime after the 15th of the month.'' In Washington, meanwhile: - Sens. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, and Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, said that on their just-concluded trip to the gulf U.S. military commanders indicated a war with Iraq could be wrapped up within five days. The senators commented after briefing Bush on their trip but declined to say if the president shared their assessment. - White House spokesman Fitzwater said there had been no new contact with Iraq on dates or times for the proposed visit of Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad or the White House visit by Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. ``We get no response ... we don't see any opening,'' Fitzwater said. - The State Department said U.S. allies had contributed more than $9 billion to support the American gulf effort and ``we are satisfied.'' Several members of Congress have criticized the allies' contribution as too small. - The White House announced that Vice President Dan Quayle will visit the U.S. troops in the gulf on a Dec. 29-Jan. 2 trip during which he will also meet with Saudi King Fahd. In Saudi Arabia, Cheney and Powell had nothing to say publicly Wednesday after the initial round of meetings. Speaking to reporters en route to Saudi Arabia, however, Cheney said concerning the Jan. 15 date, ``Most of the forces will be there by then, but obviously there is additional work to be done before you would identify them as combat ready.'' As for Saddam's intentions, Cheney said he saw no evidence that the Iraqi president planned even a partial withdrawal from Kuwait, a move some have suggested he might make in an effort to weaken the international coalition demanding a total pullout. ``He might move the pieces around on the board, but our objective is for him to get all of that stuff out of Kuwait - not half of it, not 75 percent of it, not 10 percent of it, all of it,'' Cheney said. Powell said he did not want to discuss any U.S. combat plans because doing so could help Saddam. ``I want him to sit there in beautiful downtown Baghdad and worry his butt off about it,'' Powell said. Cheney and Powell are to meet with American and Saudi military officers Thursday and Friday morning before splitting up to make pre-Christmas visits to some of the 270,000 U.S. troops already in the gulf region.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Woman Dies After Being Attacked by Leopard
DOC.TEXT: A 65-year-old woman was mauled to death at an amusement park Wednesday when the leopard she was feeding seized her by the neck and dragged her into its cage, authorities said. Francesca Arnetti of Torre Annunziata, an Italian town 5 miles from Naples, died from wounds to the neck and head, the news agency ANSA reported. After the attack, the leopard ran into the basement of a nearby restaurant. Police fired tear gas into the restaurant and shot the animal to death. Authorities are unsure how the leopard, part of the amusement park's animal exhibit, escaped its cage.

DOC.HEAD: Breast Cancer Spread May Be Helped By Normal Cells, Study Suggests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Breast cancers may recruit normal tissue to help launch their invasion of other parts of the body, a discovery that may open a new target for therapy, a study suggests. Scientists identified a gene that is activated in normal cells surrounding invasive breast cancers, spurring the normal cells to produce an enzyme that may help cancer cells spread from the original tumor. The makeup of the gene suggests that this enzyme may degrade normal tissue surrounding a tumor, creating pathways for the cancer cells to escape, scientists reported in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature. The enzyme, which the scientists dubbed stromelysin-3, is produced by stromal cells, which make up supporting structure within breasts, the scientists said. Apparently, breast cancers produce some kind of substance that activates the stromal cells to produce the enzyme, they suggested. The enzyme may be a new target for cancer therapy, they said. The work was reported by Pierre Chambon and colleagues at the Institute of Biological Chemistry of the National Institute of Medical Research in Strasbourg, France. Dr. Lance Liotta, a National Cancer Institute expert on how cancer spreads, said it was unclear what the discovery means for cancer treatment. For one thing, nobody knows whether the enzyme really helps cancers spread or whether it provides a defense, he said Wednesday. Liotta said scientists had previously identified other enzymes that help cancers spread by destroying tissue. These substances are created by cancer cells themselves, he said.

DOC.HEAD: President's Christmas Message: `Let Us Strive ... for Peace.'
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's 1990 Christmas message, released Wednesday: At Christmas, people of every age and every walk of life celebrate with a profound sense of wonder, joy and gratitude our Savior's birth in Bethlehem. Like the shepherds called from nearby fields and the Magi who journeyed from distant lands to welcome the Christ Child, we are drawn to this miraculous event in history. Born in a stable and greeted by a handful of faithful and obedient men, Christ came to assume the role of a shepherd, thus fulfilling the words of the prophet Isaiah: ``He shall feed his flock like a shepherd: He shall gather the lambs with his arm and carry them in his bosom.'' Christ's brief time on earth was devoted to tending the physical and spiritual needs of his flock: healing the sick, feeding the hungry and illuminating the path to eternal salvation. His incarnation radically altered the course of human history by challenging men and women to live according to the will of our just and merciful Father in heaven. Today's Christ's message of hope and redemption - first delivered on that holy night in the city of David - continues to bring peace and joy to millions of people around the world. As we give and receive the goodwill of Christ during this holy season, let us be mindful of the true meaning of his life on earth and especially of his greatest commandment: to love God with all our heart and to love our neighbor as ourself. Events during the past year have given us a renewed sense of hope, yet in some parts of the world, peace remains an elusive blessing this Christmas. Even in some of our own cities, poverty, despair, and drug-related violence prevent families and individuals from sharing in the promise of this season. Therefore, let us strive, by following Christ's example in word and deed, to make peace on earth a reality for all of God's children. Barbara joins me in wishing all of our fellow Americans a Merry Christmas. May this festive and holy season be filled with the warmth of family and friends and with the deep joy of knowing God's love for mankind through the gift of his Son. God bless you. George Bush

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Says Market Prices Will Be Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Market prices of major farm commodities will be mixed in the coming year as some rise because of declining supplies while others decline because of abundance, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. A new outlook report by the department's Economic Research Service said world output of grain, oilseeds and meat is rising in 1990-91. ``Consumption, however, is forecast to grow more oderately, and ending stocks of some commodities are expected to rise,'' the report said. In the United States, the average prices in the 1990-91 marketing years for various crops will show a variety of reactions. The average prices of wheat, milk, barley, oats and rice are expected to be lower than a year earlier, while the prices of corn, soybeans and most meats will hold about steady or rise slightly, the report said. Meanwhile, the mix of crops farmers plant in 1991 will probably change more than in recent years, it said. ``Farmers will be reacting to the planting flexibility provisions of the new farm (law) and will be more responsive to changing market prices,'' the report said. ``If yields revert to trend and planted acreage remains steady, foreign grain output could decline as well, perhaps lending some support to prices.''

DOC.HEAD: United Nations Nears Accord on Palestinians, Mideast Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Meeting postponed until Thursday at 10:30 a.m. EST, vote likely then
DOC.TEXT: UNITED NATIONS - The United States on Wednesday appeared close to endorsing U.N. Security Council efforts to protect Arabs in the Israeli-occupied lands, denounce their deportation and back a Mideast peace conference. The Security Council has been holding intensive consultations to avert a U.S. veto and to reconcile Western and nonaligned draft resolutions. U.S. officials are trying to find a way out of a diplomatic vise, squeezing them between their longstanding ties to Israel and their newfound attachment to Arab allies in the anti-Iraqi coalition. Western diplomats said Wednesday that agreement on a Finnish draft resolution that could be supported by the United States appeared to be at hand, although some textual problems remained. Nonaligned diplomats indicated that more serious problems may remain. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering told reporters Wednesday after consultations that the United States could vote in favor of a draft resolution submitted by Finland ``in its integrity,'' but amendments were expected. A Security Council meeting and vote was rescheduled to Thursday morning. It has been delayed seven times the past two weeks, largely at U.S. urging. The United States is trying to avoid exercising its veto of a resolution critical of Israel, which fiercely opposes an international Mideast conference. U.S. officials fear a veto, which they can exercise as a permanent council member, would anger Arab allies and thus undermine the anti-Iraqi coalition. The United States has been trying to remove any mention of a Mideast peace conference from a resolution and shift it to a nonbinding presidential statement accompanying the resolution. Complicating matters, U.S. officials also want to avoid any appearance of bowing to Iraq's demand that a Persian Gulf settlement be tied to a solution of the Palestinian problem. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has called for a Mideast peace conference. The U.S. government, which supports considering a peace conference at an unspecified time in the future, has disavowed any linkage between Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, invaded on Aug. 2, and the Israeli-occupied lands.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians `Cancel' Christmas, Israelis Promise Programs
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Palestinian uprising on Wednesday called a strike in Bethlehem for Christmas Eve, but Israeli officials said government-sponsored holiday programs would go on as scheduled. A Palestinian strike, which would close all of Bethlehem's tourist shops and restaurants on Dec. 24, ``will make for a gloomy, gloomy Christmas,'' admitted Tourism Ministry spokesman Yossi Shoval. But, he added, ``There will be no change in our Christmas events, with or without their support.'' The main government-sponsored event on Christmas Eve is an evening choir performance in Bethlehem, which is in the occupied West Bank. Religious activitis include a procession into the Church of the Nativity led by the Roman Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem, a Protestant prayer service in nearby Shepherd's Field and midnight Mass. The Israeli army posts hundreds of troops in Bethlehem at Christmas to man roadblocks and metal detectors that visitors must pass through to reach the church, where Christian tradition says Christ was born. It is the fourth consecutive year that the underground Palestinian leadership has called a strike in Bethlehem to underscore the uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The leaflet calling the strike said it was also ``due to the gulf crisis.'' Many Palestinians support Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Earlier, Bethlehem Mayor Elias Freij said the municipality would cancel traditional Christmas parades and receptions again this year in solidarity with the uprising. Bishop Samir Kafity, the Anglican bishop of Jerusalem, told a meeting of visiting American Christian leaders on Wednesday he understood the frustration of his fellow Palestinians. ``How can we celebrate the birth of the prince of peace if we have no sign of this peace coming?'' he said. He predicted ``more soldiers than worshipers'' in Bethlehem at Christmas. Shoval said the Tourism Ministry expects about 7,000 people to visit Bethlehem this holiday season, one-third fewer than last year and down sharply from before the uprising began. ``Considering the gulf crisis, it's an okay number,'' he said. Several American, Hungarian and German church choirs that were expected to perform on Christmas Eve in Bethlehem have canceled their trips, apparently out of concern about the gulf crisis, other ministry officials said. The only two currently scheduled to perform are the chancel choir of the First United Methodist Church of Oklahoma City and Jerusalem's Living Stones Community Choir.

DOC.HEAD: America's Compassion For Needy Declining, Mayors Say
DOC.TEXT: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf prvs, `Nine cities...' with comments from shelter group head

America's compassion for the hungry and homeless is losing ground to hostility and frustration over problems that won't go away and will only get worse, the United States Conference of Mayors said Wednesday. The conference, in its report on hunger and homelessness in America's cities, also warned of a growing gap between the plight of the needy and the resources to help them. The survey of 30 cities found that requests for food aid were up 22 percent in 1990, while demand for emergency shelter increased by 24 percent. By comparison, emergency food resources were up only 4 percent, and available shelter beds increased by 3 percent. The report, compiled annually since 1985, cited insufficient low-income housing, inadequate care of the mentally ill, illicit drugs and the weak economy for the increasing numbers of the desperately poor. What is equally troubling, it said, is that Americans are losing the will to care. Boston Mayor Raymond L. Flynn spoke at a news conference of the ``growing hostility'' toward those in need of a helping hand. ``What should disturb the American people is the growing intolerance that too many people feel toward the social and economic problems that are facing America's cities and streets,'' he said. ``We as an American public don't reach out to help one another like we used to,'' said Mayor Sue Myrick of Charlotte, N.C. ``We don't share like we used to. We've become a very selfish nation.'' Flynn and Myrick are co-chairs of the conference's Task Force on Hunger and Homelessness. Thirteen of the 30 cities surveyed reported negative changes in public attitudes toward the homeless, and another seven said changes were both good and bad. ``People are tired of the fact that the problem remains,'' said officials in Saint Paul. ``In a recent survey of local needs, homelessness was noted by just one percent of the tally,'' Portland reported. Nine cities said they had taken actions to limit the access of the homeless to public areas. New York recently banned panhandling in its subways because of frequent complaints from passengers. Peter Smith, president of Partnership for the Homeless, a nationwide private shelter network, said that while individual contributions to help the homeless are increasing, he agreed with the mayors that ``substantial parts of the general public have lost patience'' with the failure of the public sector to address the problem. Smith said his group, which has estimated the nationwide homeless population at 2 million, is urging churches, synagogues, public facilities and private office buildings to open their doors to the homeless during the holiday season. Among the findings: -Thirteen cities said emergency food facilities can't meet demand. Requests for food can't be met 14 percent of the time. Three-fourths of the cities said people relied on emergency rations as a steady source of food. ``Most food banks are able to supply only enough food to last a family for one to two days. Even with other sources of income and support, this is not sufficient to provide an adequate amount of food,'' Seattle officials said. -Soup kitchens in 86 percent of the cities must on occasion turn people away. ``Some sites are having to close down for several days a month when food supplies run out,'' according to Cleveland officials. -Shelters in 70 percent of the cities must turn away homeless families. Nineteen perent of requests go unmet. The average increase in requests for shelter was 24 percent, ranging from 142 percent in Charleston, which was hit be Hurricane Hugo, to 50 percent in Charlotte and between 5 and 10 percent in Chicago, Louisville, Phoenix and Saint Paul. -Single men comprised 51 percent of the homeless, families with children make up 34 percent and single women 12 percent. The cities reported that 46 percent of the homeless population is black, 34 percent is white, 15 percent is Hispanic, 3 percent is Native American and 1 percent is Asian. -People considered mentally ill account for 28 percent of the homeless. Substance abusers make up 38 percent and 6 percent were reported to have AIDS or HIV-related illness. Flynn noted that the number of people in state mental institutions dropped from 505,000 in 1955 to less than 118,000 today, and that many of these people, with no place to go, ``were sentenced to America's streets, grates, doorways and park benches.'' He said the federal budget for subsidized low-income housing has trickled down to almost nothing over the past decade, another reason more people are without homes. ``The Federal government has walked away, now with the states' downturn in their economies they are walking away, so the cities are getting a double-whammy... the cities are dealing with the problem alone.'' ``We haven't dealt with the basic social problems in this country for a long time,'' Myrick said. ``Anything we do in putting money into homeless shelters is a band-aid approach.'' Eighty-seven percent of the cities used locally generated revenues to finance aid to the homeless, ranging from $26,000 in New Orleans to $131 million in New York. All accepted federal funds from the McKinney Homeless Assistance Act, going from $23,000 in San Juan to $36 million in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Moroccan Government Prosecutes Dozens Arrested During Riots
DOC.TEXT: Authorities began trials Wednesday for a prominent labor leader and dozens of other suspects arrested in riots that broke out during a general strike last week. The labor official, Mohamed Titna Alaoui, regional secretary in Fez for the General Union of Moroccan Workers, could face a five-year prison. He is charged with inciting rebellion and spreading false information. Lawyers from three human rights groups are representing him. Rioting broke out in Fez and other cities on Friday during a one-day, nationwide general strike for higher wages. The strike was called by Alaoui's federation and another labor group. The government says five people were killed, but unions and human rights activists put the death toll at more than 30. One of the charges against Alaoui is that he gave exaggerated information about the number of deaths. About 200 people were arrested in Fez during the riots, and officials said 52 of them would appear in court this week. Dozens more have begun appearing in court in Rabat and Tangier, where disturbances also took place. On Monday, Prime Minister Azzedine Laraki proposed that the rioting be investigated by a commission of executive branch officials and lawmakers from various parties. The opposition has rejected the plan, saying the commission should be completely independent of the executive branch. The severity of the rioting has been widely attributed to poverty in Morocco's cities. Many rioters were young people who, according to opposition leaders, are frustrated by the lack of job opportunities.

DOC.HEAD: Police Investigate Top Officers In Arms Purchase Case
DOC.TEXT: The military establishment has been shaken by a widening investigation into the Israeli air force involving millions of dollars in suspected graft from purchases of U.S. military equipment. Brig. Gen. Rami Dotan, once in charge of Israel's military purchases in the United States, and an air force colonel already are under arrest. News reports Wednesday said more arrests were expected. Leading officers appeared Wednesday on Israel television to discuss the case, which involves suspected bribes and diversion of equipment. They called it a crushing blow to the military's elite air corps, which is regarded as the first line of defense for Israel. Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron said the charges, if true, amounted to treason. He pledged a thorough investigation, adding: ``We shall go until the end and cleanse this dirt from out midst.'' Ezer Weizman, a former defense minister and air force chief, said that if the charges were true, Dotan had harmed national security. It is ``as though 100 planes had been shot down,'' Weizman said in interviews with Israel television and radio. Dotan, one of the highest-ranking officers ever questioned in a weapons scandal, was arrested in October and resigned as air force chief of logistics. As is normal under the Israeli justice system, no charges have been brought because the investigation against him is not complete. But public anger over the alleged corruption heightened this week with news reports that a plea bargain was in the works that could limit full disclosure of the corruption. Two leading newspapers argued in editorials against any such deal. The military spokesman's office declined comment on the case. The allegations against Dotan follow several cases of ex-officers or reserve officers playing a role in illegal arms deals. Reserve army Lt. Col. Yair Klein was convicted last month of illegally selling arms and military expertise in Colombia. Klein claims he was helping farmers fight left-wing rebels, but the Colombian government has charged he armed and trained drug traffickers. One accusation against Dotan is that he swindled the air force out of money and equipment, according to Israel television. Millions of dollars worth of spare parts and equipment recenlt purchased by the force never reached their destination, the television said. Since his arrest, Dotan has been questioned about pocketing up to $10 million in bribes in procuring air force equipment in the United States, newspapers have reported. Much of the alleged fraud was committed while Dotan headed the Defense Ministry's acquisition delegation in New York in 1984-1985, the reports said. The Yedioth Ahronoth daily said the Romanian-born Dotan is an expert on fighter jet engines and also was involved in a recent decision in choosing between two well-known American companies to supply engines for U.S.-made F-16 jets. On Tuesday, a colonel in Dotan's unit, not formally identified in public documents, was arrested and ordered held on suspicion he received ``privileges'' from Dotan in exchange for keeping quiet about the alleged fraud, news reports said. Dozens of others were being questioned and more arrests were expected, the reports added. Israeli media also said it was suspected that Dotan plotted to attack another Israeli who informed on the racketeering to police last summer. Yedioth quoted an unidentified sergeant as saying Dotan offered to pay him $50,000 to ``silence'' Ofer Pa'il, a former employee of the Defense Ministry acquisitions office in New York. Military analyst Ron Ben-Ishai wrote in Yedioth that the military was uneasy about the scandal's possible effect on U.S. military aid of $1.8 billion a year, a large chunk of which goes to the air force.

DOC.HEAD: Nepalese Public Workers Strike for Better Living Conditions
DOC.TEXT: Most government workers showed up at their jobs but refused to work Wednesday in a strike over living conditions in this Himalayan kingdom, a labor spokesman said. More than 100,000 of Nepal's estimated 127,000 employees wore black arm bands and participated in the strike, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. He said the strikers spent most of the day basking in the sun. They are striking to demand better transportation, housing and education for their children. The spokesman for the Civil Servants' Association said the protests will continue until the government fulfills the demands. Government officials said they had begun a dialogue with the strikers to address their grievances. Hospitals, telecommunications and other essential services were excluded from the strike. The labor spokesman said the strike was peaceful.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Firm Ordered to Pay Back Wages
DOC.TEXT: The state Labor Department on Wednesday ordered a company to pay back wages to 16 people who portrayed Santa Claus and Santa's helpers during last year's Christmas season. Ciresi & Associates of Newbury, Ohio, hired people to work in malls across upstate New York last year, said Doug Myers, department spokesman. ``It's simply shameful that Santa and his helpers can bring such joy to so many New Yorkers and end up with nothing more valuable than lumps of coal in their stockings,'' Myers said. Myers said Ciresi & Associates was ordered to pay $4,821.92 in back wages and fined $850. But labor officials have to find the company first. Letters sent to its last known address have been returned unopened, Myers said, and it was not listed in the Newbury telephone directory Wednesday. There's no evidence the company is hiring Santas to work in New York this Christmas season, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Eighty-two Passengers Evacuated from Beached Lake Tahoe Paddle-Wheeler
LaserPhoto SLT2
With AM-Storms Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of a paddle-wheel cruise boat deliberately ran his craft aground in a sheltering cove after being caught in a raging storm on Lake Tahoe, and 82 passengers had to be evacuated. No major injuries were reported, but many passengers suffered severe seasickness. The Tahoe Queen stern-wheeler was on its way back from a dinner cruise Tuesday night when the storm struck. Nearby Reno had wind gusts to 65 mph. The pilot, Dave Clark, managed to steer the craft to Bitler's Pier, a sandy area near Round Hill on the lake's south shore, near its normal docking area at a marina, said Tim Smith, Douglas-Tahoe Fire Department battalion chief. ``The bow was beached purposely,'' Smith said. ``He (Clark) did a remarkable job.'' ``A couple hundred yards north of where they were and they would have been pushed in on rocks,'' Smith said. ``It's anybody's guess what would have happened then.'' Smith said the waves were the worst he's seen in 18 years. ``It was just like being on the ocean,'' he said. ``The weather just took a turn for the worse that just was not predicted.'' Suzanne Nielsen, general manager of the Tahoe Queen, said Clark is licensed for ocean-going vessels. The vessel's gangway was wrenched from the bow, but crew members and rescue workers managed to secure it from the starboard side to an outcropping of rocks. Smith said rescue workers then extended a ladder from shore, and the passengers were evacuated one at a time while the boat remained about 30 feet offshore.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Says Layoffs Will Be Needed
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro of Cuba said Wednesday that layoffs are needed to cope with his government's economic squeeze, the official Cuban news agency reported. For years, Cuba has suffered from a U.S. trade embargo. Now, bargain-rate Soviet oil supplies are being curtailed, and money to tap alternate sources is short. In an address to more than 350 foreign university students, Castro referred to the problems in procuring enough oil for his Caribbean island. ``For now we have things arranged, but one has to think about a more critical era,'' Castro was quoted as saying by Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico City. ``It would be necessary to reduce labor activity in some plaes, without failing to assure a salary to the affected workers.'' The report did not quote the Communist leader as specifying the number of layoffs he believes will be necessary, nor was any date given. Soviet officials have threatened phased reduction of overall economic aid to Cuba, which reportedly accounts for $4 billion to $5 billion a year. U.S. sources say a marked decline in Soviet purchases of Cuban sugar at prices substantially higher than world market levels has reduced another form of subsidy for Cuba's economy.

DOC.HEAD: FTC OKs Consent Agreement Allowing Roche to Acquire Genentech
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday approved a Swiss pharmaceutical company's acquisition of a leading U.S. biotechnology firm but required the Swiss concern to issue U.S. licenses for its patents for AIDS treatment. The commission said acquisition of controlling interest in Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco, Calif., by Roche Holding Ltd. might substantially lessen competition in the U.S. market for CD-4-based therapeutics for the treatment of AIDS. It told Roche that for 10 years it must grant U.S. license under its patents for CD-4-based therapeutics to anyone who requests a license. The vote was 3-1 on a consent agreement that allowed the acquisition while committing Roche to modifying business arrangements with other companies. Commissioner Deborah K. Owen, dissenting, said there were ``as yet no firms or products'' in the U.S. market for such drugs and therefore ``drawing conclusions about competitive performance in that market in the relatively distant future is speculative at best.'' Commissioner Andrew J. Strenio Jr. said he would have preferred securing relief apart from the consent agreement, but agreed with the majority that there were sufficient grounds to give final approval to the consent agreement. Commissioner Roscoe Starek III did not participate. Roche markets many pharmaceutical products in the United States and conducts extensive research and development in biotechnology. The commission said its acquisition of Genentech could also lessen competition in the world market for vitamin C and in the U.S. market for therapeutic drugs that treat growth deficiency. The commission, which put the agreement on the public record for comment, also required Roche to either break up Genentech's partnership with Lubrizol, which has researched and patented a new vitamin C process, or dispose of the partnership's vitamin C assets. A consent agreement is for settlement purposes only and does not amount to admission of a law violation.

DOC.HEAD: Headed for Gulf: Marine Unit With Special History
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf: ``A Company,'' to fix grammar, ``composed'' sted ``comprised''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 150 leathernecks from the nation's oldest Marine post are being sent to the Persian Gulf, the first time the company has been deployed for a military operation since 1906, the Pentagon said Wednesday. ``A'' Company is stationed at the Marine Barracks here, and the unit's colorful history includes the 1859 capture of insurrectionist John Brown at Harper's Ferry, W.Va. ``A'' Company, composed of about 150 infantrymen, is commanded by Capt. Bryan P. McCoy, 28, of Papillion, Neb. It's scheduled to leave Dec. 27 for Camp Lejeune, N.C., to join the 2nd Marine Division. It later will be sent to the gulf area. The Barracks was established in 1801. The last time its Marines were deployed for a military operation was in 1906 when a detachment was assigned to the expeditionary battalions sent to Cuba for pacification duty. Barracks Marines served in 1837 against the Seminole Indians in Florida. They also defended the nation's capital in the War of 1812 and served in the war with Mexico and the Spanish-American War. In recent years, Barracks Marines have served mainly ceremonial duties. They perform wreath-laying ceremonies at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery, and they march in the Sunset Parades held each Tuesday evening during the summer at the Iwo Jima Memorial. The Barracks Marines also provide security for the president's mountain retreat at Camp David, Md., and serve as guards at White House arrival ceremonies for foreign dignitaries. Capt. Cathy Engels, a public affairs officer at the Barracks, said the Marines at her post are trained infantrymen. In August, the unit was officially designated alight infantry battalion; before that it had a ceremonial status.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Recession Ravaging Minds, Bodies of Africa's Children
DOC.TEXT: Hunger, disease, war and years of economic hardship are ravaging the bodies of Africa's children and traumatizing their minds, the U.N. Children's Fund said Wednesday. While the situation of children in much of the world has improved, children in Africa have quietly fallen victim, often fatally, to cuts in social spending and wars in which they are killed or turned into child killers, the organization said. At a ceremony to launch its 1991 report on the State of the World's Children, the UNICEF director in the Ivory Coast, Malick Sene, listed statistics he said were ``a scandal'' and challenged the morality of a world tat allows such horrors. Sene is from Mali. He said Africa is the only continent where social spending has been cut dramatically, where most children never go to school and where most people wake daily to the fear of not finding enough food. Africa has the world's highest rate of child deaths from easily preventable disease and infections - more than one-third of the 15 million deaths each year attributed to such causes. Nearly half the world's 25 million refugees are African children and their mothers. Sene said Africans have done little to combat such new social phenonena as the large numbers of street children created by poverty and urban migration, and the deadly AIDS virus that in Africa affects women and children in equal numbers to male victims. ``Most terrifying of all is the situation of children embroiled in conflicts despite themselves - child soldiers, child killers (created by) conflicts whose violence will produce incalculable traumas,'' he said. ``What can we say about the particularly sad scandal of refugee children, for example - scores of thousands just in our region today. Exploited children, enslaved children, children daily ravaged by famine and hunger while we talk of human rights for adults,'' Sene said. Such outrages against children pose a moral problem that UNICEF believes can be solved if developed countries keep their promises to improve the lives of the world's children using money diverted from defense spending, he said. Sene said UNICEF estimates the $20 billion needed to produce healthier children by the turn of the century amounts to just 10 days of world expenditure on armies and munitions. African governments, particularly the military administrations that hold sway in West Africa, long have been criticized for allocating large amounts of their budgets for defense and little for social services. Health and Social Protection Minister Alain Ekra of the Ivory Coast, one of a handful of civilian governments in the region, said the health of his relatively wealthy country's children has deteriorated. Last year, the Ivory Coast cut the ministry's budget by 30 percent. ``The situation of children and women improved rapidly in the first two decades after our independence (in 1960) thanks to appreciable efforts by the government,'' he said. ``Unhappily, because of a runaway birth rate and persistent economic recession, we are seeing a stagnation, even a deterioration in the situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Embassy: U.S. Drug Agents Have Resumed Raids in Peru
DOC.TEXT: American drug agents have resumed raids on cocaine traffickers in Peru's jungle despite reported conflicts with the military, the U.S. Embassy said Wednesday. Army sources, meanwhile, denied that soldiers had interfered in American enforcement operations in the area. U.S. DEA agents are attacking ``any target that arises,'' an embassy spokesman said. Bad weather and vacations for the holidays are keeping the number of helicopter raids below normal levels, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Drug Enforcement Administation chief Robert Bonner said Tuesday in Washington that agents had suspended operations in the Upper Huallaga Valley because of interference by Peruvian armed forces. The DEA and Peruvian police operate a helicopter base in the valley, the world's main source of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine. The valley is also a center of operations by Peru's two leftist rebel groups. The Washington Post on Wednesday reported the State Department is considering removing Peru from the list of countries cooperating with U.S. anti-drug efforts. Removing Peru from the list would require the United States to cut off most of its aid to Peru. It would also require Washington to oppose loans to Peru by the International Monetary Fund and other multinational institutions. Presidential and Foreign Ministry officials said Wednesday they had no comment on Bonner's statements. An Interior Ministry spokesman denied the armed forces had ever interfered with DEA operations. The spokesman said relations between the army and the anti-drug police are ``normal.'' The Interior Ministry is in charge of Peruvian police forces. After taking office July 28, Fujimori appointed active army officers to most top posts in the ministry. An army officer at the Military Joint Command also denied that soldiers had hindered DEA raids in the Huallaga. ``If anything, it is the DEA that is interfering with army operations in the zone,'' said the officer without elaborating. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The United States and Peru's armed forces have often clashed over anti-drug strategy in the Huallaga. Peruvian officers have made clear they regard the guerrillas as a much greater threat than the drug traffickers. Political violence the past 10 years has claimed nearly 20,000 lives. The military believes anti-drug operations in the valley could push local peasants into the rebel ranks. Some 200,000 Peruvians are thought to be involved in growing and processing coca. The rebels provide protection to the drug traffickers in exchange for guns and money, police and peasants in the area say. In 1989, U.S. officials accused the army general in charge of anti-rebel operations in the Huallaga of allowing drug traffickers to operate in the region. The general was later transferred. In September, Fujimori refused to accept $36 million in U.S. military aid to fight drug trafficking. He said Peru needs more economic aid to help the peasants who grow coca leaves.

DOC.HEAD: Galileo Flyby Spurs NASA `Aliens' to Conclude There's Life on Earth
LaserPhotos LA6, LA7
DOC.TEXT: NASA scientists pretending to be explorers from another world said Wednesday they had concluded life exists on Earth, and it may be intelligent. The scientists based their conclusinon on data from the Jupiter-bound Galileo spacecraft. ``The accumulated evidence we have ... would give your hypothetical explorer a very strong indication you had biological activity on Earth,'' said Torrence Johnson, Galileo's chief scientist at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Galileo's study of Earth illustrates how researchers use data collected by spacecraft to reach conclusions about other planets. Galileo boomeranged past Earth and the moon Dec. 8, using the planet's gravity as a slingshot to speed it up and expand its orbit around the sun so it can reach Jupiter in 1995. Scientists used the opportunity to treat Earth as an alien planet, ordering Galileo to snap a few thousand pictures and make numerous measurements. They outlined their findings during a Wednesday news conference. Measurements made by Galileo's infrared light-detecting instrument showed Earth's atmosphere is rich in nitrous oxide, methane and oxygen, indicating ``there's a lot of life'' on the planet, said laboratory scientist Robert W. Carlson. Another of Galileo's instruments picked up non-natural radio signals that got stronger closer to the planet, which would make alien scientists strongly suspect Earth has intelligent life that makes radio broadcasts, Johnson said. The spaceship also detected lightning bolts, made measurements to help explain creation of the Northern and Southern Lights, determined the planet is warmed by a mild ``greenhouse effect'' and detected a high-altitude ice cloud that helps cause the annual hole in the protective ozone layer over Antarctica. On the moon, Galileo found evidence of a huge volcanic eruption 4 billion years ago. That shows such volcanic activity occurred about 200 million years earlier than previously believed, said Brown University geologist Jim Head. The spacecraft's pictures also confirmed the existence of a 1,200-mile-wide meteorite impact basin on the southern hemisphere of the moon's far side, the largest such crater ever identified, Head said. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration released nine more of Galileo's photos of the Earth and moon Wednesday. One was a mosaic, assembled from 11 separate pictures, showing all of icy Antarctica. Others showed huge lunar craters, a color map of minerals on the moon's surface, clouds swirling over South America, and Australia's larger lakes and Great Barrier Reef. The pictures didn't display evidence of life on Earth because Galileo's closest approach to the planet, at a distance of 597 miles, was over the southwest Atlantic Ocean. The detail in the pictures was inadequate to reveal buildings, scientists said. NASA also displayed two short movies, made by assembling hundreds of Galileo's still photos, showing the Earth and moon spinning. ``Top that, Ted Turner!'' Head declared after the colorized lunar movie was played. He was referring to media mogul Turner's controversial practice of colorizing classic films. Also Wednesday, Galileo fired its thrusters repeatedly to aim itself properly for its close encounter with the asteroid Gaspra next Oct. 29, said project manager Bill O'Neil. Galileo will swing past Earth again Dec. 8, 1992, for a final ``gravity slingshot'' maneuver to help it reach Jupiter. In July 1995, Galileo will separate into an orbiter and a probe. Both will reach Jupiter in December 1995. The probe will descend into Jupiter's atmosphere, returning data to the orbiter until the probe is crushed by intense atmospheric pressure. The orbiter will circle Jupiter for at least two years, studying the planet and making closeup pictures of its 10 largest moons.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says NASA Can't Attract Needed Experts, Calls For Changes
DOC.TEXT: NASA has lost the glamour that once attracted top people to its ranks and the agency is now not competitive with industry and academia in hiring of the best and brightest, according to a federal report released Wednesday. ``Contrary to the popular saying, at NASA you do have to be a rocket scientist to fill many of its demanding positions,'' said the final, full report of the Advisory Committee on the Future of the U.S. Space Program. The study said that the excitement of working for NASA has faded and that the space agency in its hiring now is ``not competitive for experienced engineers and senior technically-qualified managers.'' But to get such people, NASA now loses out to world-class industrial and academic institutions seeking the same sort of talent, the report said. ``In the past, the challenge and excitement of the space program has been a significant inducement for exactly the type of people one wishes to attract,'' said the report. Recently, however, it said, criticism of the space program and its participants, and the image of public service in general, have made NASA a less attractive employer. Because of these problems, the committee said it was not confident ``that in the future NASA will be able to obtain or retain the necessary cadre of skilled personnel in a field where the most critical asset is the talent of the individual participants.'' The 12-member advisory committee was appointed four months ago to study the civil space program and to make recommendations to Vice President Dan Quayle and to NASA Administrator Richard Truly. A summary of the report was released last week; the full report was issued Wednesday. To help NASA attract special skills, the committee called for reforms in civil service regulations that would allow the agency to pay higher salaries for specific skills and to give more flexibility in establishing pay schedules in certain circumstances. Among the other recommendations of the committee were: -Reduce reliance on the space shuttle and the development of new, unmanned launch vehicles to put satellites and other equipment into orbit. -Redesign Space Station Freedom with a goal of reducing costs and complexity. The space station mission, the committee said, should center on life sciences and human space operations and less on industrial process research. -Science should be given the highest priority in the space program and science activities should be maintained at or above 20 percent of the NASA budget. -NASA should not build a fifth space shuttle, but keep the fleet at four after the new orbiter, Endeavour, is delivered next year. -A longterm program should be established to carry out President Bush's goal of establishing a permanent base on the moon and the human exploration of the planet Mars, along with an effort ``to produce significant advances in space transportation and life sciences.'' Bush has said he wanted the Mars landing by 2019, but the committee said the schedule should be designed to match the availability of federal funds. -A project to study the planet Earth from orbit should be initiated and continued over several decades ``rather than a mission whose design is frozen in time.''

DOC.HEAD: Protests Continue, Romanian President Meets With Civic Alliance Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, Campeanu asked ... RESTORING Roman's full name and title. Picks up 12th graf, The Front ...
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leaders met Wednesday with President Ion Iliescu to discuss demands for a new broad-based Cabinet as strikes and protests continued against the government. Several thousand anti-government demonstrators rallied in Timisoara, 280 miles northwest of Bucharest, where they have been protesting all week. It was in Timisoara one year ago that the country's popular revolution began. In Bucharest, several hundred students demonstrated outside the state television building in support of Dumitru Iuga, head of the Free TV Union. Iuga has been on a hunger strike for 19 days demanding the ouster of television executives left over from the Communist dictatorship. All domestic flights were canceled and international flights were subject to long delays as employees of the state airline Tarom continued their strike. The independent daily Romania Libera said the navigators' union from the Black Sea port of Constanta called for a general strike as a ``sign of solidarity'' with students who are boycotting classes. It did not say when such a strike would begin or if there had been any positive response from workers. In Timisoara, student strikers have been joined by about 50,000 workers from 11 area factories. Union leaders in the city said Wednesday that 16 more factories had joined the warning strike. They did not say how many workers the factories employed. Meanwhile, a delegation from the non-parliamentary opposition Civic Alliance met with Iliescu to press demands for the formation of a ``government of national unity.'' Marian Munteanu, a prominent student leader who was elected temporary president of the Civic Alliance last week, said he was ``very satisfied'' with the talks. National Liberal Party leader Radu Campeanu urged the formation of a unity government in talks with the president last Thursday. Campeanu asked Iliescu to replace Premier Petre Roman with ``a neutral person not affiliated with the National Salvation Front.'' The Front, which includes former Communist officials, ruled provisionally until May, when it won free elections. Critics say the government has failed to resolve the nation's economic woes. There has been growing public dissatisfaction with the government as economic reforms, including price increases, have taken effect. Roman, in line with his program of sweeping economic reform designed to create a market economy, urged parliament Wednesday to expedite a law granting farmers and peasants ownership of the land they cultivate, thus disbanding the state farms set up under Communist rule. The law would give peasants the land they work and the right to buy more. However, no one would be permitted to own more than 250 acres. Last year's revolution ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was executed on Christmas Day along with his wife, Elena.

DOC.HEAD: Icy Wind Chills Grip the Plains; Snow in the Midwest
DOC.TEXT: The Arctic Express roared into the northern Plains on Wednesday, bringing icy wind chills and snow. At midday, Kalispell was the warmest spot in Montana at 5 below zero. Great Falls reported 22 below. The low temperatures combined with brisk wind to produce wind chill factors as low as 77 below zero at Dillon, in the state's southwestern corner. Wind chills ranged from 40 below to 60 below zero across a large portion of North Dakota, 50 to 60 below zero across South Dakota, 50 to 65 below across Idaho and 40 to 45 below over much of Nebraska. Blizzard conditions were expected into Thursday over the Tehachapi mountains of central California, as well as the eastern slopes of the central Sierra of Nevada. Rain extended across the Florida panhandle, southern Alabama and southwest Georgia. Rain was scattered over the central half of the California coast into central California. Freezing rain in southeastern Nebraska changed to light rain over northwest Missouri and southwest Iowa and back to freezing rain over east central Iowa. Snow fell over northern Illinois, southern Wisconsin, central Upper Michigan, northwest Wisconsin, Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota and much of Nebraska. Snow also fell from northwest Kansas, through Wyoming, northern Utah, northern Nevada, the Idaho panhandle and parts of Oregon into southeast Washington. High temperature records were set in Providence, R.I., at 57 degrees, Daytona Beach, Fla., at 87 and Barrow, Alaska at 27. Low temperature records broken included Billings, Mont., 17 below zero, Casper, Wyo., 16 below, and Great Falls, Mont., 25 below. Wednesday morning's low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 25 below zero at Great Falls. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 21 below zero at Great Falls to 87 at Bartow, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Man Won't Be Prosecuted Again in Case Of Woman With 46 Personalities
DOC.TEXT: A judge honored a prosecutor's request and dismissed charges Wednesday against a man accused of sexually assaulting a woman with 46 personalities. Prosecutor Joseph Paulus said he asked that charges against Mark Peterson be dismissed after consulting with multiple personality experts and determining a retrial would be harmful to the victim. Circuit Judge Robert Hawley overturned Peterson's Nov. 8 conviction on sexual assault charges earlier this week because the defense had not been allowed to have a psychiatrist examine the woman before trial. Paulus, whose handling of the case has been widely criticized, said even though he won't reprosecute Peterson he was satisfied justice was done. ``The jury verdict, although now set aside on a legal technicality, sent a strong message to the community that mentally ill individuals in our society must be protected from those who prey upon them,'' he said. The lawyer for the 27-year-old woman, who suffers from multiple personality disorder and has 46 personalities, said his client wanted another trial to ensure that her attacker went to jail, but he advised her against it. ``Right now, we are trying to get her to a doctor who can give her some long-term care,'' said the lawyer, George Curtis. ``She has been able to (get) only some free treatment that is available through government and it is infrequent.'' Hawley accepted the prosecutor's recommendation and dismissed the charge of second-degree sexual assault against Peterson, 29, of Oshkosh. The decision clears Peterson, an ex-grocery store bagger, of any criminal wrongdoing in taking the woman out on a coffee date and having sex with her June 11 in his car two days after they met. It is a crime in Wisconsin for someone to have sex with a mentally ill person who cannot understand the consequences of their actions. The perpetrator must also know the person is mentally ill. In convicting Peterson, the jury accepted Paulus' arguments that Peterson knew of the woman's mental illness and manipulated one of her personalities to have sex with her. Peterson would not comment after Wednesday's dismissal of the charge. His attorney, Mary Lou Robinson, called on Paulus to publicly apologize for bringing the case to trial. Paulus said the prosecution of the case was legitimate and claimed Ms. Robinson was trying to exploit the situation for Peterson's gain. The trial, in which the woman testified as six different personalities, attracted international attention and raised new questions about sexual consent and mental illness. Curtis, the woman's lawyer, said the stress and publicity surrounding the trial has caused his client's mental illness to worsen. Since the case became public, the victim's personalities have grown from 18 to 46. Police have been called to her home after she reported one personality was trying to kill her.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Lowers Another Key Interest Rate as Economy Slumps
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to give magnitude of rate reduction, \ point, also given in 8th graf
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve, amidst fresh evidence of a weakening economy, lowered another key interest rate on Wednesday, analysts said. The Bush administration said it expected banks to follow the Fed's lead to rejuvenate consumer borrowing, but there was no rush to do so. Economists said the central bank injected reserves into the banking system to push the federal funds rate - the interest that banks charge to make loans to each other - down by \ point to 7 percent. A day earlier, the Fed cut its discount rate, the interest it charges for direct loans to commercial banks, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, the first reduction in four years. The Fed's action came as the Commerce Department lowered its already low estimate of the economy's pace in the July-September quarter, putting the annual rate of growth in the gross national product at an anemic 1.4 percent. Analysts said the downward revision in the GNP report showed that the country was facing severe difficulty even before the Iraq's invasion of Kuwait battered the economy with soaring energy prices. Many economists were looking for the fourth quarter GNP report to signal the start of a recession, with some guessing that the contraction of output during the period could be as sharp as a 3.5 percent drop in GNP at an annual rate. They base that estimate on a torrent of dismal economic news during the period from rising unemployment to falling industrial production and weak consumer sales. It is these statistics that are prompting to the Fed to aggressively ease interest rates in the hopes that lower borrowing costs will spur such interest-rate sensitive sectors of the economy as housing and car sales. Economists said that the reduction in the funds rate engineered - but not publicly confirmed - by the Fed on Wednesday amounted to only a 0.25 percentage point cut. It would be the fourth quarter-point cut in the funds rate that the Fed has spurred in the past two months. On Wednesday, the Fed cut its discount rate, the interest it charges to make direct loans to commercial banks, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent. While a cut in the discount rate is the most dramatic signal that the central bank can send of its desire to fight a slumping economy with lower interest rates, changes in the funds rate are considered just as crucial because of the impact they have on banks' cost of funds. Normally, the credit easing moves the Fed has made would be enough to spur banks to slash their benchmark prime lending rate, which is used as the basis for calculating many consumer and business loans. However, the country's major banks, who have been facing severe losses on bad real estate loans this year, showed no move toward making such a cut Wednesday although analysts said they still expected a reduction within days. The prime lending rate has been stuck at 10 percent since last January. The Bush administration let it be known that it expected banks to do their part to spur a flagging economy. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that while a reduction in the prime rate was a ``market decision'' it was normal that ``a discount-rate cut reverberates through the system.'' The Commerce Department GNP report continued to revise downward economic growth for the third quarter. It initially estimated growth during this period at 1.8 percent in October, but revised that to 1.7 percent a month later. The GNP is the nation's total output of goods and services and its broadest measure of economic health. Economist Kermit Baker of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., said the downward revision ``is a trajectory of where the economy is headed. It indicates the fourth quarter will be a lot weaker than the third.'' Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, agreed, noting other government reports show ``the economy is falling rather rapidly in the fourth quarter'' and will continue to fall during the first part of 1991. Highlighting the continuing deterioration, the department also reported on Wednesday that construction of single-family houses in November dropped to a level not seen since the 1981-82 recession even though the overall construction figure rose by 9.3 percent, solely because of a big increase in multi-family building. The government reported Wednesday that a GNP measure of inflation was unchanged at an annual rate of 4.2 percent in the third quarter. That measure was expected to rise significantly faster in the final three months of the year given what energy prices did following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Contributing most to the downward revision in third-quarter GNP growth was weaker consumer spending and a wider trade deficit than first estimated. Consumer spending was revised from a 3.6 percent annual rate of growth to just 2.7 percent while the nation's trade deficit increase was boosted to $1.9 billion, more than three times higher than last month's estimate.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Homeless from Earthquake Passes 10,000
DOC.TEXT: The number of people forced from their homes following a killer earthquake in eastern Sicily has surpassed 10,000, officials reported Wednesday. The earthquake a week ago destroyed part of a town, Carlentini, where 12 people were crushed to death. Five others suffered fatal heart attacks. Alvaro Gomez y Paloma, a prefect overseeing aid for victims, said Wednesday that 10,026 people had been forced to leave their homes because of the damage in the province. More than 1,000 are living in tents set up by security forces. Authorities have found quarters in undamaged buildings for nearly 3,000 others. The rest are staying with relatives or friends. A series of very minor shocks rattled the area again Wednesday evening.

DOC.HEAD: Low-Key Christmas for Expatriates in Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Christmas doesn't seem much like a season of goodwill and peace for the dwindling band of Christian civilians in Persian Gulf countries close to the Kuwait crisis zone. A children's choir delighted audiences in Manama with traditional carols, but their conductor had to keep whispering ``smile, smile'' to the grim-faced kids as they sang: ``Dear Father Christmas we want you to know ``We'd like to build a snowman but we haven't any snow ``We want just a little, enough for one day ``And when we've built our snowman you can take the rest away.'' It was appropriate for Bahrain's balmy winter, where snow is seen only on Christmas cards or in movies. The children may now see the real stuff earlier than they thought. Many Western expatriate workers are sending their families to Europe or North America for Christmas and few of the families expect to come back soon. Many bought air tickets weeks ago but hadn't decided whether to use them. Now, with Britain advising British dependents to quit Bahrain, Qatar, eastern Saudi Arabia, Riyadh and Tabuk, most are likely to leave. Some other Westerners in Bahrain will take their cue from their departure, since the estimatd 4,500 Britons make up the largest Western expatriate community here. Half the island's 500,000 residents are expatriates, with the bulk of them from Asian countries. Washington is not advising the 750 U.S. citizens in Bahrain to leave. It told them the island would be well protected in event of hostilities, and Americans would be helped if in danger. The departures make it harder for the Western families remaining. Schools tailored to the foreign communities lose teachers and some shut down. Putting dampening the holiday spirit was the Bahrain government's decision to cancel celebrations on the Dec. 16 national day, citing the crisis following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. In the past, glittering streamers of electric lights put up for national day stayed up until the Christian season ended. This year - no lights. Conductor Richard Chalkley told the adult choir at the dress rehearsal for the Manama Singers annual Christmas concert they should try to look more upbeat. ``Try to smile a little bit,'' he urged. It wasn't easy. The choir is down to 80 singers, from more than 100, and now their Filipino pianist says she'll probably go home, too. The remaining members fear they may lose more singers as the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline approaches for Iraq to leave Kuwait. That's also the date for the first rehearsal of the choir's New Year season. The swelling ranks of Western military personnel are being showered with gifts and attention from back home as Dec. 25 approaches. When the choir toured Manama's hotels singing carols, it was joined by servicemen in crewcuts who helped belt out Christmas favorites. In one hotel, almost the entire audience was made up of puzzled Kuwaiti exiles in long white robes. Their quizzical expressions dissolved after a rousing rendition of ``Rudolph The Red-Nosed Reindeer.'' Bahrain has a more relaxed attitude toward the Christian festivities than neighboring Saudi Arabia, where hundreds of thousands of Western troops are deployed. Pine trees bearing Christmas ornaments adorn Manama hotel lobbies and offices. Christmas music is played on Bahrain radio. The only restriction formerly was a tacit ban on use of the word ``Christmas.'' The term has been coming into the open lately, splashed across posters in hotels. Christmas cards are openly on sale, but some bear distinctly unpeaceful messages this year. One shows Santa with his sleigh team in the desert, with a row of tanks in the background. Most of the customers at shopping centers seem to be off-duty troops. One gift displayed in stores is a T-shirt with the words: ``I Survived Bahrain 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand: Peaceful Settlement of Gulf Crisis Possible
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand said Wednesday that a peaceful settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis is still possible and France ``isn't prohibited from taking initiatives'' to avoid war. But he told a news conference that if Iraq's intransigence makes war inevitable, ``France will not fail to fulfill its historic duty.'' He said France would participate if military action was launched against Iraqi forces in accordance with U.N. Security Council resolutions. But he said France had no plans to increase its force in Saudi Arabia beyond the nearly 10,000 troops now there or en route. Mitterrand expressed regret at the U.S. opposition to a proposed Security Council resolution that would endorse the concept of an international conference on Middle East problems, including the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. ``We're not fixing the date for next week.'' Mitterrand said. ``But we think a conference would be an indispensable means of reconciling peoples.'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has said a settlement of the Palestinian situation might prompt him to make concessions regarding Kuwait, which his troops have occupied since Aug. 2. Mitterrand suggested the proposed U.S.-Iraqi talks were doomed because of a dispute over dates. If it becomes definite that these talks will not occur, he said, France might take an initiative along with its European allies. ``Until the deadline, one must hope that dialogues can take place here and there,'' he said. ``France, in the open, not acting in silence but in conformity with the U.N.'s objectives and in consultation with its Western partners, is not prohibited from taking initiatives of this type.'' Before Jan. 15, the Security Council's deadline for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, ``many things are possible,'' Mitterrand said. ``It's not forbidden to hope.'' However, Mitterrand reiterated French's support for the Security Council's demand that Iraq withdraw unilaterally and totally. Any partial withdrawal would not be sufficient, he said. ``Time is passing,'' he said. ``The leaders of Iraq, and particularly the president, must have a clear awareness of the risks they are running.''

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Claims He Helped Persuade Saddam to Release Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Former President Daniel Ortega said Wednesday he helped persuade President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to free remaining Western hostages to reduce the likelihood of a U.S.-led attack. Ortega returned to Nicaragua on Dec. 16 from a 34-day tour of the Mideast. During his trip, he traveled twice to Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, where he met with Saddam. Before leaving, Ortega met with U.S. Ambassador Harry Shlaudeman and a veteran Mideast official from the State Department, a top-level source within Ortega's leftist Sandinista Front told The Associated Press. The source said the U.S. officials did not send Saddam any messages, but simply explained Washington's position on the Persian Gulf crisis. A longtime Sandinista militant told The Associated Press that Ortega, who lost Feb. 25 elections to Violeta Chamorro, is seeking to revive his image as a statesman. The militant said it is likely Ortega will run in Nicaragua's 1996 elections. In private conversations, the militant also said Ortega is trying to drum up financial support for the Sandinistas from Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi. In an interview, Ortega said Wednesday that although Iraqi officials favor a peaceful solution in the gulf, ``they have committed themselves so much in this situation, with such polarized positions, that it is hard for them to take the first step. ``In that sense, our actions are aimed ... so that they search for the solution within the framework of the Security Council resolution,'' Ortega said. ``What we're doing is facilitating that peaceful solution.'' The U.N. Security Council has authorized Iraq's opponents to use force if Iraq fails to leave Kuwait by Jan. 15. Ortega said that when he met Saddam and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, he broached the subject of releasing the hostages before Christmas. ``We told him that it was a very sensitive theme, a theme that was being exploited in favor of war in the zone, and that the most convenient thing was to seek a way to exit totally that situation,'' Ortega said. ``In other words, we made the presentation, and he said he would seek a way to act on that.'' Ortega said while he was in Bonn, Germany, on Dec. 5, Iraq's ambassador to that country approached him with a message from Hussein. ``The message was that within the next few hours, he would release all the foreigners,'' Ortega said. The next day, Saddam announced his intention to free all remaining foreigners.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Should Be Able to Pick Children's Schools, Alexander Says
DOC.TEXT: American parents should be able to decide what schools their children attend, President Bush's choice for education secretary said Wednesday. Government doesn't tell Americans what kind of cars to buy or where to do their shopping, so why should they be told where their children must attend school, University of Tennessee President Lamar Alexander told a group of Chattanooga News-Free Press editors. ``I don't know how we drifted into telling parents what school their child should attend. This is America. They ought to be able to decide for themselves,'' Alexander said. Alexander, a former two-term Tennessee governor, would not talk about what his policies would be as education secretary before his Senate confirmation hearings next month, but he said he doesn't believe he has sharp differences with Bush. ``In my other positions, I have been elected, so I set policy. In this job, he sets the policy. I know President Bush genuinely wants to be the education president, but he doesn't have a lot of time to do it,'' Alexander said. Alexander was appointed president of the university in July 1988. He was nominated Monday to succeed Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Declare Encephalitis Outbreak Over
DOC.TEXT: The worst outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis in Florida since 1962 is over, state health officials said Wednesday. Nine people died from the disease. The onset of cooler weather cut the numbers of mosquitos that carry the disease, leading the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services to pronounce the end of the outbreak. ``We just haven't had any cases in four weeks. The mosquito count is nil. So it was the right time to call it off,'' said health agency spokesman David Adams. In addition to the deaths, 202 people were infected with the virus and thousands more were forced to curtail nighttime activities ranging from high school football to Halloween trick-or-treat. The encephalitis outbreak also frightened tourists and put a scare into merchants worried about its impact on the economy. Cases were reported in 27 counties on both coasts stretching from Jacksonville to Miami. State health officials said outbreaks of St. Louis encephalitis run in cycles of five to 10 years, with only about five cases reported during a normal year. In the 1962 outbreak, 222 cases were reported. The outbreaks are tied to increases in the population of the culex nigrapalpus mosquito, which draws the disease from the blood of migrating birds. The viral infection causes inflammation of the brain. The average age of victims in the latest outbreak was 52, and only 5 percent involved children under age 11. The youngest person to die was 58. The most cases were reported in Orange County, home of Walt Disney World, with 27.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Interest Rates-Consumers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``If someone is in danger of losing their job, it doesn't matter how cheap the interest is, they don't want to pay it.'' - James B. Warkentin, owner of a real estate agency in McLean, Va. --- ``People have been shocked into self-discipline. ... Right now, they can't justify going deeper into debt.'' - Michael Green, sales manager at a Volvo dealership in Falls Church, Va. --- ``The Middle East thing is scaring people. The fuel costs, the way Hussein is acting. People are thinking we're going to go to war and they're a little leery of spending their dollar.'' - Bob Schmiech, finance manager at a Ford dealership in Rockville, Md.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Requests NATO Units Near Border With Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Turkey, the only NATO nation bordering Iraq, has asked the Western alliance for air units to bolster its frontier before the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, sources said Wednesday. The request for the units has to be approved by defense officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization before they could be deployed. But a NATO official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that so far there has been no opposition to the request. ``So it's not a big problem,'' he said. The requested units are from the Allied Command Europe Mobile Force, a mobile multinational force armed with conventional weapons, said a senior NATO source. Set up in 1960, it is designed to be sent at short notice to any threatened part of the European command and primarily to reduce the vulnerability of the alliance's flank regions. Turkey has asked for a force comprising 5,000 men to be in place on its southeastern border with Iraq by Jan. 15, said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity. That is the deadline set by the U.N. Security Council for Iraq to unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait or face military action. The NATO mobile force has both land and air forces, and can be deployed within a week on direct orders of the defense ministers of the 16 alliance nations. It can draw troops from a number of members, including the United States, Britain, the Netherlands, Canada and Germany. Turkey's armed forces of 800,000 troops are the second largest in the NATO alliance after the United States. About 100,000 troops are along its border with Iraq. Turkish newspapers reported the government requested the NATO units last week. The reports said it was the first time Turkey had asked NATO for such a force to strengthen its own armies on the alliance's southeastern flank. Turkish Defense Minister Husnu Dogan was quoted by the newspapers as saying the reports were baseless. ``There's been no change in our policy in this regard. We have made no such request,'' he was quoted as saying. Foreign Ministry spokesman Murat Sungar, at a weekly briefing Wednesday, would neither confirm nor deny the accounts. Turkey was singled out for support during a meeting of NATO foreign ministers on Monday and Tuesday at alliance headquarters in Brussels.
