In a statement, the ministers noted that the Persian Gulf crisis ``poses a potential threat'' to Turkey and reaffirmed their determination to go to its aid in case of attack. ``We reiterate our firm commitment to the security of the entire southern region, the strategic importance of which is highlighted by this crisis,'' it said. Under NATO's 1949 treaty, member nations agree to defend one another from armed attack.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Professor Nominated to Head U.N. Refugee Programs
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese professor was named Wednesday by the U.N. secretary-general as his choice for high commissioner for refugees, ending a 10-month search that angered some of the agency's major donors. Sadako Ogata, a U.S.-trained professor and specialist in human rights, was nominated for the U.N. post by Javier Perez de Cuellar, his office said. The General Assembly is expected to confirm the choice by acclamation Friday, U.N. officials said. Mrs. Ogata, 63, would be responsible for protecting 15 million refugees worldwide during a three-year term. She would be the first woman to hold the post that has traditionally gone to Western men, including many high-profile politicians and fund-raisers. The search for a new high commissioner has been clouded by allegations of favoritism and highhandedness by U.N. officials. Some member states, especially Western nations that are major donors of refugee aid, said they were not sufficiently consulted. The secretary-general has denied the charges. The controversy broke out in November, when it appeared that the secretary-general was about to nominate Virendra Dayal, an Indian who is his closest aide. After the complaints by Western nations, Dayal withdrew his nomination, but angrily denounced his opponents and suggested they are racist. U.N. officials said her nomination marks the beginning of a new era of sensitivity to naming women to high U.N. posts and the end of domination of the refugee post by Western European men. Her selection also recognizes Japan's formidable role in the world economy and its contribution to U.N. peacekeeping and humanitarian efforts. Her husband, Shijuruo, is deputy governor of Japan's Development Bank. Mrs. Ogata is dean of the faculty of foreign studies at Sophia University in Tokyo and professor at the Institute of International Relations for Advanced Studies on Peace and Development in Asia at the university. She became Japan's first woman minister to the United Nations in 1976, and she served as chairman of the Executive Board of the U.N. Childrens Fund from 1978-79. In those years, she was also Japan's special U.N. envoy. Mrs. Ogata is the independent expert of the U.N. Commission on Human Rights for Burma. From 1982-85, she was Japan's expert on the U.N. Commission on Human Rights. She received a doctoral degree in political science from the University of California at Berkeley in 1963. Mrs. Ogata will replace Thorvald Stoltenberg, who recently resigned to become deputy prime minister of Norway. When his withdrew his nomination in November, Dayal challenged the motives of the nations that opposed him. ``It's a feeling that you have to be a Western European to do a job of integrity,'' he told a news conference. ``It's a feeling that a Western European has to carry the burden of the white man.'' The last high commissioner, Stoltenberg, replaced Jean-Pierre Hocke, who resigned in October 1989. Hocke left under a cloud when it was disclosed that he had used a special education fund over a period of years to upgrade his airline travel to first class.

DOC.HEAD: Governor-Elect Clocked Driving 80 Mph
DOC.TEXT: Gov.-elect Lawton Chiles, rushing back to the capital for a news conference Wednesday, got a speeding ticket in Georgia for driving 80 mph in a 50 mph zone, authorities said. Chiles, driving alone in a red sedan, was pulled over by two Bainbridge police officers and issued a $70 ticket, said Police Chief Larry Funderburke. Funderburke said Chiles can avoid a Feb. 4 court date by paying the ticket by mail. An apologetic Chiles said that's exactly what he intends to do. ``I just didn't realize how fast I was going. I was thinking about getting back,'' he said. Chiles said he was in Georgia hunting quail north of Bainbridge with U.S. Sen. Sam Nunn, a longtime friend. He was returning for a news conference to announce his choice for secretary of the Department of Labor and Employment Security, Frank Scruggs. Chiles said the officers didn't recognize him or know his name. He said he was given a breathalyzer test that showed he had zero blood-alcohol content.

DOC.HEAD: President Named for New Cable Comedy Channel ^Eds: Spelling of Kreek in 2nd graf is CQ.
DOC.TEXT: One day after forming a new cable television comedy channel, Home Box Office and Viacom International on Wednesday named a Fox, Inc. executive as president of their newborn Comedy TV service. Robert M. Kreek, who has been president of Fox's cable programming division since August, will start his new job immediately, even though Comedy TV won't begin operations until early next year, an HBO spokeswoman said. The two companies on Tuesday announced they would merge their separate 24-hour comedy services - HBO's The Comedy Channel and Viacom's Ha! - in the jointly-owned, 24-hour Comedy TV service. The two comedy networks had been money-losers - about $40 million each, according to one published estimate - since they began. The Comedy Channel started in November, 1989, and Ha! on April Fool's Day this year. They served a combined total of 15 million homes that Comedy TV now will inherit. Keek, a former HBO executive based in Los Angeles, will relocate to New York, where Comedy TV will have its headquarters. He will report to a board that consists of four members each from HBO and Viacom.

DOC.HEAD: Columbus Mayor to Seek Re-Election
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Dana Rinehart, who admitted last month to having an extramarital affair with a member of his Cabinet, said Wednesday he would run for re-election to a third term next year. The announcement reversed a decision the 44-year-old Republican made in July, when he cited family, financial and political reasons for not seeking another four-year term. In August, Rinehart and his wife, Carol, announced they had separated. This fall, Rinehart at first denied but later admitted having an affair with Human Services Director Brenda Dodrill. Ms. Dodrill's husband, Douglas Matteson, sued for divorce Oct. 30 and later filed court documents alleging that Rinehart and Ms. Dodrill had been seeing each other since March. Another Republican, Franklin County Commissioner Dorothy Teater, announced her candidacy for mayor last week. City Councilman Ben Espy was expected to go unchallenged by major party figures for the Democratic endorsement.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Government Resigns, Strongest Militias Voice Dissent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CLARIFY Hoss' tenure, trims to edit. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY15
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Salim Hoss resigned on Wednesday to make way for a broad-based government that will try to end 15{ years of civil war. But Christian and Moslem militia chieftains expressed reservations that could undermine peace efforts. Hoss, a Sunni Moslem and veteran of Lebanon's turbulent politics, formed his government on Nov. 25, 1989. He presented the resignation of his 14-member Cabinet to President Elias Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic. Hrawi asked Hoss to stay on as caretaer prime minister. The new Cabinet will be charged with drafting a plan to disband the private armies that have fought each other since 1975. It is expected to include members from the main warring militias as well as political parties. However, the two strongest militias - Christian chieftain Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces and Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party - expressed doubts about the plan. ``The way the president is dealing with the question of a new government indicates he might bring in an untidy government that would stumble upon its first steps,'' Jumblatt's party said. ``This could create a dangerous power vacuum.'' Jumblatt, a member of the outgoing Cabinet, has accused Hrawi of corruption and favoritism. Hrawi's aides accused Jumblatt of ``corrupt deeds'' in his Ministry of Public Works. A Lebanese Forces statement said Geagea ``will not take part in the new Cabinet ... because it looks like it is going to be a tower of Babel.'' It said the new Cabinet would require a statesman at the helm ``with the political experience and economic know-how as well as the honesty of Prime Minister Hoss.'' Hoss, 61, a U.S.-educated banker turned politician, said before resigning that he would not accept a new term. He has headed four cabinets since 1976. Lebanon's media predict outgoing Education Minister Omar Karami will become prime minister. The 55-year-old lawyer, also a Sunni, inherited the leadership of Lebanon's second-largest city, Tripoli, from his elder brother, the late Prime Minister Rashid Karami. Rashid Karami, the longest-serving prime minister since Lebanon gained independence from France in 1943, was assassinated by a bomb put aboard an army helicopter on June 1, 1987. Hoss formed his Cabinet hours after the election of Syrian-backed Hrawi to implement an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end the civil war. Its main achievements were crushing an 11-month mutiny by rebel Gen. Michel Aoun on Oct. 13 and unification of Beirut's Moslem and Christian sectors on Dec. 3. Creating ``greater Beirut'' was a key step in the peace accord. Hoss' Cabinet also enacted constitutional reforms to distribute power equally between Moslems and Christians. Hoss' aides say privately he has been uneasy about Hrawi's insistence on making major decisions and handling state affairs exlusively. The peace accord, worked out by Lebanese lawmakers in Taif, Saudi Arabia, in October 1989, maintained the presidency for Maronites, the premiership for Sunnis and the house speakership for Shiite Moslems. It stripped the president of his traditional decision-making power, stressing such powers required ``approval of both the president and the Cabinet.'' The new government must fill 31 vacancies in Parliament by appointment and raise the number of seats from 99 to 108 to attain equality between Christians and Moslems. Christians have had a 6-to-5 edge in Parliament. Because of the civil war, no parliamentary election has been held since 1972. The house repeatedly extended its four-year terms. Plans to reconstruct Beirut, shore up the economy and reinstate government authority over the rest of Lebanon must be considered by the new Cabinet. The civil war has claimed more than 150,000 lives and caused up to $18 billion damage, according to U.N. estimates. Plans call for setting up an Arab and international fund early next year with $2 billion earmarked for reconstruction.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Authorities Arrest Man Who Fled to Italy
DOC.TEXT: A man who fled to Italy in 1988 to avoid charges that he served three women drug-laced spaghetti and raped them has voluntarily returned to Cincinnati to face the charges. Nicola Iannone, 35, struck a deal with Hamilton County prosecutors and was jailed without bond in Cincinnati to await a Dec. 27 hearing, his lawyer, Martin Pinales, said Wednesday. Pinales, who was with Iannone when he returned from Italy and surrendered Tuesday to authorities at Kennedy Airport in New York, would not reveal details of the plea bargain. ``It was an agreement I reached with the prosecutors,'' Pinales said. ``I'm not at liberty to discuss it. Iannone is charged with rape, gross sexual imposition and corrupting another with drugs. The indictment alleges he sexually assaulted three women in October 1987 and February 1988 in their Cincinnati apartments after serving them drug-laced spaghetti. The women told police they woke up without their clothes on after eating dinners Iannone prepared. Police said laboratory analyses showed the leftover spaghetti contained codeine and the prescription sedatives Valium and Elavil.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested For Spitting On Police Horse
DOC.TEXT: It is not nice, and definitely illegal, to spit on a cop - even if he's a horse. That was the lesson learned by Carl Vikstrom, 43, who allegedly did the deed Tuesday to Sport, a horse ridden by police officer Will Smoke in downtown San Jose. Sgt. Greg Trapp said state law provides that police dogs and horses may not be harassed, annoyed, teased or agitated. The misdemeanor penalty against Vikstrom could get him as much as a $1,000 fine and a year in jail.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Bus Collides With Truck in Desert Sandstorm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to CORRECT number of injured to 44, sted 47, CORRECT spelling of driver's last name to McBean, sted MacVean, increase number of cars involved to at least 10. Pick up 3rd graf, `Bus driver ...' SUBS grafs 12-13, bgng ``All southbound ...' with 2 grafs detailing updated road conditions and hospital supervisor saying 8, not 11, people treated. Pick up penultimate graf, `Fire Department ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound bus collided with a truck during a blinding Mojave Desert sandstorm Wednesday, setting off a chain-reaction crash that injured at least 44 people, authorities said. No deaths were reported among the 26 bus passengers or the occupants of at least 10 other vehicles involved in the pileup on Interstate 15, the California Highway Patrol said. Bus driver Bill McBean said visibility suddenly dropped to zero during the sandstorm and he swerved to avoid a flatbed truck stopped in his lane. ``It was too late to do anything but to pull off into the median,'' said McBean. ``This happened so fast.'' The bus struck the rear of the flatbed truck, tearing off the bus door. McBean, 51, managed to keep the bus upright. ``Yeah, I think the bus driver saved a lot of lives,'' said passenger James Messner, 51, of Capac, Mich. Messner said there was no panic among the passengers, who knocked out windows and climbed out of the bus. Passenger Mark Castillo, among those who boarded the bus in Los Angeles and were bound for Las Vegas, estimated the bus was going about 40 mph. ``It was really dusty. It was just a sandstorm. At one point it got so you couldn't hardly see anything. ... You could barely see the line going down the middle of the road.'' The sandstorm developed when a blustery weather front moved through California, bringing cold, rain and snow to many areas of the state. Both lanes of I-15 were closed for two to three hours after the 11 a.m. accident, said highway patrol Lt. Gary Haley, who confirmed that visibility was zero at the time of the crash. The site is a few miles east of Barstow and 100 miles northeast of Los Angeles. Maureen Bodine, nursing supervisor at Barstow Community Hospital, said eight people were treated at the hospital. At least two were in serious condition, she said. Fire Department spokesman Loney Weems said 36 people were treated at the Yermo fire station for minor injuries, mostly cuts and scrapes. Tuesday, a tractor-trailer rig collided with a Greyhound bus and a truck on an icy highway in Utah, killing seven people and injuring 41. The crash was on Interstate 80 near the Utah-Wyoming line.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Collaborator Killed, At Least 12 Arabs Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinian militants on Wednesday stabbed to death an Arab man they suspected of collaborating with Israel, Arab reports and Israel radio said. The victim, 40-year-old Mohammed Zaher, was killed near a clinic run by the United Nations in the Gaza Strip refugee camp of Khan Yunis, Palestinian journalists based in Gaza said. Zaher's death brought to 319 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs on suspicion of assisting Israel during the three-year-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. At least 779 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt. Fifty-seven Israelis also have died in the violence. In scattered stone-throwing clashes in the occupied territories on Wednesday, at least 12 Palestinians were shot and wounded by Israeli troops, Arab reports said. Israel radio said five were wounded in the West Bank village of Bartaa in a clash that developed after Israel's military government officials demolished five houses build without proper licenses. The army command said it was checking the reports. In Nablus, the West Bank's largest town, the army also reportedly sealed shut the house of Shukri Tavila, 24, who was arrested in August 1989 on suspicion of planning murders of suspected collaborators.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Signs Production Deal With Creators of `Designing Women'
DOC.TEXT: The creators of television's hit comedy ``Designing Women'' have signed a CBS production deal that guarantees them five new series on the network, officials announced Wednesday. Linda Bloodworth-Thomason and Harry Thomason of Mozark Productions, which also makes the critically acclaimed CBS series ``Evening Shade,'' have signed a long-term contract to create five programs exclusively for the network. It is the largest series commitment ever made by CBS to a single production company, the network said in a prepared statement. The dollar amount was not revealed. ``We specifically wanted to get married to CBS,'' Bloodworth-Thomason said. ``This is a permanent arrangement.'' The agreement is the second largest production deal of its kind at any of the big three networks. Stephen Bochco's 10-series deal with ABC is the biggest production contract with a single company. Bloodworth-Thomason said all shows under the new CBS contract will likely be 30-minute situation comedies. The subject matter and debut dates have not been finalized, she said. ``Obviously we're not going to be running seven shows simultaneously,'' she said. ``Designing Women,'' a sharp-witted comedy about four female interior designers living in Atlanta, frequently breaks into the A.C. Nielsen Co.'s top 10 list. ``Evening Shade,'' featuring an ensemble cast, including Burt Reynolds, Hal Holbrook and Marilu Henner, has received favorable reviews and was recently moved to CBS' highly rated Monday night lineup, alongside ``Designing Women'' and ``Murphy Brown.''

DOC.HEAD: UNICEF Asks Leaders to Fulfill Pledges from Children's Summit
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Children's Fund on Wednesday urged world leaders to make good on a recent pledge to help prevent millions of child deaths from hunger and disease this decade. James P. Grant, UNICEF's executive director who issued the report titled ``The State of the World's Children,'' said, ``The world has never before undertaken such a global commitment'' as it did for children in 1990. Seventy-one presidents, kings and prime ministers joined envoys of 88 other nations at the United Nations on Sept. 19, the largest such gathering in history, to pledge a redoubled effort to save children. The summit set 20 goals for the year 2000, including a one-third reduction in child deaths, a halving of child malnutrition and the introduction of basic schooling for at least 80 percent of the developing world's children. An estimated 40,000 child die daily from sickness and malnutrition. Another estimated 150 million children worldwide lack proper health care and 100 million children aged 6 to 11 do not attend school, the report said. ``The declarations of political leaders are not enough. The goals for the year 2000 must become the goals of society as a whole,'' Grant said. The report urged nations to re-examine national spending priorities and public policies by ``no later than the end of 1991.'' While the cost of fulfilling the summit goals by 2000 will require roughly $20 billion a year, much of that figure can be achieved by a reallocation of resources, the report said. It suggested a small reduction in military expenditures, debt relief linked to investments in children and a reallocation of funds from high-cost services to low-cost items such as vaccines. ``With the ending of the Cold War and the easing of regional tensions, it cannot be too unrealistic to suggest a 5 percent cut in defense spending - which would liberate half of the estimated $20 billion a year needed to reach the year 2000 goals,'' the report argued. At present, the report noted, only about 3 percent of the industrialized world's aid is devoted to such basics as primary education and primary health care. But UNICEF said its goals are achievable. One of its last 10-year goals, the immunization of nearly 80 percent of the developing world's children by 1990, has been virtually reached, up from 15 percent immunization in 1980. ``That extraordinary achievement,'' UNICEF said, ``has not only saved 12 million young lives, it has also given the world new hope by showing what can be achieved when the international community commits itself to a great endeavor.''

DOC.HEAD: Folksy Almanac Takes on Big-City Magazine
DOC.TEXT: The Old Farmer's Almanac, the folksy, old-fashioned American tradition, has taken on New York Magazine, the trendy chronicle of life in the big city. The 199-year-old Almanac filed a trademark infringement lawsuit Wednesday accusing the magazine of imitating the Almanac's distinctive cover design with the Dec. 3 issue. The Almanac's publisher, Yankee Publishing Inc. of Dublin, N.H., said the covers were so similar that readers might be led to believe the Almanac authorized or in some way sponsored its use by New York Magazine. The lawsuit said the magazine, by imitating its trademarked cover, had ``impaired the value of Yankee's cover design and the goodwill symbolized by it.'' Susan Soriano, a spokeswoman for the magazine, said the magazine had not received the lawsuit and had no immediate comment. The disputed cover, titled ``The 1990 Christmas Gifts Almanac,'' promotes a story of gift suggestions for the holidays. It is illustrated in a similar design as used by the Almanac. Yankee accuses the magazine of copying, among other things, the overall distinctive yellow color, the use of red and green highlights and a red and white border, and a nearly identical style of typeface. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, seeks an order barring the magazine from using the design in the future. It also seeks unspecified damages. The Almanac has been published annually since 1792.

DOC.HEAD: Special Envoy Says Korean Society Undergoing Strain
DOC.TEXT: A South Korean presidential envoy said Wednesday his country remains committed to the liberalization of imports despite belt-tightening aimed at combatting social and economic deterioration. For the first time since 1985, South Korea will have a trade deficit this year, now estimated at $2 billion, former deputy Prime Minister Soon Cho told a National Press Club gathering. ``The economic downturn does not appear to be just an economic matter, and the whole social and political structure of Korean society seem to be under strain,'' he added. Cho said President Roh Tae-woo dispatched him as a special envoy to assure U.S. officials that import liberalization remains the ``mainspring'' of trade policy despite growing problems such as inflation and ``accelerating consumption.'' He has talked with members of Congress, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, Trade Representative Carla Hills and other economic officials of President George Bush's administration. Many U.S. officials believe South Korea has used alleged over-consumption as an excuse to discriminate against imports. Cho said South Korea has undertaken an austerity campaign ``with the innocuous motive ... to arrest the deteriorating socio-economic conditions.'' He said it was unfortunate that the campaign ``carried the smack of an anti-import'' effort. Cho called social and political conditions at home a ``state of turmoil.'' Wages have risen at least 20 percent annually for the past three years and ``workers attitudes have changed for the worse,'' he said. ``Radical student groups have been trying to instigate workers and farmers who feel they do not get a fair deal out of the country's rapid economic growth.'' Annual manufacturing growth has fallen from 17 to 7 percent and economic growth is now led by construction, service and consumption, he said, ``Farmers are poorer than urban people'' and feel industrialization has bypassed them, but they enjoy widespread sympathy and political power to resist the opening of markets to imported farm products, Cho said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Survey Indicates Drug Use Decreasing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf: ``But Dr.,'' to fix grammar, ``is accurate'' sted ``are accurate''
DOC.TEXT: Casual use of cocaine, the most virulent drug of the 1980s, has fallen 72 percent in the last five years, the government said in a report issued Wednesday. ``The magnitude of the progress is impressive indeed,'' President Bush said at a news conference releasing the Household Survey on Drug Abuse. ``The news we have today suggests that our hard work is paying off and our national strategy is having an effect.'' But critics, including Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., took issue with the survey. Biden, D-Del., said it ``misses more addicts than it counts.'' Not all the news was positive. The survey reported a continuing of a trend found two years ago: The number of people who used cocaine daily or almost daily rose by 37 percent over five years, from 246,000 in 1985 to 336,000 this year. In addition, the number of current crack cocaine users remained stable at about a half-million. NIDA Director Charles R. Schuster said the survey undercounts such users. Bush said it's too early to declare a victory despite the findings that drug use in general is down. ``As long as there are hospital rooms filled with drug-affected babies, neighborhoods ravaged by drug violence or children threatened by addiction, a declaration of victory would be premature,'' Bush said. About 12.9 million people - 6.4 percent of the population age 12 and older - are ``current users,'' also known as casual users, meaning they use some kind of illicit drug at least once a month, according to the survey sponsored by the National Institute on Drug Abuse. That's 44 percent fewer than the 23 million in 1985; an 11 percent decline from the 14.5 million two years ago. For current cocaine use, the decline was even more dramatic, down 72 percent from 5.8 million in 1985 to 1.6 million this year. Since 1988, the number dropped 45 percent from 2.9 million. The survey did not specify how much of a drug was used, only how frequently it was used. On Capitol Hill, Biden said a study by his Senate Judiciary Committee estimates about 2.4 million people use cocaine at least once a week, not the 662,000 cited in the Household Survey. And the committee report says the number of such hard-core cocaine users has increased by 200,000, rather than declining by that number as the NIDA survey indicated. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said he believes drug use is dropping ``among those who are best equipped to avoid the lure of drugs.'' ``However, I do not think that drug use has decreased among those who are a part of the populations that are homeless, in prison, in hospitals receiving treatment for AIDS and other drug-related illnesses or similar groups located in our inner cities,'' Rangel said. Administration officials acknowledged that the Household Survey misses homeless people as well as those in prison, shelters, drug-treatment centers and other institutions such as dormitories. They also said 18 percent of the households contacted declined to participate. Schuster estimated that as many as 50 percent of the more than 1 million people imprisoned nationwide are drug users. But Dr. James O. Mason, assistant secretary for health, said the survey's tracking of trends - if not the precise numbers of users - is accurate because the survey has been administered the same way all 10 times since 1971. He also said the findings are similar to those of other studies. It's evident the survey misses many drug users. For example, it estimates thre are 48,000 current users of heroin when NIDA has been saying for the past decade that there are about 500,000 heroin addicts, people who use the drug far more often than once a month. Among the survey's findings, based on interviews this year with 9,259 people age 12 and over: -The number of adolescents using any illicit drugs dropped in the past two years by 13 percent, from 1.9 million to 1.6 million. For cocaine, the number dropped 49 percent, from 225,000 to 115,000. -Emergency rooms are seeing fewer cocaine-related cases. The number decreased 9.5 percent from the first quarter to the second quarter of 1990. It's down 33 percent from the highest levels, recorded in the fourth quarter of 1988 and the second quarter of 1989. -Heroin-related emergency room cases dropped 18 percent from the second quarter of 1988 to the second quarter of 1990, about the same decrease experienced for all drug-related emergency room visits combined. -Marijuana remains the most commonly used illicit drug, even though the number of current users has declined 43 percent in the last five years, from 18 million in 1985 to 10.2 million this year. -The number of people who drink alcoholic beverages weekly declined 24 percent over five years, from 54.6 million in 1985 to 41.7 million this year. -Current cigarette users declined 11.1 percent, from 60.3 million in 1985 to 53.6 million this year. Louis W. Sullivan, secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, said the survey results ``must be greeted with guarded optimism.'' ``There are still millions of Americans trapped in the web of addiction, poor health, violence, crime and death,'' he said. ``Despite this impressive good news about our progress ... many pockets of serious drug problems remain.''

DOC.HEAD: Duvalier Legacy Hangs Over Haiti's New Democracy
AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 7th graf `The priest's ...' to UPDATE with opposition parties to be invited into government. Picks up 8th graf, `Jean-Claude Bajeaux ...' and SUBS 23rd graf, `Bazin, the . ..' to UPDATE with Bazin ruled out as premier.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Five years after the fall of the Duvalier family dictatorship, Haitians have finally chosen a president in this impoverished Caribbean nation's first fully democratic election. Now the probable winner, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, faces the job of carrying out his pledge to wash away the Duvalier legacy of repression, corruption and government neglect. That legacy includes an army notorious for its human rights abuses, an ineffectual judicial system, a population with a 65 percent illiteracy rate and a per capita income of $360 a year. The danger for Aristide - a charismatic priest with huge popular support but virtually no government experience - is that he may be unable to satisfy the high expectations he has raised among the Haiti's poor. They hope he will bring better living conditions and an end to totalitarian rule. Three days after Sunday's election, only 15.3 percent of the official results had been announced. But they gave Aristide an overwhelming 65 percent of the vote, in line with the outcome projected by international observers. The priest's nearest competitor among the 10 other candidates, former World Bank official Marc Bazin, regarded as the Bush administration's favorite, was a distant second with 11.5 percent of the vote. Aristide will ask opposition parties to form an alliance with his new government, his major adviser, Evans Paul, said Wednesday. Paul, co-leader with Aristide of the coalition National Front for Democracy and Change, said they would especially seek out the center-right National Industrial and Agricultural Party led by Louis Dejoie Jr., who drew 27,267 votes, or 8.4 percent. Jean-Claude Bajeaux, a prominent human rights activist, attributed Aristide's apparent landslide win to his fight against Duvalierists who have gone unpunished for the atrocities of the 29-year dictatorship. ``Aristide is the medium through which the people have discovered the possibility of being protected by being together,'' Bajeaux said. ``That's what the other Haitian politicians didn't understand. The people wanted justice.'' Aristide, 37, has been the target of several assassination attempts, including a 1988 attack at his former church in which at least 12 of his parishioners were murdered and 70 wounded. In the only violence of the election campaign, terrorists hurled a grenade and fired bullets into an Aristide rally on Dec. 5, killing seven and wounding more than 50 others. ``With the victory of Aristide, the people have taken back Feb. 7, 1986, which the Duvalierists stole,'' said bus driver Pierre Merveille, 44. On that day, Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled to France after a popular uprising, ending the dynasty found by his late father, Francois ``Papa Doc,'' in 1957. Haitians celebrated then, expecting broad change. Instead, they have seen five governments, four controlled by the army. Because Aristide is so closely identified with the struggle against tyranny, Haitians may be expecting more of him than they would from an establishment politician. But his popularity with the impoverished masses, ironically, may be his Achilles heel. Dr. Louis Roy, president of the interim goverment's advisory Council of State and principal author of the 1987 Constitution, said Aristide must move swiftly to make changes. ``Within his one-year grace period, he must take the first spectacular steps to show he intends to strengthen public finances, the judicial system, ... and provide essential social services,'' Roy said. But Aristide risks a backlash from such traditional powers as the military and the wealthy elite if he clamps down too hard and too fast, said Anne Fuller, associate director of the New York-based National Coalition for Haitian Refugees, who was in Haiti to observe the election. ``My feeling is that he's not going to act very quickly on these things,'' she said. Aristide adheres to liberation theology, which encourages the poor to demand their rights. He was expelled from his conservative Salesian Order in 1988 for allegedly fomenting revolution. He remains a Roman Catholic priest but has said he will renounce his calling if the Vatican imposes its policy against holding political office. His leftist philosophy has raised concern among the business establishment and the Bush administration. But the U.S. government has pledged support for the democratic transition, which is expected to result in a resumption of large-scale foreign aid. Robert Pastor, Latin America specialist at the Carter Center in Atlanta, who also observed the election, said he thought a critical decision for Aristide will be the appointment of a prime minister with sound administrative experience. Bazin has been mentioned, but the one-time finance minister and Aristide are at opposite political poles and Paul said on Wednesday ``there is no possibility'' Aristide would ask Bazin to be prime minister. The army has pledged support for the transition to democracy, but the intentions of Duvalier sympathizers within remain unclear. About 800 international observers, including former President Jimmy Carter, were on hand for the election. Millions of dollars in foreign aid poured in for voting materials and equipment. Despite serious delays at some polling stations due to logistical problems, the observers unanimously declared the election open, fair and peaceful. ---
EDITOR'S NOTE: Robert Glass is the AP's Caribbean news editor, based in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

DOC.HEAD: Misha Baryshnikov Donates Painting to Help Leningrad
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Baryshnikov is donating a Picasso painting worth at least $250,000 to a telethon to help restore historic monuments in Leningrad, where he began his ballet career, Tass reported. Business leaders, scholars and cultural figures from 100 nations are planning to attend the Jan. 6-7 ``revival telethon,'' which will be held at the Leningrad Opera and Ballet Theater, the Soviet news agency reported. Other emigre artists who have agreed to participate in the event include Mstislav Rostropovich, Natalia Makarova and Rudolf Nureyev, Tass said. The telethon will benefit a restoration project to save the city's crumbling landmarks and create a Russian emigre center, Tass said. Baryshnikov, 42, defected from the Soviet Union in 1974 and later became a U.S. citizen. He attended the Vaganova Ballet School in Leningrad when he was 14 and later joined the Kirov Ballet, the renowned ballet company.

DOC.HEAD: Former Judge, State Senator Indicted in Corruption Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A former judge, a city alderman and a state senator were among five people indicted Wednesday in a federal investigation of government corruption, prosecutors said. ``Public officials who sell their integrity disgrace themselves,'' said U.S. Attorney Richard Thornburgh. ``We have to make sure that the country is ruled by justice and not corruption.'' Longtime Alderman Fred Roti and Chicago businessman Pasquale Marcy were charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, bribery extortion and interstate travel in aid of racketeering. Roti, 70, has proclaimed his innocence since reports surfaced months ago that he was a target of a federal investigation. He appeared untroubled after a 14-count indictment was issued against him. ``You might say I'm concerned, but I guess you have to learn to live with it and be strong,'' he said. Marcy's attorney said the charges are unsubstantiated. Marcy and Roti were charged with six different instances of paying officials to influence decisions. The indictment detailed tampering in criminal non-jury trials and civil cases in state court, fixing zoning applications in the city and bribing officials in the appointment of an associate judge in Cook County Circuit Court. Marcy and Roti also were accused of fixing murder trials in 1977, 1981 and 1986. In those cases, the defendants were acquitted in non-jury trials, investigators said. Thornburgh and other officials refused to give details of the investigation, saying the probe, dubbed ``Operation Gambat,'' is continuing and more indictments are expected. David J. Shields, a former presiding judge in the chancery division of Cook County Circuit Court, and Chicago attorney Pasquale De Leo were charged with extortion, false statements and interstate travel in aid of racketeering. Their seven-count indictment charges that De Leo, 45, accepted $11,000 from an attorney working undercover for the FBI. Investigators said De Leo delivered some of that money to Shields, 58, to influence the judge's decisions on motions filed during an undercover case set up by the FBI in 1988. De Leo's lawyer, Samuel Banks, said ``my client will persist in the plea of not guilty.'' Dan Webb, an attorney representing Shields and Roti, said his clients will be vindicated in court. ``I'm confident we'll be able to establish their innocence,'' Webb said. In a third indictment, state Sen. John A. D'Arco Jr. was charged with two counts of extortion and one count of tax fraud. D'Arco, 46, has been a member of the Legislature for 13 years and is a member of the Senate's Insurance Committee. The indictment charged him with taking a $7,500 bribe from an FBI agent after agreeing to support insurance legislation. D'Arco also is charged with failing to report $5,000 of that money on his 1988 tax return. His attorney, Jeffrey Steinback, said he will plead innocent. Thornburgh said he was shocked at the corruption uncovered in the investigation. ``I think the individual acts of corruption are appalling,'' he said. ``We're going to be relentless trying to get this type of corruption exposed through effective prosecution.'' The public officials face substantial prison terms, if convicted. The extortion, racketeering and racketeering conspiracy charges bring maximum penalties of 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The maximum penalty for bribery is 10 years imprisonment and a fine of $250,000. The maximum penalty for interstate travel in aid of racketeering and giving false statements is five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. A conviction for tax fraud could bring three years imprisonment and a fine of $250,000. Another wide-ranging undercover probe centered in Chicago was dubbed Operation Greylord, in which FBI agents posed as corrupt attorneys to gather evidence on lawyers and Cook County judges. More than 90 people, including 15 judges, were convicted. Since 1978, more than 400 public officials in Chicago have been convicted on corruption charges.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Seen on TV Being Embraced by Saddam Gets Courage Award
LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.TEXT: Stuart Lockwood, a 5-year-old shown on television with Saddam Hussein when the British boy and other hostages met the Iraqi leader in August, was awarded a ``Child of Courage'' medal Wednesday. The medal was presented by the Duchess of York, Prince Andrew's wife, the former Sarah Ferguson, at a ceremony at Westminster Abbey. During the ceremony, 11 youngsters received medals for courage and bravery. Stuart, who took the duchess' hand and walked her to her car after the presentations, seemed especially interested in her auto. ``She let me look inside. It had big seats and a telephone,'' he said. The world saw a different side of the boy in Iraqi TV pictures on Aug. 23. They showed Stuart standing next to the seated Saddam during a meeting between the Iraqi leader and a group of Western hostages in Baghdad, Iraq's capital. In the footage broadcast worldwide, a smiling Saddam was seen putting his arm around Stuart's shoulders as the boy tried to shrink from the embrace. Saddam also patted the boy's head in the staged show of affection, while an Iraqi military officer ruffled the boy's hair. The TV pictures, shown repeatedly, came to symbolize the vulnerability of the foreign hostages following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq said it staged the meeting between Saddam and the group to show that the foreign guests, as it called them, were well. But critics said the televised meeting was a cynical propaganda ploy by Saddam to use the hostages to try to weaken the coalition of foreign powers opposing him. Stuart and his mother, 39-year-old teacher Glenda Lockwood, arrived back in London on Sept. 2 among the first foreign women and children to be released from Iraq. They returned on a plane with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who had gone to Baghdad to ask for the release of foreigners. Stuart's father, Derek Lockwood, a 43-year-old engineer, arrived in Britain to rejoin his family on Dec. 10 after Iraq's decision to free all foreign hostages. Mrs. Lockwood said Wednesday that Stuart had been emotionally ``clingy'' after his return to Britain. But she said the boy had reverted to his normal outgoing self following the return of his father.

DOC.HEAD: Arctic Cold Grips Northern Plains, Snow Storm In Northwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Two traffic ...' to UPDATE with four traffic deaths in California and lower injuries in sandstorm to 44, sted 47. SUBS grafs 8 to end, bgng `In western ...' with 15 grafs to UPDATE with South Dakota conditions, special weather advisory issued, longer Denver airport delays, thousands of Seattle residents still without power, children reunited with parents, Idaho roads closed.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: An arctic cold front dropped temperatures well below zero Wednesday on the northern Plains, with wind chill factors down to 77 below, and a snow storm in the Northwest stranded thousands of youngsters in schools. ``It's cold with a capital `C' ... it's the Arctic Express,'' said Chuck McCain, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Denver. The cold and high wind knocked out power for thousands and hampered firefighters battling a schoolhouse blaze in Montana. Accompanying snow cut visibility and made streets and highways slippery. Four traffic deaths in northern California and two in Oregon were blamed on slippery roads. During a sandstorm in southern California's Mojave Desert, a Greyhound bus collided with a truck near Yermo, near Barstow northeast of Los Angeles. At least 44 people were injured, the state Highway Patrol said. A tour group of 82 people who had taken a dinner cruise on a paddle-wheeler on Lake Tahoe wound up riding buses back to their hotels early Wednesday after raging weather forced the captain to beach the craft in a sheltering cove. Nearby Reno, Nev., had wind gusts to 65 mph. ``It's going to be a Merry Christmas in the Sierra,'' said Dan Nourse, of Alpine Meadows Ski Resort in California's Sierra Nevada about 40 miles southwest of Reno. ``We got 10-14 inches of new snow overnight and it's still coming down, although not as heavily.'' At noon, no city anywhere in Montana reported a temperature above zero. Kalispell was the warmest at 5 below zero and Great Falls reported 22 below. The low temperatures combined with brisk wind to produce wind chill factors as low as 77 below zero at 10 a.m. at Dillon, in the state's southwestern corner. Great Falls had a record low of 25 below zero, without the wind factored in. In western South Dakota, the afternoon temperature at the Rapid City airport was 13 below zero, but with wind gusting to more than 40 mph, the wind chill was calculated at more than 60 below. Forecasters issued a winter storm watch for the western part of the state late Wednesday. ``Make no mistake. These are dangerous conditions,'' the National Weather Service in South Dakota said. ``Skin exposed to these elements will freeze in only a few minutes. If you must travel, make sure to carry a winter survival kit.'' Casper, Wyo., had a wind chill of 60 below and Dickinson, N.D., felt like 56 below. Volunteer firefighters at Plentywood, Mont., fought vainly in wind chills of 48 below zero to save the town's high school from flames. School buses stood by with heaters running to give firefighters temporary shelter. Workers for Mission Valley Power in western Montana struggled Wednesday to restore power to about 8,000 homes and businesses that lost electricity. In addition to trees falling on power lines, circuit breakers at a substation froze, said Dan Swaney, power company manager in Polson. Snow was scattered along the leading edge of the cold air. Officials at Denver's Stapleton International Airport said flights were delayed up to an hour because of blowing snow. At the Snowy Range ski area west of Laramie, Wyo., resort owner Terri Colling said 20 inches of snow had fallen since Tuesday morning. The storm spread into eastern Washington, Oregon, northern Utah and northern California and Nevada. Snowfall stopped in Seattle after up to 10 inches of snow nearly brought the city to a standstill Tuesday. A second day of temperatures in the teens and 20s locked in a sheet of ice atop the blanket of snow, making traveling perilous. Seventy thousand people in the Seattle area were still without power Wednesday, down from 100,000 Tuesday, said a Puget Sound Power & Light Co. spokesman. At least 37 schools in King County, where Seattle is located, had remained open Tuesday night to house roughly 2,600 children and faculty who couldn't make it home, county emergency services officials said. Emergency Services spokesman Mike Hagan said the Red Cross delivered blankets and helped feed the children. Most of the children were reunited with their parents Wednesday. The district closed classes for the rest of the week. Residents of Vashon Island, southwest of Seattle in Puget Sound, were isolated overnight when ferry service was shut down by high wind and waves up to 14 feet high. Partial service was restored Wednesday. Washington State Ferries spokeswoman Princess Jackson-Smith said 25 passengers and crew had to spend the night on one ferry tied up at the Southworth dock because they couldn't land at Vashon. School closures were reported throughout western Oregon and slippery roads snarled traffic. In northeastern Nevada, near the Utah border, Interstate 80 east was closed by snow over Pequops Summit between Wells and Wendover. Blowing snow also closed a stretch of U.S. 20 near Idaho Falls, in eastern Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: Government Settles in Refugee Deportation Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to CLARIFY that settlement calls for new deportation hearings for refugees. Pick up 7th graf, `We think ...'
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge approved a settlement Wednesday with the government that stalls deportation of thousands of Salvadoran and Guatemalan refugees denied political asylum. Settlement of a 1985 civil lawsuit on behalf of about 80 sanctuary assistance organizations was signed by U.S. District Judge Robert Peckham. The agreement was supported by the Justice Department, but is subject to a final approval hearing Jan. 31 in San Francisco. ``The settlement applies to every Salvadoran and Guatemalan in the United States who has been denied asylum since 1980,'' Frand Deale, legal director of the Center for Constitutional Rights, said in a statement from New York. The settlement calls for new deportation hearings for thousands of refugees. ``As many as 150,000 denials will have to be readjudicated and up to 500,000 Salvadoran and Guatemalans will be affected by the settlement,'' Deale said. ``We think it is a fair agreement, but we'll make no further statement,'' Justice Department spokesman Joe Krovisky said. Years of legal wrangling included Peckham's rebuff of government attempts to dismiss the lawsuit. Peckham rejected government arguments that the lawsuit depended on foreign policy questions outside the court's authority. The case was handled by Deale's center, the National Lawyers Guild, the Americal Civil Liberties Union and the San Francisco law firm Morrison and Forrester. The lawsuit, claiming discrimination, contended the government was violating its own immigration laws by rejecting nearly all requests for political asylum from natives of the two Central American countries. It said despite civil strife in those countries, only 3 percent of Salvadorans and less than 1 percent of Guatemalans were granted asylum on the grounds that they feared political persecution. By contrast, the lawsuit said, half or more of the applicants from such countries as Afghanistan, Poland and Nicaragua were granted asylum. The lawsuit said the disproportional percentages plainly favored refugees ``fleeing countries deemed to be communist.'' The plaintiffs said the settlement modified the role of the State Department by allowing input from other agencies in each case. The State Department ``will now declare that its recommendation (will be) only one of several factors to be considered by asylum officers,'' the plaintiffs said. In Tucson, Ariz., the Rev. John Fife, one of eight defendants convicted on conspiracy and alien-smuggling charges in May 1986, said, ``This is a great Christmas present for refugees, the best one that I could imagine. ``Our basic legal position has now been vindicated, which was that it was the Immigration and Naturalization Service in violation of the 1980 law, not the sanctuary movement,'' he said. The lawsuit was filed against the INS and the U.S. attorney general after sanctuary movement activists were indicted in 1985, stemming from the government's undercover infiltration and secret tape-recording of church services and meetings.

DOC.HEAD: Handwriting on Wall for California Graffiti Scofflaws
DOC.TEXT: The handwriting is on the wall for California graffiti artists: A scribble could leave them walking for a year. Beginning Jan. 1, a new law will allow courts to suspend the driving privileges for a year for anyone over the age of 13 convicted of graffiti-type vandalism. Another new law that takes effect with the new year will permit cities and counties to tax aerosol spray cans 10 cents each and indelible felt-tip markers five cents each to pay for graffiti cleanups. The laws are aimed at curbing the gang-related scribbling and unsightly markups that deface the environment, such as a recent case in Los Angeles in which one youngster caused $500,000 in damages. ``The economic consequences of graffiti vandalism are enormous,'' said state Sen. Quentin Kopp, author of the license bill. ``San Francisco spent over $2 million last year cleaning up graffiti. The city of Los Angeles spent $9 million. Graffiti also debilitates urban dwellers, because it bolsters the impression that our cities are crime-ridden and unsafe,'' said Kopp, an independent from San Francisco. Other new graffiti-related laws will make it an infraction to write graffiti on public transit buses or trains and will require convicted litterers to be sentenced to picking up litter or cleaning up graffiti. Kopp said the California Legislature is getting tough on graffiti because of the proliferation of scrawls and scribbles in public places in urban areas. Last week, an 18-year-old Los Angeles man was accused of painting the word ``Chaka'' on 10,000 traffic signs, utility poles, buildings and walls in Southern California, causing about $500,000 in damage. The new law will allow a judge to suspend for one year the driver's license of a person 13 years or older convicted of graffiti-related vandalism. If a 13 or 14 year old doesn't yet have a license, the court can delay issuance of the license for a year after the teen would otherwise be able to get it. California allows driver's licenses at age 16 with a parent's signature. If the 13- or 14-year-old doesn't have another conviction for graffiti in a year, he or she can ask the court to modify the suspension. The suspension period can also be cut by one day for each hour the convicted person spend cleaning up graffiti from public property. Kopp notes that current law allows courts to suspend or delay driver's licenses for minors convicted of drug and alcohol crimes, even if the offenses are not driving-related. ``The punishment fits the crime and the criminal, because teen-agers prize a driver's license above all else,'' Kopp said. The American Civil Liberties Union and California Attorneys for Criminal Justice opposed the bill when it moved through the Legislature, saying it was inappropriate to deny a license for conduct unrelated to driving. ``More appropriate penalties for these type of minor offenses would include cleaning up the graffiti, cleaning other public areas or working with others in painting murals in public places,'' the ACLU said in a statement opposing the bill. ``That's a lame argument,'' Kopp said. ``We do not literally tailor the punishment to every crime that is committed. We do not amputate the pickpocket's hand.''

DOC.HEAD: Lincoln Center Opens a South African Musical in Brooklyn
DOC.TEXT: Mbongeni Ngema's ``Sarafina!'' celebrated the courageous schoolchildren of Soweto, the black South African enclave that exploded in rebellion against an oppressive white government in 1976. The unusual and often exuberant musical was a surprise success at Lincoln Center three years ago. It later moved to Broadway for a long run and is still touring. Now Ngema is back in New York with another musical for Lincoln Center Theater but this time the company has found its way to the Majestic, an old movie house off Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn where director Peter Brook presented his ``Mahabharata'' and ``The Cherry Orchard.'' The crumbling film palace, deliberately left in a state of semi-decay, is an evocative home for ``Township Fever,'' Ngema's latest effort, which is done in conjunction with the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The shabby surroundings complement a shantytown of corrugated iron huts strung across the wide stage. But the show, which runs about half an hour too long, is not as consistently stirring as ``Sarafina!'' That's because its more polemical moments are stridently or broadly dramatized and might have been more effective if sung or danced. But when the music takes over, ``Township Fever'' manages to be as heartfelt as its precedessor, exuding a theatricality that reinforces the show's anti-apartheid message. In ``Township Fever,'' rebellion is again in the air. Yet the musical, which opened Wednesday, takes a more ambiguous approach than ``Sarafina!'' to another turbulent episode in the history of modern-day South Africa. Ngema's new work looks at black vs. black in a world where the rules are set by the white minority. Heroes and villains are not so easily defined. The musical puts on stage the 1987 strike by black railway workers of the South African Transport Services. Ngema personalizes the events, telling them through a young man named Jazz, his girlfriend, Tonko, and best friend and eventual betrayer, Philadelphia. During the walkout, several scabs, who go to work for the railroad, are murdered by strikers. It is the leading character's friend who fingers the killers. Today, facing death sentences, they are still in jail. Ngema not only wrote the book, music and lyrics for ``Township Fever,'' but he directed and choreographed the show as well. He's the one who must take responsibility for lag in interest between the song and dance. Still, ``Township Fever'' soars during those musical moments, most of them done in mbaqanga, a type of rock music infused with jazz and found in South African townships. The score is infectious and rousingly sung by a large cast, particularly Brian Mazibuko as the doomed hero and Sindiswa Dlathu as his true love. They get strong help from a distinctive supporting cast as well as from a large, on-stage orchestra that peers out from behind those township hovels. The dancing has the same vitality found in ``Sarafina!'' One wishes there were more of it, particularly because the choreography allows designer Sarah Roberts to show off a colorful array of exotic costumes. But for the most part in ``Township Fever,'' the message is in the music and when they come together, it makes for a stirring evening of theater.

DOC.HEAD: Contractor Charged Anew in Reporter's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A man who successfully appealed his conviction in the 1976 car-bomb slaying of a newspaper reporter will be tried again on a murder charge, the Arizona Attorney General said Wednesday. Contractor and speculator Max Dunlap was charged a second time in the slaying of Don Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic, said the state official, Bob Corbin. Another man, plumber James Robison, who also won an appeal of his murder conviction in the case, was charged anew in November 1989. Both men had been sentenced to death. Bolles died June 13, 1976, 11 days after a remote-controlled bomb ripped through his car as he backed out of a hotel parking lot. Authorities never established a firm motive in the killing and theories still abound. A greyhound breeder, John Harvey Adamson, testified as part of a plea bargain he planted the bomb that killed Bolles. Adamson said Dunlap ordered the bombing to ingratiate himself with a friend, land and liquor magnate Kemper Marley, who died earlier this year. Bolles wrote extensively about Marley for his newspaper. Adamson testified that Robison built the bomb and detonated it. The convictions against Dunlap and Robison were overturned on appeal in 1980 and Adamson refused to testify again unless prosecutors met certain demands, including an education fund for his children. Prosecutors refused and Adamson eventually was convicted of first-degree murder in the killing, but an appeals court reduced his sentence from death to life in prison and the U.S. Supreme Court let that decision stand. Adamson's conviction was upheld, however. Corbin said Adamson has agreed to testify in the new cases against Dunlap and Robison in exchange for immunity from prosecution on a number of related charges and a maximum prison sentence of about 20 years on a charge of second-degree murder in Bolles' slaying. Prosecutors agreed to give Adamson credit for about 13 years he has already served and agreed to parole after he hits the 20-year mark. Corbin, who leaves office in January, has repeatedly derided Adamson's credibility since the quarrel with prosecutors over his plea bargain. Corbin would not say why he thought Adamson was a more credible witness now. Corbin insisted he didn't need Adamson's testimony when he brought the new murder charge against Robison last year, but said the case against Dunlap was different. ``We feel we need to do it on this one,'' Corbin said, refusing to elaborate. Robison pleaded innocent to the new murder charge. A lawyer for Dunlap, Rick Miller, said his client also will plead innocent.

DOC.HEAD: Year After U.S. Invasion, Panama's Democracy Faces Tough Times
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 24 grafs to UPDATE with Endara remarks, minor editing. Picks up 22 pvs, `Noriega's Defense...'
DOC.TEXT: A year ago Thursday, U.S. troops invaded Panama to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and install Guillermo Endara as president. Officially, the anniversary is called a ``day of national reflection.'' Noriega's opponents and the families of those who died in the fighting had sought a ``day of national mourning'' but didn't get it. Gone is the euphoria that welcomed the Americans and the removal of Noriega, now in Miami awaiting trial on drug trafficking charges. U.S. military presence on the streets today, however diminished, is seen as an irritant by nationalists - one small sign of the problems Endara faces in his efforts to keep his government alive and democracy intact in Panama after a troubled year. His supporters are turning against him. Labor unrest is on the rise and a feeling exists that the U.S. military is replacing Noriega as the real power here. ``The United States' interference through its forces and its ambassador is pretty open,'' said Marco Gandazegui, director of the private Center for Latin American studies in Panama. On Dec. 5, U.S. soldiers were used at Endara's request to quell a relatively minor revolt of disgruntled police. When riots broke out over a law authorizing firing of about 500 public employees who backed a strike call, one of the first people to meet with legislative leaders was Col. James Steele, head of the U.S Army Support Group working with the Panamanian government. Interior Minister Ricardo Arias Calderon heads the newly structured civilian police force that replaced Noriega's military. Government sources said the Americans told Arias Calderon to let the police ``take care of its own and organize the special military units the United States wants for Canal security.'' The sources spoke on condition of anonymity. The United States turns the Panama Canal over to Panama at the end of the century and wants to see the waterway in the hands of a stable democracy. The Roman Catholic Church, a Noriega foe and formerly a solid backer of Endara, now calls his government ``inflexible.'' Even the United States says Panama could be vulnerable to remilitarization. ``The specter of militarism reappeared in Panama, and it represented a clear and real danger to constitutional democracy,'' U.S. Ambassador Deane Hinton said of the police uprising, which Endara called a coup attempt. Hinton told businessmen that ``democracy does not come easily,'' but added: ``The government of Panama has come a long way in a year.'' Endara conceded, ``We have many problems and few resources.'' He said ``much has been accomplished,'' but ``democracy in Panama remains in danger.'' His nationally televised speech Wednesday night focused on the last years of Noriega rule. ``A night like tonight, a year ago, was the last night of tyranny in Panama. The detonator was a military action, of force, but behind it was a long calvary of suffering, of rebelliousness and protests,'' he said. He urged Panamanians ``not to let this happen again on our soil. ... The calvary is over.'' Losses from looting and other causes not stemming from the fighting a year ago have been estimated at up to $1.5 billion. Endara has suggested the United States owes reparations for invasion damage, but no amount has been mentioned. The high expectations of many following Noriega's overthrow, which according to the U.S. Southern Command left up to 345 soldiers and civilians dead, have now turned to frustration. The government is accused of inactivity and worse. Only about $84 million has been used of $461 million in U.S. aid allotted for Panama. Much has been held up pending reforms Washington asks in banking secrecy laws and the like, most aimed at drug trafficking an money laundering. Leaders here find it hard, politically, to support the demands. The military has ruled Panama, often behind a civilian facade, since 1968. The military's loss of stature apparently was behind the uprising of retired Col. Eduardo Hererra and about 35 followers this month. They said they acted to get more respect from a civilian government that had humiliated them. Noriega's Defense Forces had 16,000 members. The civilian police force that replaced them has 13,000, with drastically reduced duties and about half the budget formerly allotted. About 40 percent of the officer corps has been ousted. Endara defended his asking for U.S. troops to put down the uprising, saying it ``avoided the return of a dictatorship and a bloodbath of Panamanians.'' The president inherited a wrecked government and ruined economy. Despite withering problems, progress has been made. Unemployment is at about 25 percent, but substantially better than a year ago. The economy is growing again after years of shrinkage. ``It is not true that we haven't done anything,'' Arias Calderon protests. ``We have done a lot with human rights, democratization and returning confidence ... economic activation ... international recognition.'' Panama is moving to reduce its $3.8 billion foreign debt, after Noriega suspended payment on it for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Agrees To Stop Selling `Steve The Tramp' Dolls
DOC.TEXT: The Walt Disney Co. has decided to stop selling a doll that depicts a street tramp after pressure from homeless activists. The Rev. Christopher Rose, who inspired the protest early this month, called the action ``a hollow victory'' because there isn't enough time to recall the dolls before Christmas. ``Steve the Tramp,'' a 5-inch plastic figure and one of a series of 14 ``coppers and gangsters'' based on the story of ``Dick Tracy,'' sparked protests from advocates for the homeless who said the description on its package degraded those living on the streets. The tramp is described as ``hardened and bitter after a life on the mean streets ... a lout who would just as soon take your life as your wallet.'' Rose, rector of Grace Episcopal Church in Hartford, cited Steve the Tramp as one of the most offensive toys of the 1990 Christmas season. Rose has an annual display he calls ``Warped Toys for Christmas.'' ``I'm glad somebody there got a conscience,'' Rose said Tuesday when he learned of Disney's action. In recalling the doll, the Walt Disney Co. in Burbank, Calif., said in a statement Monday it felt the doll was ``misunderstood'' when viewed outside the fantasy world of Dick Tracy. Joining in the statement was Playmates Toys Inc. of La Mirada, Calif., which is licensed by Disney to manufacture and market the toy. ``Playmates has decided to discontinue production and distribution of the doll. Disney has removed the figure from shelves at its chain of retail stores and theme parks,'' the statement said. ``Because we are concerned that this product may be conveying a negative image of our nation's homeless, we feel it is appropriate to stop selling the toy.'' Chuck Champlin, a Disney spokesman, acknowledged that it was too late to get the toys off the shelves of all retailers before Christmas. Some retailers discontinued sale of the doll after advocates for the homeless protested and picketed stores.

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Dissidents Declare Rival Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 6th graf, The opposition ... to UPDATE with government says it will free opposition leader if she leaves Burma. Picks up 7th graf, `Most of ...'
DOC.TEXT: Burmese dissidents have declared a rival government and denounced military rulers for failing to hand over power to the opposition, which won free elections seven months ago. ``Burma has become a country shrouded by darkness because of all the unlawful arrests, tortures and persecutions and human rights violations,'' the dissidents said in a declaration issued Tuesday and seen in Bangkok on Wednesday. Diplomats in Rangoon said they feared the move could prompt a new clampdown by the government. The dissidents, calling themselves the National Coalition Government of the Union of Burma, said they had picked Sein Win as prime minister. He is a cousin of Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader whose National League for Democracy won 80 percent of the parliamentary seats contested in May's national election. The opposition leader has been under house arrest since July 1989, and her party has not been allowed to govern. On Tuesday, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar urged the Burmese government to release her. The military government said Wednesday night it would free Ms. Suu Kyi only if she left Burma to join her family in Britain. Its reply to Perez de Cuellar came in a Foreign Ministry statement carried by state radio. Most of the party's leaders have been detained since the army took power by crushing a nationwide movement for democracy in 1988. Sein Win said forming the new body ``was the only option for us to choose because this military junta has no will and no way to transfer power to the people.'' The announcement of the formation of a new government was made at the headquarters of the Karen National Union in Manerplaw, about 120 miles northeast of Rangoon on the frontier with Thailand. The Karen are an ethnic rebel group that has fought successive governments in Rangoon since the 1940s. The dissidents named an eight-member Cabinet, all of whom had won parliamentary seats in the election. Six are League members and one is an independent. Sein Win is a member of the closely allied National Democracy Party. All had fled under threat of arrest when their plan to form a parallel government became known to the Rangoon government. The military government said earlier this month it had arrested 48 members of the National League for Democracy for involvement in the plan. Diplomats from Rangoon have said the figure could be higher. The dissidents called for the immediate elimination of the military administration, a national convention including members of parliament and insurgent groups, and the establishment of a democratic government. Their goal, they said, was to create ``an independent, prosperous and modernized Federal Union of Burma.'' Troops killed thousands of people crushing the pro-democracy movement in 1988. Amnesty International and other human rights groups say hundreds and perhaps thousands of dissidents have since been detained without charge or trial or sentenced to prison terms after unfair military trials. Amnesty has cited numerous reports of routine torture of dissidents, particularly of members of insurgent groups. A Rangoon-based diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday the declaration of a rival government could give the military an excuse to intensify its crackdown on the opposition. He said it might even provide a pretext for it to declare the National League for Democracy illegal. A powerful member of the Rangoon government warned in newspaper interview published Tuesday that the declaration would be ``a great mistake.'' Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, Burma's head of military intelligence, told the Bangkok Post the existing government was recognized by the United Nations and he did not believe that any country would recognize a government-in-exile. Western diplomats expressed doubt that the breakaway group would garner much popular support inside Burma. The Democratic Alliance of Burma, an umbrella organization of 21 ethnic and other rebel groups fighting the central government, backed the declaration. The Karen are members of the DAB.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Convicted of Misdemeanor in Break-in at Love Doctor's Home
DOC.TEXT: A woman suing a former gynecologist she says performed expiremental ``love surgery'' on her without her consent was cquitted Wednesday of a burglary charge involving an alleged break-in at his house. A jury found the woman, Janet Phillips, guilty of a misdemeanor charge of criminal trespass at the home of James C. Burt. Ms. Phillips is among about 40 women who have sued Burt in connection with his self-described ``love surgery'' on female genitalia, designed to increase sexual responsiveness. The women claim Burt performed the surgery either without their consent or by fraudulently obtaining their consent. Ms. Phillips' lawsuit is expected to be the first to go to trial. ``It's been very hard on me and my children,'' Ms. Phillips said after the Common Pleas jury made its decision. ``I feel like I can sleep tonight. It was an extremely long ordeal.'' The burglary charge against Ms. Phillips, 44, carried a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison and a $7,500 fine. The trespass charge is punishable by a maximum 30 days in jail and a $250 fine. Ms. Phillips was accused of entering Burt's suburban Washington Township home between Jan. 1, 1989, and March 30, 1989. Prosecutors said she broke in and took a lapel pin as ``psychological retribution.'' Ms. Phillips' lawyer, James Rion, told the jury the home was unoccupied and his client took nothing. Burt surrendered his medical license in January 1989 just days before he was to appear at a disciplinary hearing. The Ohio Medical Board board earlier charged that the surgery in some cases resulted in sexual dysfunction, emotional distress, infection, chronic pain and the need for corrective surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo to Pay More for U.S. Troops Based in Japan
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet approved Thursday a new five-year defense plan that will slow the growth of military spending but increase Japan's share of the cost of keeping U.S. soldiers on its soil. The average annual increase in military spending will be 3 percent during the new $171 billion plan that begins next spring, down from more than 5 percent annual growth the past five years. ``The Soviet Union was a potential threat for Japan in the past, but we now believe that our potential threat ... has disappeared,'' Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto said at a news conference. Tokyo will shoulder more of the costs of basing 50,000 U.S. soldiers in Japan, increasing its share from about 40 percent to 50 percent within five years, according to the government. ``The Japan-U.S. security treaty is the core of Japan's defense policy, and therefore we will continue to increase our support for U.S. troops in Japan,'' Sakamoto said. Japan now pays about $3 billion annually toward stationing U.S. troops here, including many of the expenses for the 22,000 Japanese base workers. Under American pressure to pay more, Japan is now offering to cover the basic salaries of Japanese base workers and utilities by the end of the new 5-year plan, Sakamoto said. He said the additional cost to Japan would be $1.65 billion over five years. The U.S. Embassy had no immediate comment on the proposal. The United States, which has provided a defensive umbrella for Japan since World War II, has in the past pressed this nation for bigger military buildups. But Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has argued that Japan's defense spending should reflect the easing of the Cold War in Europe. Sakamoto said there would be no increase in the number of Japanese army soldiers, who now number 153,000. He said the government would consider troop cuts after three years. Defense Agency officials and senior lawmakers of Kaifu's governing Liberal Democratic Party have opposed a sharp defense budget cut, saying the reduction in tensions has not yet extended to the Far East. Even with slower growth, the new program will include purchase of such advanced items as airborne warning and control systems, which are flying command posts, according to a military official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Continue as Nancy Cruzan's Condition Deteriorates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7, `Randall Terry ...' to UPDATE with Operation Rescue founder expected by Thursday.
DOC.TEXT: Ten people protesting the removal of a feeding tube from Nancy Cruzan were forcibly removed from a hospital Wednesday and outside doors to the building were locked as demonstrations continued outside. Ms. Cruzan's condition deteriorated in the fifth day since a feeding tube was removed Friday, said Barbara Shoun, a spokeswoman for the Missouri Rehabilitation Center. Her parents fought lengthy legal battles before winning the right to remove the feeding tube in the first right-to-die case decided by the U.S. Supreme Court. They contend their daughter would not want to live in her present state. Ms. Cruzan, 33, has been in a persistent vegetative state since a 1983 car accident. A leader in the anti-abortion movement was on his way to this southwest Missouri town in an attempt to meet with the parents to try to persuade them ``not to kill their daughter.'' Randall Terry, founder of Operation Rescue, was expected to arrive in Mount Vernon by Thursday, said Bob Jewitt, an Operation Rescue spokesman in Atlanta. ``This may be the most important story in the pro-life history,'' Jewitt said. ``This woman is not in a persistent vegetative state. She is not a carrot. She's a human being with blood in her veins and she must be saved.'' Joe and Joyce Cruzan will not meet with Terry, said their attorney, William Colby. ``They had an auto accident that took their daughter and they were faced with two horrible decisions and now somebody they love very much is dying,'' Colby said. ``There is enough pain from the auto accident that to compound that by having a group of strangers who never knew Nancy interfering with the medical decisions is inappropriate,'' he said. About 20 demonstrators gathered at the hospital Wednesday and some were allowed into the hospital chapel. Some then demanded to meet with the center's director and went to his office and began kneeling and praying and refusing to leave, Mrs. Shoun said. About eight or 10 of the demonstrators were put in wheelchairs and pushed out of the building. Others were told to leave and did so, Mrs. Shoun said. ``We've told groups that want to protest that they're welcome to come - as long as they stay outside,'' Mrs. Shoun said. About a half-dozen protesters camped on the front steps Wednesday afternoon, kneeling and praying. One held a sign that said ``Please feed Nancy.'' Authorities arrested 19 people Tuesday who were held in the Lawrence County Jail on $500 bond. All identified themselves as Nancy Cruzan and the sheriff's department said they could not be bonded out until they gave their real names. All but one was fasting. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in June that Missouri could require ``clear and convincing'' evidence that Ms. Cruzan would want to die. The Cruzans went back to local court where three friends and co-workers of Ms. Cruzan testified they had talked about such a situation and Ms. Cruzan had indicated she would want to die. Probate Judge Charles Peel ruled Friday there was sufficient evidence to allow the tube to be removed.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Agrees to Death Penalty for Convict Who Requested It
