DOC.TEXT: Jurors on Wednesday granted a convicted murderer's request for the death penalty for the 1983 slaying of a jewelry store employee. ``You'd be making a very correct decision by sentencing me to death,'' Jermarr Arnold told the jury, which recommended death by lethal injection to a judge. The end of the trial's punishment phase means Corpus Christi Caller-Times reporter Libby Averyt no longer faces the possibility of being jailed again in the case. Ms. Averyt was jailed Dec. 7 for refusing to answer questions about unpublished information from her interviews with Arnold, 32. Prosecutors did not enter as evidence her stories that led to a constitutional confrontation with the newspaper. District Judge Eric Brown, who had found Ms. Averyt in contempt of court for not answering questions in a pre-trial hearing, allowed her release from jail Dec. 9. But she remained under subpoena until the trial ended. In refusing to answer questions, Ms. Averyt cited protection under the First Amendment. She said Wednesday she would have done the same thing if called back to the stand. Arnold told the jury he had no apologies, excuses or remorse for killing 21-year-old Christina Marie Sanchez during a robbery. A death sentence prompts an automatic appeal. Brown said he would await the outcome of the appeal before setting a sentencing date.

SHANNON, Ireland - President Bush's top military deputies are heading to Saudi Arabia to discuss plans for war with Iraq, but they concede some ground forces won't be ready to fight by the deadline for Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were arriving in the Saudi capital of Riyadh today for two days of meetings with American and Saudi military officers. Then they will spend two days making pre-Christmas visits with U.S. troops in the region. Cheney and Powell, speaking with reporters traveling with them, said the United States will be ready to go to war by the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline regardless of whether all reinforcements have arrived in the region and reached combat readiness. They refused to give specifics of the plans they were to discuss with the senior U.S. commander in the Middle East, Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, saying they did not want to tip their hand to Saddam, the Iraqi president. ---= WASHINGTON - Some of the 125,000 reservists called to active duty for the Persian Gulf crisis may be away from their homes and jobs longer than they had imagined. The Defense Department said Tuesday it may ask Congress for authority to keep non-combat reservists on active duty for a full year. The current limit is six months. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has made no final decision but probably would seek the extra authority after Congress returns in late January. Non-combat reservists provide support such as medical care, intelligence analysis, aircraft maintenance, truck driving, water purification and legal assistance. They account for about 110,000 of the reservists called up from all four services. ---= LONDON - Amnesty International issued a reported today charging that Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait have tortured and killed hundreds of people, including 300 premature babies who died because incubators were stolen. Amnesty's first comprehensive description of abuses in occupied Kuwait since the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2 gives few precise figures. But Norma Johnson, the human rights organization's head of communications, said today that ``About 1,000 people have been executed, many hundreds have been tortured and something like 10,000 still remain in detention in Kuwait. ``People going out of their homes to buy food, innocent Kuwaitis, are being picked up by the Iraqi troops, taken back to their homes, and hen they are identified by their parents, for example, are simply being shot in front of them,'' she said in a radio interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. ---= WASHINGTON - The Bush administration's new policy on race-exclusive scholarships is only increasing the confusion on what colleges and universities can and cannot do for minorities, educators and lawmakers say. ``It's ripe for a lawsuit,'' said Tom Jipping of the conservative Free Congress Foundation. ``I hope it happens.'' Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, said, ``The confusion is considerable. It's only made worse by this clarification.'' The revised policy still threatens most scholarships for minority students, said Atwell, whose group represents about 1,800 public and private colleges and universities. Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., called a hearing today by his House Education and Labor Committee in an effort to clear up questions about the administration's decision to retreat from its decision to ban college scholarships based solely on race. ---= JACKSON, Miss. - New witnesses, including a former Ku Klux Klansman, led to a new murder charge against an aging segregationist who twice escaped conviction in the 1963 ambush slaying of civil rights leader Medgar Evers. Byron De La Beckwith, 70, of Signal Mountain, Tenn., was freed on $15,000 bail Tuesday for a Feb. 22 hearing on whether he should be returned to Mississippi to stand trial a third time. The retired fertilizer salesman, who flies the Confederate flag outside his home, was defiant during a court appearance in Chattanooga, Tenn. ``I'm going to resist tooth, nail and claw because I think all this is nonsense, poppycock and something to stir the people up ... and incite the lower forms of life to force and violence against the country clubs,'' he said. ---= HOUSTON - A sweepstakes offering a trip aboard the Mir space station was pronounced a hoax by the official Soviet news agency, and the contest operators were called to appear today before a grand jury. The district attorney's office Tuesday subpoenaed three executives of Space Travel Services to answer questions on whether the promotion - which contestants can enter by dialing a 900-number for $2.99 - violates Texas lottery laws. ``There's just so much information coming from so many sources so fast we just had to look into it. We're dubious,'' said Russell Turbeville, head of the consumer fraud division. Texas law bars charging people for a chance to win something. Space Travel insisted it has a contract with the Soviets and said the Tass news report calling the sweepstakes a hoax resulted from a misunderstanding. The Houston company also said the contest is legal because people can also enter by mail for free. ---= LONDON - Big Ben's chimes, which traditionally announce the queen's Christmas Day message and ring in the New Year, might not make it onto BBC airwaves this time around. Seems the main bell has lost its distinctive bong. A decision has yet to be made, and some British Broadcasting Corp. officials think it would be a big mistake depart from tradition by banning the bong this holiday season. Big Ben's bells have traditionally been used on BBC airwaves as a lead-in to news bulletins, but disappeared temporarily in March after cracks were found in the hammer arm of the 132-year-old main bell that sounds the hours. The original Victorian hammer was removed and replaced with a new $15,000 steel hammer.

DOC.HEAD: Italians Worry About Even More Art Escaping
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: By FRANCES D'EMILIO
DOC.TEXT: The rich patrimony of artworks and archaeological relics in Italy's churches, ruins and museums is slipping away through a sieve of inadequate security and border controls. Many Italians feel the virtual elimination of border restrictions between European Community nations in 1993 will amount to holding the door open for art smugglers and saying, ``Have a nice trip.'' They also worry that objects legitimately purchased from collectors or dealers will cross borders without records, making research more difficult for art historians and archaeologists. Italy has led efforts to preserve some controls on cultural treasures. Holding the European Community's rotating presidency this fall gave it the perfect opportunity to press the issue. The Italians soon found the lines firmly drawn in what has been called the battle of the haves and have nots. On Italy's side are other Mediterranean ``haves'' like Spain and Greece. France, which always has tried to keep its art at home, also has pressed for controls. Britain is the leading advocate of a liberalized art market. It has less to protect and is a center of the international art market. When talks began in May, the two camps ``were farther apart than on monetary unity,'' said an official of the Italian Foreign Ministry. In late November, with Italy's term as president running out, culture ministers asked the EC executive branch to consult experts on devising a system for returning illegally exported treasures. They also agreed to consider certifying artworks and artifacts and tightening controls on art leaving the Community. Spain proposed that each item be issued a kind of visa. Britain has said it might consider certification for pieces beyond a certain worth, but the ministry official said that would not work for Italy. ``A small Etruscan vase can be worth only 5 million lire ($4,300), but for us, the value is much more,'' he said, because it helps complete the story of a collection found in a particular tomb. Robert Spengler of the French Culture Ministry said a ``small government ministry'' might be required to handle certification. Another suggestion is restricting the scope of what constitutes a nation's heritage. On Dec. 13, The European Parliament urged EC nations to use better-trained custom officials and adopt tougher laws on sales of art and artifacts. It also said member nations shouild respect each other's laws on the subject. Those laws vary widely. In Italy, anything unearthed of archaeological interest becomes state property. If a stone lid of an Etruscan sarcophagus turns up in Holland, can the owner be forced to give it back, especially if he can prove he brought it in good faith from a reputable dealer? Would it all end up at the World Court? Alessandra Melucco of the Central Institute of Restoration in Rome said other countries had little sympathy for Italy, given its failure to protect excavations and museums adequately. A superintendent of art in Naples, in desperation, ordered a sculptured 15th-century church entrance walled up this fall soon after it was restored. He said that was the only way to keep vandals and thieves from striking again. Rome's archaeology superintendent, Adriano La Regina, thinks 1993 might not be so bad. ``It's better that objects are displayed in a museum, wherever it is in the world, than to stay in our storerooms on the theoretical pretext that they must be studied, while nobody studies them,'' he said at a forum sponsored by Archeo, an Italian archaeology magazine. After years of talk, Parliament approved funds this year for an ambitious inventory of Italy's cultural riches. Police recall countless thefts in which the museum or church did not have a photo that might aid in recovery. Baldassare Conticello, superintendent at Pompeii, said at the forum: ``If an object is stolen, and you can prove it, in the end it will return, since theft is covered by legislation of all nations. But only a few `producer states' such as us, Greece, Turkey and Cyprus have laws covering wealth that's underground.''

DOC.HEAD: New Generation of Resistance in East Timor
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Buras Vertimor was 6 years old in 1975 when Indonesian invaders dropped from the sky above his home in East Timor. Now he is 21, part of a new generation of East Timorese who continue resisting Indonesia's annexation of their half of the island. West Timor is part of Indonesia, but East Timor formerly belonged to Portugal. Vertimor, who fled Timor in September, belongs to an underground youth movement linked to Timorese guerrillas who are trying to focus international attention on the largely forgotten conflict. Guerrilla leader Xanana Gusmao has described the youth movement as Indonesia's ``fundamental problem'' in East Timor. Robert Domm, an Australian trade unionist who met with Gusmao in September, says young people have been radicalized by the struggle. ``A whole new generation of Timorese are in some ways even more militant than the older generations,'' he said during a visit to Lisbon. The resistance campaign, which young Timorese liken to the Palestinian uprising in Israeli-occupied territories, has taken advantage of Indonesia's cautious efforts to open the impoverished territory to outside scrutiny. East Timor was closed to outsiders after the invasion and annexation. Reports after the invasion told of massacres, famine and epidemics. Diplomats in Jakarta, capital of Indonesia, say 60,000 people died and Roman Catholic Church officials say up to 100,000 Timorese were killed. Human rights groups estimate nearly one-third of the population, put at 650,000 by a Portuguese census of 1974-75, died in the years following the takeover. Indonesia has not provided casualty figures. It says East Timor is peaceful now and Indonesia is introducing economic and social improvements. Vertimor helped organize a student demonstration during the visit of Pope John Paul II to Dili, capital of East Timor, in October 1989. Security forces arrested him shortly afterward. He said he was beaten and tortured before his release and flight to Portugal. Indonesia accuses Portugal of running a propaganda campaign against it. The United Nations still considers Portugal, the colonial ruler of East Timor for nearly 500 years, the legal authority in the territory. The Indonesians say they invaded after Portugal's withdrawal in 1975 left East Timor in chaos. The Revolutionary Front for an Independent East Timor, known by the acronym Fretilin, won a brief civil war with conservative and pro-Indonesian forces and declared independence 10 days before the invasion. Fretilin is the main political force behind the guerrillas, who Indonesia says have been reduced to about 200 poorly armed men who raid villages for food. Officials of Fretilin claim to have 4,000 guerrillas with logistical and moral support from almost the entire native population. Vertimor said he began working actively for the underground in 1985 after four cousins were killed for aiding the resistance. ``I'm a Christian,'' he said, ``but I have the right to hate.'' He said nearly all his generation supports independence. After the communist victory in Vietnam in 1975, the West backed Indonesian President Suharto as a bulwark against communism in Southeast Asia. The United States and Australia classified Fretilin as communist. Cristiano Costa of Fretilin said the leadership includes centrists and conservatives as well as leftists. The guerrillas in East Timor also have the support of the conservative Timorese Democratic Union, Fretilin's foe in the civil war. Gusmao, the insurgent leader, has urged a cease-fire and negotiations with Indonesia. He says the guerrillas will accept the results of a U.N.-supervised referendum in the territory. In November, Foreign Minister Ali Alatas of Indonesia rejected negotiations. Alatas said his government does not consider Fretilin the sole representative of East Timor's people. Resistance leaders acknowledge Indonesian investment in the last several years has improved the economic situation, but say the main beneficiaries are thousands of Indonesian immigrants sent to East Timor since annexation.

For release Thurs PMs, Dec 20, and thereafter ^More Offbeat Mozart by Sellars in '91
DOC.TEXT: Peter Sellars tends to do things a little differently - even Mozart. For starters, he set ``The Marriage of Figaro'' in Manhattan's glittering haven for all that glitters, Trump Tower. That was last week, when PBS aired the first of three Mozart operas that the innovative American directed for the long-running ``Great Performances'' series. On Jan. 4, viewers will be offered the Sellars edition of ``Don Giovanni.'' Filmed in Vienna and set in Spanish Harlem, it features a cocaine-snorting Don who likes to consume Big Macs and stage orgies. On Feb. 15, his ``Cosi Fan Tutte'' will arrive. It's set in a Westchester County diner. Sellars, whose shows all have English subtitles, says he's done all this ``so Americans who have not taken a course in Baroque costume design can understand the characters and the social structure.'' During last week's ``Figaro'' overture, footage of posh Manhattan stores, shoppers and limousines was shown. The ``Don Giovanni'' overture plays over street scenes in the South Bronx - ruined buildings, graffiti and dead rats. The 33-year-old director says that he used New York locales because they're recognized worldwide. Mozart put ``Figaro'' and ``Don Giovanni'' in Seville, which Sellars says was similarly ``known'' 200 years ago. ``We did these operas to please two sets of people - people who know nothing about opera and connoisseurs who can tell the sophisticated choices we're making musically,'' he says. Sellars, whose productions often cause outrage and uproar among traditionalists, sees Mozart as a man of the moment. ``Mozart wrote the most topical operas in the history of opera,'' says the director. He introduced ``Figaro'' by saying: ``Stay tuned for an evening of out-of-control sexual exploitation and aggression, political theory and big entertainment.'' Much as young Americans leave for Saudi Arabia in 1990, ``Cosi'' offers two men who are leaving for war, Sellars says. ``In 1791, active duty was the French Revolution which was under way down the street. When they sing, `People say the army is fun,' the irony was not lost on Mozart's audience.'' ``Cosi,'' Sellars says, is also about ``suburban wife swapping'' and is incorrectly called a comedy of manners. ``It burrows to the root of deceptions that people live with and the quality that these deceptions have of eroding every piece of happiness you've ever known.'' He believes the three operas ``are about how your heart and everything you believe are always shifting.'' People of different classes and opposite sexes trade clothes and identities, he says. ``Mozart says, `OK. Now be in somebody else's shoes and see what life is like. See that everything you believed before is open to question.''' The operas were performed before a live audience on a stage built in a TV studio in Vienna. ``You get live performances for live people, not lip synching or the weird pall that comes over singers when they're singing in a studio to nobody in particular. It's acrobatic staging. They're doing the wildest motions while staying correct musically.'' Five American singers, Sanford Sylvan, James Maddalena, Susan Larson, Frank Kelley and Sue Ellen Kuzma, are in both ``Figaro'' and ``Cosi.'' Eugene Perry sang Don Giovanni, with his twin, Herbert Perry, as the servant Leporello. --- Elsewhere in television... DEPT. OF OH, LET THEM GOOD TIMES ROLL: Farrah Fawcett and her true love Ryan O'Neal are coming to CBS next year, and in a Thursday sitcom. On Jan. 10, they'll premiere in ``Good Sports,'' playing co-anchors who don't get along at an all-sports cable network called the All Sports Cable Network. Moving right along now, she plays a former top model now making a career in sports journalism. O'Neal plays ``Downtown'' Bobby Tannen, identified by CBS as ``the former bad boy of pro football, known for his quick temper and wasted talent.''

DOC.HEAD: Strains and Adversity, Not Festivity, Formed Christmas Story
DOC.TEXT: Peculiarities, some of them humiliating, surrounded the coming of that child whose birth is celebrated at Christmas. The circumstances were strange and disturbing, yet also commonplace. It was not the tinseled, decorative affair that characterizes the modern holiday. Yet odd strands of awe and wonder interwove the ordinary human behavior described in the records. ``How shall this be?'' asked a bewildered Jewish girl, Mary, when a transcendent message came to her that she would bear a divine son. ``I have no husband.'' The upshot, synthesized from biblical accounts, was this: Soon, aware of her pregnancy, the troubled girl temporarily left her parents' home in Nazareth to seek consolation from an older cousin in Jerusalem, staying three months before returning to Nazareth. A just, local man to whom she had been engaged, the carpenter Joseph, was bitterly upset at her condition. In distress, he at first intended to break off their marriage plans. But the account says he decided to do so quietly, being ``unwilling to put her to shame.'' Then at night, tossing about in a dream, in that veiled intermingling of grief, compassion and conscience, heavenly counsel came that Mary had conceived by holy means and her son would ``save his people from their sins.'' Joseph rose from bed that day, rejuvenated and glad, and took Mary as his wife. But they had tough ordeals ahead, even interludes of terror. Under the circumstances, ancient, non-biblical accounts say gossip rimmed their union in Nazareth. In any case, when notified he must go to Bethlehem to register for occupying Rome's taxation, Joseph protectively took Mary with him, even in her late pregancy, on that dusty, 90-mile trip. Tired and footsore, they reached the town, crowded with travelers, soldiers and tradesmen. Her time had come and Joseph sought desperately to find lodgings where the child could be delivered. But the inn had no room. Perhaps advised by the innkeeper or some bystander, Joseph took his worried wife to a nearby cavern-like stable and made a pallet for her among tethered animals. ``And she gave birth to her first-born son ...'' It wasn't exactly a prepossessing place to enter the world, a smelly, dung-littered livestock stall. Not fancy, for sure, not glittery like the holiday, but a shabby shelter for the homeless. It was down with the least and lowliest that the child began life. Afterward, rough-clad shepherds showed up, telling how while tending flocks in the valley below, a glorious light had fallen on them. As they trembled in fear, an angelic voice assured: ``Be not afraid; for behold I bring you good news of a great joy ... for to you is born this day in the city of David a Savior who is Christ the Lord.'' The account says the skies throbbed with sublime music, ``Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace among men.'' In awestruck curiosity, the shepherds went to the hilltop town, finding the child, as they had been told, ``wrapped in swaddling cloths, and lying in a manager.'' After leaving, they excitedly spread word of their experience among rustic comrades. The family apparently settled temporarily in Bethlehem. At eight days, the boy was circumcized, and later dedicated at the Temple in nearby Jerusalem to God's service. A year or more later the Magi from the East who had discerned celestial signs of a pre-eminent birth, appeared in Jerusalem, arousing suspicions of King Herod. After visiting the child and offering gifts, they sought to throw Herod off the trail by returning another way. But it was then that the terror struck. Warned of it in a dream, Joseph roused his family and fled by night, headed for safety into Egypt. Behind them, blades of Herod's troops fell on Bethlehem toddlers in a pandemonium of screams and blood. For a year or more, Joseph, Mary and the child remained as refugees in Egypt, finding whatever shelter and livelihood they could. It was a time of uncertainty and hardship. After Herod's death, they returned to Nazareth in upland Galilee, where the child grew into adulthood and a ministry that led to his crucifixion and ensuing resurrection. His story, from the beginning, was humbly common, yet most uncommon. That child was fully human, Christians believe, yet also fully divine in the human context, ``very God of very God.'' Wild, incredible, some say, misassuming that humanity negates godliness. Logically, however, to be perfectly, consummately human to the utmost, without flaw or failing, must reflect that higher order, the highest possible in earthly terms. John's Gospel says: ``In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God ... And the Word became flesh, and dwelt among us, full of grace and truth.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri PMs, Dec. 21

DOC.HEAD: Tough Year Doesn't Hurt Fund Sales
DOC.TEXT: It's evidently going to take more than one bad year in the financial markets to dull investors' voracious appetite for mutual funds. Thanks to such events as the crisis in the Persian Gulf and the onset of an economic slump, just about all types of long-term funds have turned in poor performances for 1990. All 14 categories of stock and bond funds monitored by the Wiesenberger Investment Companies Service showed declines in their average net asset values for the 12 months through Nov. 30. Yet sales of new fund shares to investors show no sign of flagging, setting their strongest pace since the most ebullient days of the 1980s bull market. Through the first 10 months of this year, reports the Investment Company Institute, the industry's main trade group, sales of long-term funds (as opposed to money-market and short-term municipal bond funds) came to $125.18 billion. That put them on the verge of surpassing the $125.71 billion total recorded for all of 1989. When full-year figures are in, they appear certain to rank as the third best ever, behind only 1986, with sales of $215.85 billion, and 1987, with $190.63 billion. An especially striking element of this year's activity is that sales of stock funds have been running slightly ahead of bond and other income funds, which represent a larger category. That has happened even though the average equity fund's net asset value dropped 10.7 percent over the last 12 months, by Wiesenberger's calculation. Indeed, ``not since 1974 have such a preponderance of equity mutual funds shown a loss in any year,'' observes Reg Green, editor and publisher of the Mutual Fund News Service in Bodega Bay, Calif. Steve Norwitz, a spokesman for the Baltimore fund-management firm of T. Rowe Price Associates, points out that business has been notably hot for international equity funds, even though nearly all overseas stock markets also have fallen this year. The ICI numbers show international fund sales of $6.97 billion through the first 10 months this year, more than four times the $1.54 billion tally at the corresponding point in 1989. What to make of all this bullishnessness in the face of adversity? Most analysts say it sends a clear-cut message that fund investors are seizing on what they perceive as a buying opportunity. The memory is still fresh in their minds, analysts reason, of the profits that awaited most people who stepped up to buy in the aftermath of the crash in '87. Some skeptics see this is as a danger sign. Typically, they say, bear markets don't bottom out until mutual-fund investors have been scared away in large numbers. Optimistic observers, by contrast, say it could be a sign that fund investors have learned to think longer-term, building up their holdings in good times and bad. In either case, keen enthusiasm among the public for funds may be at least partly offset by a wary mood among fund managers themselves. At the end of October, stock funds that report to the ICI were keeping a record 12.9 percent of their assets in reserve, ``parked'' in money-market investments. ``Never before have the funds had so much buying power,'' argues Norman Fosback, editor of the Fort Lauderdale, Fla.-based advisory Mutual Fund Forecaster. ``Never before have fund managers been so bearish on the market as to hold such huge amounts of cash. ``When portfolio managers are deeply bearish, the market nearly always proves them wrong by moving sharply higher.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday, Dec. 20

For Release PMs Thurs, Dec 20
DOC.HEAD: Banks Aren't Eager for Action
DOC.TEXT: It may not be as easy as it used to be to slow or reverse an economic decline. Recessions aren't necessarily alike, and what works on one might not on another. Like strains of flu, they may vary vastly from their predecessors. Dealing with this one may be a particularly onerous task, and the biggest problem already has been hinted at. It is the poor financial condition of the banks themselves, and their desire to keep matters from getting even worse. While the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate, or the rate at which the commercial banks borrow money from the central bank, those banks seem less inclined than before to pass on those savings to borrowers. That attitude could mess up the Fed's plans. In fact, to some extent it already has. While the Fed has lowered since summer by a full percentage point the overnight rate banks charge each other, the banks haven't lowered their rates to customers. The entire idea of an easier Federal Reserve policy - lowering interest rates or expanding the money supply - is to spur commercial interaction by pumping money through the banks into the economy. That is the expected remedy, the routine antidote, the aspirin for treating dangerous economic slides, which the current one has become. But if the banks let the buck stop with them, would-be users of that money remain frustrated. What makes this recession unlike many others, according to those who have studied it, is that it is primarily debt-induced. Much of that debt is owed to banks. The banks can't collect. It has put them in a dangerous position. Rather than pass on savings to customers, therefore, they have shown a tendency to hoard what funds they have. They are also retrenching, writing off billions of dollars of loans and closing many of their lending operations. Rather than putting money out in the form of loans, they are trying to get rid of the loans they already have. In many instances, loans not written off entirely are packaged for sale at huge discounts - just to get rid of them. Loans and customers got the banks into trouble. They are licking their wounds. They are declaring their primary goal now is: 1. survival, and 2. clearing the books for the next upturn, in which they vow to be more prudent. The prime rate at major banks has been at 10 percent all year long, and there isn't likely to be any rush to lower it substantially. The earliest indication, from a Midwest bank, is for a one-quarter point drop, which certainly doesn't qualify as dramatic, except that any decline is rare these days. Credit-starved customers aren't likely to leap at such a cut. In fact, those to whom the prime doesn't even apply - homeowners, for example - might see more immediate results. Mortgage rates often are tied to government securities prices - not to bank attitudes - and could fall sharply. That aspect of the Fed's easier money policy by itself could have a very meaningful consequence for the economy. Many homeowners are strapped, and mortgage delinquencies are rising. Those with variable rates, especially those with mortgages up for their periodic review, could find quick relief. The psychological factor also is important. For many months the Fed had steadfastly declined to let up on its tight money policies, presumably because it considered inflation its No. 1 enemy. Now that relief has finally come, it may generate buying and selling activity among those individuals and companies that had been on the sidelines. Just the psychological attitude could be enough to produce some action. That's how economies move ahead, one positive step leading to another. But don't rely too heavily on the banks. It's unlikely that they'll be the ones to step out ahead of the pack.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thurs, Dec 20.

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Bonfire of Vanities, Adv 21,0963
DOC.NOTE: $Adv 21
For Release Fri AMs, Dec. 21, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: A Master of the Universe Takes a Fall in the South Bronx
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Bonfire of the Vanities'' opens Friday.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Sherman McCoy is a self-styled ``Master of the Universe,'' an ultimate WASP who moves like hot-buttered bourbon through the power houses and privileged lairs of New York City. If he went any higher in life, he'd be God. Peter Fallow is a rather rumpled, shallow, smarmy, booze-soaked journalist who crawls through the sewers of the world struggling for that one last story. If he went any lower in life, he'd be a drowned rat. The worlds of McCoy (Tom Hanks) and Fallow (Bruce Willis) combine in Brian De Palma's latest movie, ``Bonfire of the Vanities.'' And as McCoy falls from grace, Fallow ascends like the angels. Set in New York City, the Warner Bros. release takes some pretty rough jabs at Manhattan socialites, local politicians and self-styled religious leaders, the media and especially the Bronx - that long-lamented stepchild of a borough. It was bad enough in Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel, which explored the social, legal and financial worlds of New York and found them to be rotten. Now it's up there on the big screen, with Tom Hanks, Bruce Willis, Melanie Griffith and Morgan Freeman involved in the nasty goings-on. Michael Christopher (``The Witches of Eastwick'') adapted Wolfe's book. De Palma also produced. During filming earlier this year, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer protested what he considered the poor treatment of the borough - as a burned-out, ugly, crime-ridden heap - and asked that a disclaimer run with the movie. One does. The plot revolves around McCoy, a Wall Street bond trader, whose dumb- blonde married mistress, Maria (Melanie Griffith), backs McCoy's Mercedes into a black teen-ager while they are lost in the South Bronx. The youth falls into a coma and the police, after getting part of the license plate from another teen-ager at the scene, zoom in on Sherman. McCoy takes the rap for his mistress, not knowing the political and racial circus in which he would become embroiled. A district attorney with ambitions to be mayor (played by F. Murray Abraham), seizes the incident to further his campaign. A black activist minister (John Hancock) joins in the circus with everyone else, including Fallow. Hanks, Willis and De Palma were recently in Los Angeles to help ignite ``Bonfire,'' and they talked about the movie's depiction of New York. ``Actually, there were no actors in this movie; they were all taken off the street,'' cracked Willis. Then, seriously: ``No, it's really a kind of send-up of the people of New York. Tom Wolfe had an almost prescient vision of things to come. He wrote some of the characters in the book even before they emerged in the media. ... ``I think Tom Wolfe's view, as is Brian DePalma's view, is a little tongue-in-cheek. I don't think he's saying, `This is what life is.' I think he's saying, `This is a kind of melodramatic view of it.''' Willis and his wife, actress Demi Moore, have bought an apartment in New York, reportedly for $6 million, and are spending even more money to refurbish it. ``You gotta be a little bit nuts to live in New York,'' Willis said, ``but there's no place like it that I've found.'' Remarked Hanks: ``I think there's accuracy in our depiction of New York City. It's not the be-all and end-all. There's a policeman in the movie who says he works Bruckner Avenue (in the Bronx) and Park Avenue (in Manhattan), and there's good and bad in both places. ``I think this movie is seeing much more of the bad in both places. But not just for New York City but American society as a whole, I think there is truth to be found in our depiction of the political system, the justice system, the clergy, the economic system, race relations, the media.'' De Palma, who has lived in New York for several years, commented: ``When you're shooting New York City, you've got to avoid all the cliches. When you're trying to deal with a comic, styled land of the rich and famous, you've got to find images that embody that. ... We took on a kind of comic stylization. ``The world depicted in `Bonire' is very true to these particular characters building a huge case on another character's fall.'' If New York takes its lumps in ``Bonfire of the Vanities,'' the media is savaged. Willis' scandal-sheet reporter manufactures his stories. Has Willis been the victim of such fabrication? ``Many times,'' he said sadly. ``I had it happen three or four times this past summer. When I was in Rome, there were three or four stories written that were entirely fictional. They must have included 25 quotes from me, from my wife, from two of my co-stars. Not one word of it was true.'' After five years of such treatment, Willis has learned to stay cool: ``I can't stop these things, I can only control my reactions. Occasionally, like now, I can express my feelings. Otherwise, I just accept it as part of the entertainment business.'' Hanks maintained that the swarming reporters and camera people of ``Bonfire'' are not exaggerated: ``To anyone who has come out of a courtroom after being convicted or acquitted, it's an intimidating process.'' Hanks has mostly escaped the scandal peddlers: ``I've been there a couple of times, but I'm just not the fodder, not as interesting.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, Dec. 21
$Adv21
For release Fri AMs, Dec. 21, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Slow Hurting of Chernobyl Children Evokes Christian Help
DOC.TEXT: Gradually now comes the hurt to the children of Chernobyl. As the silent, hidden blight starts appearing, they're beginning to get help from scattered groups of American Christians. ``The situation is bad, and it's going to get worse,'' said the Rev. Paul S. Moore, whose New York City radio ministry, CitiHope, is raising money for medical supplies. ``In a real way, it means giving children back their lives,'' he said. A threatening shadow fell over inhabitants of the Ukraine and Byelorussia after the fiery rupture of a Soviet nuclear plant on April 26, 1986, at Chernobyl filled the atmosphere with radioactive particles. But only lately has the extent of the effects of that accident begun to appear, with the impact increasing with time. Pyotr K. Kravchanka, foreign affairs minister of the Byelorussian republic on which 70 percent of the contamination settled, said that at the outset the resulting volume of cancer and related cases could not be predicted. ``We are now seeing only the beginning stage,'' he said in an interview, citing a doubling of thyroid ailments among children, a sevenfold increase in anemia cases and a rise in leukemia cases. ``The peak volume of sickness has not yet come,'' he said. Scientists project the mounting toll will hit its high point in 1996-97, he said, but treatment is severely limited by a lack of medicine and diagnostic equipment. A fifth of Byelorussia's population, or 2.2 million people, including 800,000 children, ``have become innocent victims of Chernobyl,'' the ``hostages of postponed effects of radiation,'' he told the United Nations General Assembly. As the disaster's effects grow, several small, independent American religious and other groups, as well as ethnic communities of Byelorussians and Ukrainians in some cities, have begun limited steps to provide medical aid. A catalyzing influence for such efforts resulted from Moore's visit in September to Minsk, capital of Byelorussia, where he observed firsthand the spreading marks of radiation to which children are most vulnerable. ``You can't realize the gravity of it until you experience it, until flesh touches your flesh and you go through the hospitals with the doctors and see the wasting bodies of the children,'' he said. ``Most Americans are not aware of the extent of the implications now and in the future.'' He said he was told 37,000 Byelorussian children are being treated for pre-cancerous conditions, with more cases diagnosed daily. But, he added, the supply of medicine is so inadequate that only 15 percent can be saved, compared to the 85 percent who could be saved with sufficient medicine. Soviet pharmaceutical supplies, limited and chiefly from East Germany, were said to have been disrupted by German reunification. Moore, also an assistant minister at St. George's Church in Manhattan, said that through sponsorships enlisted on his radio ministry, his project so far has supplied $650,000 worth of methotrexate and other anti-cancer drugs and vitamins. He said that as a result, treatment has been started on 400 Byelorussian children, and that by early January, he expects to have rounded up enough medicine to increase that number to 1,000. Moore said pharmaceutical companies will provide the drugs for such charitable purposes at 5 percent of costs, meaning that the usual cost of $4,000 to $5,000 for two or three years of treatment to bring a cancerous condition into remission is reduced to $100 to $200 per child. The Rev. Michael Christensen of San Francisco's Hamilton United Methodist Church is coordinator of Moore's expanding project. Paul Maxey, associate executive director of Interchurch Medical Assistance of New Windsor, Md., which serves 15 relief agencies as a liaison with drug companies in obtaining medicines for such causes, said: ``Reaction to the Chernobyl situation has been slow because of the incubation time before the effects show up. Churches have not been challenged to do much about it. But it has now become a very distressing problem.'' He said a few, mostly local groups now are getting involved. In Richmond, Va., the Rev. Paul F. McCleary, director of the Christian Children's Fund, said his group began sending aid to the Soviets as a result of a fact-finding trip with a Virginia medical team to Minsk in mid-November. ``It's a very grave situation,'' he said, adding that a pre-Christmas shipment of medicine was being assembled. ``It's a very large medical catastrophe and assistance is needed to improve the diagnosis process and start treatment earlier,'' he said. ``It's the first instance of a major nuclear catastrophe, something entirely new in the human experience. It's important that we monitor it and track the record so if another such event occurs we cope with it more properly. ``It's a very significant activity for us and all mankind.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri AMs, Dec. 21

DOC.TEXT: A Christmas Eve telecast involving troops in the Persian Gulf area, ``Christmas with the Gulf,'' is to be presented by the Vision Interfaith Satellite Network. It said the exclusive program, linking soliders in Bahrain with families gathered at designated churches in England and Germany, was being made available to all cable television systems in the United States, whether or not they are affiliated with VISN. Jeffrey C. Weber, programming and operations vice president, said the hour-long special, co-produced with the British Broadcasting Corporation, is to be presented by VISN at 10 p.m. EST Christmas Eve and will be repeated at 1:30 p.m. EST on Christmas Day. The network is owned and operated by the not-for-profit National Interfaith Cable Coalition, made up of 23 Roman Catholic, Jewish, Protestant and Eastern Orthodox faith groups. --- DAYTON, Ohio (AP) - United Methodists on the average are older and better educated than Americans as a whole, and a majority of them at one time have been affiliated with another denomination, a survey found. Responses from 758 lay members and 1,003 clergy showed 37.6 percent of the lay members and 50 percent of the clergy were older than 50, compared to 25.7 percent for the entire country. For lay members, 49.9 percent had completed at least four years of college, while 92.9 percent of the clergy had done so. That compared to 20.3 percent of the U.S. population. --- FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) - The leadership council of the Sisters of Mercy criticized the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf as wasting human and material resources on a ``primitive method of conflict resolution.'' At a meeting, the Roman Catholic order's council added: ``This expense is especially deplorable at a time when we, along with others committed to education, health care and social welfare, are struggling and often failing to find the means of providing these basic human rights for an increasing number of people.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Reform Jewish leaders say the National Council of Churches ``caused us great pain'' by a statement equating Iraq's invasion of Kuwait with Israel's relationship with Palestinians. This ``plays into the hands of Saddam Hussein and his effort to escape responsibility for the rape of Kuwait,'' the interreligious affairs committee of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations said in an open letter. --- VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. (AP) - At the request of Soviet television officials, the Christian Broadcasting Network is providing 27 regional networks there with a 30-minute special on the meaning of Christmas. Michael Little, a CBN vice president, said Soviet officials asked for the special on the historical, biblical aspect of Christ's birth ``to explain to their Soviet auidience what Christmas is all about.'' The host of the show will be CBN's founder and president, Pat Robertson. He said that the Soviet networks also will broadcast another CBN special, ``Don't Ask Me, Ask God,'' in January and that a CBN animated Bible series, ``Superbook,'' currently airs weekly in the Soviet. ``I'm frankly overwhelmed by the unbelievable spiritual hunger that exists in the Soviet Union,'' Robertson said, adding: ``In my wildest dreams I could not have conceived of the magnitude of the opportunity that has been presented to us.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri AMs, Dec. 21

DOC.HEAD: Guard Families Spend `Quiet Christmas' Without Their Men
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: National Writer Fred Bayles spent three weeks this fall with the 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard as its men trained and deployed for Saudi Arabia. In this story, he looks at how their families are coping in their absence. ---

Ashley Deloach didn't hesitate when the teacher asked her class to draw what they wanted for Christmas. The 6-year-old drew a picture of her father, Sgt. Earnest Deloach. Spec. Don Graham is constantly on the mind of his 4-year-old daughter Crystal. ``She asks all the time when is he coming home,'' said her mother, Rebecca. ``She still doesn't understand. She thinks her daddy's at the armory.'' Deloach and Graham are among the 14 members of the 26th Quartermaster Detachment that left the Allendale, S.C., armory for Saudi Arabia nearly four months ago. In that time, Deloach's two children had birthdays, the car's transmission has started to leak, and the checkbook balks at balancing. And now Christmas. ``I miss him terrible,'' said his wife, Lillie. Life has settled in for the families of the 265th since August, when the water purification unit got a big sendoff from Allendale City Hall. They were the first South Carolina National Guard detachment to deploy to Saudi Arabia. Now, another 328 state guardsmen are in Saudi Arabia, including 22 men with another Allendale unit that left last week. Another 2,000 guardsmen are in some stage of preparedness. ``You run into other people who say, `Hey, I've got someone over there, too,''' said Ima Jean Rooker, whose 20-year-old son Mark is the youngest member of the 265th. ``It's just growing into one big family.'' The 265th families are the seasoned veterans of the homefront, each with stories about missed birthdays and anniversaries, the treacheries of the family car, the vagaries of military mails and the joy of unexpected phone calls from Saudi Arabia. ``I'm just managing until he's home,'' said Joanne Badger, who has had to cope with the absence of her husband, Willie. ``It's hard.'' Harder still on Christmas, a time when the close-knit families of the small town are used to big celebrations. ``It's going to be a real quiet holiday,'' said Clevetta Jackson, wife of the 265th's commander, Sgt. Ronnie Jackson. ``We didn't even bother to put up a tree. We usually make a big thing about that.'' This is the first time in 20 years the mother of two has missed a Christmas with her husband, a forceful man who uses the word ``damn'' like a punctuation mark. ``We used to complain about him being so loud,'' she said. ``Now it's so quiet around here we can hardly stand it.'' Adele Harris will go to traditional dinner at her father's house, where several clans gather for the day. But two important faces will be missing: her husband, Henry, a retired schoolteacher, and her brother Don Graham, a construction supervisor with seven children. Both are in the 265th. ``Everybody's trying to keep their chin up,'' she said. The 265th's families have filled the time with a new routine: mailing off letters and packages, and waiting in return for the letters and occasional phone calls from the men. The gifts that went out from the Allendale homes illustrate the hardships of life in the desert. Mrs. Rooker sent her son socks and long underwear to cut the chill of the desert at night. He also got a pillow, his art pad and a Christmas tree. Mrs. Badger sent canned food to break the monotony of Army chow. Everybody included Christmas cookies and candies with the usual batteries, newspapers and magazines. While most of the wives write several times a week, they also send videocassettes documenting sports and family events the men have missed. The tapes are viewed by the men in a desert tent equipped with a videotape recorder hooked to a generator. Estella Cohen sent her husband, Sgt. Hullie Cohen, a tape of their son playing football for The Citadel. Other family members produced a Christmas video complete with carols, Santa Claus and a warning from Mrs. Harris that her husband would face the wrath of Santa Claus if he didn't write. ``We sang `Rudolph' and `Silver Bells,' '' she said. ``We didn't do, ``I'll Be Home for Christmas.''' Communication between the desert and the homefront has improved in the last few months. Letters sometimes arrive within a week; the men have been able to call with some regularity. ``The first thing he says is he's ready to come home,'' said Mrs. Cohen. ``He said, `When I first left I was strong, but now I'm ready to come home.''' The homecoming is a major focus of the families. Plans already are being laid for a party that will include the one thing foremost on the men's minds: beer. ``We'll have plenty of it at the party, but they might be too tired to drink it,'' Mrs. Badger said. The 265th originally was called up for three months. The call-up was extended another three months in November, which would mean a homecoming in February. That could change if the United States goes to war. The families prefer to believe they will see their men in two months, rather than allowing their emotions to be roiled by the daily bulletins from Baghdad and Washington. ``Some would say they've got a job to do and it's in the Lord's hands,'' said Mrs. Rooker. ``It still doesn't keep me from this deep feeling in my heart that Mark has to come back. ``At times it gets to you and you have to let it go. Once you cry it out, you feel better.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues AMs, Dec. 25
For Release Thursday AMs Jan 3 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Descendants of U.S. Confederates Keep Dixie Alive in Brazil
LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: The aroma of Southern fried chicken and the strains of ``Dixie'' fill the air. A Confederate flag flutters in a warm breeze. Young women in colorful hoop skirts square-dance with partners dressed in the gray uniforms of the Confederacy. Welcome to Americana, where descendants of Rebels who fled the United States after the Civil War hold an annual picnic to keep some of their traditions alive - even though most of them don't speak English. Memories of the Rebel past remain strong in this fertile sugar-cane region 85 miles northwest of Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city. In a graveyard at nearby Santa Barbara D'Oeste, about 400 Confederate settlers and some of their offspring are buried in the shade of pine, eucalyptus, mango and palm trees. Among them is the great-uncle of Rosalynn Carter, wife of former President Carter. His epitaph reads: ``To the Memory of W.S. Wise. Born in Edgefield, South Carolina, Oct. 13, 1833. Died in Santa Barbara, Brazil, April 14, 1877.'' An inscription on another tombstone captures the defiance of those who came to Brazil: ``Roberto Stell Steagall - Once a Rebel, Twice a Rebel and Forever a Rebel. Born Sept. 1899. Died Jan. 1985.'' Steagall's paternal grandfather, Henry Farrar Steagall, was a Texan who served in Gen. Robert E. Lee's army and arrived in Brazil in 1866. ``Wherever our ancestors settled, they were warmly welcomed, except at the local cemetery,'' said Judith MacKnight Jones, 75, the community's unofficial historian. She is one of the few who speaks English, complete with a drawl. ``They were not allowed to bury their dead in the Roman Catholic cemeteries because they were all Protestants, so they built this one, which also serves as a monmument to our heritage,'' Mrs. Jones said, pointing to a concrete obelisk with four Confederate flags engraved on it. Sitting at a picnic table watching the square dance was Sydney Mills, a large man in a cowboy hat, boots and leather vest, who carried a riding crop. Mills, 73, is nicknamed ``The Texan.'' ``I've been dressing like this for more than 30 years as a way to pay homage to my Confederate ancestors,'' Mills said in Portuguese. His grandfather, William Thatcher Mills, came from Dallas in 1866 to plant cotton in Santa Barbara D'Oeste. Like Mills, most of the descendants know little of their family histories. About 3,500 Southerners arrived between 1866 and 1890 to settle this southeastern region, where the climate and soil are similar to the southeastern United States. They introduced cotton, the metal plow and the sewing machine. Many settlers could not adapt and nearly 3,000 returned to the United States by the turn of the century, Mrs. Jones said. Most of the immigrants eventually moved to Americana, which grew up around the region's first railroad station, built in 1875. The city now is known for textile mills. Today, Mrs. Jones said, no more than 300 of the people living in or near this city of 160,000 can trace their ancestry directly to Confederate immigrants. The total number of descendants in Brazil is difficult to gauge, Some probably are unaware of their Confederate ancestry, others went elsewhere and there is no record of their numbers. In 1967, Mrs. Jones chronicled the Confederate immigration in the book ``Soldier Rest, A North American Epic Under Brazilian Skies.'' She wrote it in Portuguese, but hopes for an English translation. Most of the Civil War exiles were plantation owners, she said, but the group included teachers, doctors, lawyers, businessmen and adventurers. ``They came from all over the South: Alabama, Georgia, Texas, South Carolina and Mississippi,'' she said in an interview. ``They all felt conditions under Reconstruction would be unbearable, so they decided to leave the old South and head for Brazil.'' The first immigrants arrived in 1866, drawn by reports from American Protestant missionaries and the Brazilian government that their knowledge of cotton farming was needed. Another attraction was the abundant slave labor available in Brazil, Mrs. Jones said. Slavery was not abolished in Brazil until 1888. Initially, the transplanted Americans did not mix with the local residents. Integration and intermarriage with Brazilians was frowned upon. ``They had their own teachers, doctors, preachers and language to protect their values from outside influences,'' Mrs. Jones said. The self-imposed segregation began crumbling in the early 1900s. Grandchildren of the settlers married outside the community and began to mix with Brazilian culture. Besides the yearly picnic, about 60 descendants meet every three months to keep in touch and exchange information on their ancestors.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs Jan 3

DOC.SECOND: BC-AP Arts: The Godfather, Adv23-2 Takes,1182
DOC.NOTE: $Adv23
For release Sunday, Dec 23, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: `The Godfather': The Epic Behind the Epic
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: --- ``George, what should I do? Should I make this gangster movie or shouldn't I?'' - Francis Ford Coppola, speaking to George Lucas in 1970. ---

Francis Ford Coppola is working around the clock, pushing himself and his editors to get the latest ``Godfather'' film into theaters by Christmas. He insists a spring release would be better, but Paramount Pictures, eyeing the deadline for the Academy Awards, wants it out before the end of the year. The movie is screened in San Francisco and the projector breaks down four times. Four days later, when the film is seen in Seattle, several scenes have been cut and many others added. Audience response is mixed. The time is December 1974, and as a weary assistant gazes at a preview card, he lets out an audible groan, ``I hope there will be no `Godfather, Part III.''' Responds the director, ``So do I.'' But it's happening again, Coppola frantically editing, Paramount executives nervously waiting, stories about on-set blowups and last-minute switches,endless curiosity over this most lavish of Christmas presents. A new ``Godfather'' film is Hollywood's equivalent to a world tour by the Rolling Stones, and its aura of money and power is something the Corleones would have appreciated. The two ``Godfather'' movies have grossed $800 million and won nine Academy Awards between them. But that's industry talk. To moviegoers, ``The Godfather'' means Brando and Duvall, Pacino and De Niro; a bloodied horse head and a brotherly kiss on New Year's Eve; weddings and christenings; death in a tomato garden; bullets ripping through James Caan at a toll booth. To the artists, it means fame, revitalized careers. Marlon Brando was washed up. Al Pacino was an unknown stage performer. Coppola was a failed director hired because he'd work cheap. The stakes for ``The Godfather, Part III'' are enormous. The budget reportedly topped $50 million, and a flop could spell financial ruin for Coppola. He and his production company filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors during shooting, listing assets of $22.2 million and debts of $28.9 million. Also, Paramount has struggled this year. ``Ghost'' was an enormous hit, but both ``The Two Jakes'' and ``Another 48 HRS.'' flopped. If critics don't take to the new ``Godfather,'' the studio could be shut out from the Academy Awards, as it just was by the New York and Los Angeles Film Critics associations, which both named another Mafia movie, ``GoodFellas,'' as best picture. Coppola has compared the Corleones to the Kennedys, tragic American dynasties. People care about Vito, Sonny, Michael and Connie. Mario Puzo's ``The Godfather'' came out in 1969 to mixed reviews, and with complaints from the Italian-American Civil Rights League that the book reinforced stereotypes. But the novel quickly topped The New York Times' best-seller list, and within two years of its first printing, 10 million copies had been purchased. Puzo, the son of illiterate Italian immigrants, sold the film rights to Paramount for $85,000. --- ``Coppola, oh yeah, let me tell you something about Coppola. Coppola would make a great producer - you know he's a hustler, he's got all this talk and cha-cha-cha, but he's no director.'' - Producer Albert Ruddy, before making ``The Godfather.'' --- Paramount wanted a low-budget film, an easy profit-maker, and envisioned a Christmas 1971 release. Ruddy, who had worked on TV's ``Hogan's Heroes,'' was assigned to produce. For director, he sought Peter Yates (``Bullitt''), who declined, and then Costa-Gavras (``Z''), who also said no. Ruddy then called on Coppola, a 32-year-old director whose last two films had bombed. Paramount, burned by such big-budget failures as ``Catch 22'' and ``Paint Your Wagon,'' needed someone it could control. Also, as Ruddy noted, Coppola was an Italian who ``knew the way these men ate their food, kissed each other, talked.'' Coppola, deeply in debt, reluctantly accepted. The budget was to come in under $2 million. --- ``I assure you that Marlon Brando will never appear in this film.'' - Paramount President Stanley Jaffe. --- Puzo and Coppola worked on a screenplay and the director began casting. Caan, an old friend of Coppola's who had appeared in the director's ``The Rain People,'' was quickly chosen to play Sonny Corleone. Robert Duvall, also in ``The Rain People,'' was an easy choice for ``consigliere'' Tom Hagen. For Michael Corleone, Paramount insisted on a star, preferably Robert Redford or Warren Beatty. Coppola had his eyes on Al Pacino, an off-Broadway actor of Silician descent. The studio objected. Pacino's screen tests were poor. He was too short, too inexperienced and, ironically, looked too Italian. But the director wouldn't budge and Paramount, anxious to get shooting under way, gave in. The casting of family patriarch Vito Corleone could only be compared to finding the perfect Scarlett. Coppola interviewed every old Italian actor he could find: No one was good enough. Age, Ruddy and Coppola decided, didn't matter. They simply needed a great actor. They considered Sir Laurence Olivier, but he was too ill. They also considered Brando, who Puzo had in mind when he wrote the character. The brooding star of ``A Streetcar Named Desire'' and ``On the Waterfront'' was then 47 and better at emptying studio coffers than filling them. It had been years since he had had a hit, and budgets had soared for his last movies reportedly because of on-set battles between Brando and his directors. Executives wanted nothing to do with him. Coppola persisted. Paramount agreed to give him a chance, but set three conditions: One, Brando would receive no salary, only a percentage; two, the actor had to guarantee, with his own money, that he would not cause the film to go over budget; three, he would have to take a screen test, something he was as likely to do as submit to an interview. Brando agreed to all three. For his screen test, the actor put on a fake mustache, slicked back his hair with shoe polish and stuffed Kleenex in his mouth. He got the part. Some Italian actors protested the casting of non-Italians Brando, Caan and Duvall, and the IACRL proved as demanding as Paramount. It staged a rally, hosted by Frank Sinatra, at Madison Square Garden to raise funds to stop the film, threatened labor disruptions on the set and insisted there was no such thing as the Mafia. Ruddy promised to keep the words ``Mafia'' and ``Cosa Nostra'' out of the film. (The words are back in for ``The Godfather, Part III.'') He also agreed to attend a testimonial dinner, hire league members as bit players and extras and donate New York's opening-night box office to the league's hospital fund. With publicity building and Coppola's wheels turning, the budget was increased to $6.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: $6.2 million.
DOC.TEXT: Filming started March 29, 1971. Coppola had requested an 80-day shooting schedule, but Paramount would only give him 53. With time so short, scenes were rushed and the dailies came out poorly. It was rumored Coppola would be replaced by Elia Kazan, who had twice directed Brando. The actor helped put an end to such talk by insisting he would stop working if Coppola was fired. Director of photography Gordon Willis, frustrated with Coppola's inexperience, walked off the set at one point. Crew members mocked Talia Shire, Coppola's sister, as incompetent. The director's obsession with retakes drove everyone crazy and a rebellious Paramount editor was fired. ``At first everybody was so uptight. Francis was a wreck and Pacino looked like he was going to die,'' said Caan, who helped lighten the mood by cracking jokes with Duvall and mooning Brando on the set. Shooting fell behind schedule and the release date was pushed back to Easter 1972. The final budget approached $7 million. The finished movie ran for three hours and stayed that way despite complaints from the studio. It was first seen in late February, and most exhibitors who saw it were unimpressed. On March 11, 1972, ``The Godfather'' opened in New York and all was forgiven. Critics raved and fans poured in. There were ``Godfather'' games and ``Godfather'' soundtracks. Shouts of ``make him an offer you can't refuse,'' the Corleone way of doing business, were heard from playgrounds to advertising offices. It was one of those rare films in which every shot seemed to have been lovingly crafted, the simplest dialogue took on additional meaning and even the most minor character had depth and personality. Brando had the most memorable role, but Pacino's Michael was the center of the movie. All the horror and beauty of ``The Godfather'' can be seen in his transformation from an awkward college graduate to a cool, ruthless mob boss, becoming more confident and skillful on the outside as his soul burns inside. Michael Corleone is one of Hollywood's great tragic figures, his rise and fall comparable to Orson Welles' Charles Foster Kane in ``Citizen Kane'' and Broderick Crawford's Willie Stark in ``All the King's Men.'' And, like ``The Maltese Falcon,'' ``The Godfather'' had plenty to say about the stuff that dreams are made of. The film's final shot, a door closing on Diane Keaton as Pacino and associates scheme for the future, recalls the conclusion of ``The Maltese Falcon,'' a closeup of elevator doors closing on Mary Astor as the police take her away. The following March, Brando won an Oscar for best actor, and the movie won best picture and best screenplay. Four months later, Paramount announced a sequel with Coppola to write and direct. ``The Godfather, Part II'' alternates between chronicling Vito's early years and Michael in middle age. Pacino, Duvall, Keaton and Shire returned. Caan, who had been murdered in the first film, appeared in a flashback sequence. Brando was not in the sequel. Paramount was furious at him for turning down the Oscar in protest of Hollywood's treatment of American Indians, and the two sides couldn't agree to terms. To play the young Vito Corleone, Coppola selected Robert De Niro, who had attracted considerable attention for his role as a dying baseball player in ``Bang the Drum Slowly.'' Willis, apparently thinking more highly of the director, was behind the cameras. Shooting began in September 1973 and dragged on for eight months. The budget was a cool $13 million, more than double what it was supposed to cost. --- ``My father assured him either his brains or his signature would be on the contract.'' - Michael Corleone, explaining how Vito helped a singer to get a nightclub owner to release him from a contract. --- ``The Godfather, Part II,'' another three-hour job, was released in December, and reviews were mixed. Still, interest was strong enough to bring in millions at the box office, and six Oscars, including best film, best director, best screenplay, best supporting actor (De Niro) and best score to Coppola's father, Carmine. Paramount was already considering the next ``Godfather'' film, with or without the troublesome director. While Coppola floundered, churning out such flops as ``Rumble Fish'' and ``One From the Heart,'' the studio plotted. In 1977, Charles Bludhorn, chairman of Gulf & Western Industries (Paramount's parent company), met with director Richard Brooks (``Blackboard Jungle'') and gave him a 53-page treatment for ``The Godfather ... III.'' Brooks wasn't interested. Bludhorn collaborated on a script with Puzo. Novelist Vincent Patrick, who wrote ``The Pope of Greenwich Village'' and Dean Reisner of ``Dirty Harry'' fame took a shot at it. John Travolta was going to star, or maybe Sylvester Stallone. In 1988, rumors circulated that Coppola was in Italy, working on - could it be? - ``The Godfather, Part III.'' A year later, they were confirmed. Coppola was back, so were Pacino, Keaton and Shire. Willis was there, too, as was Carmine Coppola for the score. --- ``I could make five failures, five pictures nobody liked, and I'd still be the guy who directed ``The Godfather.'' - Francis Ford Coppola. --- Andy Garcia, who plays Sonny's out-of-wedlock son, seem the best bet to come out a winner with the new movie, to do a ``Pacino'' and become a major star. Pacino and Keaton are established actors re-enacting familiar roles. Sofia Coppola, the director's daughter, is a risk. An inexperienced actress, she was a last-minute substitute for Winona Ryder and has a key role as Michael's daughter and Garcia's love interest. So far, reaction to her performance has been negative. Then, there's the director himself. Beyond all the talk of money and awards, the saga of the Corleones is also the saga of Coppola. ``The Godfather'' is an accidental classic. But was that film just a fluke for Coppola? Does he have anything left to say about the Corleones? ``The artist's worst fear is that he'll be exposed as a sham,'' Coppola said back in 1975. ``I've heard it from actors, directors, everyone. ... Deep down we're all living with the notion that our success is beyond our ability.''

DOC.HEAD: With BC-AP Arts: The Godfather
``THE GODFATHER'': THE EPIC BEHIND THE EPIC
``Godfather'' Players: Coppola Proves a Godfather to Actors' Careers
DOC.TEXT: The movie event of the year, ``The Godfather Part III,'' hits the nation's screens on Christmas Day with the expectation that Francis Ford Coppola will again prove godfather to actors' careers. He did it with the first two sagas of the Corleone family, restoring Marlon Brando to greatness and establishing Al Pacino and Robert De Niro as superstars. The obvious candidate for the bigtime from the new film is Andy Garcia, who plays Sonny Corleone's out-of-wedlock son. He has already delivered strong supporting performances in ``The Untouchables,'' ``Black Rain'' and ``Internal Affairs.'' Previewers of ``Godfather III'' seem to agree that Garcia has arrived. There was less agreement about Sofia Coppola, as Mary Corleone, the don's daughter. When Winona Ryder was unable to fulfill the role, Coppola made the controversial casting of his own daughter. Her only previous acting came in her father's films. Early reaction has been fairly negative for Sofia, some of whose lines had to be relooped because of her ``Valley Girl'' voice. Most of the cast are alumni of the previous ``Godfathers'' - Pacino, Diane Keaton, Talia Shire - or established character actors such as Eli Wallach, Joe Montegna, Raf Vallone, Helmut Berger. The new film could revive the career of George Hamilton, and boost Brigid Fonda and Franc D'Ambrosio, the opera singer making his film debut as Pacino's son. ``The Godfather'' was a 1972 phenomenon, not only because it amassed more money than any previous film, but also for its starmaking capacities. Pacino, who had made only one previous film, ``Panic in Needle Park,'' became an immediate star. The same was true with Diane Keaton, in her second film after ``Looking for Mr. Goodbar.'' Robert Duvall had been playing smaller roles since ``To Kill a Mockingbird'' in 1964. His role as the consigliere elevated him to stardom. Both Keaton and Duvall went on to win Academy Awards. James Caan was already a popular actor, but his role as the hot-headed Sonny Corleone in the first two films provided a big boost. Coppola's sister, Talia Shire, might be called the queen of the sequels. She has appeared in all three ``Godfathers'' as the Corleone daughter, and as Rocky Balboa's wife in the five ``Rockys.'' ``The Godfather Part II'' brought Robert De Niro the Oscar as supporting actor and broadened a career that appeared stuck in small-budget crime movies. The film also initiated an acting career for the legendary acting teacher Lee Strasberg. John Cazale returned as Fredo, the weak member of the Corleone family. His career was cut short by cancer. Among the other ``Godfather'' actors who have died: Strasberg, Sterling Hayden, Richard Castellano, John Marley, Richard Conte. Besides Pacino, Keaton and Shire, Richard Bright has appeared in all three films, as the henchman Al Neri. Al Martino skipped No. II but returns in ``The Godfather Part III'' as the flamboyant crooner Johnny Fontane.

DOC.HEAD: The Road Home: One Homeless Man's Journey on the Way Back
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This story is accompanied by BC-The Road Home-Poll, an AP poll measuring Americans' feelings about homelessness
With LaserPhotos, AP Graphic
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The road home for the homeless is long and strewn with hurdles. Here is one man's struggle to escape the box that had been his home for a year and take inventory of what was left of his life. ---

The car waited for Kevin Brown, its motor idling. Inside, the heater blasted warm, seductive air. The car was there to take him to a home with real walls and real doors, to a room of his own, to a new life - or a chance to reclaim his old one. For the past year, Brown had lived under a highway, in a box fashioned of cardboard and plywood. This was the day he'd been waiting for - moving day. The slide into homelessness has been well-chronicled, but advocates for the homeless say there's a less-told story: the struggle to get off the street. And Kevin Brown had made it. But outside the car, with the temperature just above freezing, his 29-year-old girlfriend Pat sat in the darkness next to the box that had been their shared home for eight months. She sobbed, hunched over, rocking ever so slightly, and feverishly sucked her thumb. Pat was the only thing keeping Brown from spending his first night indoors in more than a year, from taking a hot bath, from being able to shut a door - an act so simple, but one he desperately craved. Because she had left her home to live with him, Brown said he felt responsible for Pat, who declined to give her last name. If they were to be separated - he going to the residence to which he had been struggling to gain admission and she to a women's shelter - he first wanted to make sure she was safe. But when she refused to go, he became resolute about leaving. ``I'm not going to pass up this opportunity,'' said Brown, 28. ``I been homeless way before she even thought about being homeless. Now is my big chance ... She can't stop it! She can't stop it!'' He bolted from the station wagon and ran into the thicket of boxes, tarps and lean-tos along the Hudson River that are home to about 15 people on an abandoned stretch of road under the West Side Highway. ``I think he's tired,'' said Jonnie Scott, one of three city social workers inside the car. ``He's tired, and he wants to change his life. He wants to be somebody.'' --- Advocates for the homeless say one of the biggest problems confronting those who want to find a permanent place to live is the tremendous amount of sophisticated bureaucratic maneuvering required by government agencies. The system, they argue, forces people already overloaded with problems to submit applications, fill out forms, make follow-up phone calls and have patience and faith in a process that requires large amounts of both. ``It's an absolute act of heroism that someone is able to get out of a box,'' said Carol Fennelly, spokeswoman for the Community for Creative Non-Violence in Washington, D.C., founded by the late Mitch Snyder. It shelters about 1,400 men, women and families. ``They have such a hard time getting back to a regular place because they have no place to take showers, no place to get mail, no place to get phone calls,'' she said. But the bureaucracy is necessary to ensure the homeless are sent to the right shelter or home, said Ray Diaz, deputy commissioner of Special Services for Adults in New York, whose various agencies decide the fates of people like Brown. Brown, a former construction worker who once earned $22 an hour, was homeless for a year, after spending his rent money on his cocaine addiction. His quest to get into Rena's Residence for Adults began in June, when he happened to walk by the home and spotted a sign in the window. The Harlem residence is funded by the city and state and can accommodate 99 men and women. The city's Human Resources Administration governs who is admitted, which means that once Rena's recommends a candidate, the person's file must be submitted to the labyrinthine city bureaucracy. Brown said he made five visits over the course of getting his application approved. Although he said he sometimes felt he was getting the runaround, he was determined to be patient. ``I knew deep in my heart this is what I needed,'' Brown said, ``So I always just said, `OK, I can wait.''' Rena Chinhenzva, who runs the residence, says it targets those looking for a permanent way out of homelessness and not just a warm room for the night. She tries to help her residents enroll in vocational schools or, if they want, get their high school diplomas. ``We want to give them back their pride,'' Chinhenzva said. The problem of getting people off the streets and into a place of their own is exacerbated by the public's increasing feelings of futility over the issue of homelessness, said Gary Blasi, president of the National Coalition for the Homeless and a Legal Aid Foundation attorney in Los Angeles. ``There is just a certain level of weariness,'' Blasi said. ``If people don't have a sense that things are getting better, after awhile they just give up. And then they turn their attention to things like Saudi Arabia.'' So while troops mass in the hot desert sand, he said, more and more men, women and children will be gathering on America's icy sidewalks. ``The forecast for the homeless this winter is about as cold as it ever has been,'' he said. --- Brown came back. And after about 20 minutes, Pat climbed into the back of the car. She was sobbing and gasping convulsively, all the while keeping her right thumb firmly planted in her mouth. ``I don't want to stay in a shelter,'' she said haltingly. Scott had gone for a walk with Pat and persuaded her to go to a women's shelter, at least for the night, a particularly cold mid-December evening; Pat had not submitted an application to Rena's. One of the reasons Pat was so distraught, Brown said, was because he had worked hard to make their makeshift home comfortable. The box, about the size of a Volkswagen bus, was insulated by used carpets thrown on top. Electricity tapped from a nearby streetlight powered a black and white television, with a bulb inside that created enough heat to keep them warm, Brown said. Meals were made over a hearth of cinderblocks. A nearby fire hydrant offered running water, and they took sponge baths inside the box. A bucket was their toilet. In an open-air area outside the box sat a kitchen table decorated with a bouquet of wilted flowers inside a juice jar. If it wasn't under a highway, it all might be considered cozy.
