DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: considered cozy.
DOC.TEXT: Brown, a Queens native, said his family would have gladly taken him in, and he did stay with them for awhile. But then he began to feel he could conquer his drug problem only by himself, so he fled. Now, he was on his way back. One of the first things he planned to do was call his family, he said. During his year of homelessness, he wrote to them, but he never told them how he was living. Brown loaded four suitcases and five trash bags full of clothes and his and Pat's most valuable possessions into the car. He then wedged himself into the back seat because Pat insisted on sitting on his lap for the ride to the women's shelter. ``I'm not going to baby you!'' Brown told her. `` ... You better straighten up, Pat. I told you a way long time ago that one day this was going to happen.'' At the shelter, there was little time to say goodbye. With a brief hug, they parted. ``I feel great!'' Brown said as he walked briskly to the car, waiting to take him to Rena's. ``I feel great!'' After a weekend of solid sleep in a warm room, Brown said he was setting his sights on the future again. He plans to enroll in a vocational school, study building maintenance and get his high school diploma. He also said he was looking forward to the coming Sunday, when he would go to church for the first time in more than a year. ``I'm just going back to school and going back to the church,'' Brown said. And his new life at Rena's? ``I'm living in a dreamboat,'' he said with a hearty laugh.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Deny Firsthand Knowledge of Homelessness
With AP Graphic
With BC-The Road Home
DOC.TEXT: Many Americans deny firsthand knowledge of homelessness and blame it mainly on tough breaks or bad economic luck, an Associated Press poll has found. A majority of the respondents, 54 percent, say their knowledge of the homeless is based on news reports or word of mouth. Fewer than half say their knowledge of the homeless is a result of something they have seen or dealt with in person. Only 15 percent know someone who has become homeless in the last year. That measure of Americans' scant firsthand knowledge of the problem holds true for all income groups, and drops to 10 percent in non-metropolitan areas and to 7 percent among Americans over 65. Yet polls over the years have shown Americans want the government to do more to help the homeless. In January, for example, a CBS News-New York Times poll found 71 percent saying the Bush administration had not shown enough concern. In the current poll, 58 percent said federal spending on helping the homeless should be increased. That is not a significant change from the 60 percent who provided the same answer in a Media General-Associated Press poll in November 1988. This time, 75 percent of those who wanted increased spending said they would be willing to pay more taxes for it, compared with 86 percent two years ago. The overall acceptance rate for a tax increase to help the homeless has dropped from 52 percent to 44 percent, perhaps because of the economic downturn. One out of seven Americans rate as likely the chances that they or a member of their family could become homeless in the coming year. But only 4 percent rated it very likely and 67 percent rated it not at all likely. The total answering very likely or somewhat likely was 19 percent in the South and West, compared with 5 percent in the Northeast and 14 percent in the north-central states. It was 20 percent for women, compared with 9 percent for men. A gender gap also showed up in measuring attitudes toward the homeless. Among men, 21 percent agreed that ``the homeless themselves are mainly at fault becaue of their unwillingness to work or their behavior, such as alcohol or drug use.'' Only 13 percent of the women agreed, making the overall total 17 percent. Twenty percent of men and 21 percent of women agreed that ``our society is mainly at fault because we do not provide sufficient housing for them.'' Thirty-eight percent of the men and 45 percent of the women said a third statement best reflected their attitude: ``Neither the homeless nor society is mainly at fault because they become homeless through tough breaks or bad economic luck.'' Overall, 41 percent agreed with the tough-luck explanation of homelessness, while 17 percent volunteered the answer that both the homeless and society are mainly at fault for the problem. The survey of 1,004 adults was conducted Dec. 5-9 by ICR Survey Research Group of Media, Pa., part of AUS Consultant Cos. The poll used a random-sampling method that generally should produce results accurate to within three percentage points. When responses are broken down by age groups or income categories, the margin of error increases as the subgroups get smaller.

DOC.HEAD: How AP Poll on Homelessness Was Conducted
With BC-The Road Home
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press poll on homelessness was conducted by telephone Dec. 5-9 among a random sample of 1,004 adults in the contiguous United States. Interviewing was done by ICR Survey Research Group of Media, Pa. The results were weighted to adjust for variations in the sample. The poll had a three-point margin of sampling error, meaning that 19 of 20 times its findings should be within three points of the result if every adult American were asked the same questions. The error margin is larger for subgroups. There are other sources of potential error in polls, including the wording and order of questions. These are the questions in this poll; because of rounding, sums may not total 100: 1. Is your knowledge of the homeless a result of something you have seen or dealt with in person, or is it just based on news reports and word of mouth? In person: 45 percent. Word of mouth: 54 percent. Don't know or no answer: 2 percent. 2. Which of the following statements best reflects your attitude toward the homeless in the United States today? - The homeless themselves are mainly at fault because of their unwillingness to work or their behavior, such as alcohol or drug use: 17 percent. - Our society is mainly at fault because we do not provide sufficient housing for them: 20 percent. - Neither the homeless nor society is mainly at fault because they become homeless through tough breaks or bad economic luck: 41 percent. - (volunteered answer) Combination of both homeless and society: 17 percent. - Don't know or no answer: 5 percent. 3. Do you think federal spending on helping the homeless should be increased, decreased, or remain the same? Increased: 58 percent. Decreased: 7 percent. Remain the same: 23 percent. DK-NA: 12 percent. (For those who said increased) Would you be willing to pay more taxes for that? Yes: 75 percent. No: 22 percent. DK-NA: 3 percent. 4. I'm going to ask you to rate the chances that you or a member of your family could become homeless in the coming year. Do you personally feel the chances are ... Very likely: 4 percent. Somewhat likely: 11 percent. Somewhat unlikely: 16 percent. Not at all likely: 67 percent. DK-NA: 3 percent. 5. Do you know someone who has become homeless in the last year? Yes: 15 percent. No: 85 percent.

DOC.HEAD: At 40, the Laugh Track's Still (Ha! Hahaha! Ahahaahaha... ha!)
DOC.TEXT: Man has been called the only animal that laughs; television, the only machine. And 1990 was the year that ``canned laughter,'' the use of prerecorded hilarity in the TV comedy sound track, turned 40 years old. Like many 40-year-olds, the laugh track didn't need or want to be reminded of its age, or that it first appeared on ``The Hank McCune Show,'' an unremembered, filmed sitcom that made its debut on NBC on Sept. 9, 1950. ``The Hank McCune Show'' was about an amiable bumbler who created chaos wherever he went. Its home audience, seated at the electronic hearth, heard the unmistakable sound of an audience's laughter if they noticed it at all. All was not what it seemed. The show, noted the trade newspaper Variety, ``has an innovation in a sound track that contains audience laughter. Although the show is lensed on film without a studio audience, there are chuckles and yocks dubbed in. ``Whether this induces a jovial mood in home viewers is still to be determined, but the practice may have unlimited possibilities if it's spread to include canned peals of hilarity, thunderous ovations and gasps of sympathy.'' And spread it has. To the early producers, the laugh track seemed as reasonable as the ``claque'' - paid applauders who pack a theater to heat up an audience's response to the show. Radio comedies had never had that problem. Their actors usually were big stars who performed at microphones on bare stages in front of studio audiences that had come prepared to laugh. But producing filmed comedy for the hungry new medium meant using sound stages, where audiences could not fit. The laugh track synthesized audience reaction and cued the audience - however ungently - when something was funny. ``If there's one basic truth in show biz,'' said Pat Weaver, the then-president of NBC, ``the one basic truth is nobody knows what the audience reaction is going to be to any project until it is actually played.'' Weaver said the laugh track was predicated on the psychological fact that people are more inclined to laugh when they are ``among'' people who are laughing. ``Not that I was in favor of laugh tracks,'' Weaver added.``The idiots that were running the programs all got carried away, even if they were really good comedies,'' he said. ``I was in favor of a laugh track that was intelligently used,'' he said. ``That was the way it started and the way it should have continued.'' It didn't. Technology evolved to the post-production ``laugh machine,'' where a technician could mix the audible range of human reactions from snort, chuckle and giggle to guffaw, belly laugh and roar into an audience's silence. A skilled technician could play the laugh machine like a musician, exhorting the ``canned peals of hilarity, thunderous ovations and gasps of sympathy'' into a symphony of synthetic response. ``The machine will love it'' and ``we'll fix it in post'' became stock excuses for a gag that fell short or, worse, an unfunny script. Even ``I Love Lucy,'' where Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz virtually invented the three-camera sitcom filmed before a live audience, ``sweetened'' its laugh track with canned yocks when the audience got cold. ``There's no question that we have been conditioned to the sound of laughter,'' said George Schlatter, executive producer of the comedy series ``Laugh-In,'' which premiered in 1968. ``It's now a science. You can't tell when it's a track. ``Whether that's improving the quality of television is the real question - and I don't think so,'' he said. This from a man who once took a collection of political speeches and dubbed laughs, music and applause under it. (``It was wonderful. I was going to market it but my lawyers said they would throw themselves under the car.'') ``Laugh-In'' was blisteringly paced, blackout comedy series that redefined television comedy. It was filmed, for the most part, before a studio audience, and it was the laugh track's finest hour. ``Because the bits were so short and we did so many of them .. . in order to get more jokes per minute, we many times removed the laughs,'' Schlatter said. ``On `Laugh-In,' electronic editing was perfected, because the cuts were made so fast that we no longer could make physical splices,'' he said. ``And me, with my perverse sense of humor, I'd put in laughs where there were none.'' James Komack, executive producer of the hit sitcom ``Welcome Back, Kotter'' and many others, made sure each of his shows had a different laugh track. ``With `The Courtship of Eddie's Father,' it was a very light track, almost like music,'' Komack said. ``With `Chico and the Man' and `Welcome Back, Kotter,' (both filmed before a studio audience) most of the time what you heard was the laughter of the audience.'' The exception is when the director cuts into a scene, forcing the audio engineers to blend different sound tracks together. Using laughter, rather than ambient noise, makes for a seamless transition between different ``takes.'' ``If you ever try to do a show without a laugh track, you'll see a huge difference,'' Komack said. ``It flattens. The only way to get away from a laugh track is to use music, which can indicate when something is funny.'' ``Sweetening'' is still employed on those days when a great script and a hot cast collide with a cold audience, Komack said. ``Then it's determined by the taste of the producers - by the morality of the producers,'' Komack said. ``After a while, you learn that it's valueless. In the extremes, people are going to hear it and say, `Why are they laughing?' and they'll turn off your program.'' Komack also cited his experience as an actor and writer in the three-year run of Jackie Cooper's series ``Hennesey,'' which began in 1959. In its third year on the air, Cooper decided to ax the laugh track. ``It was a brave, artistic, very clever, very creative, marvelous show - and it got canceled,'' Komack said. The critical question these days is whether a quality series can survive without canned laughter. Critics loved recent, laugh track-less shows like ``The `Slap' Maxwell Story'' and ``Frank's Place,'' but the show didn't last. Apparently we Americans tend to get nervous if we sit alone with the TV, laughing in the dark. As Schlatter put it: ``Genuine wit doesn't really need the machine; the audience does.'' And let the record reflect that ``The Hank McCune Show'' went off the air just three months after its premiere.

DOC.HEAD: Anna Maria Horsford in Role of a Former Schoolmate in TV Movie
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Georg in 13th graf is cq
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Anna Maria Horsford knew the role all too well before she auditioned to play Veronica Perry, the mother of a young black man killed by a New York policeman. The victim's mother and Miss Horsford were classmates in junior high school. The actress' acquaintance with the Perry family led her to reject the way her role had been drawn for the NBC movie ``Best Intentions: The Education and Killing of Edmund Perry,'' which will air in late January or early February. Perry, an honors graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, was due to attend Stanford University when he was shot to death June 12, 1985, by an undercover policeman in New York's Morningside Park. The policeman said Perry, 17, and his brother, Jonah, then 19, attacked him and tried to rob him. Miss Horsford, who stars on NBC's ``Amen,'' attended Wadleigh Junior High School in Harlem with Mrs. Perry. She had never met Edmund, but knew of his educational promise. She also has been a contributor to the Better Chance program that enabled Edmund to attend the exclusive private school Phillips Exeter. ``I'd been keeping in touch through a teacher at Wadleigh,'' Miss Horsford said. ``I was so thrilled when Edmund was chosen for the program. Veronica had two bright boys and a daughter in the program. But knowing a person doesn't mean you know the inner workings of the mind. ``Not until I got the script did I learn the details. She really pushed her kids. She didn't ask what they wanted. That's no crime - I'd probably do the same thing. I have a nephew in the program, and I was pushing and my sister was pushing.'' When Miss Horsford auditioned, it was suggested she play Mrs. Perry like a stage mother. ``They didn't know at the time I knew her,'' she said. ``I closed the script and said no. I said you can't say that about a mother trying to teach her kids about racism. I said she was a successful woman in her own right. What did I mean by that? I said she had three children by the same man, her husband, and where I come from that's success. ``There are so few roles that get to the depths of a woman, especially a black woman. You don't see many of us on the screen. I think you have an obligation to fill in all the strengths and all the weaknesses. I don't care what the color is, we all have flaws. ``Many people don't know that what they're doing may not be seen as correct. She pushed her children, but a mother wants the best for her children. You have to see her life and goals through her eyes.'' Miss Horsford said that after she got the role, she was troubled by doubts about the official version of the shooting. ``I didn't want to be part of a situation that Eddie did this crime and that he's responsible,'' she said. ``Then one morning I got up and said, `It's right to feel that uncomfortable because I'm playing the mother.' Use that discomfort - `Not my son!''' The movie also stars Taurean Blacque as the father, Jonah Perry Sr., Curtis McClarin a Edmund Perry, Georg Stanford Brown as a teacher, and Christopher Barnes as Edmund's friend. Kevin Hooks directed on location in New York from a screenplay by Richard Wesley, based on the book by Robert Sam Anson. ``When we filmed in Harlem, the boy's mother came down,'' Miss Horsford said. ``We hadn't seen each other in a long time. We talked about everything but the reason we were there. I met the other two kids. We tried very hard to deal with the present. We were shooting the movie, but we didn't talk about it. ``The only thing I didn't say that I wanted to say was how sorry I was. But I was so happy that I was playing her rather than someone who didn't know the nuances.'' Miss Horsford was interviewed on the set of ``Amen,'' which has returned after NBC took it off the air at the end of last season. She was rehearsing a scene with Sherman Hemsley, who plays her father, Deacon Ernest Frye. The show ended as Horsford's character, Thelma Frye, married the Rev. Reuben Gregory, played by Clifton Davis. ``I went from being the vampy virgin to the oversexed newlywed,'' she said, laughing. ``Thelma's the same, but she's happy. She's starting to find little faults with her husband.''

DOC.HEAD: A Holiday Season on the Brink of War: The Nation Waits
DOC.TEXT: It is a bittersweet season in America, a pause at the edge of war. The nation has embraced hostages newly released, soldiers soon to depart and memories of those already gone to the Persian Gulf. With some urgency, families have drawn especially close in the knowledge that neither home for the holidays nor peace on earth can be presumed. ``There's anxiety and loneliness,'' said Patricia Enninga, whose son is in the Persian Gulf with the Army's 82nd Airborne Division. ``People are trying to grab onto whatever they can ... but everything keeps changing.'' Saddam Hussein says he won't let go of Kuwait. President Bush stands firm behind his line in the sand. Between them lies Jan. 15, the date after which the United Nations has approved the use of force against Iraq. And in the balance are the families of 440,000 U.S. troops, some of whom already are in Saudi Arabia. ``We're in a state of limbo,'' said Mrs. Enninga of Brooklyn Center, Minn., who counsels families through Support Our Country's Military. ``No one likes that feeling. No one likes not knowing.'' A half-century ago, President Franklin Roosevelt tried to soothe similarly anxious Americans as Adolf Hitler drew the nation into World War II. ``Mankind is all one - and what happens in distant lands tomorrow will leave its mark on the happiness of our Christmases to come,'' Roosevelt said in an address on Christmas Eve 1940. ``But for most of us it can be a happy Christmas if by happiness we mean that we have done with doubts, that we have set our hearts against fear.'' On the eve of 1991, however, ours is not a nation resolved. ``The question I hear being asked is: `Is the risk worth it?' And I don't know what the answer is. I just know I keep hearing the question being asked over and over again,'' said Bill Drengler, an attorney with the National Guard in Wasau, Wis. Drengler, who opposed the Vietnam War, joined the Guard 18 months ago out of a sense of duty to his country. Now, he is spending the holiday season helping members of mobilizing units put their legal affairs in order. ``Most of the time that means helping people write their wills,'' Drengler said. ``It's difficult in a fleeting moment to wonder whether you're going to be sharing the holidays with your family a year from now.'' Operation Desert Shield has prompted countless newspaper columns and letters to the editor. Cartoonist Garry Trudeau says his readers apparently haven't minded his comic strip's Persian Gulf focus, and radio talk-show hosts can't get their listeners off the topic. Prayer vigils and other demonstrations for a peaceful end to the conflict take place one day in Fort Wayne, Ind., another in Lawrence, Kan., the next in Casper, Wyo. In just as many towns, merchants pack up morale boosters for troops in Saudi Arabia: books, food of all kinds, designer sunglasses, cologne, even a complete ballfield lighting system. Families send tons of letters, videotaped messages, regulation socks, photos, cookies, prayers. Already sobered by a deepening economic downturn, Americans are reflecting on what a bloody war in a far-off desert could mean. ``It's an interesting moment for the country because it reflects a kind of maturity,'' said Todd Gitlin, a sociologist at the University of California at Berkeley. ``I certainly haven't detected much gung-ho feeling on anyone's part. There is doubt built in ... and that in many ways is healthy.'' Recent polls have found Americans split on whether the United States should take military action if Saddam doesn't withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15. Bush's overall gulf policy has received mixed reviews. ``In the beginning, my son and I both believed we were there for a reason. Now it's getting foggy,'' said Elaine Smith of Pittsburgh, mother of Marine Lance Cpl. Scott Schmeltz. ``I don't want him there. I want him home with me.'' Surrounded by five kids ages 7 to 14, Brenda Mabey is doing her best to make their holiday cheerful. But she is without husband Gary, who has been called to duty with the Wyoming Air National Guard. Still Stateside, his phone calls have kept her going. But when her husband has gone overseas, who will offer such reassurances? ``I spent all day ... decorating the house for Christmas and I was blue. I was standing by the tree and Gary called,'' Mrs. Mabey said. ``I lay on the couch and bawled for an hour on his shoulder. He listened and said, `I know, sweetheart. You'll be all right. Hang in there.' '' For the Coles, too, it is a poignant yuletide season. John Cole, an oil worker, was among the ``human shields'' held 4{ months in Iraq. Saddam's early December decision to release his foreign hostages came as an unexpected gift. But the Coles haven't mounted a tree in their Odessa, Texas, home. And there are no plans for a big holiday meal or caroling. The family is not yet done dealing with the gulf crisis. ``Last year wasn't great because we had a son in Panama who was shooting and being shot at come Christmastime. Now the same boy is in Saudi Arabia, due to start shooting and be shot at,'' said Mrs. Cole, whose son shipped out with the Army shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``It's a very unhappy adult world that we live in,'' she said. But perhaps most heart-breaking are the children who this year have been touched by the swirling stuff of politics and world events. ``It sometimes gets sad and lonely,'' said 9-year-old Ben Munyon, who has been cared for by a baby sitter since his parents were deployed to Saudi Arabia in August. ``I just write them. I get my picture off the wall and hold it. Sometimes I fall asleep like that.'' ``Dear George Bush,'' wrote Jamille Byrd, a 7th-grader from Killeen, Texas whose father is in Saudi Arabia, ``We need our mothers, fathers and friends home for Christmas.''

DOC.HEAD: Quaker Oats Ordered to Pay for Trademark Infringement
DOC.TEXT: A slogan used by Quaker Oats Co. to advertise its Gatorade sports drink infringes on a small company's trademark, a federal judge has ruled. U.S. District Judge Prentice Marshall ordered Quaker to pay $24.7 million in damages to Sands Taylor & Woods of Norwich, Vt. for using the phrase ``thirst aid'' in the slogan. Sands Taylor & Woods operates a soft drink mix company and a soda shop. Ron Bottrell, a spokesman for Quaker Oats, would not comment immediately on the ruling. Quaker has used ``thirst aid'' on Gatorade bottles and in its advertising jingles since 1984, Bottrell said. Gatorade has been on the market since 1967. Primarily used by athletes or those performing strenuous exercise, it is designed to replenish the fluids and electrolytes lost in high heat or through exercise.

DOC.HEAD: Belgian Petrofina, American Phillips To Develop Norwegian Oil Field
DOC.TEXT: The Norwegian government has authorized development of the Embla oil and gas field by Belgian Petrofina and the Norwegian unit of Phillips Petroleum Co., Petrofina said Wednesday. Petrofina, which holds a 30 percent stake in Embla, said production is expected to start during the fourth quarter of 1992 and is should reach around 50,000 barrels a day of oil and 85 million cubic feet of gas a day. The field operator is American Phillips, the Norwegian unit of Phillips Petroleum, which is based in Bartlesville, Okla. A three-phase development is planned, beginning with drilling eight production wells and installing an unmanned platform. The platform will be controlled from the Eldfisk oil field, about three miles away. The second phase will include an evaluation of the southern part of the Embla field. If the results are positive the field will be developed during a third phase of operations.

DOC.HEAD: Belgian Bank To Buy 45 Percent Of French Bank
DOC.TEXT: The Belgian commercial bank Generale de Banque said Wednesday it had agreed to pay about $200 million to buy a 45 percent stake in Banque Parisienne de Credit. The seller is the French financial hous Compagnie de Suez. Generale de Banque said the purchase is conditioned on approval by French and Belgian banking authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Say Microsoft Boss Seeking Rights to Well-known Paintings, Photos
DOC.TEXT: William Gates, chief executive of Microsoft Corp., is personally seeking to purchase the electronic-imaging rights to thousands of well-known paitings and photographs, a published report said today. The reported move by the 35-year-old trendsetter in the high technology field would follow a recent flurry of acquisitions by international conglomerates of the rights to movie and music archives. The buyers feel those archives could provide royalties from distribution as well as programming for hardware such as video and compact disk players. The Wall Street Journal said Gates said he hasn't bought any rights yet, but it quoted people negotiating with him as saying he wants to lay the foundation for a library of electronic still-images that could be licensed to future entertainment systems. The story said Gates has quietly pursued the venture he is calling Interactive Home Systems and declined to say how much he is investing in it. He was quoted by the newspaper as saying his immediate goal is to produce a pilot database of about 10,000 images before deciding whether to compile a more extensive library of one million images. The story said those familiar with his plans say he is considering using the images to support educational programs and for use in entertainment packages to be displayed on big-screen TVs in the home. Gates formed his venture more than a year ago to study the commercial prospects of electronic images. The company has four employees and is entirely funded by Gates. He was quoted by the Journal as saying the venture remains speculative. ``We may do it; we may not do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Economy Grew at 1.4 Percent Annual Rate from July Through September
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 2nd graf, The Commerce, to make first estimate 1.8 percent, sted 1.7 percent. Also moving on gheneral news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy was still growing at a weak 1.4 percent annual rate from July through September, the government said today, but most economists believe it since has slipped into a recession. The Commerce Department reported its final estimate of the third-quarter gross national product was even slower than its initial estimates. It first said in October that the GNP had inched up 1.8 percent but revised that downward to 1.7 percent last month. In another report, the department said housing starts jumped 9.3 percent in November, their first increase in 10 months. But the gain was due entirely to a rebound in multi-family starts as single-family building fell to a level unmatched since the 1981-82 recession. The Federal Reserve Board noted the ``weakness in the economy'' Tuesday when it lowered the discount rate from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, effective today, to stimulate growth and ease the severity of any contraction. But most economists say it will take months before the effects of a lower rate work their way through the economy. The rate is the interest the Fed charges on loans to banks and other financial institutions. Even Bush administration officials, while avoiding the use of the word ``recession,'' agree the economy is weakening. Earlier this week, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady admitted it is experiencing a ``significant slowdown'' that is likely to persist through early 1991. Surveys of private economists and professional forecasters show that most believe the economy actually is contracting and will continue to deteriorate into next year. They contend the economy was stumbling along the rim of a recession before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and that the subsequent oil-price shock shoved it over the edge. A recession generally is defined as two consecutive declines in the GNP, the nation's total output of goods and services and its broadest measure of economic health. It grew at an anemic 1.7 percent annual rate during the first quarter, but slowed to an a barely perceptible 0.4 percent rate in the second. The department also reported that a GNP measure of inflation rose at an annual rate of 4.2 percent. It had been revised to 4.2 percent last month after the department initially said it had risen 4.1 percent. In its housing report, the department said starts of new homes and apartments totaled a seasonally adjusted 1.13 million units following a 6.6 percent drop in October. It was the first increase since a 23.2 percent gain last January. Contributing most to the downward revision in the GNP was a slower gain in consumer spending and a wider trade deficit than first estimated. Consumer spending rose just 2.7 percent rather than the 3.2 percent reported last month. The trade deficit was $1.9 billion, compared to a $500 million gap in last month's estimate. The largest upward revision was in government spending, up 1.2 percent rather than 0.6 percent as reported last month. Business investment advanced 8.9 percent while housing fell 19.8 percent during the quarter. Business inventories dropped $4.8 billion. The changes meant the total GNP was growing at an annual rate of $4.17 trillion in the third quarter, when adjusted for inflation. That was a gain of $15 billion over the second quarter. The GNP would need to increase 1.0 percent in the current quarter to meet the administration's 0.7 percent growth estimate for the year. Although most economist agree the economy has slipped into a recession, they disagree over how negative economic growth will be and how long the downturn will last. And most hedge their predictions on the outcome of the Persian Gulf crisis. Surveys indicate most economists believe the recession began in the current quarter and will end by April. A December survey of 30 professional forecasters by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia shows a consensus of the participants project the economy to decline at annual rates of about 1.3 percent in the current quarter and 0.9 percent in the first quarter of 1991 before inching ahead again in the second. The consensus forecast of 52 prominent economists surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators this month finds an identical projection. Nevertheless, individual forecasts vary widely with some analysts saying the economy is in worse shape than the consensus and others contending it is in better. Analysts at Mitsubishi Bank in New York, for instance, say economic growth is dropping at a 2.5 percent rate. Economists at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York say the GNP is declining at a 3 percent rate this quarter. Fuji Securities in Chicago say the economy will decline by 3.0 percent to 4.0 percent from October through December. The surveys' consensus also shows the economy resuming growth in the second quarter. But, again, this view is not unanimous. The Merrill Lynch economists, for instance, say they believe ``a recovery can begin sometime in the second half of 1991.'' Economists at Levy Economic Forecasts in Chappaqua, N.Y., also forecast the recession itself will end in late 1991. But they contend the recession marks the beginning of a ``contained depression'' caused by overinvestment and that the resulting overbuilding and excess capacity will take years to absorb.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 2.23 points at 2,628.96 in the first hour and a half of trading. DOC.HEAD: Judge Might Order Another Vote on Southland Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp.'s emergence from bankruptcy court proceedings may be delayed by a second creditors' vote on a prepackaged reorganization plan. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Harold Abramson said Tuesday he may order creditors to vote again on the plan the company filed in October when it sought protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws. Southland, the Dallas-based owner of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, put the restructuring plan to a vote just before the bankruptcy filing. Bondholders who oppose the package claim Southland did not allow sufficient time for a fair vote. They also claim some ballots were miscounted. ``I am prepared to hold that the vote doesn't comply with the law,'' Abramson said during the second day of testimony. Southland, which had sales of almost $8 billion last year, said it was overwhelmed by the debt left from its $4.9 billion leveraged buyout in 1987. The company has been struggling under heavy interest payments brought on by the buyout, which was announced before the Oct. 19, 1987 stock market crash, but financed after it. The bankruptcy filing listed $2.53 billion in assets and $3.38 billion in liabilities. Southland first proposed a restructuring last March, when it announced the sale of most of the company to Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., its Japanese affiliates. The buyers would provide $430 million in cash for stock in the reorganized company. That amounts to 70 percent of the reorganized Southland. Creditors would get 25 percent and the company's founders, the Thompson family of Dallas, would get 5 percent, under the prepackaged plan. In a prepackaged filing, most creditors have approved a reorganization plan before a company enters bankruptcy. If a judge approves, the terms of the plan are then imposed on the dissenting creditors. Proponents say the speedier process assures a fairer deal for more creditors. Southland operates approximately 6,900 7-Eleven stores and other convenience outlets in the United States and Canada, with another 6,000 stores in the United States and 21 other countries run by licensees, of which Seven-Eleven Japan is the largest.

DOC.HEAD: Repeating for all needing
Grain, Soybean Prices Retreat
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The market opened lower on news that officials of the U.S. Agriculture Department and the Soviet Union, meeting in London on Tuesday, failed to agree on implementation of the export credit program, said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Among the issues in dispute is how grains will be shipped to the Soviet Union. News that the Soviets bought 266,500 metric tons of corn is expected to weigh on corn futures. Corn rallied earlier this week on rumors of a sale of up to 600,000 metric tons. Sluggish export demand for wheat and soybeans is expected to weigh on those futures. In early trading, wheat was } cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.51 a bushel; corn was } cent to 1{ cents lower with December at $2.24\ a bushel; oats were } cent lower with March at $1.14{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3{ cents lower with January at $5.80 a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle futures were pressured by sluggish retail beef demand and weakness in the cash markets. Pork futures fell due to lower cash hog prices and expectations for steady to lower pork product prices. Live cattle were .05 cent to .27 cent lower with December at 80.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .40 cent lower with January at 88.82 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent lower to .05 cent higher; with February at 49.07 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .22 cent lower to .23 cent higher with February at 62 cents a pound. Livestock and pork futures settled lower in Tuesday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has confirmed Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp.'s reorganization plan, ending five years of litigation. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz on Tuesday signed the order that will allow the company to stay in business. Wheeling-Pittsburgh employs about 7,100 people at six major plants in western Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia. Bentz said Dec. 8 he intended to approve the plan. He made the announcement after two days of hearings into objections filed by the Farmers Home Administration and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Under the reorganization plan, about $600 million in cash will be distributed to creditors, company officials said. Plan proponents say the reorganization is viable and will allow the company to compete. The plan creates two corporations. One is Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corp., a holding company led by New York investor Ronald LaBow, who bought 86 percent of the company's secured debt. The other is Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp., an operating subsidiary. Company officials have said the company plans a $454 million capital improvement program over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: Government Wants Takeover of Hotel Employees Union, Cites Mob Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hotel Employees Restaurant Employees in 2nd graf is cq. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A union representing Atlantic City casino workers is controlled through mob killing, extortion, embezzlement and bribery, the Justice Department said in court papers filed today. In a suit filed in U.S. District Court, the Justice Department is seeking to take control under civil racketeering statutes of the 22,000-member Local 54 of the Hotel Employees Restaurant Employees International Union. The local represents hotel, bar and restaurant workers in Atlantic City casinos and in other southern New Jersey cities. The suit seeks court-ordered control of the local, the restriction of the union's international president from the local's affairs, the removal of the local's president and five other officials, and the forfeiture of illegally obtained profits. Also named was Edward Hanley, president of the Washington, D.C.-based international since 1973. The suit said he was an associate of senior members of the Chicago-based organized-crime family. Citing alleged dealings with organized crime figures in New Jersey, New York and Las Vegas, prosecutors are seeking to bar Hanley from further association with Local 54. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said at a morning news conference that the local has been controlled for 20 years by the Bruno-Scarfo organized crime family, which controls Philadelphia and southern New Jersey. ``Through their brutal and often deadly acts of violence and intimidation, members of the Bruno-Scarfo families have destroyed the integrity of the union and its leadership,'' Thornburgh said. Thornburgh said the organized crime families earned perhaps hundreds of thousands of dollars through sweetheart contracts and kickbacks. U.S. Attorney Michael Chertoff said a key informant and witness in the case would be Phil Leonetti, a mob informant expected to testify against John Gotti, reputed boss of the Gambino crime family in New York City. Two murders, an attempted murder and extortion are alleged in the complaint served on defendants in several states, including some held in federal prisons, Chertoff said. Nicodemo ``Little Nicky'' Scarfo has been controlling the local from prison, where he is serving a life sentence for his 1988 conviction on Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act charges, according to the complaint. Scarfo and eight other alleged crime family members also were named in the suit. William Roy Silbert, who became Local 54 president in 1984, was handpicked by Scarfo to take over for Francis Gerace, who was forced to step down by the Casino Control Commission, according to the suit. Gerace, who has remained with the union as a business agent, was also named in the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Two French TV Networks Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds details, background of strike. CORRECTS date of TV awards ceremony.
DOC.TEXT: The president of two troubled state-run television channels resigned Wednesday. Journalists at one channel are on strike, and popular programs on the other have been canceled for financial reasons. Philippe Guilhaume, president of Antenne 2 and FR3, announced his decision at a news conference while strikers jeered. He blamed unspecified ``political powers'' for creating obstacles that made his task impossible. The resignation coincided with separate crises at each of the channels. which together employ more than 4,500 people. At FR3, which specializes in cultural programs and regional news, most of its 600 journalists have been on strike since Nov. 28 seeking higher wages. About 100 of the strikers staged a protest at luxury Plaza-Athenee hotel as Guilhaume arrived to hold his news conference. At Antenne 2, which competes with the privately owned TF1 for the largest share of French viewers, executives recently cancelled or cut back a half-dozen popular programs for budgetary reasons. The channel reportedly has amassed a deficit of more than 100 million dollars for 1990. Antenne 2's problems were thrust into the national spotlight on Monday night, during the annual awards ceremony for the French television industry. One of the winners was Frederic Mitterrand, who has been host or producer of several Antenne 2 programs, including some that have been affected by the cutbacks. Before a national TV audience, Mitterrand - a nephew of President Francois Mitterrand - placed his trophy on the floor. ``That's where public television is - on the floor,'' he said, noting that his protest was being broadcast by TF1, a former public channel which was privatized in 1987. The Socialist government had made clear that it was not prepared to defend Guilhaume. Prior to the resignation, Communications Minister Catherine Tasca had questioned how Guilhaume could ``declare that all is going well at a company in which the majority of employees say there are problems.'' Guilhaume, 48, was named head of the two channels in August 1989 by the government advisory board which oversees the television industry.

Some investors were taking profits, while others ``were putting money to work because of the promise of lower interest rates,'' one trader said, accounting for the market's mixed tone. Among the volume leaders, Citicorp fell { to 13|. On Tuesday the company estimated a fourth-quarter loss of $300 million to $400 million, and proposed to cut its dividend. DOC.HEAD: Economy Shrinks 1.2 Percent, Worse Performance in 10 Years
DOC.TEXT: Britain's economy shrank 1.2 percent in the third quarter, the biggest contraction in 10 years, the government said Wednesday. The Central Statistical Office said a cut in oil production was to blame for the drop in its average estimate of gross domestic product. The Treasury's top official, meanwhile, said the outlook was for a weak performance in the fourth quarter of 1990 and early 1991. But Chancellor of the Exchequer Norman Lamont told a year-end briefing of foreign journalists that the current slowdown is a desirable by-product of years of rapid expansion. Although companies and industries undoubtedly will suffer from a slowdown, ``this is the price you pay to get inflation down,'' he said. Lamont predicted the downturn would not last as long as Britain's 1980-81 recession.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Recalls Econolines for Emissions Problem
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Wednesday recalled about 11,000 1989 Econoline 150 and 250 vehicles with 5.8-liter engines because of a potential emissions problem. The company said some vacuum hoses may have become damaged and may leak nitrogen oxides into the air. Owners will be notified by mail and inspection and repair will be performed for free.

DOC.HEAD: Economists: Rate Cut Will Help Borrowers, Won't Avert Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, White House, with 3 grafs to to UPDATE with Fitzwater today sidestepping question on whether banks should lower their prime rate. Picks up 8th graf pvs, Commerce Secretary. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve's dramatic decision to cut a key interest rate effective today will reduce Americans' borrowing costs, but won't avert a recession, economists say. The first drop in the Fed's discount rate in four years, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, will almost certainly prompt banks to reduce their lending rates, analysts said. The discount rate is the interest the Fed charges member banks for loans. Despite a series of modest credit-loosening steps by the Fed starting in late October, major banks - under pressure to shore up their dwindling profits - have steadfastly resisted passing on lower rates to borrowers. The prime rate - the interest that banks charge their best business customers - has been stuck at 10 percent at all but a handful of smaller institutions. A wide variety of other business and consumer loans are tied to it. Norwest Bank of Minneapolis was the first to respond to the Fed's action. Late Tuesday, it announced a cut in its prime rate to 9.75 percent. A drop in the discount rate is the most visible way the central bank can signal its determination to rescue the economy from a slump. For months, the Bush administration had been pressuring the independent agency to do more to stave off recession. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater had applauded the Fed's latest move, saying ``it should be helpful in promoting growth in the economy in the months ahead.'' But today, he sidestepped a question on whether banks should lower their prime lending rates in response to the Fed action, saying that was a market decision. ``Normally a discount-rate cut reverberates throughout the system,'' Fitzwater said. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher called it ``a very positive step'' that would set the base for economic recovery. Economists agreed, but they added that looser credit is coming too late to avert a recession, loosely defined as a contraction of the economy lasting at least six months. They said recovery will not come until late next year, at the earliest, even if the Fed cuts rates further, as expected. ``It will really almost be summertime before we feel the full impact of the changes,'' said economist Paul Getman of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``Unfortunately ... poor growth over the next six months is preordained.'' Many economists had not expected a decline in the discount rate until next month at the earliest. They assumed the Fed would wait to see whether a shooting war broke out in the Persian Gulf after the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Analysts said three factors prompted the central bank to move sooner: concern that the economic downturn is accelerating, worry about the weakness of the banking system and the opportunity to move on a day when the bond market was rallying on good inflation news. ``The Fed obviously is now seeing an economy that is spiraling downward,'' said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. in New York. ``Virtually all of the numbers they've been looking at have been extremely negative.'' Unemployment in November jumped to a three-year high of 5.9 percent. One of the few bright spots in the economy has been trade, but the Commerce Department reported Tuesday that the deficit took an unexpected leap to $11.6 billion in October, the worst monthly trade gap in 2{ years. Until now, aggressive easing by the Fed had been prevented by a substantial minority of policymakers who feared that inflation - already aggravated by skyrocketing oil prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis - would resurge. However, the Labor Department reported Tuesday that consumer prices in November rose at a moderate 3.7 percent annual rate, down from an 8.9 percent rate over the previous three months. Also, analysts said the increasing fragility of the nation's largest banks added to the concern of the Federal Reserve, which was created in 1913 to protect the nation's financial system. On Tuesday, the largest U.S. bank, Citicorp, said it would lay off 8,000 employees, slash its dividend to shareholders and set aside $350 million to cover bad loans.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the 1st Ld-Writethru of AM-Gulf-Oil Prices, which moved on FFF-level news wires Tuesday, Dec. 18, are asked to use the following story
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Tuesday that an industry survey showed the nation's supply of crude oil had risen from 332.1 barrels to 341.5 million barrels in the week ended Dec. 14. The American Petroleum Institute survey actually showed that the supply of crude had fallen, to 331.5 million barrels. The incorrect figure was distributed by an API spokesman in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Shares End Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices ended higher on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday, boosted by a year-end shortage of stock. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 16.9 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 2,178.7. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 12.9 points at 1,707.1 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 6.93 points to close at 1,153.01. Volume came to 509.3 million shares compared with 575.3 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: All Nippon Airways to Buy As Many As 25 Boeing 777s and 10 Airbuses
DOC.TEXT: All Nippon Airways, Japan's second-biggest airline, said Wednesday it would order 15 of Boeing's new 777 airplanes and take options on 10 others in a deal potentially worth several billion dollars if all options are filled. All Nippon also said it would order five A-340s from European rival Airbus Industrie and take options on five others. An All Nippon official said both types of planes will cost about $150 million each, and replacement engines and other related equipment could bring the value of the total package to $5.6 billion. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said contracts will be signed early next year with Boeing Co. for the 15 firm orders and 10 options for delivery between 1995 and 2000. He said the planes, with 411 seats, will be used on domestic routes. Boeing would receive $2.25 billion for the 15 firm orders. The announcement boosts Boeing's 777 order book to 49 firm orders. United Airlines of Chicago ordered 34 of the new widebody twinjets in October to launch the new plane. United also took options on 34 more 777s that are to go into service in mid-1995. Boeing had hoped to launch the plane with 100 orders, but went ahead with the lower number. The All Nippon official said the airline would sign contracts early next year with Airbus for five firm orders and five options for delivery between 1996 and 2000. The A-340 planes, with 236 seats, will be used on international routes, he said. All Nippon now has a fleet of 105 aircraft.

The stock market was mixed today, struggling to extend its late rally Tuesday sparked by a cut in the Federal Reserve's discount rate. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 33.41 points Tuesday, slipped back 0.74 to 2,625.99 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers held a slim edge on losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 748 up, 719 down and 512 unchanged. Stocks turned sharply higher in the final hour of trading Tuesday, spurred by the Fed's announcement that it would lower the discount rate, the interest it charges member banks on loans, to 6.5 percent from 7 percent. Some market participants were anticipating follow-through buying today, but concerns about the economy and the tensions in the Middle East continued to nag the market. ``The market still has more things on its mind'' than interest rates, said William Raftery, a vice president at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``A lower discount rate is helpful, but it doesn't get you off the sick bed right away.'' Some investors were taking profits, while others ``were putting money to work because of the promise of lower interest rates,'' one trader said, accounting for the market's mixed tone. Among the volume leaders, Citicorp fell { to 13|. On Tuesday the company estimated a fourth-quarter loss of $300 million to $400 million, and proposed to cut its dividend. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost .05 to 180.14. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .52 at 305.55. Volume on the Big Board came to 130.63 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: EC Fines 3 Chemical Firms $66.2 Million for Cartel
DOC.TEXT: The European Community on Wednesday fined three chemical concerns a total $66.2 million for running a cartel in the Western European market for soda ash. The action includes the largest EC anti-trust fine ever imposed - $41.4 million against Solvay, Belgium's largest chemical company. Solvay called the fine ``utterly unreasonable'' and said it would appeal. The EC Commission also fined Britain's Imperial Chemical Industries PLC $23.5 million and Chemische Fabrik Kalk GmbH, a unit of BASF AG of Germany, $1.38 million. The commission said the companies had an agreement by which ICI would not sell soda ash on the continent if Solvay and Chemische Fabrik Kalk stayed out of Britain. The commission said Solvay and ICI had fixed the market so that companies looking for secondary sources of soda ash ended up buying from the cartel anyway. Soda ash is used in the chemical industry as a neutralizing agent. It also accounts for up to 60 percent of the raw material costs of glass making. It is so widely used the commission said the cartel's effect ``is ultimately felt by millions of consumers.'' The fine is the second blow to Solvay in the three months. In October, the EC withdrew all anti-dumping duties on soda ash imports from the American Natural Soda Ash Corp. Analysts say the end of the duties may hit Solvay's earnings severely. Soda ash and its derivatives represent 10 percent of Solvay's total sales.

DOC.HEAD: Mannesmann, Digital Equipment Forming Joint Venture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CLARIFY that computer units have seen their profits drop. SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Mannesmann's computer ...,' to ADD profit figures.
DOC.TEXT: Mannesmann AG said Wednesday it is forming a joint venture with Digital Equipment Corp. that will give Digital effective control over the German company's computer operations. The transaction ends Mannesmann's lengthy search for a partner for its computer units, which have seen their profits slide. At the same time, it provides Digital with a greater presence in Europe, especially in the field of industrial computer applications. Under the terms of the agreement, Mannesmann will spin off the computer operations of its Mannesmann Kienzle GmbH division into a jointly owned company, Digital-Kienzle Computersysteme. Digital will pay about $230 million for a 65 percent stake in that company, which would be Digital's biggest external investment ever, the announcement said. Mannesmann's computer units have annual sales of about $540 million. Their profit dropped sharply last year to about $2.4 million from $15.4 million the year before. The German subsidiary of Digital had revenue of $835 million in its fiscal 1990, which ended June 30. Digital Equipment, based in Maynard, Mass., had worldwide revenue of $12.9 billion in its fiscal 1990.

DOC.NOTE: $adv00
For Release in Yearend Editions
DOC.HEAD: Things Cool To Normal In Seattle
With BC-Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Credit Boeing for the soft landing. Recessions usually hit this area harder than elsewhere. But this time, economists say, the good fortune of The Boeing Co. should cushion Seattle and much of Washington state from the economic downturn of the rest of the country. In a state where a superheated economy produced an average annual job growth of 5 percent since 1985, economists are forecasting that things might return to normal. Economically, the late 1980s were kind to Seattle. Real estate values soared in a city considered by many to be among the most livable. Jobs were so plentiful that fast-food joints offered $7.25 an hour for flipping burgers. Developers rebuilt the city's skyline with more than a dozen major buildings. Much of that prosperity can be attributed to Boeing, which has 104,700 workers in Washington and accounts for one out of every six jobs, directly or indirectly, in the state. By late December Boeing had received $46.6 billion in new commercial jet business for 1990, approaching a sixth record year of orders. Planes ordered three or four years ago are rolling off assembly lines at a rate of better than one a day. In November, however, state officials acknowledged that the recession gripping much of the country had spread mildly to Washington. State economist Chang Mook Sohn forecasts a net loss of 10,000 non-farm jobs statewide in the first half of 1991, about .5 percent of the 2.1 million member workforce. In Seattle, a real estate market that had seen home prices climb 60 percent to 70 percent from 1987 to 1989 returned to normal, as too many homes were put up for sale for prices too few buyers could afford. Construction also declined, with some commercial developers delaying projects and complaining about an overbuilt downtown. Weak manufacturing and construction in turn have hurt services, the retail-wholesale trade and finance sectors, Sohn said. What happened? Again, Sohn and other economists look to Boeing. From 1983 to 1989, Boeing's employment in this area exploded from 58,000 to 106,000 - 37 percent of all jobs created in Washington during that period were with the planemaker. ``It was the main force behind the rapid immigration to the state and the main force behind the housing boom that resulted,'' said Douglas Pedersen, vice president and chief economist for Security Pacific Bank of Washington. Boeing's employment peaked in 1989 as commercial production became more efficient and defense cuts threatened government projects. While the growth in aerospace jobs appears over for now, Sohn says Boeing's employment isn't likely to fall much further. One of the big differences between the current downturn and previous recessions, Sohn said, is the role of the aerospace industry. In the past, a slowdown in planemaking was an advance symptom of a recession and tended to pull down Washington's economy. ``Aerospace works this time is a buffer rather than a destabilizing force,'' he said. The recession of the early '80s was magnified here by Boeing laying off 22,000 employees as orders and deliveries of aircraft fell. In 1982, 106 aircraft were ordered and 176 were delivered. As 1990 drew to a close, Boeing's orders already had reached 517 airplanes, and it had delivered at least 364. It has a firm backlog of at least 1,850 planes and hundreds more options for purchases, and is booking delivery dates past the turn of the century. The region isn't without its worries, though. The timber industry, for example, is hurting from a slump in homebuilding and higher log prices. The home construction slowdown also has hit here, but again, not as hard as elsewhere. Statewide housing starts for 1990 total 43,600, about 3.8 percent fewer than 1989, Pedersen says. Commercial construction also is lagging. ``There's very little new building under way and little likelihood of more building in the next few years,'' said Jon Runstad, president and chief executive officer of Wright Runstad, a major Seattle developer.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Yearend Editions

DOC.HEAD: Lagging Exports Push Grains, Soybeans Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as export trade continued to lag behind expectations. Helping to push prices lower was news that U.S. and Soviet officials Tuesday failed to agree on terms of the $500 million to $1 billion export credit offer made by the United States. The Soviet Union wants the credit offer to include the cost of shipping farm products to the USSR, a condition the United States is relunctant to agree to. Analysts said if the cost of shipping is included, it would leave the Soviets with less money to purchase grain. Soybean futures were heavily pressured by word of a major purchase of South American soybean meal by the Soviet Union. ``So much attention is being paid the lack of business from the Soviet Union that people are ignoring the fact sales to our traditional customers - Taiwan, South Korean and Japan - are down,'' said analyst Joel Karlin of Research Department Inc in Chicago, adding that those countries are buying from China, which had a record crop. ``They don't feel the pressure to buy U.S. grains as they have (felt) in the past,'' Karlin said. At the close, wheat was { cent to 4 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.47} a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 3{ cents lower with December at $2.24 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1} cents lower with December at $1.05\ a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents to 7} cents lower with January at $5.76{ a bushel.

DOC.NOTE: $adv23
For release Sunday Dec. 23 and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Digital Struggles To Boost Profits, Maintain No-Layoff Policy
With BC-Digital-Olsen
Graphic, LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A 150-year-old former woolen mill in this sleepy Massachusetts town seems an unlikely home for the world's second-largest computer company. But then, Digital Equipment Corp. is not your typical $13-billion-a-year corporation. Unlike many major companies, Digital has never felt the need for a flashy headquarters. It also has never laid off an employee, even at the depths of a computer industry slump in the early 1980s. Now, that corporate benevolence is being tested as Digital girds itself for the double whammy of a computer industry downturn and a recession. The hard times already have hit home at the ``mill,'' as employees call the red-brick complex 30 miles west of Boston that once turned out Army blankets. Earlier this year, Digital reported its first-ever loss, a $256 million deficit for the quarter ended June 30. For the fiscal year ended that day, Digital's profit dropped to $74.4 million from $1.07 billion a year earlier. To blame was a $550 million charge against earnings Digital took to pay for a plan that is aimed at reducing staff through voluntary severance offers. Digital's stock price also has suffered, falling from an all-time high of $199.50 in 1987 to the range of $57 a share. The company announced several waves of cutbacks, including plant closings and the elimination of 9,000 employees through the end of next June by voluntary means. Some industry analysts predict even more staff cuts - including layoffs. John Logan of the Boston high-tech research firm Aberdeen Group believes Digital will fire at least 10,000 of its 123,000 employees in early 1991. Other analysts peg the number at 20,000. Analysts blame Digital's problems chiefly on a bloated payroll. Logan said workers at a Phoenix assembly plant were put to work painting the walls after demand for the products they made dried up. Digital recently said it would close the plant. ``They can lay off 15 percent of their organization and still not cut into the meat,'' Logan said. He said Digital has the lowest revenue per employee of any computer maker - about $104,000 during last fiscal year, compared with $164,000 at International Business Machines Corp. in 1989. But layoffs would not come without a price, particularly to Kenneth Olsen, Digital's 64-year-old co-founder and president. ``It's a personal tragedy of Ken Olsen to have layoffs,'' Logan said. He added that worker morale has been hurt as employees wait for the expected pink slips. Not that Digital's predicament is unique. Many other computer companies have been eliminating workers as demand slowed. Troubled Unisys Corp. has endured several rounds of layoffs, and industry leader IBM has been scaling back through voluntary means. Like other computer makers along Massachusetts' Route 128 technology belt, Digital has been hurt by the slowdown in sales of minicomputers, machines designed for more than one user that are smaller than closet-size mainframes but larger than desktop models. As personal computers and the slightly larger models called workstations have grown more powerful, they have chipped away the market for minicomputers - Digital's traditional strength. But Olsen blames his company's problems on the economy, not a minicomputer slump. ``For the last few years people have not, in this country, been investing in the future,'' he said recently in his modest office, where vacuum tubes and computer parts line the exposed brick walls. Digital was geared up for a certain level of sales, he said. When these revenues failed to materialize, profits sagged as excess overhead took its toll. ``We have a religious belief that as we make more computation available for less money, the demand will grow even faster. So in the last few years - more than ever in the past - we have been increasing the (computing) capacity we offer and at lower price.'' The formula failed as the economy slowed. ``But we believe it's a short-term thing,'' he said. Digital also was hurt as customers waited for promised new models before placing orders. Among the newer machines are Digital's first mainframe computers, which the company announced in October 1989 in a bid to compete more directly with IBM. However, shipment of these VAX 9000 models was delayed several times. In the most recent acknowledgement of problems, Digital said last week it would swap some of the circuits in the 100 or so mainframes it has delivered to prevent a problem that caused some of the machines to crash. Digital's cutbacks, profit declines and problems with the mainframes don't take away from the fact that the company has been a singular American success story, industry watchers say. Analyst Peter Schay of the research firm Gartner Group Inc. in Stamford, Conn., calls Digital ``arguably the most successful startup of the post-war period in any industry.'' Olsen was a young Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate when he co-founded the company in 1957, with the help of venture capital. Digital's first breakthrough product was the PDP-1, which in effect was the first personal computer. Introduced in 1960, the PDP-1 used a video screen and a keyboard to enter information directly into the computer - a major advance in an era when programs were entered using punch cards, and users sometimes had to wait hours or days until a program was processed. Digital continually upgraded the PDP line. But its next breakthrough was the VAX line, introduced in 1977. All VAX models can be hooked together easily and use the same software - in contrast to IBM's computer lines. In a long-running ad campaign, Digital has pounded home the message that ``Digital has it now'' - playing off IBM's unfulfilled promise of being able to link all its machines seamlessly in a network. The VAX line has been enormously popular, helping Digital's profit grow nearly fourfold from 1984 to 1988, while revenues doubled. The company's good fortune began to wane after the October 1987 stock market crash, as the slowing economy hit all computer makers. About the same time, the minicomputer slump set in, some customers began to perceive Digital's product line as tired, and competitors introduced machines that provided stronger competition, analysts say. Also, Digital was hurt by the growing interest among customers for ``open'' computer systems - in which machines from any maker can be connected and use the same software, analysts say. In 1988, Digital announced products that provide these features by masking the differences between computer brands. It since has become a leader in computer ``integration,'' or making different brands work together. Digital announced in October it plans to make its VAX line compatible with software written for the Unix operating system, which is becoming an industry standard. An operating system is the base layer of software that controls a computer's internal functions. In the past two years, Digital has taken other steps to address the open-systems movement. It introduced a workstation line that uses the Unix operating system rather than the VAX one. It also began offering IBM-compatible personal computers made for it by Tandy Corp., addressing its lack of home-grown personal computers. And in October, Digital announced new small computers that also use Intel Corp. microprocessors, which are the ``brains'' of IBM and IBM-compatible personal computers. These machines, which Digital makes itself, are aimed at small- and medium-sized businesses. ``DEC today is a very different company than it was 2{ years ago from a product point of view,'' Schay said. He also said Digital's profit slump shouldn't overshadow the fact that the company is financially strong, with low debt and a large cash reserve. Olsen emphasized the same point. ``Our profit is down but we're not troubled in the traditional sense,'' he said. ``We've gone through many recessions,'' he added. ``We'll do better when our customers are successful.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv Sunday, Dec. 23
