For release Sunday, Dec. 23 and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Olsen: ``They'll Have To Kick Me Out''
With BC-Digital
DOC.TEXT: Like Henry Ford at Ford Motor Co. and Thomas Watson at IBM, Ken Olsen is the guiding light at Digital Equipment Corp. That raises the question of how the computer giant will fare once the 64-year-old co-founder and president moves on. Though Olsen says he has no plans to retire anytime soon, and the company has no mandatory retirement age, Digital eventually will have to deal with life without the man who has run it for 33 years. But Digital-watchers don't appear too concerned. ``I really don't believe it's a one-man company,'' said Wes Melling, an analyst at the high-tech research firm Gartner Group Inc. who once worked for Digital. ``There's no question he is a very strong personality and that the culture he has built into the company strongly reflects his values and management style. But I think it is the kind of culture that can exist independent of the man,'' Messing said. ``Digital is kind of a Japanese company in the sense that many of the key decisions are made as consensus decisions,'' he added. ``He picks things he thinks are critical for the company and he really focuses on those things. That also says that there are 200 other projects out there that the managers get to manage.'' Industry analysts take Olsen at his word that he has no plans to retire soon. That appears to ease concern about the lack of a designated heir-apparent. ``He is a founder. He has said many times he wants to continue in an active role. So I'm not going to forecast what might happen,'' said Jay Stevens, who follows Digital for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. John Logan, an analyst at the computer research firm Aberdeen Group, said Digital has a group of vice presidents in their 40s that Olsen ``has been grooming for 20 years'' as possible successors. Olsen has been giving more day-to-day responsibility for running Digital to John Smith, the senior vice president for operations. But Olsen denies that has any bearing on a decision to retire. ``I always say I'll leave graciously, but maybe they'll have to kick me out. But it won't be for a while,'' he said in a recent interview.
DOC.NOTE: End adv Sunday, Dec. 23

DOC.HEAD: USX, Union to Resume Labor Contract Talks
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. and the United Steelworkers union said Wednesday they will resume talks Jan. 7 on a new labor contract for 18,000 workers. ``If we're going to keep making steel, we have to make a deal,'' said chief union negotiator Andrew ``Lefty'' Palm. The current four-year contract expires Feb. 1. Talks aimed at an early agreement were recessed Nov. 10 after the sides failed to reach a contract by that date. ``We've kept the door open for the resumption of the process, and the groundwork has been laid for us to negotiate an agreement that meets the needs of our members,'' Palm said. USX, the nation's largest steel maker, said it was optimistic an agreement will be reached by Jan. 31. Palm said ``it's hard to say'' whether negotiators will meet the deadline. ``USX plays everything right to the end,'' he said. The union wants USX to fall in line with other steel makers who restored pay cuts that workers absorbed during the industry's decline in the early 1980s. Palm said the company's last proposal would have restored wages to the 1982 level but not provided increases beyond that. The union is seeking an additional $1.50 an hour, he said. Companies that have agreed to reinstate pay concessions include Bethlehem Steel Corp., National Steel Corp., Armco Inc. and financially ailing Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. and LTV Steel Co. USX Chairman Charles A. Corry has said the company will ignore the agreements with other steel makers. The union has also said the company's proposal failed to address cost-of-living increases and the possibility of a corporate restructuring. USX plans to make its steel division a wholly owned subsidiary. The current contract was reached after a six-month work stoppage in 1986. USX makes steel in Pennsylvania, Illinois, Indiana and Alabama. It also mines iron ore and operates several joint ventures, including a partnership with Japan's Kobe Steel in Lorain, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: NBC International in Distribution, Production Pact in Japan
DOC.TEXT: The international arm of the National Broadcasting Co. said Wednesday it has formed a joint venture with two Japanese companies that will distribute NBC programs in the Far East and produce shows in Japan. NBC said the deal will improve its ability to distribute NBC-produced programs in Asia and to explore potential media investments in Japan. But even in announcing the venture, NBC executives said the new company was being unfairly constrained by federal regulations that limit what the three major U.S. television networks can do in program production and distribution. NBC and the companies that own the other two networks, CBS Inc. and Capital Cities-ABC Inc., have asked the Federal Communications Commission to lift or modify the financial interest and syndication rules. The Hollywood studios generally oppose modification of the rules, saying the networks are gatekeepers of the broadcast airwaves and would have too much power over what is shown on television without them. NBC International said its partners in the new venture called NNBC are Mitsui & Co. Ltd., a Japanese trading company, and TV Tokyo Channel 12, a Japanese TV network. Terms of the venture agreement, including how much each partner was investing and what their relative equity stake in the new company is, were not disclosed. The new company will distribute NBC-produced entertainment and sports programming in Japan and other countries in the Far East, according to J.B. Holston III, senior vice president and general manager of NBC International. This could include shows such as the dramatic series ``Shannon's Deal'' or the miniseries ``Lucky-Chances.'' Richard Cotton, general counsel at NBC, said NBC would like to be able to distribute programs other than those it produces itself, but cannot do so because of the federal regulations. The new venture would also produce a variety of programs in Japan that could then be sold to TV networks or stations abroad, Holston said. Cotton said federal regulations would prohibit NBC from importing any of these co-produced programs for use on its U.S. television network, however. ``Today's agreement represents a significant international business opportunity for NBCI, and we look forward to the day when we can increase our international activities,'' Holston said. NBC International has a number of similar distribution agreements in other countries, Cotton said. NBC spokesman Richard Cutting said the only similar co-production agreement involving NBC is Tango Productions in Great Britain, where its partner is the independent television company Yorkshire TV. Earlier this week, NBC News said it had entered into a joint newsgathering venture with Nippon Television Network of Japan, another Japanese broadcast network. That deal is separate from the NNBC joint venture.

DOC.HEAD: Indicates Company Could Be `Split Up' If Plan Fails
DOC.TEXT: Philips President Jan D. Timmer suggested Wednesday that the Dutch electronics giant might be broken up and sold in pieces if his drastic reorganization plan fails. ``Splitting the company up is the very last resort, a step that neither I nor Philips are ready to take,'' Timmer said in an interview published in a company news journal distributed to the staff. Timmer did not elaborate on what he meant, but the remarks appeared timed to clear the air of rampant speculation that the 285,000-employee Philips empire was in danger of crumbing. This past summer Timmer decreed an extraordinary cost-cutting drive at Philips aimed at trimming fat from the company and making it more competitive with aggressive Japanese rivals. Part of the cutback involves eliminating 55,000 jobs among Philips' worldwide operations, which manufacture consumer electronic items ranging from light bulbs to televisions. ``I do not deny that the restructuring operation will involve the ending and divestment of activities, but it is certainly not the intention to let the company fall apart,'' Timmer said. ``Our first responsibility is to restore Philips to full health,'' Timmer said. ``We are assuming that if everyone does their bit, improvements can be made throughout Philips that will allow us to maintain the company in its present form.'' Timmer said ``we are already seeing the first signs of improvement'' for Philips, which is expecting a $2.4 billion loss this year. ``Without these measures the company would have got into tremendous difficulties,'' Timmer said. ``If you accept the presidency, then you cannot evade the responsibility to take a hard, uncompromising line in turning the company around if that is what is needed.'' Tom Gietman, an Amsterdam-based analyst with the Van Meer-James Capel brokerage firm, speculated that the statements were aimed partly at Philips' Dutch labor unions, which are negotiating to minimize the impact of the job losses. ``It is just a warning to the negotiators to take a better position,'' Gietman said. Fokko Tuin, head of research at Kempen and Co., said that Timmer ``is indicating ... that as long as possible everything will be kept together as it is. But in the end, a break-up remains a possibility.''

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Urges Auto Industry to Redesign Seat Belts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf pvs, Improper use, to UPDATE with industry group saying it will discuss and consider recommendation. Picks 6th graf pvs, A 1988. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The National Transportation Safety Board on Wednesday urged the auto industry to redesign seat belts so they can easily be used by children, short adults and the elderly. In a letter to 33 American and foreign auto companies, the board said the change would increase seat-belt use and promote safety. It hopes to persuade automakers to install an adjustable upper anchor for the shoulder strap portion of the seat belt in all new cars. European automakers generally offer adjustable upper anchors, but the system isn't generally available in the United States, the board said. Earlier this year, the boardincluded the proposed change on a ``most wanted'' list of safety recommendations. The board said in its letter that serious accident injuries may result from improper seat-belt use because of an inability to adjust them to the size of the occupant. ``Improper use can degrade the belt's ability to prevent serious injury and, given certain accident circumstances, may introduce the possibility of serious belt-induced injuries,'' the letter said. Thomas Carr, director of safety for the Motor Vehicle Manufacturer's Association in Detroit, said the group and its member auto companies would ``discuss and consider'' the recommendation. Carr agreed that if seat belts are more comfortable there are less objections to using them. ``The only issue is to what extent people might misadjust belts, not putting them in the best position because it's a lot more comfortable,'' he said, contending that seat belts now are positioned ``to the advantage of the vast majority of the population.'' A 1988 NTSB report noted that the most common mistake in seat-belt use, especially in seating children, was to place the shoulder portion of the belt behind a child's back. Parents commonly do that because they can't adjust that part of the belt and don't want it to come in contact with a child's face or neck. ``Short adults also share the fear of neck injury from an ill-fitting shoulder harness and also may be tempted to misroute the belt,'' the board said. ``Another form of misuse noted was the placing of the shoulder portion of the belt under the arm, a routing that can have fatal consequences.'' The board said that while the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration declined to require a redesign to make shoulder harnesses adjustable, it encourages manufacturers to do so voluntarily. Ford, the board said, plans to introduce the device in some four-door models next spring and will phase it in forher car, light truck and van models over the next two to three years. General Motors provides the adjustable anchor only on the four-door Oldsmobile 98 and the four-door Buick Park Avenue, it said. The board said that because of mandatory seat-belt laws in 36 states, seat-belt use increased from 14 percent in 1984 to 50 percent this year. In a 1988 study of serious accidents, 80 percent of 214 front-seat occupants wearing properly adjusted seat belts sustained only minor or moderate injuries or no injuries at all, the board said.

DOC.HEAD: Times Discloses Some Terms of Bass Settlement
DOC.TEXT: After settling a shareholder suit with Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass and others, the Times Publishing Co. has emerged with $8.1 million cash and a healthy balance sheet, newly disclosed documents show. The settlement reached last August specified that neither side would reveal any details, but Times Publishing released some information Tuesday to satisfy requests from the state of Florida. The disclosure gave several details about the privately held company that publishes the St. Petersburg Times. But the amount the company paid Bass to drop his suit was not reported. Under the terms of the settlement, Times Publishing agreed to buy back a 40 percent stake owned by the Bass group. The group had purchased the stake in August 1988 for about $28 million and had offered to buy the rest of the company for $270 million earlier this year. The documents released Tuesday show total bank debt for the newspaper company as of Nov. 30 was $9 million. ``The company is strong and vital and we can go on to other things,'' chief executive and editor Andrew Barnes said. According to company treasurer Catherine Heron, the company's cash position ``would cover the majority of existing bank debt.'' The $9 million debt will be paid off by 1995, she said. The documents were released to the Florida Attorney General Bob Butterworth's office, which was concerned that the shareholder settlement could adversely affect the Poynter Institute for Media Studies in St. Petersburg. The institute is the chief shareholder of Times publishing. After acquiring its stake, the Bass partnership had sued Times Publishing over dividend payments, the bulk of which support the institute's educational programs. Under the settlement, Times Publishing agreed to buy back the Bass stake and redeem an issue of non-voting stock, which paid healthy dividends to the institute. At the time of the settlement, the company claimed the agreement would not hurt the institute. It said the preferred shares held by the institute would be replaced by debt, which would pay more in annual interest than the preferred stock once paid in dividends. The company said the institute also could expect to receive dividends from the common stock it holds. The latest disclosures show the institute eventually will own all of the Times Publishing common stock. Robert Lanzillotti, dean emeritus of the University of Florida's graduate business school, was hired by the institute to independently review the Bass settlement. He said it ``will make possible substantially greater financial support for the institute's operations and growth over the long run.'' In addition to the St. Petersburg newspaper, one of the largest and most prominent in the South, Times Publishing runs Congressional Quarterly, Florida Trend and Georgia Trend magazines.

DOC.HEAD: Shanghai Securities Market Opens, But Few Stocks Offered
DOC.TEXT: China's first computerized stock market opened Wednesday in Shanghai with almost no stocks for sale. Instead, government bonds are the main offering and even their sale will be tightly restricted. The new Shanghai Securities Exchange, which opened with great fanfare, falls far short of what economic reformers envisioned several years ago when they proposed setting up a nationwide tock market. The exchange listed only seven stocks on opening day, reflecting the government's fear of allowing financial speculation. Authorities also are unenthusiastic about stocks because they transfer ownership of companies from state hands to the private sector. The market concluded 93 transactions involving a total of 10.29 million yuan, worth about $1.98 million on its first day, the official news agency Xinhua said. It said more than 500 people attended an opening ceremony presided over by Shanghai Mayor Zhu Rongji, widely regarded as an economic reformer. Chinese with cash to invest have demonstrated a keen interest in buying securities, especially stocks, but the government has not made it easy for them. Until Shanghai's market opened, they had to keep track of differing prices at unlinked trading counters at various Shanghai banks. Most counters were open only a few days a week. There was a burst of excitement Monday night after the Shanghai-based Shenghua Electronics Corp. announced plans to sell 120,000 shares of stock. Thousands of people lined up overnight at the scattered trading counters to get application forms to buy. ``If you want to be a stockholder, you must suffer through the cold,'' one man told the Shanghai Evening News newspaper. With the opening of the unified market, investors will have one-stop shopping. But they will be able to buy and sell only through the exchange's 22 member brokerages. Gong Haocheng, governor of the Shanghai branch of China's central bank, said buyers are limited to 10 shares apiece of each stock issue in order to control speculation. Bonds are traded only for the years 1986-89. Gong said authorities have not decided whether to let foreign-funded enterprises sell shares. The Shanghai Securities Exchange originally was planned as a nationwide market and has established ties with more that 60 security trading counters around the country. However, it will be competing with the computerized Securities Automated Quotations System that opened in Beijing two weeks ago and also will trade securities on a national basis. The two systems were to have worked closely but apparently are now under the guidance of rival government authorities. In addition, the southeastern special economic zone of Shenzhen already has a primitive stock market with six listed companies. Shenzhen and nearby the Zhuhai special zone both plan to develop computerized markets next year. The government allowed the first stock issue under Communist rule in 1985. Thousands of companies have issued stocks, but generally only to employees. Few are actively traded.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up In Domestic Trading, Gold Surges
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished higher in domestic trading Wednesday after putting in a mixed performance overseas. Gold prices advanced in foreign dealings and then surged when trading shifted to the United States. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery jumped $9.50 a troy ounce to settle at $386. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $383.90, up $8.15 an ounce from Tuesday's late bid. The advance in precious metals prices was attributed to follow-through buying following the Federal Reserve's move late Tuesday to trim a key lending rate. The Fed said it will lower the discount rate, the interest charged on loans to member banks, to 6.5 percent from 7 percent. Lower interest rates tend to boost gold prices because they make it easier for investors to borrow to buy the metal. But lower rates usually are harmful for the dollar as they erode the value of fixed-income securities. Still, analysts said the dollar remained particularly resilient in U.S. dealings. Despite the lower interest rates, ``concerns about the Persian Gulf are discouraging dollar-bears from selling,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at IDEA. The dollar also drew support from rumors that the Bank of Japan was preparing to follow the Fed's lead and lower interest rates. Lower Japanese rates would be helpful to the dollar as well as U.S. bonds by widening the rate differential between Japan and the United States. ``The yen was very weak,'' Chandler said, noting that investors bought the European currencies and sold off their yen. Activity was very quiet, and traders predict the coming week will continue to be slow unless tensions escalate in the Middle East, said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.24 yen to close at 133.27 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 134.05 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 134.05 yen, up from 132.72 yen on Tuesday. In London, the British pound slid to $1.9316 from $1.9350 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.9310 to buy one pound, cheaper than Tuesday's $1.9430. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.4783 German marks, up from 1.4780; 1.2675 Swiss francs, up from 1.2667; 5.0425 French francs, up from 5.0375; 1,117.75 Italian lire, down from 1,118.00, and 1.1588 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1554. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.4780 German marks, down from 1.4840; 1.2690 Swiss francs, down from 1.2695; 5.0405 French francs, down from 5.0550; 1.6735 Dutch guilders, unchanged; 1,117.25 Italian lire, down from 1,121.25; and 1.1593 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1563. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $380.50 a troy ounce from $377.50 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $380 from $377.20 bid. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 16 cents to close at a bid $377.47. Silver prices also rose. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.095 a troy ounce, up from $3.96 on Tuesday. In London the metal advanced to a late bid price of $4.03 a troy ounce from $3.97.

DOC.HEAD: War Takes Back Seat to Weather on Lethargic Oil Market
DOC.TEXT: Weather, not war fears, had the biggest impact on a generally sluggish oil market Wednesday, with unseasonable warmth in the Northeast depressing natural gas even as a chilly forecast lifted heating oil. Amid lackluster trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil settled at $26.93 per barrel, up one penny, on contracts for delivery in February. ``I would call that ominous stability,'' said Philip L. Dodge, an analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. ``It suggests something's going to happen that nobody's anticiating.'' Brokers have said the market will likely stay quiet through the holidays, barring major developments in the Persian Gulf. Although many oil traders have decided recently that war in the desert seems more likely than peace, they have not gone on a buying spree. Oil supplies are adequate and there is a lingering perception that last-minute diplomacy could defuse the standoff, sending prices plunging. Prices for crude oil have therefore shown no inclination to move out of the mid $20-per-barrel range in recent sessions. ``On fundamentals, it would probably go to $20 a barrel or below,'' said Stephen Smith, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. ``If there was war, it would probably go to $40. It's sitting halfway in between not knowing where to turn.'' Without any rumblings of war or peace stirring up the market, the weather seemed to be taking control on some futures contracts. Home heating oil showed the greatest strength Wednesday, rising 2.17 cents to 77.84 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January. ``There's been a forecast of Arctic temperatures heading our way,'' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``It kept prices up.'' Thus far, the fall has been unseasonably warm, keeping demand down for heating oil and natural gas. Natural gas contracts have plummeted in recent weeks as a result, and the cold weather hitting much of the nation this week was not enough to lift them. On Wednesday, natural gas for February delivery fell 6.4 cents to $1.897 per 1,000 cubic feet. ``Inventory for natural gas is simply brimming,'' Smith said. Unleaded gasoline showed little change, rising .70 cent to 67.42 cents a gallon on contracts for January delivery.

DOC.HEAD: Soon, They Will Have Tried Everything But The McKitchen Sink
DOC.TEXT: What would a McDonald's Corp. restaurant call an experimental submarine sandwich? Obviously, it's the McSub. The fast-food giant, which recently beefed up its menu with pizzas and specialty sandwiches, has given five outlets in this college town permission to try their luck with the McSubs. The test reflects a desire by restaurants near the University of Wisconsin to find a product tailored to students and is not being promoted by the corporation, said Carol Koepke, McDonald's regional marketing manager in Milwaukee. ``They were looking for a convenient, portable sandwich for football games and other activities,'' Ms. Koepke said. Many of the McDonald's staples came about in response to customer needs, she said. For instance, the Big Mac was first sold in industrial areas of Philadelphia where workers wanted a bigger sandwich, she said. The new sub was developed in conjunction with Oscar Mayer Co., which has its headquarters in Madison and supplies the meats in the sandwich, Ms. Koepke said. ``It's a small test operation, but it holds the possibility for some more business,'' Oscar Mayer spokesman Jim Aehl said. The five flavors of a McSub, vegetarian, Italian, ham and cheese, turkey and turkey combo, range in price from $1.99 to $2.59. The come in an eight-inch bun and with the standard submarine fixings of tomatoes, lettuce, onions, and special sauces. ``It is a very popular item,'' Ms. Koepke said. ``But it is too early to tell whether we will roll it out nationally. We tested the Chicken McNuggets for 10 years before we took it national.''

DOC.HEAD: Lowering of Prime Rate Boosts Gold, Silver
DOC.TEXT: The decision by the Federal Reserve to reduce its discount rate helped boost the price of gold and silver Wednesday on New York's Commodity Exchange. On other markets, grain and soybeans were sharply lower, livestock and pork futures were mixed and energy futures gained. Tuesday's cut in the discount rate means the federal government is trying to stimulate the economy, said Peter Cardillo, director of commodities research at Jesup, Josephthal & Co. Inc. The lowering of the discount rate particularly helped silver and platinum futures, which had been in a free fall due to concerns about the economy. ``Silver and platinum depend solely on economic conditions,'' Cardillo said. ``If the economy can be lifted, then obviously both metals will do better because of lower interest rates.'' Gold traded higher on renewed fears of war in the Persian Gulf. Those fears were rekindled by Iraqi rhetoric following the European Community's refusal to meat with Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz. Also contributing to tensions were reports Iraq is adding to its forces in Kuwait, as well as a planned meeting between Saudi Arabian officials and U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Gold settled $9.50 to $10.10 higher with the contract for delivery in February at $388.00 a troy ounce; silver was 13.2 cents to 14.1 cents higher with December at $4.095 a troy ounce; platinum was $.50 to $7.70 higher with December at $416.40 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures were lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as export trade continued to lag behind expectations. Helping to push prices lower was news that U.S. and Soviet officials Tuesday failed to agree on terms of the $500 million to $1 billion export credit offer made by the United States. The Soviet Union reportedly wants the credit offer to include the cost of shipping farm products to the USSR, a condition the United States is reluctant to agree to. Analysts said if the cost of shipping is included, it would leave the Soviets with less money to purchase grain. Soybean futures were heavily pressured by word of a major purchase of South American soybean meal by the Soviet Union. ``So much attention is being paid the lack of business from the Soviet Union that people are ignoring the fact sales to our traditional customers - Taiwan, South Korean and Japan - are down,'' said analyst Joel Karlin of Research Department Inc. in Chicago, adding that those countries are buying from China, which had a record crop. ``They don't feel the pressure to buy U.S. grains as they have (felt) in the past,'' Karlin said. Wheat was \ cent to 4 cents lower with December at $2.47} a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 3{ cents lower with December at $2.24 a bushel; oats were 1\ cent to 1} cents lower with December at $1.05\ a bushel; soybeans were 5\ cents to 7} cents lower with January at $5.76\ a bushel. Energy futures moved higher in quiet trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Robert Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the market's strength came from a stronger feeling that war eventually will erupt in the Middle East. Light sweet crude was 1 cent to 34 cents higher with February at $26.93 a barrel; heating oil was .70 cent to 2.17 cents higher with January at 77.84 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .41 cent to .70 cent higher with January at 67.42 cents a gallon; natural gas was .064 cent lower to .010 cent higher with January at $2.046 per 1,000 cubic feet. Livestock futures were lower and pork futures higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, with cattle prices pressured by lower cash prices and reduced retail beef demand. Frozen pork bellies were up the 2-cent limit as traders took advantage of the slide in prices in recent trading sessions to pocket profits. Live cattle were .12 cent to .45 cent lower with December at 80.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent to .50 cent lower with January at 88.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent to .50 cent lower with February at 49.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.88 cents to 2 cents lower with February at 64.10 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaitis Paid PR Firm $5.64 Million In 3 Months Since Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS figure 4th graf ``Hill &'' to read 5.64 sted 5.7. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaitis have spent $5.64 million for a public relations firm to promote the country's cause after the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2, Justice Department records show. The money was paid to Hill & Knowlton Inc., for the period Aug. 20-Nov. 10, according to records the firm filed with the foreign agents registration office. Frank Mankiewicz, a senior Hill & Knowlton executive, said Wednesday that Kuwait's account was for ``a big job on a big stage ... the assignment is to be effective.'' Hill & Knowlton disbursed $2.7 million of the $5.64 million, including $644,571 for video production and $140,412 for travel. Citizens for a Free Kuwait, a group that receives most of its money from the Kuwait government-in-exile, hired Hill & Knowlton to ``provide counsel on a national media program, strategic planning and message development,'' the records said. The public relations firm helped arrange National Free Kuwait Day, set up interviews for reporters in the United States and Saudi Arabia, contacted government officials and educators and ``drafted and disseminated mailings to Congress'' on the Persian Gulf crisis and human rights issues. Since the invasion, Kuwait's government-in-exile, which is based in Taif, Saudi Arabia, has attempted to draw international attention to the situation inside Kuwait, particularly the purported atrocities committed by Iraqi troops. Hassan Al-Ebraheem, president of the citizens group, said it has spent a lot of money on the public relations campaign but ``would you not do the same for your own country?'' The $5.64 million Hill & Knowlton received from Kuwait was by far the largest amount the company was paid by any foreign entity for the six-month period. The next largest amount was $1.89 million paid by Mazda Motor Corp. Mankiewicz 138 people were registered on the Kuwait account, but a core group of 75 people spent most of the time on it. Rep. James A. Hayes, D-La., said he was distressed by the money paid by a foreign entity to a public relations firm. He said he believed it was wrong for a public relations firm to be in the middle of a foreign policy debate. In effect, he said Kuwait, which is prohibited from directly contributing to congressional campaigns, was buying influence through Hill & Knowlton.

DOC.HEAD: Pier 1 Posts Loss in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Pier 1 Imports Inc. lost $1.7 million in the third quarter as sales turned sluggish following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Pier 1's loss of 5 cents a share came on sales of $145.7 million during the quarter that ended Dec. 1. During the same quarter a year ago, Pier 1 earned $5.7 million, or 16 cents a share, on sales of $131.3 million. The sales slump mirrored a drop in business at other retailers across the country that followed the Iraqi invasion. Consumers have also been spending cautiously because of the weakening economy. Pier 1 said its sales picked up as the holiday shopping season began. For the first nine months of Pier 1's fiscal year, the company said it earned $8.6 million, or 24 cents a share, on sales of $433.7 million. That's a 56 percent decline from the 1989 nine-month profit of $19.8 million, or 55 cents a share, on sales of $380.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Gift-Givers Still Sending Holiday Packages, Shippers Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS two grafs after 19th pvs, Federal Express, to clarify Christmas deliveries. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The sagging economy and retailers' tales of woe haven't kept holiday gift-givers from packing up cardboard boxes and sending them to loved ones across the country or to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. United Parcel Service, the U.S. Postal Service and Federal Express Corp. all say their volume has kept up with expectations, although final numbers won't be known until after Christmas. At UPS, where 307 million packages were expected to be sent between Thanksgiving and Christmas, there are no signs that the sending of gifts has slacked off this season, said Alan Caminiti, a spokesman for the Greenwich, Conn.-based company. The company projected business would peak this week at 22 million packages a day, twice the normal volume. ``We're pretty much right on target,'' Caminiti said. ``Customer counters have lines around the buildings.'' Customers are alo standing in lines at post offices across the country to send packages nationwide and to troops participating in Operation Desert Shield, said Mark R. Saunders, a Postal Service spokesman in Washington. In the weeks through Dec. 31, the Postal Service expects to deliver 4 billion cards, letters and packages, Saunders said. About 1 percent of that total - or 40 million - will be parcels. He said volume is holding steady with last year at this time, when the Postal Service delivered as many as 5 million packages and 200 million cards and letters in a single day, Dec. 18. Federal Express Corp., which normally delivers 1.3 million packages a day, could see volume jump by as much as 17 percent a day in the week before Christmas, said Armand Schneider, spokesman for the Memphis, Tenn.-based company. Company officials made no hard projections about holiday shipping volume, however, because of the worsening economy. ``We knew the economy was soft and we didn't know if it (volume) would increase at all,'' Schneider said. UPS predicted holiday business would be slightly above last year's totals, Caminiti said. So far its projections are holding true, with the only surprise a sudden increase - 15-25 percent - in the number of packages sent by air delivery. A national ad campaign touting UPS's air service probably helped boost the service, he said, but there could be another factor. ``The economy aside, society is in a hurry,'' Caminiti said. While the volume of holiday packages appears to be consistent with past years, both Saunders and Caminiti said that can't be relied upon as an economic indicator. There's no way to tell whether those boxes are filled with the same number of gifts or less expensive items than in years past, Saunders said. ``You can send a gift for $100 and you can send a gift for $10 and it's still a piece of mail,'' he said. There has been one economic benefit. To handle the extra volume, UPS has added 70,000 temporary employees to its work force of 240,000. Federal Express relied on its 94,000 regular employees to handle the job, while the Postal Service used a regular year-round temporary staff of 21,000 that also works at other busy periods. Both Federal Express and UPS said all their Christmas packages would be delivered by Christmas Eve. If bad weather prevents UPS from delivering all packages by Christmas Eve, UPS will deliver them Christmas morning, Caminiti said. The Postal Service will also deliver packages Christmas morning for customers who use its Express Mail Overnight service, Saunders said. And in some parts of the country, postal carriers dressed as Santa Claus will hand over the gifts.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Gets Approval to Sell Seattle-Tokyo Route For $150 Million
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines received a federal bankruptcy judge's approval Wednesday to sell its prized Seattle-Tokyo route to healthy rival American Airlines for $150 million. The sale was one of a number of actions sanctioned by Judge Helen Balick. She is overseeing the reorganization of the airline that sought refuge from creditors Dec. 3 because of crushing debts and high fuel prices incited by the Persian Gulf crisis. The Houston-based airline, which like many companies is incorporated in Delaware, is among the weaker commercial carriers in an industry that's under enormous pressure from a slumping economy that has discouraged air travel. Continental had wanted to retain the Seattle-Tokyo route. It is one of the most profitable because of burgeoning business between the West Coast and Asia. But as the airline's financial problems grew more acute, management decided the route was expendable and the cash provided from a sale could be put to better use. Continental officials said the proceeds from the sale, which was first announced shortly after the airline sought bankruptcy protection, would be used to buy new aircraft it has ordered. For American, the route provides a critical gateway to the Pacific, where the airline will compete directly with United Airlines, which now dominates U.S.-Asian air travel. The route sale still requires Transportation Department approval. In other actions Wednesday, Balick also approved some preliminary payments to contractors refurbishing Continental's terminal at New York's LaGuardia airport. She agreed to hold a hearing Dec. 28 on the airline's request for permission to pay some tour operators and travel agents.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Offers Top Brokers Cash Incentives - If They Stay Five Years
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. announced a plan Wednesday to keep top stockbrokers at the firm by offering up to $80,000 in annual incentives that can't be cashed in for five years. Shearson follows Merrill Lynch & Co. in revamping its compensation program during a period of slumping retail brokerage activity across Wall Street that has made stockbrokers more willing to take other jobs. Under the Shearson program, brokers and branch managers who have completed five years of consecutive service and meet production criteria will receive 4 percent of their gross production up to a maximum $80,000. After that, employees in the program will be eligible for awards of 1 percent to 5 percent of gross production annually, again up to a maximum $80,000 a year. To qualify, brokers must increase their production by certain percentages over a previous three-year average. The brokers cannot receive the money before five years, a move preventing those who qualify from leaving the firm and taking the bonus. The cash, however, will earn interest. Also, Shearson said it can revoke an award under certain conditions depending on a broker's performance. ``It's golden handcuffs is what it amounts to,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in San Francisco. ``When things are slow is when you tend to lose more people,'' he said. ``When business is good brokers are always less inclined to leave.'' For branch managers and brokers with the highest levels of production, 25 percent of the incentive awards will consist of stock in American Express Co., Shearson's parent. During the five-year waiting period, employees will receive cash dividend payments on the stock. Last week, Merrill Lynch said it would give a certificate to each of its 10,500 brokers that could be worth up to $100,000 if they remain at the firm for 10 years. Unlike Merrill, though, Shearson said it is not changing its method of commission payouts that comprise compensation for its 9,000 brokers. Merrill said newly hired, inexperienced brokers would receive salaries in their first two years. ``It's incentive to stay and do quality business and to stay and be productive,'' said Joseph J. Plumeri, president of Shearson's private client group. ``It was never on our mind to keep people from leaving.'' Shearson said in a statement it was forming a board that would review every award recommendation against a set of guidelines based on ``superior client service, integrity, quality, ethics and teamwork.'' The board will consist of senior managers, including Shearson Lehman Brothers President Jonathan S. Linen. Analysts said the compensation incentives by Merrill and Shearson, the nation's top two brokerage firms, marked a change. Typically, Wall Street firms give annual bonuses to brokers based on production levels. Eckenfelder said the programs were cheaper than recruiting top-flight brokers from other firms with large bonuses. He also said that reducing attrition among top brokers could help improve the firm's bottom line.

DOC.HEAD: Hewlett-Packard Reshapes Computer Group, Buys Chip Equipment Firm
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. said Wendesday it has restructured its computer division and expanded its presence in the semiconductor test equipment business by agreeing to buy Applied Optoelectronic Technology Corp. Hewlett-Packard, which posted $13.2 billion in revenues in its 1990 fiscal year, also said it will focus more resources on the telecommunication market. Hewlett-Packard's revamping of its Computer Systems Organization follows a companywide reorganization of executive responsibilities announced Oct. 5. Under the computer reorganization, four groups - computer systems, workstations, information networks and engineering applications - were merged into two groups. Willem P. Roelandts, former general manager of the computer systems group, heads one of the new groups, Networked Systems. The group is responsible for developing and marketing workstations, minicomputers, RISC technology, core networking, operating systems, languages, databases and computer integration. Robert J. Frankenberg, former general manager of the information networks group, heads the new Cooperative Computing Group, which is responsible for developing and marketing distributed computing applications, user interfaces, and office and personal network products. Roelandts and Frankenberg will continue to report to Lewis E. Platt, head of Computer Systems. ``Our simplified structure will help us speed products to market,'' Platt said. The deal with privately held Applied Optoelectronic Technology (AOT), based in Milpitas, is expected to be completed in late January. Terms were not disclosed. AOT, an 11-year-old company with under $10 million in 1990 revenue, designs and produces automatic test equipment for semiconductor manufacturers. The equipment, which integrates computers and instrumentation, tests devices during the manufacturing process. AOT also makes systems that test smart-power modules. These modules incorporate control functions for making decisions and power functions for performing tasks, such as adjusting the speed of a car's motor or activating electronic door locks. In autos, smart-power integrated circuits can regulate anti-lock brakes, adjust the suspension based on the weight of passengers and sense tire pressure. Robert I. Chen, AOT's president and founder and a former Hewlett-Packard employee, will continue to head the company. AOT, which sells systems and instruments to several of the world's leading automotive companies, will operate under its own name as a division of Hewlett-Packard. Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of AOT is part of a strategy to become a bigger player in semiconductor test equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Taj Mahal Must Present Financial Forecasts To Commission
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's Taj Mahal hotel and casino has to give its financial forecasts for the next five years to state gaming regulators, the state Casino Control Commission ruled Wednesday. The commission said in its ongoing hearings on the financial stability of the 8{-month-old Taj Mahal that the casino must present its monthly forecasts for 1991 and quarterly predictions for the years 1992-95. The Taj Mahal must also submit fully executed documents to the commission that show how it plans to implement agreements with its lenders, Commission Chairman Steve Perskie said. Perskie said he anticipates conducting the next hearing on the Taj Mahal sometime in January after the commission can study all the data. The commission has the power to take away a license if it finds the casino operator is financially unstable. Trump attorney Nicholas Ribis said he expected the financial forecasts and the documents would be ready by Dec. 28. The commission's hearings are looking at the stability of the Taj Mahal, which renegotiated its $675 million debt one day after failing to make a $47.3 million payment Nov. 15. The casino intends to file a ``pre-packaged'' bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code and leave bankruptcy protection by spring. The Taj Mahal's restructuring would give bondholders half ownership in the Taj Mahal in exchange for accepting a lower interest rate, 12 percent instead of 14 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Urge Federal Regulators to Review AT&T Takeover Bid
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen Ohio congressmen on Wednesday urged federal regulators to scrutinize American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s $6.1 billion takeover bid for NCR Corp. The legislators claim the merger could be anti-competitive and result in higher telephone rates. ``If the merger does not work, the costs of repaying the $6 billion which AT&T is borrowing is likely to be borne by long-distance telephone consumers,'' the congressmen said in a letter to the Federal Communications Commission. In their letter to Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, the lawmakers warned that the merger could give AT&T ``the potential to develop an unfair advantage'' in the financial services sector. U.S. Rep. Tony Hall, the Democrat who spearheaded the effort, said the letters are ``part of a counterstrike by the delegation to block the takeover, which is strongly opposed by local Ohio government and business leaders.'' Also signing the letters were Democratic Reps. Louis Stokes, Douglas Applegate, Thomas Luken, Edward Feighan, Marcy Kaptur, Mary Rose Oakar, Donald Pease and James Traficant, and Republican Reps. Michael Oxley, Bob McEwen, Michael DeWine and Paul Gillmor. Rep. John Kasich, a Republican, signed only the letter the Justice Department. There are 21 congressional districts in Ohio. AT&T's $90-per-share cash tender offer was rejected unanimously by NCR's board. AT&T has said it will try to persuade stockholders to call a special meeting and seek to oust the Dayton, Ohio-based computer maker's board of directors.

DOC.HEAD: Union Texas Abandons Sale Effort
DOC.TEXT: Directors of the nation's second largest independent oil company Wednesday abandoned efforts to sell the firm because they received no acceptable bids. Insead, the board of Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc. decided to try to sell the company's U.S. onshore and offshore exploration and production businesses and its hydrocarbon products businesses. That would leave only the company's international exploration and production businesses, said spokeswoman Carol Cox. A company statement said Union Texas would also pursue ``other restructuring alternatives,'' but Ms. Cox declined comment on the alternatives. ``No assurance can be given that the activities will result in any transaction,'' a statement from the Houston-based company said. The announcement briefly halted trading in Union Texas stock on the New York Stock Exchange. Union Texas stock closed at $15 a share Wednesday, down $1. Union Texas's board announced April 30 the company was on the block, and analysts said at the time it could sell for as much as $2.25 billion. If Union Texas had sold for the expected price of $25 a share, Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts, a leverage buyout specialist that owns 40 percent of the company, could have earned a profit of about $750 million on stock bought five years ago at $7.50 a share. Allied Signal Inc., the aerospace and automotive parts conglomerate, owns another 40 percent, also has said it was interested in selling its Union Texas holdings. Union Texas owns 38 percent of the largest natural gas producer in Indonesia, one of the hottest exploration areas in the world. It also has crude oil production and exploration operations in the North Sea, Gulf of Mexico and a 42 percent interest and joint operation of an ethylene plant in Geismar, La., near Baton Rouge.

DOC.HEAD: Union Approves Concessions to Keep Briggs Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Union workers at small-engine and lock maker Briggs & Stratton Corp. voted Wednesday to accept wage cuts and other concessions to keep their jobs from being transferred south. Members of Allied Industrial Workers Local 232, which represents some 6,000 workers at Briggs' plants in Milwaukee, voted 2,512 to 2,246 to accept the concessions. The concessions include a $2 an hour wage cut for the 1,200 workers in the small engine division, increased health insurance costs for workers and elimination of a company-wide profit sharing program. In exchange for the concessions, the company promised not to move any of its engine or lock work out of its suburban Milwaukee plant at least until July 1994. Briggs had threatened to move the jobs to plants in Kentucky or Indiana if the Milwaukee workers did not accept the wage cuts. ``We were very disappointed about it. They were holding a club above our members' heads. We accepted it because the priority is job security,'' Local 232 President Dick Crofter said. Briggs Chief Executive Frederick P. Stratton issued a brief statement after the union vote indicating the company hopes to improve relations with the union. Workers in the small-engine division average about $14 an hour, according to figures supplied by Local 232 of the Allied Industrial Workers. Those employees also receive fringe benefits valued at about $5.75 an hour. A southern facility would eliminate transportation costs to Briggs customers, many of whom are now in the South, officials said.
